It was nearly dawn Monday when Roger Porter, the president's domestic policy adviser, floated a compromise through Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., a member of the Senate negotiating team, designed to defuse the dispute. Chafee's proposal was quickly accepted. ``They were looking to be accommodating,'' said Wise of the White House compromise. ``... We got substantially what we wanted.'' He noted the dollar amount - $250 million over five years - was the same as in the original proposal. The White House has declined to endorse the compromise publicly, saying its language still has to be studied in detail. But a White House source acknowledged that the worker assistance issue no longer is a matter of concern. That shouldn't be surprising, said a congressional source involved in the discussion. ``They wrote it (the compromise). We watched them use the typewriter.'' Under the compromise, workers who lose their jobs because of the new clean air requirements would get 26 weeks of additional financial assistance after unemployment compensation runs out, similar to Wise's original provision. But rather than go to all workers, benefits would be restricted to those who could show financial need and money would be strictly administered by the Labor Department through the states. With worker benefits no longer automatic, cost could be contained, administration officials explained.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Goddard Leads Arizona Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Republican Fife Symington easily foiled Evan Mecham's bid to reclaim the governor's seat from which he had been ousted. But the GOP millionaire is up against a tougher foe in Terry Goddard, the former Phoenix mayor who wants to keep the governor's seat in Democratic hands. Polls consistently have showed Symington trailing Goddard. Democrat Rose Mofford, the former secretary of state, inherited the governor's job in 1988 after the impeachment of her Republican boss, Mecham. She decided not to run for a full term. Symington's biggest advantage over Goddard is in voter registration, since there are nearly 100,000 more Republicans than Democrats in Arizona. But the five-way primary left the GOP badly split. Conservatives, especially those who supported Mecham, seemed reluctant to join the Symington camp. There even was a short-lived effort to find a conservative to run as an independent. Max Hawkins, a former top Mecham aide, is waging a write-in campaign for governor that may attract conservatives who otherwise would vote for Symington. Mecham has done little to bring the warring GOP factions together and gave the Republican nominee a less-than-warm endorsement. ``As I've said many times, Goddard will be a 100 percent disaster. Fife will be only an 80 percent disaster,'' he said. President Bush is expected to make an appearance for Symington before the election, but analysts doubt it will have much effect on the campaign. Recent polls show Bush losing popularity both nationally and in Arizona, and such endorsements ``are of declining and almost minimal value'' in any case, said Phoenix political consultant Bob Robb. Symington began his general-election campaign by labeling Goddard a ``tax-and-spend liberal'' and himself a ``Goldwater conservative.'' But as the campaign wore on, the labels wore thin. Symington ``has a very long row to hoe'' but that the GOP candidate is doing what he needs to do, says Robb. What he needs to do, Robb says, is find fault in Goddard's record during six years as mayor of Phoenix. Symington accuses Goddard of being a professional politician who will raise taxes. Goddard, meanwhile, boasts that the city budget was balanced each of the six years he was mayor and that there was only one general tax increase. He has challenged Symington to disclose information about his dealings as a Phoenix developer to show ``who owns Fife Symington.'' Other key campaign issues have played to Goddard's advantage, analysts say. Goddard is pro-choice on abortion, while Symington has switched positions several times during the campaign. Now Symington says he believes abortion should be an option up to the point when a fetus is viable outside the womb. ``What he has managed to do is alienate both sides,'' says Arizona State University pollster Bruce Merrill. Both Symington and Goddard favor a state holiday to honor the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., an issue that will be on the Nov. 6 ballot. But Merrill said Goddard probably stands to gain the most if it passes, which recent polls show is likely. Voters who favor the holiday also support Goddard by about a 3-1 margin, polls indicate. Mecham was impeached by the state House and convicted by the Senate of misusing money from supporters and interfering with a police investigation of an alleged death threat by one of his aides.

DOC.HEAD: SDI Backers See Hope for Program in Compromise
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Proponents of the Strategic Defense Initiative remain cautiously optimistic that last-minute changes in the 1991 defense bill will give new life to the embattled anti-missile program. ``It's an improvement,'' Rep. Jon Kyl, R-Ariz., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said Tuesday. ``A lot of it will depend on the spirit in which it's applied.'' The House planned today to consider the $288 billion authorization bill setting military spending ceilings for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The legislation calls for a nearly $2 billion cut in President Bush's request for SDI, barely keeps alive the B-2 bomber program and slashes troop levels. Action on the defense blueprint comes a week after House and Senate bargainers worked out a compromise from differing bills passed earlier by the two chambers. The road from that announced agreement to today's expected approval has been rocky. Shortly after lawmakers agreed on the military package, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he would recommend a presidential veto in light of the bill's restrictive language on the SDI budget, provision on base closings and sharp reductions in troop strength. Congressional staffers and Pentagon officials worked throughout the weekend and Monday to reach a compromise, finally settling on changes that in some cases give Cheney greater authority and won his backing for the bill. The bill slashes $1.8 billion from Bush's proposal of $4.7 billion for SDI, commonly known as Star Wars. The cut represents $700 million less than Congress spent on Star Wars last year and reflects the increasing belief on Capitol Hill that although the Pentagon envisions early deployment, SDI will largely exist as a research program. Initially, the bill divided spending on SDI into five separate programs and imposed limits on each category's budget. The language was modified to win Cheney's approval. ``It's not as rigid'' in terms of preventing the SDI office from transferring money from one category to another, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters Tuesday. Only Congress' interpretation of the language will determine whether the programworks, Kyl said. ``Oversight must be in a spirit of cooperation, not finding fault but making it work,'' he said. Last-minute changes in the legislation also provide Cheney with added flexibility on troop cuts. Negotiators agreed on a reduction of 100,000 from the 2.1 million troops worldwide. Added to the bill was authority for the defense secretary to limit the cut to 80,000 based on the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Pentagon and congressional officials also changed details in the provision setting up an independent commission to recommend military bases for closing or realignment. The revisions have no impact on the overall concept. In other legislative developments Tuesday, the House voted to spend $19.3 billion this fiscal year to operate the Commerce, Justice and State departments, including more money for savings and loan prosecutions and the drug war. The bill was approved, 377-40, and was sent to the Senate. The total spending in the bill is $529 million less than the amount appropriated for the three departments last year and $681 million less than requested by Bush. The bill provides $8.5 billion for the Justice Department, including $105 million in various divisions for savings and loan investigations and $694 million for the Drug Enforcement Administration. DEA spending is $146 million more than last year but $6 million less than requested by the president.

DOC.HEAD: Subsidy-Cutting Farm Bill On Way To Senate For Final Approval
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 farm bill, described by one House member as the child nobody wants, is on its way to the Senate for final approval. The House voted 318-102 Tuesday to accept the revisions made in their original bill by a House-Senate conference committee. Most of those speaking in favor of the bill said they were sorry about the changes in farm support required by deficit reduction mandates. ``We have a farm bill child,'' said Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan. ``We would like some other kind of child. We don't want to claim parentage. We have to take the responsibility and move ahead.'' After the House and Senate passed their original bills, budget negotiators decided that farm spending over the next five years would have to be reduced by $13.6 billion to assist in cutting a total $500 billion from the federal budget. That left the conference committee with the job of adjusting subsidy programs to cut farm spending during the next five years to $40.8 billion. Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said all the members of the Agriculture Committee thought the cut was too great since farm spending is less than one percent of the overall budget. The Bush administration, which originally sought even greater cuts in agriculture, was blamed for the bite. ``It is a bad bill,'' said Rep. David Nagle, D-Iowa, who voted against it. ``It is a bad bill for American farmers and was handcrafted by the administration.'' ``The administration of George Bush and (Agriculture Secretary) Clayton Yeutter in my judgment has worked to lower farm prices in America,'' said Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., chairman of the Agriculture subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains. ``In my judgment, it has been a disgrace what has happened to rural America. ... This bill tries to put a stop to it. It's a meager attempt, but it is the best we could do under the circumstances,'' he said. The bill directs farmers to reduce subsidized acreage by 15 percent, on condition Congress passes the expected budget cuts still being negotiated by the House and Senate. In addition to the subsidy programs, the farm bill establishes new environmental practices for farmers, sets up national standards for organic farming and revises agricultural trade policy. It offers programs for minority farmers and dying rural communities, establishes new methods for preserving forests and streamlines the procedures for delivering food aid abroad. De la Garza said cuts in farm support could be renegotiated if economic conditions change during the five-year life of the farm bill. ``Nothing is permanent in legislation,'' he said. ``We don't know what is happening at GATT, but that might necessitate some changes.'' U.S. officials negotiating the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have been trying to get other countries to reduce the subsidies they place on exports. If successful, U.S. agricultural sales internationally could change dramatically. The talks are expected to be completed in December. Meanwhile, ``we will have some $13.6 billion worth of cuts which are painful, unjust and unfair. But we are being responsible as I said we would be,'' said de la Garza.

DOC.HEAD: Senate To Put Off Investigation Of `Keating Five' Until After Election
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee, unable to make a decision to dismiss or advance cases against the ``Keating Five'' senators, will instead hold a post-election hearing that will keep the inquiry alive for all those under investigation. The committee decision ignored for the present its special counsel's recommendation that the investigation be dismissed against Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, and the only Republican in the probe, John McCain of Arizona. McCain branded the decision to do nothing now - and hold hearings starting Nov. 15 - an ``act of political cowardice.'' Glenn pronounced himself ``disappointed.'' Dropping McCain would have left only three Democrats under investigation among the five senators who assisted Charles H. Keating Jr. - a major political donor and the S&L owner who presided over the nation's costliest thrift collapse. The delay cost Republicans a valuable campaign issue. The committee special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, also proposed that the investigation be continued against three Democrats: Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle of Michgan and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. The ranking committee Republican, Sen. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire, said the three Democrats and three Republicans on the panel voted without gaining a majority of four on ``every possible combination and permutation'' that would have advanced or dismissed the investigation. But the committee was unanimous, he said, in ordering the fact-finding hearing that panel Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said could take 10 days. Heflin said the committee expected to complete its work and report to the Senate by Dec. 31. Cranston issued a statement saying, ``The public is entitled to get beyond the malicious rumors and selective leaks, and to know all the facts. I see this as an opportunity to achieve the public vindication I know I deserve.'' McCain called the committee's refusal to act ``an outrage'' that will lead to allegations of a cover up of findings that proposed his exoneration. Riegle said he was bound by a committee requirement not to discuss the case, but said, ``It's impossible to respond adequately to false charges and inaccurate and misleading characterizations.'' Glenn said he was ```disappointed by the ethics committee's decision not to make a decision.'' He said he has no hesitancy in appearing at the public session but added, ``I don't see how that helps the committee make up its mind.'' All five senators have denied any connection between Keating's money and their help for the Irvine, Calif.-based thrift, which was seized by the U.S. government in April 1989 at a potential cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion. Documents recently obtained by The Associated Press and others indicate that Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle had more extensive relationships with Keating than they previously acknowledged. For example, the documents show that Cranston wrote Keating to thank him for a $250,000 contribution to a Cranston-backed voter registration project and at the same time expressed his pleasure that Keating met with the top thrift regulator to plead his case about Lincoln. And they reveal how DeConcini assisted Keating in his effort to have former top thrift regulator Edwin J. Gray removed from the examination of Lincoln. Keating, who ran Lincoln and its parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, was indicted Sept. 19 in California on state criminal fraud charges. The indictment was related to sale of $250 million in high-risk bonds to depositors from Lincoln's branches, bonds that became worthless when American Continental went bankrupt.

DOC.HEAD: Graddick Campaigns For Hunt, Says Some Blacks Vote `Like Sheep'
DOC.TEXT: Former Attorney General Charlie Graddick said while campaigning for Gov. Guy Hunt's re-election that some black voters go to the polls ``like sheep'' carrying marked ballots. Graddick urged members of a Montgomery civic club to vote against Democrat Paul Hubbert. Graddick said black leaders such as Joe Reed collect money from candidates to buy votes in the black community. Reed is chief of the Alabama Democratic Conference and Hubbert's top assistant at the Alabama Education Association, Graddick said some blacks ``go to church on Sunday and they are issued marked ballots. ... I think that these people just don't use what I think God gave them as their brain ... these people who are using marked ballots to go in and vote like sheep.'' He said using marked ballots is ``pretty unique to the black community. It has been that way for years.'' Reed said that Graddick's claim about him buying votes was ``not true.'' He said Graddick sought ADC's support in 1986 and was turned down. At the time, Graddick was seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, which he lost.
DOC.HEAD: Feinstein, Wilson Debate In Doubt
DOC.TEXT: A second gubernatorial debate between Dianne Feinstein and Pete Wilson was thrown into doubt after a television station said a new format could cause serious technical problems. Wilson's campaign said if another studio could not be found for Thursday night's scheduled debate, a rescheduled contest was unlikely. Feinstein's camp said securing another studio in time would be nearly impossible. The problems centered on a debate format proposed by the Republican Wilson, who says he could not come back to California from Washington on Thursday because he must attend to Senate business. Wilson wanted to debate the Democrat Feinstein via satellite from Washington, while Feinstein and reporter panelists would remain in San Francisco's KPIX-TV studio as planned. Feinstein reluctantly agreed to the format. But late Tuesday afternoon, KPIX announced it didn't want the satellite format because technology could fail at an important point in the debate, possibly affecting viewers' opinions of the outcome.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Greeted by Protests in Waterbury, Stamford
DOC.TEXT: President Bush encountered rain everywhere in his campaign visit to Connecticut, as well as a smattering of protesters angered by his veto of civil rights legislation and his Persian Gulf policy. In Stamford, where Bush campaigned for Republican gubernatorial candidate John G. Rowland, a dozen AIDS rights activists protested what they consider inadequate federal funding for research and treatment of AIDS. In Waterbury, about a dozen local black activists stood in the rain with about twice as many anti-war activists to protest at Bush's appearance on behalf of GOP congressional candidate Gary Franks. The black activists said Bush should not have vetoed the Civil Rights Act of 1990. ``I think it was an awful bad move,'' said Booker T. Paris, a member of the local chapter of the NAACP. ``It will not only hurt him with black voters, it will hurt him with white voters too.'' The anti-war demonstrators called for a full U.S. withdrawal from Saudi Arabia. They said the Gulf crisis should be settled peacefully by the United Nations.
DOC.HEAD: Parmer Charges Gramm with Ethics Violation
DOC.TEXT: Democratic senatorial nominee Hugh Parmer says U.S. Sen. Phil Gramm received an illegal gift and vowed to file a complaint with the Senate Ethics Committee if no one else does. Gramm's spokesman Larry Neal said the charge was ``laughable'' and that Parmer should resign from the race. ``Now that he has abandoned all hope of winning, he wants to spend the last few weeks smearing the senator's reputation,'' Neal said. Parmer said Gramm bought lakefront property near Corsicana in 1983 for below market price and at below market interest rate. This deal constituted a gift that Gramm did not report on his public financial statements, Parmer said. In addition, Parmer said Gramm bought the land from Dr. Louis Gibson, who then was director of First Republic Bank of Corsicana. Parmer said the bank had a political action committee in Washington that lobbied members of Congress. ``It is illegal for members of Congress to receive gifts from persons with a direct interest in legislation before Congress,'' Parmer said.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Indicates Silber, Kerry Leading
DOC.TEXT: A new poll indicates that Democrats John Silber, for governor, and Sen. John F. Kerry lead their Republican opponents. The telephone poll of 600 likely voters was conducted Friday to Sunday for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV by KRC Research. The poll has a margin of error of 4 percentage points. In the race for governor and lieutenant governor, Silber and running mate Marjorie Clapprood were the choice of 45 percent; Republicans William Weld and Paul Cellucci got 39 percent; the Independent High-Tech ticket of Leonard Umina and Lawrence DeBerry got 5 percent; and 12 percent were undecided or refused to answer. In a KRC poll taken 4{ weeks ago, Weld and Cellucci led Silber and Clapprood 43 percent to 42 percent. Umina and DeBerry were not included in that poll. In the race for U.S. Senate, incumbent Kerry led Republican James Rappaport 52 percent to 38 percent. Nine percent were undecided, refused to answer or said they liked someone else. In the poll taken after the Sept. 18 primary, Kerry's lead was smaller, 45 percent to 41 percent.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Three Security Force Personnel Killed In Two Bomb Blasts
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded simultaneously at two checkpoints early Wednesday, killing at least three security force members and injuring 20 people, most of them soldiers, authorities said. One of the bombings struck a checkpoint at the village of Killeen on the border with the Republic of Ireland, 40 miles south of Belfast, police headquarters said in a statement. The post is on the main road between Belfast and Dublin. The second checkpoint hit, also on the border with Ireland, is near Londonderry, 65 miles northwest of Belfast. The British domestic news agency Press Association quoted unnamed sources in the security forces as saying the two attacks appeared to have been coordinated. No group immediately claimed responsibility but suspicion inevitably fell on Irish Republican Army, which is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Both checkpoints have been attacked by guerrillas several times in the past. At Altnagelvin Hospital, staff treating casualties from the attack near Londonderry said two people were dead on arrival there. They said eight more had been admitted, six of them in serious condition, and another seven were expected. Mervyn Ferris, the unit administrator at Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry near Killeen, said one person was killed in the Killeen attack and that seven other people were being treated at the hospital for cuts, bruises and shock.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Effort To Alter Endangered Species Act For Owl
DOC.TEXT: A Senate showdown over the threatened northern spotted owl turned into a debate over the future of the Pacific Northwest's oldest forests and a vote of confidence in the Endangered Species Act. ``The owl is an indicator species. As it goes, so goes the forest,'' Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., said Tuesday night. On a 62-34 vote, the Senate rejected an attempt to circumvent the Endangered Species Act so Northwest logging could continue regardless of the impact on the rare bird. Republican senators in Oregon and Washington pushed the plan to help soften the economic blow on communities expected to be hit hard by dramatic reductions in timber harvests as a result of federally mandated protection of the owl. Gore and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, led the charge against Oregon Sen. Bob Packwood's amendment to the Interior appropriations bill. The Senate also voted 52-44 to reject an amendment to the bill by Sen. Wyche Fowler Jr., D-Ga., to reduce road-building funds for the Forest Service by $100 million from a planned $196 million. Timber companies rely on public funds to ``go up to the top steep slopes, the older growth, places of scenic beauty,'' Fowler argued. Road-building expense caused the forest Service to lose $365 million on timber sales last year, he said. Western senators contended the amendment would gut logging in their states. ``Mill towns into ghost towns, that's what the Fowler amendment creates in my state,'' said Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore. The Fish and Wildlife Service's decision to declare the owl a threatened species in June ``sounded a warning that within our lifetime an entire ancient ecosystem may be lost forever,'' Mitchell said. Forest Service biologists have determined the owl is on the road to extinction unless logging is banned across millions of acres of the Northwest's oldest forests. The government predicts logging reductions to protect the owl will cost the Northwest tens of thousands of timber jobs by the end of the decade. Experts estimate about 3,000 pairs of the secretive, 20-inch owls survive in the old-growth forests of Oregon, Washington and northern California. Packwood's amendment to the Interior appropriations bill would have eased the criteria required to convene the Endangered Species Committee. That Cabinet-level panel, commonly referred to as the ``God Committee,'' has the authority to overrule the act's protection of wildlife if it determines the economic consequences of such protection is too severe. ``I hope we have not reached the point where the Holy Grail is science and only science and nothing else counts,'' Packwood said in a Senate floor speech. The Endangered Species Committee chaired by the secretary of interior has met only twice in the 17-year history of the Endangered Species Act, once in a dispute over the snail darter and Tennessee's Tellico Dam. A final vote on the Interior appropriations bill, which includes controversial funding for the National Endowment for the Arts, is expected later this week.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Passenger Fined for Pinching Flight Attendant
DOC.TEXT: An airline passenger who pinched a flight attendant's rear end was slapped with a $775 fine. Jay Scott Curtis, 25, of Hobbs, N.M., was among eight oil field workers charged with causing a drunken ruckus aboard the American Airlines flight Sept. 16. The men, who were flying to Lubbock after attending a Dallas Cowboys football game, were jailed on charges of interfering with a flight crew, a federal offense carrying up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Curtis was sentenced Friday after pleading guilty to a lesser offense, simple assault. The seven other men are scheduled for trial Nov. 5. The men, who work for various oil companies, boarded with their own alcohol, and after it was confiscated, refused to buckle their seat belts, made sexual suggestions to the flight attendants and yelled profanities to prevent attendants from delivering preflight instructions, the FBI said.

DOC.HEAD: House Slashes Administration Request For S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers angry at the Bush administration's hide-and-seek call for new taxpayer dollars for the savings and loan bailout are moving to approve only a fraction of the billions being sought. The House Banking Committee voted Tuesday to slash to $10 billion the administration's request for $57 billion to continue the bailout through the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Both Democrats and Republicans on the panel suggested Congress should deny any new bailout money in view of Bush's assertion a year ago that ``never again'' would taxpayers be tapped for it and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's refusal to testify why that has changed. But warned by regulators that the bailout's total costs might swell an additional $300 million in the next three months without the funds, the committee voted just enough money to keep the program going through February. ``The more you give them, the more they are going to squander,'' complained Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis., who suggested not approving any new funds. ``Here we are at the 11th hour subjected to the old squeeze play.'' The Senate Banking Committee two weeks ago approved the administration's request for $57 billion. But congressional and administration sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they don't expect it to ever reach the Senate floor for a vote. Instead, they said, the House is likely to pass its committee's version within the next two days and send it to the Senate. Senate leaders would then attach the House version to another bill, possibly one toughening penalties for S&L fraud, through a parliamentary maneuver that would allow senators to avoid a recorded roll-call vote on the issue. Administration officials had warned in recent months the $50 billion that Bush sought and got from Congress a year ago would not be enough - after contending then it be more than ample. Over the summer, Brady suggested another $40 billion to $80 billion might be needed. However, the administration never submitted a formal request for the money until Brady wrote the chairmen of the House and Senate Banking committees two weeks ago, saying virtually all of the original $50 billion had been spent. The bailout ``will virtually cease within the next two months unless additional funds are provided,'' he warned, leaving hundreds of insolvent thrifts still operating and losing federally insured deposits. House Democrats, joined by some Republicans, insisted that administration officials make a pitch for the new money in public hearings and before TV cameras to share more of the political heat for the swelling S&L problem. Brady refused several requests to testify. Just two weeks before an election in which polls show the S&L crisis contributing to voter antipathy toward officeholders, lawmakers were irked even more when they learned that Brady was posing for photographers rather than appear at one scheduled hearing. ``The administration should have been here,'' Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said just prior to the House panel's vote Tuesday. ``This is going to be a long haul on the savings and loan bill and everybody's going to have to do some heavy lifting.'' The House panel's chairman, Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, said further money to keep the bailout going beyond February will not occur ``until Secretary Brady and other officials of the administration appear in full-dress oversight hearings.''

DOC.HEAD: Debate To Begin On Issue Of Obscenity In Federally Supported Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Senate debate expected to start in early afternoon; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jesse Helms will try to slip a new anti-obscenity noose around the National Endowment for the Arts when the Senate begins debate today on the emotional issue of federal support for artistic works that some view as offensive. Helms, a conservative North Carolina Republican, is leading the fight to impose explicit new curbs on the NEA's grant-making powers. He is opposed by a bipartisan group of senators who favor having the courts decide whether NEA-supported works are obscene. On Monday night, Helms introduced a proposal to forbid the arts endowment to spend federal funds on any works that ``depict or describe, in a patently offensive way, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' The ban proposed by Helms omits any mention of obscenity by name, apparently to satisfy objections by opponents of such curbs that the NEA has no business making judgments about obscenity. At midday today, the Senate planned to start seven hours of debate on the Helms amendment and a rival plan backed by Sens. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., that would penalize grant recipients who are later convicted of violating obscenity laws. The proposed Helms ban, if approved, would replace a laundry list of anti-obscenity curbs that Congress slapped on the NEA a year ago. The bill up for Senate action today would renew those restrictions, extend the endowment's life through next September and trim its proposed $175 million budget by $5 million. The current ban forbids NEA support for works that ``may be considered obscene, including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' That Helms-inspired ban was approved amid an escalating political controversy over NEA grants for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano, which Helms and other conservative lawmakers denounced as obscene and sacrilegious. The Senate bill also would allow NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer to continue his requirement that grant reipients sign a non-obscenity pledge. The pledge has caused widespread protests in the arts community and resulted in three federal lawsuits challenging the pledge's constitutionality. By contrast, the House voted last week to boost the endowment's $171 million budget to $180 million, outlaw Frohnmayer's pledge and omit any explicit anti-obscenity restrictions. The House bill says only that obscenity lacks artistic merit, is not protected speech and ``shall not be funded.'' The House voted overwhelmingly to scrap the current obscenity ban and instead to require the NEA to recover its money from any grant recipient whose works are later ruled obscene by the courts. A similar compromise was contained in a separate bill approved by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee by a 15-1 vote with strong bipartisan support, but Helms effectively blocked floor action on that measure. Differences between the House and Senate bills will have to be reconciled by negotiators from both chambers before a final NEA bill is enacted.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Airport Security Bill
DOC.TEXT:
The Senate has passed legislation to upgrade security at airline and airports, including directing the government to develop guidelines for warning passengers of terrorist threats. But rather than face a possible veto, it amended the bill approved by the House last week to give the Bush administration more flexibility in making airlines buy and use explosive detection devices that have been widely criticized for their inaccuracy. The Federal Aviation Administration wanted to make airlines acquire 150 of the ``thermal neutron analysis'' devices at a total cost of $175 million and deploy them at 15 international airports in the United States and 25 abroad. But a test of the device last April at New York's JFK Airport by a presidential commission that investigated the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, showed that it could not detect the amount of plastic explosives used in that bomb. The bill, approved in the Senate on Tuesday, now goes back to the House, which is expected to approve the Senate changes and send it to the White House.
---
DOC.HEAD: Court Reverses Decision Allowing AT&T Discounts For Corporations
DOC.TEXT:
A federal appeals court has invalidated a Federal Communications Commission decision that allows American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to discount long-distance packages for large corporations. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here held Tuesday that the FCC did not fully examine whether the customized long-distance services AT&T offers its larger corporate clients violated the Communications Act. The appellate court ordered the FCC to review its 1989 decision on the so-called Tariff 12 services offered by AT&T, whose long-distance operations are subject to government regulation. AT&T started offering the long-distance packages to companies such as General Electric Co., Ford Motor Co. and DuPont in 1988. Several of AT&T's long-distance competitors, including MCI Telecommunications Inc., and US Sprint, challenged the arrangements. ``We have the impression that there is a certain air of unreality about this case,'' said the court opinion. ``The FCC (one way or another) will undoubtedly permit AT&T to compete effectively against its competitors in the large user market if that is what is really involved here. But we are obliged to insist that it do so by turning square corners of administrative law.''
---
DOC.HEAD: House Passes Fish Net Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House has passed and sent to President Bush a bill that would ban the use of large-scale drift nets in U.S. waters up to 200 miles offshore and their use by American fishing fleets anywhere in the world. On a voice vote, the House dropped its own version of the legislation and agreed to adopt a bill approved earlier this month by the Senate that also would require Bush to seek an international ban on drift-net fishing The nets, which can extend up to 40 miles around, have been blamed for the deaths of thousands of dolphins, other sea mammals and birds caught in their paths as they are dragged through the water to trap commercial fish. The bill expands the 1976 Magnuson Fishery and Conservation Act to include previously exempted tuna in government controls over commercial and sport fishing within 200 miles of the U.S. coastline. The legislation also requires the government to develop standards that tuna canners would have to adopt in order to label their product ``dolphin safe.'' Some companies, according to lawmakers, have adopted the ``dolphin safe'' label in response to boycotts by environmentalists even though they continue to purchase tuna known to have been caught in nets responsible for dolphin deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Balloon Technique Opens Blocked Tubes in Infertile Women
DOC.TEXT: A new device that opens blocked fallopian tubes with a tiny balloon can offer a simpler and cheaper method for helping infertile women become pregnant, doctors reported today. However, the technique is designed for a particular type of blockage, present mong only 10 percent of the estimated 1 million American women who have blocked fallopian tubes. The procedure, which requires neither surgery nor general anesthesia, is similar to the use of balloons to open the clogged arteries of heart patients, according to the report in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The balloon is mounted on a flexible tube called a catheter and threaded through the womb into one of the fallopian tubes, which connect the uterus to the ovaries. Once the balloon is in place, doctors inflate it to open the passage. Dr. Edmond Confino, the study's lead author and director of education in obstetrics and gynecology at Mount Sinai Hospital Medical Center in Chicago, said the procedure could reduce by two-thirds the cost of treating women with blockages, who now usually choose between microsurgery or test-tube fertilization. The procedure is expected to cost a third as much as test-tube fertilization, which totals about $6,000, succeeds about 20 percent of the time and results in only a single pregnancy. Microsurgery, in which the patient's abdomen is opened, typically costs up to $10,000, Confino said. A surgeon not involved in the study said he believes the technique offers no significant advantages over still another method, simple catheterization. Simple catheterization uses the flexible tube itself to clear the blockage. ``I'm not against the technique, it's just another variation,'' said Dr. Rafael Valle, associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Northwestern University Medical School in Chicago. Confino said the balloon device is superior to regular catheterization because it causes far fewer puncture wounds and provides longer-lasting results. The device is designed to treat proximal tubal occlusion, or blockage of a tube near the point where it enters the uterus. It isn't designed to treat the much more common distal tubal occlusion, which is blockage farther up the tubes where they pick up the egg from the ovary. This type afflicts 90 percent of the women with blocked fallopian tubes. The balloon procedure, called transcervical balloon tuboplasty, is awaiting Food and Drug Administration approval. In tests, the procedure opened one or both tubes in about 135 of 150 women, and about 45 conceived, Confino said. Confino said the study covered the first 77 subjects, all of whom had proximal blockage. Seventy-one of them had one or both tubes cleared. Six couldn't be cleared. In 13 of the 77, after doctors cleared the proximal blockage, they found distal blockage that could not be cleared, the report said. Among the remaining 64 subjects, 22 became pregnant within a year, it said. Seventeen had normal deliveries. Five miscarried. One patient had a pregnancy that developed outside the womb and had to be ended. In two cases of the 77, the tuboplasty procedure punched a pinpoint hole in the wall of the fallopian tube, but no complications resulted, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Guccione, Penthouse to Pay Former Model $4 Million
LaserPhoto NY36 of Oct. 23
DOC.TEXT: Bob Guccione and Penthouse magazine have been ordered to pay more than $4 million to a former Pet of the Year who said she was forced to perform hard-core sex acts and sleep with two Guccione associates. ``Sexual slavery was not part of her job description,'' Supreme Court Justice Elliott Wilk said in finding that the magazine publisher made sexual demands on Marjorie Thoreson as a condition of employment at Penthouse, where she worked from 1973 to 1980. His ``cold and calculating ... use of sexual coercion forced her to safeguard her employment by sacrificing her body,'' the judge said Tuesday. Thoreson, 37, testified during the 1989 trial that Guccione forced her to perform hard-core sex acts in a pornographic movie and used her sexual favors as partial payment to furnish a hotel-casino he owned in Atlantic City. She said Guccione also ordered her to carry on an affair with his financial adviser so he would move from England to the United States. She said she severed the relationship because it appeared the adviser was going to leave his wife and children. Thoreson's lawyer, Murray Schwartz, said she cried when he called her in California with the news. This decision is ``for all the women like her who may have suffered at the hands of Guccione,'' Schwartz said. ``He has finally been held accountable.'' Penthouse's lawyer, Jeffrey Daichman, called the award an outrage and said he will appeal. He said that Thoreson had a relationship with Guccione before she was employed by Penthouse. But ``during the time of her employment, there was no sexual relationship between her and anybody associated with Penthouse.'' At the trial, Guccione testified that Thoreson was a potential Marilyn Monroe whom he had rescued from a life of crime. Guccione's only evidence to contradict Thoreson was his word, Wilk noted. The judge, who heard the case with no jury, added, ``I do not believe him.'' Wilk awarded Thoreson $60,000 in compensatory damages and $4 million in punitive damages. The judge said the amounts were based on Guccione's $150 million personal worth and Penthouse's market value of about $200 million. Thoreson, originally from St. Paul, Minn., approached Guccione in 1973 at age 20. She sent him nude photos of herself and a letter. At the time, she was living in California, where she was working as a cocktail waitress and topless dancer, did some modeling and took acting lessons. She also had several minor brushes with the law, the judge said. Guccione said in a statement Tuesday that Penthouse presented evidence that Thoreson was a former prostitute, drug abuser and ``three-time felon who had violated her probation.'' Thoreson said she told Guccione she wanted to be an actress. He signed her to a personal management contract, changed her name to Anika di Lorenzo, made her Penthouse Pet of the Year in 1975 and took her into his New York townhouse. In 1976, Guccione cast Thoreson in ``Caligula,'' a movie based loosely on the life of the mad Roman emperor. The film features bloody tortures, nudity and hard-core sex. At Guccione's urging, Thoreson said, she had her breasts enlarged for the role. In the movie, shown at the trial, Thoreson engages in sex acts with a man and a woman. Thoreson sued Guccione for fraud and sexual harassment after he fired her in 1980 because she refused to accompany him on a trip to the Far East. She said she feared he would pass her around to the businessmen he was meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Share Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar surged against the Japanese yen Wednesday while share prices sank. The dollar closed at 128.38 yen, 1.25 yen higher than Tuesday's close of 127.13 yen. The currency opened at 128.10 yen and ranged between 127.75 yen and 128.50 yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 421.42 points, or 1.67 percent, to end the day at 24,876.88. The Nikkei rose 227.44 points on Tuesday. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bond fell to 84.46 points from its 84.81-point close Tuesday. Its yield rose to 7.815 percent from 7.735 percent. Stock market investors are fearful of another steep drop after recent consecutive gains in the Nikkei. Wednesday morning's drop was the first since Monday. ``They were getting reluctant to buy any more in such a short period of time,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. Suzuki said the market was also suffering from a lack of fresh news to stimulate investors' buying interests. On the foreign exchange, the dollar's rise was accelerated by selling by institutional investors once it passed the 128-yen level, dealers said. The dollar has risen 2.73 yen in the last three trading days after a 13-day slide of 13.55 yen. The speed of the dollar's drop against the yen, combined with market fears of intervention, triggered the dollar's recent upswing, dealers said. Some dealers said the dollar may have hit bottom, and could rise back as high as the 129-yen range, while others said it is too early to determine whether the weak-dollar trend has reversed because investors are still wary of the U.S. federal budget and the Middle East. ``The situation favoring the strong yen has not changed. The dollar's fall to the 123-yen level was much too rapid. Traders were nervous about selling but did it anyway because everyone else was doing it,'' said Akiko Baba of the Bank of Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Yuppies - With Cars, No Less - are the New Hobos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bobb is cq in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Barry ``Brakeshoe'' Schwartz got the bum's rush when he tried to catch a bus from the Los Angeles freight yard to the Hobo Club meeting. ``The buses wouldn't pick us up because we were too dirty,'' Schwartz explained. So he took a $21 cab ride to the bar where the club meets in Beverly Hills. Schwartz, a video maker from Oakland, represents a new breed of hobo: part-time wanderers with jobs, credit cards and, gasp, automobiles. The 4,000 members nationwide of the Hobo Club share their freight-car forefathers' grimy fashion and yen for unauthorized rail travel, but little else. ``Hobos are known as people without very much money,'' said Sheri ``Hometown'' Doyel, 23, who did her thesis on rail riders while attending the University of California at Los Angeles. ``And here we are in Beverly Hills drinking $3 and $4 beers. ... It's ironic.'' Hobo culture is serious anthropological stuff and there is ``something very American'' about it, Doyel said. ``People think hobo, they think homeless,'' she said. ``It's not the same thing.'' The first hobos were said to have been unemployed men who rode the rails seeking work after the Civil War. Hobo lore has it the originals carried hoes for field work, hence the name ``hoe boy.'' ``In the old days, it was need and desperation,'' said Garth Bishop of Los Angeles, publisher of the Hobo Times newsletter. ``Most of the young people now do it for a weekend - for a vacation adventure.'' The use of monikers like ``Freight Train George'' and ``Minneapolis Jewel'' became part of the subculture. The nicknames, precursors to truckers' citizens-band radio ``handles,'' were intended to obscure a hobo's background. But they have come to describe characteristics of the hobos themselves. Don't make the mistake of calling them tramps, or worse, bums. Hobos claim they are honest guys and gals who work when they can - not like the petty criminals they call tramps. Bums are, well, bums. The railroads say some of their ranks are transients - and all of their wanderlust is illegal. ``It's hardly glamorous,'' said Cathy Westphal, spokeswoman for The Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Co. ``Our equipment was not meant for the transport of human beings.'' Westphal said the world of illegal rail travel also is populated by people who would ``just as soon slit your throat as look at you.'' And she said ``yuppie hobos'' set a poor example for children. ``I can't tell you how many children get their legs cut off'' trying to hop moving trains, she said. Hobo Club members agreed there may be some danger - they refer to train wheels as ``salami slicers.'' But it isn't enough to stop them. ``Danger is going 70 mph without a seat belt,'' said Greta Shred, 27, a filmmaker and electrician from San Francisco. Several club members have never even been on a train, Bishop said. Membership is automatic with an $18-a-year newsletter subscription. During the monthly meeting, the call of the steam engine's whistle, made by a wooden flute-like device, pierced the cigarette smoke-filled air. A guitar-picking hobo provided toe-tapping renditions of ``King of the Road'' and ``American Pie.'' A black-and-white movie depicted hobo life during the 1930s. Few thought it was the least bit unusual to meet on ever-so-chic Wilshire Boulevard, hardly the haunt of the downtrodden. They were quick to point out that railroads were responsible for much of California's early growth. ``It makes perfect sense,''said Bobb ``Santa Fe Bo'' Hopkins, who described himself as an actor and writer. ``The wealthiest and the poorest are those that don't work 9-to-5. We're here to make a life, not make a living.''

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Election At a Glance
With PM-Pakistan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are facts about Wednesday's parliamentary election in Pakistan: --- THE COUNTRY - Pakistan, the world's ninth most populous country, was created in 1947 as a homeland for India's minority Moslems. It has seen only four popularly elected governments. The military has ruled Pakistan for more than 25 of its 43 years. Rich in resources, Pakistan is plagued with widespread poverty and illiteracy. Most of the country's 110 million people are landless laborers earning less than $400 a year. Pakistan is burdened with a defense budget that eats 52 percent of the total expenditure. --- THE ELECTION - More than 1,300 candidates are contesting the 207 seats reserved for Moslems in the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament. Another 41 candidates are contesting 10 seats reserved for non-Moslems such as Christian, Hindu, Zoroastrian and Sikhs. --- THE ISSUES - Despite a host of social and economic problems, the only campaign issue has been Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister whose government was dismissed Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, incompetence and mismanagement. --- THE CANDIDATES - Ms. Bhutto's populist, center-left Pakistan People's Party joined forces with three smaller parties to form the Pakistan Democratic Alliance. Her key opponent is a coalition called the Islamic Democratic Alliance, which embraces 18 parties espousing a variety of political ideologies. There are 30 other parties contesting the election. They follow a wide range of political principles, from right-wing to far-left and religious fundamentalism to secession. At least three parties are demanding independence for southern Sindh Province and several other parties were established along ethnic lines. --- THE VOTERS - There are 47.3 million eligibile Moslem voters and another 1.4 million non-Moslem voters. Turnout in the November 1988 election was 43.2 percent and many predict Wednesday's turnout will be even lower. Because less than 25 percent of the population is literate, voters will check their candidate's party symbol. Ms. Bhutto's alliance is identified by an arrow, while the symbol of the Islamic Democratic Alliance is a bicycle.

DOC.HEAD: Risque Rappers Perform Without Incident
DOC.TEXT: 2 Live Crew took the stage in their first show since they beat an obscenity rap and came off too tame for many fans. ``It wasn't as nasty as they wanna be,'' said Kelly Jackson, 20, of Cincinnati. About 850 fans attended the concert Tuesday at the 1,300-person capacity Ritz Music Hall. Police observed the performance and said they found nothing wrong. No arrests were made during the adults-only, no-alcohol show. On Saturday, the rap group, whose music contains references to oral and anal sex and violence against women, was acquitted of obscenity over a show held after a judge pronounced their album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' obscene. On Tuesday, band leader Luther Campbell, wearing an American flag bandanna, took the stage with the advice, ``If you don't like what we sing, don't bring your ass in the house.'' The band often stopping short of finishing the lyrics, instead pointing their microphones toward the audience, which responded by shouting the dirty words. Some fans thought the 50-minute show was too brief and that the rappers were unable to express themselves as explicitly as they did before their trial. ``It was too limited in what they could say,'' said Peter Adams, 25, of Indianapolis. Campbell performed several numbers with the top of his jeans unbuttoned. Four women dancers wore outfits that left most of their buttocks exposed. ``We have no objection to the show from a legal standpoint,'' said police spokesman Andrew Stoner. ``The women's outfits were more than adult exotic dancers wear in Indianapolis.''

DOC.HEAD: State Promotion in Japanese Sex Magazine Gets Official Suspended
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin's tourism director was suspended for arranging a promotional article in a sexually explicit Japanese magazine. Development Secretary Robert Trunzo announced Tuesday he ordered Richard Matty suspended without pay for seven days after consulting with Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. ``I see no merit in promoting our state in a publication with sexually explicit material that most people in Wisconsin would find personally offensive and which is degrading and insensitive to women,'' Trunzo said in a letter to Matty. Use of the magazine is ``inconsistent with our department's commitment to the state's equal opportunity and affirmative action policies,'' Trunzo said. ``The governor suggested disciplinary action,'' Trunzo said. ``He was furious.'' Matty and other state tourism officials arranged to promote Wisconsin in the magazine Hoseki, Trunzo said. A reporter and photographer for the magazine visited in 1989, touring the state with Knowles, and ran a 12-page article in February. Matty said he did not have time to review a copy of the magazine before publication of the promotion. ``I was acting on the recommendation of our foreign office that it was a popular, well-read and good promotional tool for Wisconsin,'' he said. Trunzo said he also expected to discipline two other state tourism officials, including the director of the Wisconsin office in Tokyo. The disciplinary action was not the first against Matty, 58, since he was appointed by Thompson in 1987. Matty was suspended for three days last year and agreed to pay $6,957 to settle a sexual harassment complaint by a former employee.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leaders Angered Over Bush Veto of Bias Bill
With PM-Civil Rights, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Months ago, President Bush was ``talking the talk.'' But in the language of the civil rights movement, ``talking the talk'' must be accompanied by ``walking the walk,'' and now Bush is seen as walking the wrong the way. Civil rights leaders bitterly accused the president of betrayal for vetoing, as expected, a major anti-discrimination bill Monday. Bush said the measure would have led to hiring quotas, something sponsors dispute. Coretta Scott King, widow of Martin Luther King Jr., said Tuesday the president had pandered to ``those who profit from discrimination.'' She said the veto ``demonstrates racist attitudes among those who call the shots in the White House.'' ``How far we have regressed since the days when a courageous and principled president supported civil rights legislation and challenged the nation to a higher standard of equality,'' she said, referring to President Lyndon Johnson, who signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Civil rights leaders' criticism for the veto ended a relatively peaceful period in the relationship between the White House and minorities. ``We don't have to read his lips anymore,'' said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the Atlanta-based civil rights group founded by King. ``His lips have spoken loud and clear.'' ``A few months ago, he was talking the talk,'' said Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., once a King aide. ``He met with people. He said good things. It was a breath of fresh air for the civil rights movement.'' But Lewis said Bush walked the wrong way. ``The civil rights forces will continue to talk and negotiate, if not about this bill, about something else,'' Lewis said. ``But there is a rift, there will be a schism, because his action was very divisive.'' The Senate planned an override vote today on the measure, which would effectively overturn six U.S. Supreme Court decisions that have made it harder for women and minorities to prove job discrimination. Two-thirds majorities in both the Senate and House are required to override a veto. Bush predicted Tuesday that Congress would uphold his veto. ``I feel pretty good. I think we're in good shape,'' he said in Waterbury, Conn., where he was campaigning for Gary Franks, a black Republican congressional candidate who also opposed the bill. Asked what signal his veto sent to minorities, the president said, ``I think it sends a signal that we are for civil rights and are opposed to quotas.'' He added, ``I do what I think is right and I think I'll have strong support across racial lines.'' In Chicago, Eugene Dibble, a black businessman and Republican fund-raiser, was distressed. ``It makes me very uncomfortable to have these two or three pictures of President and Mrs. Bush sitting on my desk,'' Dibble said. ``I don't know what to say when someone black comes in here and asks me: `How could you support the man who vetoed civil rights?' '' In Washington, Jesse Jackson said the veto was ``a call to a return to massive direct action.'' He said that could include street demonstrations and other forms of non-violent protest. Jackson accused Bush of ``a closed-door policy and he has a closed-mind policy - he is betraying the American dream.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Aid Cut May Help Peace Process; Amnesty Report; Rebel Bombs Kill Two
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Senate promise to link military aid to conduct by both the Salvadoran government and the rebels could speed up peace talks that resume early next month, some Salvadoran leaders say. The Senate last week halved the $85 million aid package and promised to cut aid altogether if the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani were to withdraw from peace talks. If the rebels fail to demonstrate good faith in negotiations - or launch a major offensive - the slashed $42.5 million would be restored. On Tuesday, the rebels launched their second hit-and-run attack on a military headquarters in week. But their two homemade mortar-type bombs fell about 500 feet short of their intended target, the downtown Defense Ministry, killing two children and wounding two women. Six days earler, similar homemade mortars were used in an attack on the main air force base on the capital's eastern edge. The 11-year-old civil war has claimed the lives of about 72,000 people. Amnesty International today reported a significant upsurge in the number of killings by army-supported death squads. The London-based human rights group said 45 people were killed by death squads in the first seven months of 1990 - more than during all of last year. Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria called Friday's Senate vote to halve military aid the result of ``successful incursions by the FMLN in Washington.'' He was referring to the leftist rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, which has waged war against a succession of U.S.-backed governments. ``It's not as if we don't need the aid. Because those fighting the system, those in the FMLN, are still waging their battle,'' Santamaria said Monday. But Santamaria, head of the government delegation to peace talks with the rebels, also emphasized that the U.S. move provides an incentive to the FMLN to contribute more to the success of the peace process. Rebel and government negotiators are scheduled to resume peace talks Nov. 4 in Mexico. Peace talks have bogged down on the issue of the future role of the armed forces. The rebels demand a drastic purge and reduction of security forces that would culminate in the ``demilitarization'' of Salvadoran society. The government says it is in favor of weeding out negative elements from the army. But it rejects a wholesale purge. Monsignor Gregorio Rosa Chavez, Roman Catholic auxiliary bishop of San Salvador, told a news conference on Sunday that the aid cut ``gives rise to signs of hope because it is a recognition that peace cannot be constructed with arms.'' He said the congressional move ``makes the peace process more viable.'' Juan Jose Martell, a leader of the leftist Popular Social Christian Movement, said the reduction and conditioning of the aid ``is a positive message to both sides in the conflict.'' But the defense minister, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, said the cut in aid constituted ``a negative signal to everything that represents the country's institutionality and a positive signal to the belligerent adventure planned by the FMLN. It would prolong the conflict.'' Many of the civil war's deaths have been blamed on right-wing death squads operating in cooperation with the military. Several military officials have been charged in the murders last year of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. ``People are just fed up with this thing,'' Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said after the Friday vote, referring to the millions of dollars in U.S. aid sent to El Salvador over the past decade.

DOC.HEAD: Revised List of Great Books Plugs 60 New Authors; Drops Four
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Contemporary American writers Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Eugene O'Neill made the grade. So did women authors Jane Austen, Willa Cather, George Eliot and Virginia Woolf. But 18th century English novelists Henry Fielding and Laurence Sterne aren't as great as they used to be, say the editors of the newly revised ``Great Books of the Western World.'' Fielding's ``Tom Jones'' and Sterne's ``Tristram Shandy'' were dropped from the new-and-improved version. The works of 60 new authors were brought into the fold with such minds as Plato, Aristotle and Homer. The volumes include the writings of historians, philosophers, scientists, theologians and others from ancient Greece and Rome, medieval and modern Europe and the Americas. It's been 38 years since Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc. published the original set, featuring 74 authors and 443 works including books, essays and plays. The Chicago-based publishing company said it was time to give recognition to new writers and a second chance to some who were passed over the first time. ``It's not that it was outdated,'' said Robert P. Gwinn, chairman of Encyclopaedia Britannica. ``But basically the world is changing, and we thought we needed to include 45 new authors who made significant contributions in the first half of the 20th century.'' Four authors were dropped from the earlier collection, which included no women or 20th-century authors. The revised set features 130 authors and 517 works totaling 37,000 pages in 60 volumes. The idea for the original 54-volume set came from Mortimer J. Adler, an author and philosopher who has served as a member of Britannica's board of editors since its inception in 1947. Now he's the project's editor in chief. He and a team of editors and consultants, from ABC newsman Hugh Downs to science fiction writer Isaac Asimov, were the final judges. ``We weren't searching for the archaeological monuments of the past,'' Adler said. ``These works are still contemporary. What makes them great is that you can't exhaust them. You can read them again and again and still learn something from them.'' Not everyone believes the list is all that great. The volumes include mostly European and a few American authors, said Reginald Gibbons, an English literature professor at Northwestern University. ``I don't see many Latin American and African American authors,'' Gibbons said. ``I think that's very disappointing. It's a good list, but it's not a great list.'' ``If they've only just gotten around to adding the names of Jane Austen and Virginia Woolf,'' he said, ``then they must be taking a terrifically cautious approach to education. I think that's wrong.'' Also dropped from the list: Fourier's ``Analytical Theory of Heat'' and Apollonius of Perga's ``On Conic Sections.'' Prices for the set range from $1,399 to $1,899 depending on the type of binding.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Tokyo Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar surged higher against the Japanese yen today in a reversal of early October's dollar-selling spree and Tokyo share prices fell, ending a seven-day climb. The dollar closed at 128.38 yen, up 1.25 yen from Tuesday's close of 127.13 yen. It opened at 128.10 yen and ranged between 127.75 yen and 128.50 yen. The U.S. currency now has gained 3.98 yen in four trading days, after a 13-day plunge of 13.55 yen. ``Investors had been selling the dollar since early October, and they have started buying it back because they became worried that the U.S. and Japanese monetary authorities never welcomed the weaker dollar,'' said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. ``But as far as economic fundamentals are concerned, nothing has changed,'' Yasuda said, adding that market players remained wary about the U.S. budget and the Middle East. ``The market sentiment was reversed quickly, and I think it's just a temporary phenomenon,'' he said, predicting that the dollar will settle in a 127-131 yen range. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 421.42 points, or 1.67 percent, closing at 24,876.88. Share prices were hurt by the weaker yen and profit-taking after the Nikkei's recent gains from its 1990 low of 20,221 points on Oct. 1, traders said. Over the past three weeks, the Nikkei had gained 25 percent, including a 13 percent gain in the last seven trading days. Investors ``were getting reluctant to buy any more in such a short period of time,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. ``Investors were taking a break.'' Suzuki said the market today also lacked fresh news to stimulate investors' buying interest. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds closed at 84.44 points, down from their 84.81-point close Tuesday. Their yield rose to 7.810 percent from 7.735 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Member of Gorbachev's Council to Quit, Become Ambassador to Luxembourg
DOC.TEXT: A prominent Central Asian writer has become the first person to quit President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advisory council, a move symbolic of frustrations with the stagnation of Soviet reform efforts. Chingiz Aitmatov, a writer from Kirghiz once touted as a candidate for the Nobel prize in literature, confirmed in an interview Tuesday that he is leaving the Presidential Council to become ambassador to Luxembourg. Rumors of Aitmatov's appointment to the diplomatic post had caused a sensation in the Soviet press. The prestigious council, which Gorbachev created this year as an alternative to the Politburo, is one of the most important of the newly established or reformed Soviet political institutions. ``Young people want to be involved in politics, but I really don't care about it,'' said Aitmatov, 62, looking worn and tired during an interview in his office. He said that his appointment to Luxembourg ``has the blessing of the president,'' Gorbachev, and awaits only the agreement of the Luxembourg government. Although he said he ``was not a pessimist,'' he was generally downbeat about the future of the Soviet Union, in keeping with the gloom that has gripped the country with the onset of winter and the apparent failure of what had promised to be a bountiful harvest. Aitmatov dismissed people who say the total collapse of ``the Soviet empire'' would be good. ``It is a sick organism, but a living one,'' he said. ``Fragmentation and disorder inside this organism would not benefit anyone, inside or outside the country.'' Aitmatov said his duties on the Presidential Council included ethnic problems. But otherwise, he declined to shed much light on the inner workings of the council, one of the most important of the newly created or reformed Soviet political institutions. Gorbachev created the council earlier this year as an alternative to the Politburo, the party body that formerly made important national decisions. The list of members reads like a Western-style Cabinet, including the ministers of defense, foreign affairs and interior, the state planning chief and the head of the KGB security police. Aitmatov is one of two novelists on the body, and the only representative from mostly Moslem Central Asia. The other writer is Valentin Rasputin, a leader of the ecological movement from Siberia and a Russian nationalist. The most famous son of Kirghizia, Aitmatov was catapulted to world literary fame in the early 1980s by his play, Ascent of Mount Fuji, and a novel, The Day Lasts More than A Hundred Years, that expressed the frustrations of the Soviet Union before Gorbachev's reforms. This month, Aitmatov published an epilogue to his novel, recounting the suicide of the hero after he is arrested on political charges. Aitmatov's departure from the Presidential Council and the country symbolize new frustrations born of the apparent failure of Gorbachev's reforms to improve living standards or to shake the Communist bureaucracy's grip on power. The Kirghiz legislature is considering a sovereignty resolution, like those approved by nearly all of the 15 Soviet republics including Russia, said Aitmatov. But for the time being, ``we Central Asiass can't leave Russia,'' he said, citing the economic ties that he said now are more important than cultural and religious differences. The four Central Asian republics of Kirghizia, Uzbekistan, Turkmenia and Tadzhikistan are generally more rural and poorer than the rest of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Store Changing Uniform Colors For Fear of Gang Violence
DOC.TEXT: A supermarket chain is getting rid of its red employee uniforms for fear they will be mistaken for gang colors. ``We didn't want to jeopardize anybody,'' said Steve Katzenberger, executive director of retail operations for Colorado's 66 King Soopers stores. The chain's clerks - often minimum-wage teen-agers who must walk home from work through crime-ridden neighborhoods - had first raised the concern. Red is the color of the Bloods. The other major gang in Denver, the Crips, uses blue. Denver police said they knew of no incidents in which workers wearing supermarket uniforms have been hassled by gang members. King Soopers, which has offered red, yellow, tan and white uniforms, will phase out the red garments, including shirts, aprons and caps, Katzenberger said. Supermarket clerks Tuesday said they welcomed the changes. ``You've got to play by the rules of the neighborhood,'' said yellow-shirted clerk Mike Devin at a store in Aurora. Another chain, Albertsons, said it is sticking with red uniforms but getting rid of its blue ones, while Safeway said is switching from red, white and blue to gray. But both chains said the changes had nothing to do with gangs. Employees at a Safeway in Denver expressed concern about wearing blue in Crips territory. ``I take this off before I walk home,'' said Dennis Williams, a clerk in a blue vest. ``There are a lot of Crips hanging around here.'' On Oct. 10, Denver's school system banned gang-related garb, including Los Angeles Raiders caps, modified high-top sneakers and certain haircuts.

DOC.HEAD: Zephania Mothopeng
DOC.TEXT: Zephania Mothopeng, who broke away from the African National Congress to help form South Africa's much more militant Pan Africanist Congress, died Tuesday at age 77. Mothopeng had suffered from cancer and pneumonia. Like African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, Mothopeng spent years in prison for his political activities and was widely recognized in South Africa as a symbol of the black population's struggle against apartheid. But unlike Mandela and other ANC leaders, Mothopeng opposed negotiating with the white-led government. Unhappy with the ANC's efforts to work with non-blacks, he and others formed the Pan Africanist Congress in 1959. He was serving a 15-year sentence on terrorism charges when he was freed three years early in 1988 after being diagnosed with cancer.
DOC.HEAD: Louis Althusser
DOC.TEXT: Louis Althusser, one of Europe's most prominent Marxist philosophers, died Monday at age 72. The cause of death was not disclosed. He was already well known in 1980 when he strangled his wife at the Ecole Normale Superieur, where he taught. He was judged incompetent to stand trial and hospitalized at a psychiatric facility, from which he was released in 1984. Althusser was known for his provocative interpretations of the works of Karl Marx, Sigmund Freud and Mao Tse-tung. His books included ``For Marx,'' published in 1965, and ``Lenin and Philosophy,'' in 1969.
DOC.HEAD: Barney Nagler
DOC.TEXT: Barney Nagler, a sportswriter, TV producer and columnist for The Daily Racing Form, died Monday of a respiratory infection. He was 78. For the past 40 years, Nagler's column, ``On Second Thought,'' had appeared in The Daily Racing Form. He also was a television producer and writer for ABC and NBC, and is credited with naming ABC's ``Wide World of Sports.'' He wrote biographies of jockey Willie Shoemaker and boxer Joe Louis.
DOC.HEAD: Dora Baker Kelley
DOC.TEXT: Dora Baker Kelley, a World War I veteran of the Army Nurse Corps, died Monday at age 102. Mrs. Kelley served in the Corps in 1918-19 before going to work for a hospital in Temple. Later she worked at Veterans Administration hospitals in Detroit and Muskogee, Okla., and at hospitals in Dallas. She retired at 79.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected IRA Bombs Kill Six, Injure 27
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with IRA claim of responsibility. Picks up 10th pvs, `The mainly ...'
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded simultaneously before dawn today at two checkpoints near the Irish border, killing at least six security forces members and injuring 27 people, mostly soldiers, authorities said. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the 4:12 a.m. attacks, the domestic news agency Press Association reported. One person was killed by the bomb detonated a checkpoint at Newry, a village about 40 miles south of Belfast on the main road between Belfast and Dublin. Five were killed in the other blast, which targeted a checkpoint near Londonderry, 65 miles northwest of Belfast. Both posts have been attacked by the IRA several times in the past. Police said that in both cases the bombs were driven to the checkpoints by civilians acting under IRA threat. Police said a 65-year-old man drove a van to the security checkpoint outside Newry, jumped out of the vehicle and shouted: ``There's a bomb in the van!'' Before police, soldiers and the driver had time to get clear, the bomb exploded. The driver suffered a broken leg. Staff at Altnagelvin Hospital treating casualties from the attack near Londonderry said two people were dead on arrival and three other soldiers died at the scene. Six soldiers were admitted, all in serious condition. The hospital said 11 other people had to be treated for shock and minor injuries. Mervyn Ferris, the unit administrator at Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry, said one person was killed in the Newry attack and that 10 other people were being treated at the hospital for cuts, bruises and shock. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. The group wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Soldiers blanketed Newry and the surrounding area in a huge security operation following the attack. Army helicopters flew low overhead and traffic headed for Dublin was diverted. Paddy Collins and his wife, Cara, were awakened by the blast, which shattered windows and blew the doors off hinges at their home about 1,200 feet from the checkpoint. ``There was an awful bang and blue lightening outside. All the windows came in,'' he said, adding that three of the couple's four children were asleep in the house and were covered with shattered glass. ``We were afraid to go out, but we heard soldiers running outside, literally screaming. They were frightened for their lives,'' said Collins.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Mixed in European Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fluctuated in a narrow range in quiet European trading early today. Gold was mixed. A dealer in Frankfurt said there was little reason to expect the dollar to change its current ``directionless'' dealings in the short term. In the long term, dealers expect the U.S. currency to continue its downward trend. ``Selling pressure will be stronger and stronger,'' said Kenji Kawahara, foreign exchange manager in London for Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.25 yen to a closing 128.38 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 128.90 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.5187 German marks, up from 1.5175 -1.2780 Swiss francs, down from 1.2810 -5.0835 French francs, up from 5.0700 -1.7090 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7098 -1,137.50 Italian lire, up from 1,136.50 -1.1703 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1708 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9445, compared with $1.9461 late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $371.10 per ounce at midmorning, down from $371.75 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $371.65, up from $371.40 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 21 cents to close at a bid $371.80. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.26 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's $4.24.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Reports Rise in Death Squad Killings This Year
DOC.TEXT: Army-supported death squads already have killed more people in El Salvador this year than during all of last year, Amnesty International said today. Between January and early August, 45 people were reportedly killed by death squads in the Central American country, compared to 40 in 1989, said the London-based human rights group. Amnesty said killings, torture and ``disappearances'' have continued in El Salvador despite a U.N. Agreement on Human Rights signed July 26 by the government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the guerilla Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ``Bodies of victims have been found mutilated, some with their faces completely destroyed and others with signs of having been brutally tortured. Victims have been shot dead on the streets or in their homes,'' the Amnesty report says. The Nobel Peace Prize-winning group detailed several killings, including an agricultural cooperative member slain Aug. 1 at work, and a union member who was taken from his home by two men in civilian clothes July 23. His body was found the following day. Amnesty said its information on the death squad killings came from former members of the security forces, among other sources.
