Amnesty said its sources and other information ``including testimonies by former members of the military, suggests that those responsible for these actions (death squad killings) are linked to the armed forces.'' AThe report says four apparent death squad killings that occurred in the days following the U.N. accord ``suggest that those responsible are continuing to operate with the confidence that they will not be punished.'' Amnesty said Cristiani's government had acknowledged reform was needed and that the security forces sometimes committed ``excesses.'' But the government has denied involvement. ``However, the extent and nature of the abuses and the fact that human rights violations have been committed with almost total impunity under this and previous government has left little doubt of official complicity,'' Amnesty said. The rights organization said it was also concerned about reports of rights abuses linked to the rebels. The report on El Salvador is based on findings by Amnesty delegates who visited the country in April. The report contains 34 recommendations, including making full investigations into violations; strengthening the office of the Attorney General and ensuring its independence, and protection for judges and witnesses involved in human rights cases. About 72,000 people have been killed in the 11-year-old civil war. The two sides began cease-fire talks in May and are scheduled to meet Nov. 4 in Mexico. After the U.N. agreement, the government spoke out publicly against torture and established rights training courses, Amnesty said. The government revised detention guidelines and established a 24-hour office to provide information on detainees, the report says.

DOC.HEAD: Death-Penalty Expert Charged With Posing as an Engineer
DOC.TEXT: A self-proclaimed expert on the death penalty and builder of execution machines was charged with posing as an engineer after a Jewish group incensed by his views on the Holocaust revealed he held only a history degree. Fred A. Leuchter Jr., 47, was arraigned Tuesday on a charge of fraudulently practicing engineering. He pleaded not guilty and was released on his own recognizance. The offense carries up to 90 days in jail and a $500 fine. Leuchter, a resident of suburban Malden, designs and builds electric chairs, gallows and lethal injection machines for states with the death penalty, including Tennessee, New Jersey, Delaware, Illinois and Missouri. He also has served as a technical adviser to states on executions. Leuchter came under fire after writing a report claiming that gas chambers at some Nazi death camps could not have been used to kill hundreds of thousands. He appeared as a paid expert at the 1988 trial in Toronto of Ernst Zundel, a publisher later convicted of knowingly disseminating false information in booklet questioning whether 6 million Jews perished under the Nazis. The state began investigating Leuchter in April after being contacted by Holocaust Survivors and Friends in Pursuit of Justice, based in Albany, N.Y. The group disclosed that Leuchter held only a bachelor's degree in history from Boston University. In a telephone interview, Leuchter said the state's engineering license requirements are designed to protect the public from poorly constructed buildings and do not apply to his work since it is done out of state. Massachusetts has no death penalty. While admitting he has only a history degree, Leuchter said, ``The bottom line is that anyone who goes to college has the necessary math and science, which I do. I've worked as an engineer for 25 years. I'm not some Johnny-come-lately.'' Shelly Shapiro, the Holocaust group's director, said the group argued that Leuchter is ``dangerous because he gives a scientific front to those who would deny the Holocaust. He provides them with what they think is expertise on gas chambers.'' ``We set out to show that he is no expert on gas chambers and no engineer,'' she said. Leuchter said he was not anti-Semitic, and added, ``Some of my best friends are Jewish.'' Leuchter had also come under fire for his business practices. In July, Alabama Assistant Attorney General Ed Carnes alleged that Leuchter would routinely offer his services as an adviser to states conducting executions. If his offer was spurned, Leuchter would offer to testify on behalf of death penalty foes that the state's execution machines would not work properly, Carnes said. ``What he has done is make money on both sides of the fence,'' said Carnes. Leuchter denied Carnes' charges and said Holocaust groups had pressured states to not do business with him. ``The Jewish groups have effectively put me out of business,'' he said. ``They are doing the same things the Nazis did, interfering with my right to free speech and to earn a living.''

DOC.HEAD: Freak Chain-Reaction Accident Kills Man in S.C.
DOC.TEXT: A train derailed on tracks washed out by floodwaters and knocked down a highway overpass, and two automobiles fell into the gap. One person died. Stormy weather Tuesday also proved perilous to motorists in North Carolina. A road in Randolph County was washed out, leaving a house-size hole into which two vehicles drove. Both drivers were seriously injured. North Carolina had at least two tornadoes and record rain - 4.23 inches in six hours - that swelled rivers to flood stage, the National Weather Service said. No injuries were reported from the twisters. In Orangeburg, S.C., flooding washed out rail supports and caused four coal-filled train cars to derail and hit a highway overpass above the tracks, Highway Department spokesman Sam McCuen said. The bridge collapsed, and two automobiles plunged into the chasm, killing one person and injuring two others, McCuen said. Another highway bridge washed out about five miles away and one car drove through, injuring two people. In Asheboro, N.C., at least 6 inches of rain left a 30-foot-long, 20-foot-deep hole in a road, and two vehicles fell in. One driver was hospitalized in critical condition, the other in serious condition. ``It was scary, very scary,'' said Linda Hicks, co-owner of the wrecking service that towed one of the vehicles out of the pit. ``This was a first for me, and I hope and pray this is the last. It was a bad scene.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls on Northeast; Warm, Clear Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in Maine, New York and Massachusetts early today and clouds covered most of the rest of the East Coast and parts of the South. Sunny skies were forecast across the West and Midwest. Flood warnings were in effect in Pennsylvania, and many rivers and streams overflowed their banks in New York, where rain fell for a third straight day. Highs in the 80s were forecast for Florida, the Southwest and West, with temperatures in the 60s expected in the Pacific Northwest and most of the Midwest. Temperatures in the 50s and 60s were forecast for the Northeast. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 97 degrees at Monrovia, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Impostor Takes Toll on Highway Receipts
DOC.TEXT: A man in a blue toll-taker's uniform cheerfully greeted motorists, made change and wrote receipts on a busy expressway for several hours before co-workers realized he was an impostor. ``He was actually pretty good,'' said Richard Gilkison, who noticed when the stranger showed up bright and early to take 15-cent tolls at the Crosstown Expressway Friday morning. ``He'd collect for an hour or two, then take himself a little break. He looked real professional, waving a flag and everything.'' Crosstown officials are accustomed to vagrants who shove paper or clothing into automatic bins, then run out to collect the blocked change, said toll manager Peter Bond. This man was a bit more open, he said. Instead of jail, police took the impostor to a homeless shelter. They did not publicly identify him. Bond said the average daily take from each booth is about $265, much of which is collected by toll-takers during rush hour. He said he isn't sure how much money was collected during the Friday morning shift. ``It's fascinating that he went to the trouble of wearing the uniform,'' said Laura Blaine, chairwoman of the Tampa-Hillsborough Expressway Authority. ``He could have just asked for a job.''

DOC.HEAD: Lugar Says Conflict Close in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said today ``we are very close to conflict'' in the Persian Gulf and that people should not misinterpret recent developments as indicating peace is at hand. ``The fact is that we're headed toward conflict,'' Lugar, a member and former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said during an interview on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``We're headed toward conflict because Saddam (Hussein) is reinforcing, as far as we can see, his forces in Kuwait, shows no sign whatsoever of giving up anything, and the United Nations is on a collision course to make sure he does give it up,'' Lugar said. He was asked about reports that the Saudi defense minister, Prince Sultan, had raised the possibility Iraq might gain territory in return for ending its occupation of Kuwait. ``I don't think the Saudis are prepared to compromise,'' Lugar said. ``I think the remarks were unfortunate for two reasons. First of all, they gave an impression to world markets that peace was at hand. ... Secondly, it has raised once again questions as to how fragile the coalition of all the forces trying to undergird the United Nations resolutions may be.'' Prince Bandar, the Saudi envoy in Washington, denied his country had suggested that Kuwait make a deal with Iraq. ``I think the possibility of armed conflict depends entirely upon our ability and willingness to bring it about,'' Lugar said. ``I would hope that it would be perfectly clear to Saddam Hussein and to the rest of the world that we are very close to conflict, if the Iraqis don't move they're likely to be pushed out, peace is not at hand, and that people would not misinterpret or try to misinterpret these small signs as they see them,'' Lugar said.

DOC.HEAD: Dummy Hanging from Overpass Causes Fatal Crash
DOC.TEXT: A highway prank proved lethal when a scarecrow dangled from an overpass so frightened a motorist that she swerved to avoid it, and ended up in a ditch. Tracey Ann Pearson, 28, of Clio was driving along Intersaate 69 in Genesee County Monday night when she noticed the hay dummy, which appeared to be standing in the road, Davison Township Police said Tuesday. When Pearson swerved into a ditch, her car rolled over, and she was tossed out and fatally injured, said Officer Donald Brock. The scarecrow had been stolen from the lawn of a house about three miles from the accident site, Brock said. The culprits who hung the scarecrow could face charges of negligent homicide, but no arrests were made Tuesday, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon Tries to Disband Its Militias; Chamoun Buried
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's government spoke with militia leaders today about withdrawing their forces from Beirut under a peace plan aimed at ending the nation's 15-year-old civil war. At the same time, the victims of a slaying that jeopardized the peace process - Christian leader Dany Chamoun, his wife and two small sons - were buried at the family's hometown of Deir Al-Kamar southeast of Beirut. The four were gunned down in their apartment in Beirut's eastern suburb of Baabda on Sunday. No group has claimed responsibility for the killings. Chamoun, 56, the younger son of former President Camille Chamoun, was a staunch ally of defeated rebel. Gen. Michel Aoun. Chamoun's killing came eight days after Syrian and Lebanese troops crushed Aoun's 11-month mutiny in an assault on his tiny enclave. The attack left 550 people dead and more than 1,200 wounded. Aoun took refuge in the French Embassy, where he remains. A government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said efforts to create a militia-free greater Beirut ``are now on the front burner.'' On Tuesday, Syrian Vice President Abdul Halim Khaddam met with Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic, and Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem. Parliament Speaker Hussein Husseini, a Shiite Moslem, also took part in the talks along with the army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud. Syria has 40,000 troops deployed in most of the war-torn nation under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 21-nation Arab League. The government source said a committee handling contacts with militia leaders was instructed after Khaddam's visit to ``work out the mechanism for the militia withdrawal from greater Beirut.'' For years, Christian and Moslem militias have battled for control of the region. The committee, comprised of the agriculture and defense ministers ``informed the militia leaders in telephone contacts that the greater Beirut plan enjoys Syria's unlimited support,'' the source said. ``The committee did not register any serious rejection of the greater Beirut plan.'' Greater Beirut stretches along a 15-mile coastal strip from the Dog River in the north to the Damour River in the south and covers the city's immediate southern and southeastern suburbs. ``The greater Beirut is expected to start taking shape very soon. Maybe as of next week,'' the source said. After his talks in Beirut, Khaddam told reporters that Syria ``will extend all forms of assisstance to help the government assert its authority over lebanon's entire territory.'' Khaddam said he was confident that all Christian and Moslem militias ``will cooperate with efforts to re-establish state authority and restore the reins of power to the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Balkan Meeting Points to Gradual Opening of Albania
DOC.TEXT: A gathering of Balkan foreign ministers that opened today is one more sign that Albania, Europe's most backward country, is gradually cracking out of its Stalinist shell. The two-day meeting is only the second such gathering since World War II, and the first high-level international meeting in Tirana in decades. Albania's government virtually sealed the tiny country for years, but has been seeking slowly to end its isolation. The gathering opened with calls for closer cooperation in the region, which in the past has been a powder keg of Europe. But differences immediately emerged, with Greece taking a swipe at Albania on the treatment of its Greek minority. In his opening speech, Albanian President Ramiz Alia called for a ``zone of peace and security'' in the Balkans: Greece, Turkey, Yugoslavia, Albania, Bulgaria and Romania. The meeting underscored dramatic changes in Europe since the first Balkans meeting in Belgrade, in February 1988. The fall of communism in Eastern Europe has brought new freedoms, but has also made for an upsurge in nationalist feelings - especially in the Balkans, where the mix of of religions and ethnic groups has always been volatile. Yugoslavia, where ethnic divisions are so fierce that the country may split apart, is at odds with Albania over the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, an ancient heartland of the Serbian republic, bordering Albania. Greece and Turkey are traditional enemies, divided today over the fate of Cyprus. Albania and Greece disagree over Albania's alleged mistreatment of its estimated 400,000 Greek minority. Bulgaria and Romania are quarrelling over cross-border pollution. The Serbs in Yugosalvia want more rights for the ethnic Serbs in Romania. And Bulgaria, Greece and Yugoslavia disagree over who really should control the territory known today as the southern Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. Bulgaria's foreign minister, Luben Gotsev, supported by his Greek counterpart Antonis Samaras, proposed forming a secretariat in the Bulgarian capital, Sofia, to coordinate regional cooperation. Gotsev, Samaras, and Romania's foreign minister, Adrian Nastase, all urged measures to overcome the region's ethnic, religious and historical differences. Bulgaria and Romania proposed that a Balkan summit be held next year. Romania urged that a code of conduct on ethnic matters be considered. Samaras, apparently referring to Albania's treatment of its Greek minority, asked the session: ``Can we call a country free if any man or woman in this country is not allowed to exercise fully their religious rights? ... Does this not also apply to political and economic rights?'' In the wake of Eastern Europe's revolutions, Albania has embarked on cautious domestic reform and moved to end its isolation abroad. It restored diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union and is seeking the same links with the United States. The Balkan nation of 3 million people has also declared it wants to join the 34-nation Helsinki process. Albania was the only European nation not to sign the Helsinki Final Act in 1975. To be admitted, Albania is likely to have to take human rights reform further than it has to date. On Tuesday, as diplomats and journalists arrived in Tirana for the Balkan meeting, Albania's Communist-run daily published the draft of an election law that for the first time permits secret ballots and multiple candidacies for each of the 250 seats in the Communist-run Parliament. However, the draft stopped short of permitting any new political parties, and a legal expert indicated Alia does not intend to abandon one-party rule. ``There will be pluralism of opinions,'' Aleks Luarasi told reporters. ``But there won't be any party pluralism.''

DOC.HEAD: Final Arguments in Former Winery Worker's Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor summarizing his case against accused murderer Ramon Salcido portrayed the winery worker as a methodical killer who bandaged his own finger while slashing his victims' throats. Salcido was lucid when he slashed the throats of his three daughters, left them to die at a dump, then pondered killing more of his family, prosecutor Peter Bumerts told the jury in final arguments Tuesday. ``Before he even leaves the dump, he's thinking about his next victims,'' Bumerts told the San Mateo Superior Court jury. Salcido, 29, has admitted killing seven people, including six family members, during the April 1989 wine country rampage. Defense attorney Marteen Miller argued that Salcido was incapacitated by mental problems, drugs and alcohol at the time of the slayings. Miller asked jurors to ``have the courage'' to convict Salcido of less than first-degree murder, which carries the death penalty in circumstances of multiple murder. Second-degree murder carries a basic penalty of 15 years to life, while terms for manslaughter can range from two to 11 years. Bumerts displayed poster-sized color photographs of the shot and stabbed bodies. ``The fact is Angela Salcido was shot in the head and the arm by the defendant,'' Bumerts said as he posted a photo of Salcido's 24-year-old wife, Angela, dead in the couple's Boyes Hot Springs home. Prosecutors have said Salcido was angry at his wife after learning that their first child, who was conceived before they were married, was fathered by another man. Defense witnesses testified that Salcido was an atypical Mexican man who was overwhelmed by financial and legal problems. Bumerts portrayed Salcido as a methodical killer who already had slain five family members by the time he arrived at the Grand Cru Winery to shoot his co-workers on April 14, 1989. He challenged the defense allegation that Salcido was suicidal. ``Here is a man who wants to kill himself, stepping over dead bodies to get to a bandage to bandage his finger ... which he cut while killing people,'' Bumerts said. The trial began Sept. 17 and the jury was scheduled to begin deliberations today following instructions from the judge. Salcido is charged with fatally shooting his wife, Angela, 24, and cutting the throats of their three daughters. Sofia, 4, and Teresa, 22 months, died. Carmina, then 2, survived, telling detectives, ``Daddy cut me.'' Now 4 years old, Carmina has been adopted by a wealthy couple. Salcido also is accused of fatally stabbing his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, and her daughter, Ruth, 12, and cutting the throat of another Richards daughter, Marie, 8, and shooting to death co-worker Tracey Toovey, 35. Salcido also faces two counts of attempted murder for attacks on Carmina, another co-worker, Kenneth Butti, and Butti's wife, Terri.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bomb Attacks Leave Six Dead, One Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE death toll, arrests. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Simultaneous bomb attacks at two security checkpoints in Northern Ireland today killed six soldiers and left a civilian missing and presumed dead, police said. The IRA claimed responsibility. Five men were arrested in the Irish Republic in connection with the predawn attacks, which also injured at least 27 people, six seriously, police said. Police said in both cases, the bombs were driven to the checkpoints by civilians acting under Irish Republican Army threat. One of the drivers, an elderly man, warned the soldiers at a checkpoint, but not in time. The IRA claimed those forced to drive the bombs to the checkpoints were ``collaborators,'' who had done construction work for the security forces. A police spokesman in Dublin said the five men were arrested just across the border from the checkpoint near Londonderry, 65 miles northwest of Belfast, where five of the soldiers were killed and the civilian was reported missing. The other soldier was killed at a security checkpoint in Newry, a village about 40 miles south of Belfast, police said. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was said to be ``deeply shocked'' by the bombings. Hospital officials said the injured included six members of the security forces, all of them seriously hurt. Both checkpoints are on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. The Newry station is located on the main road between Belfast and Dublin. Both posts have been attacked by the IRA several times in the past. The missing civilian at Londonderry was believed to be the driver of the car carrying the bomb, police said. At the Newry checkpoint, police said, a 65-year-old man drove up in a van, jumped out and shouted: ``There's a bomb in the van!'' It exploded before police, soldiers and the driver had time to get clear. The driver suffered a broken leg. Police said both bombs exploded just after 4 a.m. The IRA claim of responsibility came in a statement to the British domestic statement to the British domestic news agency Press Association in Belfast. It warned that attacks would continue until Britain abandoned its ``futile war in Ireland.'' The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. In Dublin, the Republic of Ireland condemned the killings. ``The people who carried out these savage murders stand condemned by the overwhelming majority of people on this Island,'' said Prime Minister Charles Haughey. ``Their actions are futile and serve no purpose other than to bring suffering and tragedy in their wake.'' Soldiers blanketed Newry and the surrounding area in a huge security operation following the attack. Army helicopters flew low overhead and traffic headed for Dublin was diverted. Paddy Collins and his wife, Cara, were awakened by the blast, which shattered windows and blew the doors off hinges at their home about 1,200 feet from the checkpoint. ``There was an awful bang and blue lightening outside. All the windows came in,'' he said, adding that three of the couple's four children were asleep in the house and were covered with shattered glass. ``We were afraid to go out, but we heard soldiers running outside, literally screaming. They were frightened for their lives,'' said Collins.

DOC.HEAD: Toxic Shock From Usually Mild Strep is Rising, Researchers Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 10th graf, `We have...' to add background on how doctors diagnose the syndrome.
DOC.TEXT: A potentially deadly bacterial cousin of toxic shock syndrome is on the rise, targeting both children and adults, scientists say. Researchers at a national microbiology conference said Tuesday the illness is a severe streptococcal infection. Strep is frequently thought of as the cause of strep throat. But in rare cases it can cause extremely serious infections, such as the pneumonia that killed Muppets creator Jim Henson in May. Three years ago, researchers began to talk of toxic shock caused by strep, not the staph bacteria linked to tampon use. Toxic shock is characterized by low blood pressure, rash, peeling skin and multi-organ infections. Researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and in Pima County, Ariz., studied 128 cases of group-A strep infections in 10 hospitals in the Tucson area from 1985 to 1990. None of the 54 cases from 1985 to 1987 resembled toxic shock syndrome. But six of the 74 infections studied from 1988 to 1990 did. The pattern is clear, Dr. Charles Hoge of the CDC reported at the Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: ``Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome was significantly more likely to occur'' after 1988. One of the six patients died; for all the group-A strep infection patients in the study, the death rate was 20 percent. Toxic shock syndrome gets its name from the toxins produced by the bacteria at fault. Lab findings from the Arizona study suggest a toxin may also be the culprit in the serious strep infections, Hoge said. Three of the Arizona toxic shock-like cases occurred in children, and other researchers also reported waves of serious strep infections in youngsters. Doctors at Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., reported that eight of their 29 cases of group-A strep from 1971 to 1990 had symptoms resembling toxic shock syndrome. The hospital has seen four cases this year. ``We have not had four children previously in one year with multi-systemic streptococcal syndrome,'' said Dr. Mary Anne Jackson. ``We're trying to draw the attention of clinicians to this entity ... tell them to think of this.'' Doctors make a diagnosis based on blood tests showing ``group A'' streptococcal bacteria, accompanied by a syndrome of symptoms including low blood pressure and shock; skin rash, flaking or inflamed skin; and the spread of infection to organs such as the kidneys or heart. Doctors at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, reported 16 such cases over 10 years. Strep was once the frequent cause of serious illnesses such as scarlet fever and rheumatic fever, but the most dangerous strains, for the most part, faded from view around the 1940s. Henson was the most famous recent victim of severe streptococcal illness; he died of a rapidly spreading pneumonia. When group-A strep infections proceed to the bloodstream, the fatality rate is 20 percent to 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Props Mistaken for Explosives at Airport
DOC.TEXT: A grenade and shell casings in unclaimed luggage caused quite a stir at Los Angeles International Airport until detectives found they were movie props owned by an actor returning from the East Coast. The Police Department bomb squad was called Tuesday morning to remove three bags said to contain ``live'' explosives and a disassembled rifle. The bags apparently arrived Sunday aboard a United Airlines flight from Washington's Dulles Airport, said airport spokesman Lee Nichols. ``United has had the bags for a couple of days and nobody claimed them,'' Nichols said. When a United employee opened a bag in an attempt to identify the owner, ``ammunition'' and a ``grenade'' were showing. ``An individual who shipped the luggage missed a flight out of Dulles and he didn't arrive until today. He was an actor participating in movie filming on the East Coast,'' Detective Richard Kensic of the Police Department's Criminal Conspiracy Section said Tuesday. Actor Jose Alvarez, 26, of Los Angeles was questioned about the incident and released, said Detective Edward Brimmer. ``He was somewhat shocked by the whole thing. At first he didn't see the significance,'' Brimmer said. ``Then he hit his head and said, `Oh, my God, I had that hand grenade in there, didn't I?''' It isn't unlawful to have such items, the detective said. But it is against the law to represent them as genuine explosives. The discovery immediately raised questions about airline security procedures. ``I can't comment on that,'' United spokeswoman Sara Dornacker said from the airline's Chicago headquarters. ``We use a variety of security measures to make sure contraband doesn't get through,'' she said. The baggage claim area was cordoned off but operations weren't affected, airport official Tom Winfrey said.

DOC.HEAD: Returning British Hostages Tell of Riot, Poor Condition
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Some hostages in Iraq are not given enough food, many are sick and several rioted to protest the conditions, Britons returning home from Iraq said today. One diabetic said he was denied insulin. ``We were in really bad shape,'' Jim Thompson, one of 32 Britons freed Tuesday, told reporters on the flight home from Iraq. Thompson, 50, an engineering company manager, said he was among 15 foreigners held as human shields at an Iraqi armaments factory. President Saddam Hussein has prevented hundreds of Westerners from leaving Iraq or occupied Kuwait since his forces invaded the emirate on Aug. 2, and some detainees are being held at strategic locations to prevent an attack. ``We told the guards, unless you do something ... we are going to have a disturbance,'' Thompson was quoted as saying. He said when nothing was done, they tore down fences, broke windows, daubed anti-Saddam remarks on walls and shouted anti-Saddam slogans until guards forced them back into their rooms at gunpoint. He did not say where the factory was located or when the incident happened. Others told of being moved from site to site as part of Iraq's human shield policy. Syd McCann, 52, said after Iraqi troops stopped him from escaping across the Syrian border, he was held at two strategic locations outside Baghdad. One was a factory making machine parts. The other was a factory he believed was making explosives or chemicals. ``They tended to drive us backwards and forwards,'' he said. London sales executive John York, a diabetic, told the British Broadcasting Corp. in a radio interview: ``The Iraqi authorities would not give me the insulin. I have since found out ... that there is plenty of insulin available in Iraq.'' Doctors on the flight said the sick included people suffering from a variety of illnesses including cancer, heart trouble, diabetes, liver complaints, punctured eardrums, epilepsy and stress. Dr. Ronald Eccles, 42, who was detained in Iraq while on a physiology lecture tour, warned of health problems among those still trapped in Iraq. ``There are a lot of stress-related diseases coming out,'' said Eccles, who suffers from severe arthitis. ``People have been developing heart trouble and diabetes. If they had any medical problems in the past they are flaring up and are made much worse by the ordeal. ``Everybody was getting upset. You start to get angry, but you don't know where to direct it. It's a bit dangerous to start taking it out against the Iraqi soldiers,'' he said. The 32 Britons were released Tuesday after the intervention of former Prime Minister Edward Heath. They arrived in London today. The Foreign Office says some 800 Britons remain in Iraq and another 650 in Kuwait. About 1,000 Americans are in Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Keeps Growing as Pan Am Sells Assets to Stay Alive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 8th, `UAL will also...' to add Paris route. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The parent of United Airlines bought a prized gateway to Europe from cash-strapped Pan Am Corp. Pan Am agreed to sell most of its routes into London to UAL Corp. in a $400 million deal, the airlines announced Tuesday. The agreement accentuated recent moves by both companies, one poised to grow with new routes and planes, the other determined to reduce its huge losses. UAL bought Pan Am's cherished Pacific routes five years ago for $750 million and since has become a key airline in that part of the world. Pan American World Airways pioneered world air travel more than a half-century ago but lost hundreds of millions of dollars during the past decade of heightened competition brought about by airline deregulation. The agreement on the London routes came after fruitless efforts by Pan Am to find a merger partner or buyer for the airline. UAL will acquire Pan Am's routes into London from New York, Washington, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Seattle. UAL will also get unused Pan Am international routes originating in San Francisco, Washington and London, as well as gates, hangar and office space at San Francisco and Washington's Dulles International Airport, two Boeing 747 jumbo jets and spare parts. The agreement will give United a Dulles to Paris route. Pan Am said it will concentrate on one major European hub, Frankfurt, Germany, as well as strengthen schedules to other European cities, including Oslo, Norway; Zagreb, Yugoslavia; Hamburg and Nuremberg, Germany, and Amsterdam.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Strike For Higher Minimum Wage; Two Dead, 17 Vehicles Burned
LaserPhoto MLA5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with lower death toll, government spokesman rejecting wage demand, restrictions at U.S. air base, 43 arrests. No pickup. ^By CLARO CORTES
DOC.TEXT: Leftist unions staged a nationwide strike today, paralyzing public transportation and many businesses. The military denounced the action as a Communist bid to foment insurrection. Suspected Communist rebels burned at least 17 vehicles to force drivers to join the strike, and police said at least two people were slain and four injured in strike-related violence. Police said earlier today that two other people had died in a bus attack but later said that report was mistaken. At least 43 people were arrested, including Medardo Roda, leader of a militant transport union. Police said Roda may be charged with sedition and other offenses linked to the violence. Crispin Beltran, chairman of the militant May First Movement that called the strike, went into hiding following reports he would also be arrested. The strike crippled public transportation in Manila and several provincial cities. Department stores, banks, hotels, factories and other major enterprises closed or operated with skeletal crews. It was unclear whether most absentees supported the strike or simply were unable to get rides to work. The May First Movement was demanding a $1.50 raise in the minimum daily wage - a 42 percent increase. Officially the minimum daily wage in Manila is $3.50, but a recent government survey shows 55 percent of businesses in the capital pay less. Minimum wage-earners already are too poor to buy meat, and inflation is running at 12 percent. President Corazon Aquino had urged workers not to join the strike, saying the nation's fragile economy could not afford the wage increase. ``We are not giving in to the 38-peso demand,'' a government spokesman, Adolf Azcuna, said. Speaking in a radio interview from his hiding place, Beltran said the work stoppage would continue Thursday if the workers' demands were not met. The nationwide strike, the most extensive since 1987, also marked the first time the Communists had taken such an active, visible role in a labor protest. The chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, denounced the strike as Communist-dominated and said the violence was the work of guerrillas of the Communist New Peoples Army. ``The (rebels) have decided to use this strike to promote their insurrectionary situation,'' de Villa told reporters. Leftist leader Nathaniel Santiago blamed the government for today's unrest. ``This anger of our society is a natural reaction to the government's turning its back on the people and a realization that it is futile to deal with a government that is numb to the suffering of its people,'' Santiago said. The strike appeared most successful in the capital and surrounding areas of central Luzon island, a longtime Communist stronghold. Officials said about 20 percent of the Labor Department employees did not show up for work, and most government agencies allowed employees to leave early. Among the firms shut down was Atlas Consolidated Mining Co. in Cebu, the largest copper producer in Asia, where 10,000 workers walked out. Schools and colleges in Manila and surrounding provinces were also closed. Authorities at the U.S. Clark Air Base in Angeles City north of Manila imposed travel restrictions on base personnel for security reasons.

DOC.HEAD: No Foreign Concessions at Yosemite, Park Service Chief Urges
DOC.TEXT: The National Park Service director has urged the chief of MCA Inc. to sell its food and lodging concession in Yosemite National Park before MCA is acquired by a Japanese company. Park Service Director James Ridenour told MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman that many park lovers are concerned that a takeover of MCA by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. would put the concession in foreign hands. Ridenour suggested in a telephone call last week that MCA sell the concession to a non-profit or other group or to the Park Service itself, the Los Angeles Times reported in today's editions. ``If the price is right, the government would be interested,'' said Park Service spokesman George Berklacy. MCA owns the Yosemite Park & Curry Co., which operates lodgings, restaurants and stores in Yosemite under a contract that expires in 1993. Early today, three of the four roads into Yosemite were closed by rockslides after a strong earthquake. Matsushita and MCA are negotiating a possible purchase of MCA, which also owns Universal Studios, record companies, a film library and a television station. ``What is driving this is these national parks are America's national treasures, and while foreign owners have the right to invest in the United States, that doesn't mean they should be buying up all of America,'' said Steven Goldstein, spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, who presides over the National Park Service. ``People identify Yosemite ... with mom and apple pie,'' Goldstein said. Wasserman did not react immediately to the proposal, Goldstein said. Officials with Matsushita, MCA and the Curry Co. refused to comment on the proposal. Estimates of Curry Co. holdings in the park range between $100 million and $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Claims Petroglyphs His Own Work
DOC.TEXT: The government was so excited by rock carvings found in a national forest that it started building an interpretive center to explain to visitors how ancient people carved them as messages to spirits. But when artist Jeff Kerker saw a magazine story about the petroglyphs, he sent a message of his own to the U.S. Forest Service: The carvings were his handiwork, and were only 15 years old. ``I wasn't trying to fool anyone,'' said Kerker, of Bandon. ``I was interested in how long it might take to make them. All it took was one afternoon.'' Kerker said he had photos of the carvings in the Siskiyou National Forest to prove he made them. The Forest Service was waiting to see Kerker's evidence before deciding whether his story was true. But enough of a question was raised that work was suspended on the interpretive center being built at Daphne Grove outside Powers, said spokeswoman Patty Burel. ``There is the off chance we never will be able to tell, since there is no exact science for dating petroglyph art like this,'' she said. ``Right now everything is on hold.'' The carvings were discovered in 1987 on three boulders along the South Fork of the Coquille River, Burel said. One represented a fish, but the others weren't clear. The carvings were taken to a Forest Service office for preservation, and replicas were carved for the interpretive center. A variety of archaeologists inside and outside the Forest Service examined the carvings and decided they were genuine, Burel said. One reason was that the carvings had been eroded, and another was that they were below the river's high water mark. ``That was important, because the petroglyphs were considered to have spirits,'' said Janet Joyer, archaeologist for the Siskiyou National Forest. ``When the water rose, then the petroglyphs would be under water. They were thought to transmit the people's prayers down to the salmon people. ``The salmon people lived underwater in human form. When they were requested by human beings, they took on fish forms and sacrificed themselves.'' Kerker said he had figured the water would erode the carvings from the soft stone and never thought anyone would discover them. Joyer said the development carries a good lesson. ``This will be important for archaeologists, a reminder that we must be conservative with things like this that are not dateable,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Dole To Become First Bush Cabinet Member to Depart
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts graf 4, When Bush, to note Dole's absence from Cabinet meeting.
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, praised for easing hostilities between the union movement and Republicans during her nearly two years in office, is resigning to head the American Red Cross, officials say. Mrs. Dole, the only women to head a department in the Bush administration, will be the first member of the president's Cabinet to quit when she makes the announcement, expected today. On Tuesday, President Bush appeared to confirm her departure, first reported by administration and congressional sources. Asked at a Republican fund-raiser in Connecticut if Mrs. Dole had resigned, he replied only, ``tomorrow.'' When Bush met with his Cabinet today at the White House, the labor secretary was not there. Mrs. Dole, 54, called AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland on Tuesday afternoon and told him she was stepping down to become president of the Red Cross, said Ken Young, Kirkland's top aide. ``Lane told her he was sorry that she was leaving and he had enjoyed working with her and that he thought she'd done a good job,'' Young said. ``She worked with us, she was accessible and she clearly told her various departments to work with us and others.'' At the Labor Department, Mrs. Dole worked to strengthen job safety programs and toughen enforcement of child labor laws. She was also praised for her efforts to settle the bitter Pittston coal strike in 1989. But others criticized her ``low profile'' within the administration and complained that she was not a part of the White House policymaking process. For instance, White House chief of staff John Sununu, not Mrs. Dole, took the lead on last year's minimum wage negotiations with Congress, labor officials complained. There was no explanation for her reported decision to take the Red Cross job, which pays $185,000 a year. Cabinet secretaries make $98,400. Even before the official announcement, there was speculation about a successor. Among those mentioned were Constance Newman, head of the Office of Personnel Management, and Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., should she lose her bid for the Senate in the Nov. 6 election. Mrs. Dole, wife of Senate Republican leader Bob Dole, won praise from union leaders who had been rendered outcasts in the Reagan administration. ``It's a genuine loss to the Bush administration and to working people across the country,'' said Janice Lachance, a spokeswoman for the American Federation of Government Employees. ``It will be very, very difficult to replace her.'' ``She was very committed to her open-door policy'' toward organized labor, Lachance said. John Peterpaul, vice president of the Machinists union, offered a different view. ``I don't think she'll be missed by the workers of America,'' he said. ``She's been so low profile.'' He expressed bitterness about Mrs. Dole's handling of the Eastern Airlines strike that started in March 1989, when the administration refused to appoint a presidential emergency board to intervene in the crisis. As labor secretary, Mrs. Dole offered few new initiatives. Some union leaders argued that she was limited by what they perceived as a pro-business administration. Still, she was credited with strengthening programs that unions felt went neglected during the Reagan era. In addition to her work on job safety and child labor laws, she proposed mandatory seat belt use for all job-related travel and reviewed ways to help women advance in their careers and crack what she called the ``glass ceiling'' that stopped their upward mobility. Mrs. Dole got mixed reviews regarding labor disputes. She and Bush took a hands-off approach toward the Eastern strike and the violent Greyhound bus walkout earlier this year. But she was lauded for her appointment of a ``super mediator'' to settle a bitter strike by Appalachian coal miners against the Pittston Co. For months, rumors had been rampant that Mrs. Dole would step down to seek political office. Some observers speculated that she would run in 1992 for the Senate seat now held by Democrat Terry Sanford of her native North Carolina. In an interview less than two months ago, Mrs. Dole indicated she was not yet ready to change jobs. ``I have plenty of challenges right where I am,'' she said. Her departure will leave U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who also holds Cabinet rank, as the top-ranking woman in the administration. Mrs. Dole's inclusion in the Cabinet was seen as an effort on Bush's part to mend fences with her husband, a bitter and unsuccessful Bush opponent during the 1988 presidential primaries. Mrs. Dole got her first Cabinet post in 1983, when President Reagan appointed her transportation secretary. She resigned that Cabinet job to work in her husband's 1988 presidential campaign. A Harvard-educated lawyer, Mrs. Dole has had a Washington career that spans more than two decades. She worked in the old Department of Health, Education and Welfare, the Federal Trade Commission and President Nixon's Commission on Consumer Interests.

DOC.HEAD: Light Turnout in Polling Seen as Referendum on Bhutto's Ouster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 20 grafs to UPDATE death toll, more on turnout, CORRECTS number of seats at stake. Pickup 18th graf pvs, `Ms. Bhutto's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LAR1, ISL1, NY6
DOC.TEXT: Pakistanis turned out in unexpectedly small numbers today for a bitterly contested national election widely considered a referendum on the dismissal of Benazir Bhutto as prime minister. At least four people were killed and 11 injured in disputes involving rival parties, officials said, and there were scattered reports of voter harassment, intimidation and ballot-box theft. The month-long campaign claimed at least a dozen lives. Tens of thousands of heavily armed soldiers, paramilitary troops and police patrolled throughout the country during the voting. Today's general elections were only the fifth in Pakistan since its 1947 inception, and never before was the military deployed in such large numbers during polling. About 50 million people were eligible to vote, but election officias said turnout was light, perhaps reflecting cynicism about the future of democracy in Pakistan. Ms. Bhutto claims her Aug. 6 dismissal amounted to a ``constitutional coup'' by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, and that abuse of power charges filed against her are baseless slander. After casting her own vote in her ancestral hometown at Larkana in southern Pakistan, the former prime minister predicted victory for her party. ``We have turned the tables on them,'' said Ms. Bhutto, who was unopposed in her bid for re-election to parliament. ``If we win, they will have no choice but to let us form the next government.'' Analysts predicted the vote would be close between Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning Pakistan People's Party and three smaller allied parties and the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 parties united only by their dislike for Ms. Bhutto and strained by individual ambitions. Voters in Ms. Bhutto's hometown of Karachi lined up outside polling booths three hours before they opened. The longest lines were in the sprawling slum district of Lyari, where Ms. Bhutto's jailed husband, Asif Ali Zardari, 38, is a candidate. Lines also formed in parts of the eastern city f Lahore, the longtime stronghold of Ms. Bhutto's opponents. But at polling stations elsewhere, officials reported turnouts ranging from 10 to 40 percent during the nine hours of voting. No overall figures on the turnout were immediately available. The government, which is controlled by Ms. Bhutto's foes, filed a seventh abuse of power charge against her just hours before the polls opened today. But the campaign to destroy the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto politically may have backfired. It halted the steady decline in her popularity and helped galvanize the disgruntled rank-and-file within her party. Just hours before the polls opened a candidate of Ms. Bhutto's right-wing opposition was gunned down along with five companions, news reports said. Earlier this week, several of Ms. Bhutto's party workers were killed. Police refused to link the latest killing to the elections, but the prime minister in the army backed caretaker government, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, suggested that Ms. Bhutto's party loyalists were involved. The victim was contesting a rural seat in Punjab province, where 60 percent of the country's 102 million people live and where the outcome is expected to be decided. He and his companions were killed by gunmen who fired on their vehicle during an 11th-hour tour of his constituency. In addition to charging Ms. Bhutto and seven former Cabinet ministers with abuse of power, the caretaker government had her husband arrested on Oct. 10 for the alleged kidnapping and extortion of a Pakistani-born British citizen. More than 1,300 candidates are vying for 214 of the 217 seats in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that will choose Pakistan's next prime minister. Two independent candidates were elected unopposed, while voting was postponed in one constituency because one of the candidates was shot and killed. Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning Pakistan People's Party and three smaller parties faced the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 diverse parties united only by their dislike for Ms. Bhutto. In a nation with a literacy rate of less than 25 percent, voters placed their thumbprint next to their party's symbol. Ms. Bhutto's symbol is the arrow; the Islamic Democratic Alliance uses the bicycle. Most analysts doubted either side would emerge with an outright victory, resulting in another shaky coalition government as fragile as the last. Whoever forms the next government will be forced by the constitution to share power with the president and the country's most powerful institution - the military. At least 55 international poll-watchers monitored today's balloting, and their assessment could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in vital economic and military aid from the West. In December 1988, Ms. Bhutto became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. Her accession to power followed the first free elections in Pakistan after more than a decade of military rule. But Ms. Bhutto's stewardship was troubled, and Ishaq Khan called her government Pakistan's most corrupt and incompetent ever when he dismissed her. If found guilty on the abuse of power charges, Ms. Bhutto could be denied her seat in Parliament and banned from politics for seven years. She has insisted her government was competent and clean and called the president a liar, cheater and dictator. She said she would demand his resignation if she returns to power. Ishaq Khan, 73, was a stalwart of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who overthrew Ms. Bhutto's father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, in a 1977 coup. Zia ruled Pakistan until his death in a still-unexplained plane crash in August 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Rioting, Police Fire Kill 18; Political Crisis Continues
DOC.TEXT: At least 18 people were killed today in riots and by police nationwide during a strike called by a right-wing Hindu party that is trying to bring down Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government. Singh said he will prove on Nov. 7 that he can muster a majority in Parliament despite the defection of the Bharatiya Janata Party. Whether he can do so is questionable. India could soon face new elections. The government called a special one-day session of Parliament on Nov. 7. The reports of violence during today's strike came mostly from small cities and towns in western and southern India where both Hindus and Moslems live. The violence and the political crisis were precipitated when Lal Krishna Advani, president of Bharatiya Janata Party, was arrested at sunrise Tuesday while leading a cross-country caravan to build a Hindu temple on ground now occupied by a 16th-century Moslem mosque. Five people died Tuesday night in riots in the western state of Gujarat and police shot to death one person today in Ahmedabad, the state's largest city. Another nine people were killed today in riots and clashes between police and Hindu demonstrators in Jaipur, capital of Rajasthan state that lies between Gujarat and New Delhi, United News of India reported. One man was stabbed to death and three others died in clashes and police firing in the southern state of Karnataka, Press Trust of India said without elaborating. It said two people were killed in police firing in West Bengal state. United News of India said two people were killed in police firing in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The news agency described the clashes as ``communal violence,'' a phrase that usually means Hindu-Moslem clashes. Indian news media routinely avoid giving specific details in such cases, contending that religious tension would only be heightened. Clashes, stone-throwing and arson also were reported in Bombay and other major towns. In New Delhi, many stores were closed and the city government pulled its 4,000 buses off the streets. Police stepped up patrols and reported making more than 400 ``preventive arrests.'' Such arrests are common in India where the law permits people to be held without charge if the authorities believe public safety is in danger. News reports say as many as 50,000 people have been detained in the last two weeks in potential trouble spots. Singh, who took office nearly 11 months ago, told reporters he would try to prove he has the parliamentary majority he needs to remain in power. In the past, his centrist National Front relied on the support of the Bharatiya Janata Party to pass legislation. The prime minister said President Ramaswamy Venkataraman had agreed to call Parliament into session ``within a week after Oct. 30.'' Oct. 30 is the date set by Hindu holy men and political leaders to start constructing the temple on the site now occupied by a mosque in Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. The Ayodhya temple campaign has triggered violence that left more than 80 people dead in Hindu-Moslem clashes earlier this month. Singh sought to resolve the mosque-temple dispute in court, but Hindu fundamentalists pressed ahead with plans to start building the temple. Advani ignored Singh's pleas to call off his temple campaign. A few hours after he was arrested, his party withdrew its support for Singh's government. The Bharatiya Janata Party, or Indian People's Party, proclaims itself to be a nationalist organization that cannot deny the ``Hindu nature'' of India. Eighty-two percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus. Moslems, who make up 12 percent of the population, fear the destruction or relocation of the Ayodhya mosque would have a snowball effect on hundreds of other Moslem sites across the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Set for Northrop's Challenge to Stealth Brand Name on Condom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT typo in Northrop.
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. is trying to shoot down a trademark for a red-white-and-blue contraceptive marketed as the Stealth Condom and sold in a black cardboard package modeled after the B-2 bomber. The manufacturer of the radar-eluding Stealth bomber asked the U.S. Patent and Trademark office in Washington, D.C., last July to refuse the product trademark registration. The trademark board has scheduled a hearing Nov. 15 for condom seller John Hughes, 28, to respond to Northrop's objection. The military contractor claims the Stealth Condom name ``may falsely suggest a connection with'' or ``bring ... disrepute'' to Northrop. Hughes says he thinks it unlikely anybody would confuse his product with an $800 million bomber.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Kill Two Guerrillas in Lebanon Raid
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops struck unusually deep into southern Lebanon early today, killing at least two Arab guerrillas, the army said. No Israeli troops were hurt, the army said. The predawn raid was into the heart of territory controlled by the fundamentalist Shiite militia Hezbollah, or Party of God, near the village of Hunah, 15 miles north of the Israeli border, the army said. ``The terrorists were armed and belonged to the Hezbollah,'' said a spokesman, who remained anonymous according to regulations. Israel radio said the forces, from the elite paratrooper brigade, fired immediately upon encountering the guerrillas at a short range. The radio report said two or three more guerrillas were wounded. Lebanese police said the two Hezbollah guerrillas were killed in a fight with the Israeli-allied South Lebanon Army militia. Police said Hezbollah responded by firing rockets inside Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon. Israeli troops usually confine their activities to the ``security zone,'' which it jointly patrols with the 2,500 members of the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army militia. Israel maintains the 2- to 10-mile-wide buffer zone in Lebanon to protect its northern border from guerrilla raids. Israeli troops have killed 78 guerrillas in southern Lebanon since January, the radio said. Guerrilla activity in southern Lebanon has increased, with guerrillas trying to infiltrate Israel earlier this week and firing Katyusha rockets on northern settlements Oct. 16. The incidents caused no injuries or damage, Israeli authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Seeks 35,000 Volunteers To Combat Yearly Arson Spree
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ze'ev in 9th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Coleman Young says he will mobilize 35,000 volunteers and thousands of city workers to fight the annual Devil's Night arson spree that in the past has left hundreds of buildings charred. The 1990 anti-Devil's Night campaign, unveiled Tuesday, will concentrate on three areas identified as ``hot spots'' that traditionally experience the most fires. Devil's Night is Oct. 30, the night before Halloween. Last year there were 223 fires during the three-day period that began two nights before Halloween. Investigations last year led to nine arrests and prosecutions, Fire Marshal Donald Robinson said. The number of fires was down considerably from the mid-1980s. Department of Public Works crews have demolished about 600 vacant and abandoned houses in the hot spot areas in recent weeks and are continuing to take them down. Abandoned cars throughout the city are being removed. The city is imposing curfews, offering rewards for information leading to arrest and conviction of arsonists and mobilizing the volunteers with the help of 3,500 block clubs to keep an eye out for arsonists. Young said the city also was playing down the name Devil's Night in hopes of discouraging would-be fire bugs. ``We're attempting to come up with a more positive image for the city,'' the mayor said. ``It's obvious that Devil's Night has a bad connotation. It always has. Then some guy writes a book about it and it becomes worse.'' The blazes surrounding Devil's Night have become a topic in the controversial book ``Devil's Night and Other True Tales of Detroit'' by Israeli author Ze'ev Chafets. The book offers a critical look at the predominantly black, economically depressed city of 1 million and its frayed relations with the largely white suburbs. Metropolitan Detroit has more than 4 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole today became the first member of President Bush's Cabinet to resign, leaving after two years to become head of the American Red Cross. Mrs. Dole's departure was announced by President Bush, who said she had ``earned the respect of the American people and as secretary of Labor has made the work place safer, healthier and more secure.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Vaccinating Soon-to-Be Moms Beneficial to Infants
DOC.TEXT: Vaccinating pregnant women for flu helps protect their babies from the disease after birth, is safe and could point the way to other such vaccines, according to Baylor medical school researchers. Thirteen women in a Baylor College of Medicine study were immunized against flu in the last trimester of pregnancy, and each gave birth to an infant with high levels of antibodies to the influenza virus, Dr. Janet Englund reported Tuesday in Atlanta at the Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy. The conference is sponsored by the American Society for Microbiology. None of the mothers or infants had complications from the vaccine, and while flu antibodies produced by the mother's body were imparted to children in the womb, there was no evidence that the vaccine itself reached the fetus, Englund said. ``Maternal immunization to protect the infant during the first months of life appears to be safe and feasible,'' Englund reported. Maternal immunizations were performed by some physicians in the 1960s, but fell out of favor amid concerns over complications. Baylor researchers said their study shows protection can be safely passed along in the womb, without passing along vaccine that isn't necessarily appropriate in the fetus. Researchers believe flu immunity passed from a mother to child lasts about four months, providing crucial protection in the earliest stages of life, Englund said. ``This is a model for other vaccines,'' she said, adding that vaccines against whooping cough and Haemophilus influenza B - Hib disease, a leading cause of meningitis - might be used similarly. Those diseases kill large numbers of infants in developing countries. ``We'd like this to be a Third World shot - one that could be used to help the mother and the baby,'' she said. Influenza vaccine is already recommended for pregnant women at high-risk of severe flu complications. Vaccines made with live viruses, such as measles vaccine, should not be given to pregnant women, according to federal health officials. The researchers gave a different vaccine - tetanus - to other pregnant women in a control group; their infants showed signs of tetanus protection.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Confined To West Bank, Gaza After Revenge Attacks
LaserPhotos NY7,11
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with death of Palestinian wounded Oct. 8 on Temple Mount, death of another Arab in Tuesday's revenge attacks. No pickup. ^By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops sealed the borders of the occupied territories today in an effort to curb a wave of bloody revenge attacks by Arabs and Jews. An order from Defense Minister Moshe Arens banned the nearly 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip from entering Israel after attacks on Tuesday left two Arabs dead and seven people wounded. In Jerusalem, tensions over the killings of Palestinians on the Temple Mount on Oct. 8 increased with the death today of a 20th Arab victim. Police sources and family members said Salim Ahmad Khaldi, 18, was apparently shot by an Israeli civilian on a street near the holy site during the melee. Most of the other victims were killed when police charged the shrine, which is holy to both Arabs and Jews. Hospital officials said another Arab also died today of beating wounds suffered at the hands of Israelis after he stabbed two women soldiers on Tuesday in northern Israel. A general strike was called in Arab east Jerusalem, and uprising activists ordered merchants in the main Arab shopping streets and the narrow alleys of the Old City to close. In an interview on army radio, Arens denied that confining Palestinians to the territories amounted to returning to the 1967 border before Israel captured the land. ``We have to take the correct steps to ensure our control over this country and the safety of the citizens,'' Arens said. He said he hoped Palestinians would realize ``that persisting in these violent attacks will only increase the tragedy of the Palestinian people.'' Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh said the order would ``last for several days'' and should not seriously affect the troubled Israeli economy. About 110,000 Palestinians work in Israel, and Israel radio said Jerusalem employment agencies got 20 times the usual number of calls for construction workers, cleaners and other jobs filled by Arabs from the territories. At the Erez crossing into the Gaza Strip, thousands of Palestinians arrived today in private cars, taxis and buses. Many carried suitcases or makeshift bundles as they were loaded into buses and trucks to go home. Israel radio said at least 600 Israelis in Tel Aviv called police to report the whereabouts of Arab laborers who had stayed behind despite the order. Fear of Palestinian attacks has gripped many Israelis, and the daily Maariv published a guide today on how to defend against a knife-wielding attacker. Interior Ministry officials also reported brisk trade at Israeli gun shops. Just hours before the closure order on Tuesday, Israeli civilians fired on an Arab-owned car near the southern Negev town of Mivtahim, killing Maher al-Shaher, 30, a Gaza laborer, and wounding his three cousins, one seriously. The army said the incident was being investigated by police. Responsibility for the attack was claimed by a previously unknown underground group, ``Eye for an Eye,'' in phone calls to Israel Television and radio. The laborers, who were returning from work in Israel, said they saw a civilian firing an Israeli-made Uzi submachine gun at them from a Jeep, Israel's news agency Itim said. Earlier Tuesday, a Palestinian knifed two unarmed women soldiers and another Arab bludgeoned two Israelis with a hammer, police said. The knifing occured in Kiryat Tivon in northern Israel, when Omar Shawaneh, 39, of the West Bank village of Silat el-Harithiya shouted ``Allahu Akbar'' (God is great), then stabbed two women soldiers who were hitchhiking. Police said Shawaneh was captured by a group of soldiers and civilians and witnesses said he was severely beaten. He died today of head injuries at Rambam Hospital in Haifa, officials said. One of the soldiers, Naama Yekutiel, a youth instructor, was in serious condition today withy a chest wound that punctured a lung. Also Tuesday, in the southern coastal city of Ashkelon, an Arab machine shop worker wielding an 11-pound hammer battered his Israeli employer and a neighbor, police said. Both were hospitalized and the 23-year-old Palestinian, who claimed to be avenging a friend killed in Gaza, was arrested, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Belgium Says Will Assist African Force in Rwanda
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda today announced a cease-fire with rebels seeking to topple its government, the Belgian foreign minister said. Belgium promised to support an African force to monitor the truce. Hundreds of civilians have been killed in the fighting that started Sept. 30 when rebels, predominantly refugees from Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe, invaded from its northern neighbor, Uganda. Belgium's foreign minister, Mark Eyskens, said he was told the cease-fire began this morning but there were reports that the rebels had violated it. Eyskens told a news conference in Nairobi that he learned of the truce in a telephone call from his Rwandan counterpart, Casimir Bizimungu. Rwanda, in agreeing to the cease-fire, accepted the rebel demand that both sides maintain their positions while officials pursue a negotiated end to the conflict, Eyskens said. The rebel Rwandese Patriotic Front has said its fighters cannot withdraw from the country because Uganda has refused to allow their return. Belgium, Rwanda's former colonial ruler, has been leading international efforts to settle the conflict peacefully. Eyskens was joined at the news conference by Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and Defense Minister Guy Coeme. Soon after the rebel invasion, Belgium sent several hundred troops to Rwanda to protect its nationals and embassy, but it has insisted the monitoring force be made up of Africans. ``We think it is the responsibility of the Africans and the Organization of African Unity should play a major role,'' said Eyskens, adding Belgium would provide logistical and financial support to the force. He would not disclose the size of the proposed force or say how much money the Belgium force would cost. France also sent troops to protect its citizens and embassy in the tiny central African country, while Zaire sent up to 1,000 soldiers, who have been fighting alongside the Rwandan army. The rebels have insisted the foreign troops must leave Rwanda before they would open peace talks. They also have demanded Rwandan troops stop killing civilians and the government release thousands of people arrested for allegedly supporting the insurgency. It was not immediately known if the rebels were standing by those conditions. Uganda's president, Yoweri Museveni, on Monday announced the rebels had told him they were ready to accept a truce.

DOC.HEAD: Big Loser is Big Winner in Guinness Book
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Retransmitting to correct cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: A man who lost almost 700 pounds and the holder of a record number of records were among the winners who joined to promote the newest edition of the Guinness Book of Records. The 1991 U.S. edition of the book lists U.S. records along with world records for the first time. The record-holders gathered Tuesday at the Guinness World of Records, a museum, to promote the book. Michael Hebranko, 37, is listed in the ``Super Heavyweights'' category for reducing from 905 pounds to 215 pounds. He's shooting for 180 pounds. The 6-foot New York man said he lost the weight through surgery, severe dieting and with help from exercise guru Richard Simmons. ``Taking off the 700 pounds was easy - keeping it off is the killer,'' Hebranko said. ``It's not like balancing 200 cigar boxes and then it's over.'' Bruce Block, of St. Joseph, Mich., balanced a world-record 212 cigar boxes on his chin for 13.5 seconds at Rock Island, Ill., in February. The boxes, without stogies, weighed 90-some pounds. On Tuesday, just for fun, Block hoisted 102 boxes. The ceiling at the museum wasn't high enough for 212. Ashrita Furman, who holds a record 25 records, bounced on a pogo stick and juggled three rubber balls. For an encore, he yodeled while walking on his hands. Furman's feats include pogoing up Mount Fuji, riding a rowing machine with wheels attached, balancing a milk bottle on his head and ``joggling,'' jogging and juggling at the same time. ``I do this as a challenge for myself,'' he said. ``I'm always looking for something new.'' Also on hand to promote the 1991 edition was Donald H. Burns, the town crier of St. Georges, Bermuda, who set a world record on Jan. 18, 1989, by shouting at 119 decibels. ``GOD SAVE THE QUEEN!'' bellowed Burns, who wore knickers and a maroon cape and respectfully held his hat over his heart. ``GOD BLESS AMERICA!''

DOC.HEAD: Entire State Urged To Pause for `Moment' Against Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of business and political leaders wants Connecticut residents to stop what they're doing for five minutes Thursday morning to think about drug abuse. The group, called Drugs Don't Work, has organized ``The Moment of Consciousness,'' to last from 10:55 a.m. to 11 a.m. It's being promoted with radio, television and newspaper public service announcements across the state. ``For five minutes, businesses will stop ... schools will stop ... TV and radio programming will be interrupted,'' the television ads say. ``We're asking you to do one more thing in your life to fight substance abuse.'' Donald Streater, a recovered heroin addict who once worked on the U.S. House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said a pause is a good symbol of drug abuse. ``It would seem to dramatize what happens when one takes drugs - everything stops and nothing gets done,'' he said. The event coincides with a nationwide effort in which anti-drug organizations are asking people to wear red ribbons this week. But William Kauffman, president of Drugs Don't Work, said the Connecticut effort is unique. ``We don't know of anyone in the nation who has tried to stop a state - or at least make it pause,'' Kauffman said. More than 1,300 schools and businesses have agreed to participate, representing more than 400,000 of the state's 3.3 million residents, organizers said. In Bethel, town officials have proclaimed ``The Moment of Consciousness Day'' and plan to ring church bells and turn on the lights of town vehicles. At an Allstate Insurance office in Farmington, more than 100 workers plan an anti-drug rally. William Olds, executive director of the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, criticized the effort for not placing enough emphasis on treatment and on fighting abuse of legal drugs like alcohol and tobacco. ``I think some people would argue there are better ways to influence the public,'' Olds said. ``But I can't think of an alternative.'' Programming on Connecticut television stations will be replaced by a pre-recorded message from ABC anchorman Peter Jennings during the moment. The message will include toll-free numbers viewers can call to register their commitment to fighting substance abuse or get information about drug treatment.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the best.
DOC.TEXT: Oct. 19 Albany (Ore.) Democrat-Herald on Social Security: The government is in deep money trouble and the economy is headed for the basement. So what does the United States do? It raises the payments it makes to 40 million people getting Social Security checks, whether they need the extra cash or not. The boost in benefits was automatic. At 5.4 percent, it's the biggest in more than eight years. The increase is determined by the rate of inflation. The worse inflation gets, the bigger the increase. That's good for those getting checks. It's bad for those paying the bill. Social Security already takes more than 15 percent of the pay of working Americans. Many people getting Social Security checks are well off and don't need the money. But of course they take it. They're entitled to it by law. They paid into the system when they were working, and now they're entitled to whatever they get, whether they need it or not. While this is going on, our government is trying to decide on how much more each of us gets to pay in taxes to cover the uncontrolled spending of the federal government. There's something perverse about a government that wants to raise taxes when it already takes from the earnings of struggling young people so that it can give more money to everyone over 65, even those whose hefty incomes allow them to enjoy their senior years without money worries at all. --- Oct. 17 The Rapid City (S.D.) Journal on the free market: Capitalism is a great tool for human progress, but Germany is proving that the free market is too free. German companies have been prime contributors to Iraq's military complex, including its abilities to manufacture and deliver chemical weapons and its progress toward building nuclear weapons. The German government needs to step in and bring those merchants of death to heel. But we can't be smug or self-righteous about this issue. The United States supported Iraq in its long war against Iran, overlooked its use of chemical weapons, and urged other Arab nations to help finance Iraq. And our nation has supported terrorism that suits our national purposes and profited handsomely by weapons sales that aid our balance-of-trade deficit problem. The lesson here is that the free market has limits. Governments need to place sensible restrictions on death merchants. --- Oct. 20 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on education: There is a new buzzword in the air these days: Eurocentric. It is used as both a description and condemnation of the standard curriculum in America's public schools. Like most educational fads, the complaints about Eurocentrism contain a modicum of truth, but this is all too often accompanied by overheated and potentially destructive rhetoric. Everyone recognizes that the schools' curriculum is based on the premise that America's political, economic and cultural institutions are basically European in their origin and character. But it is a sign of our peculiar times that this feature of the curriculum should be considered a cause for complaint rather than an obvious - indeed, inescapable - reflection of historical realities. --- Oct. 23 Long Beach (Calif.) Press-Telegram on 2 Live Crew: They are among the most unsavory heroes of the Constitution imaginable: three rappers from Florida whose most consistent theme is the celebration of abusive sex. Perhaps only the Nazis and Klansmen who march before the Lincoln Memorial more sorely test the nation's commitment to free speech than do the lyrics of 2 Live Crew. That is as it should be. The First Amendment was designed to protect those at the fringes as well as those at the center. Indeed, even more so. Free speech always is most vulnerable when it is exercised outside the limits of conventionality. There, where non-conformist and anti-social ideas are likely to find their most vociferous proponents, crusaders from the center find reason to attack. In that context, a group like 2 Live Crew, with its brutal street verses and artless performances, seems almost to be begging for the abrogation of its free-speech rights. If so, 2 Live Crew nearly got its way. After a federal judge held that the group's album was obscene, Broward County successfully prosecuted a record store owner for selling it. Fortunately, a related prosecution of the group for performing the songs in an adult-only nightclub was a laughable failure. ... (On Oct. 20) another Broward County jury had no difficulty throwing the charges out. Together, the rulings demonstrate the fundamental strength and the troubling weaknesses of the law's approach to obscenity and free expression. Even when confronted with essentially the same work in essentially the same community, juries can differ in significant ways. ... (But) what happens when, as in Florida, the community itself isn't sure? Then, the benefit must go to the alleged offender, for too often, would-be censors react to artwork simply because they don't understand it. To which it must be said, of censorship as of other criminal acts: Ignorance is no excuse. ---
