DOC.HEAD: Cuban Passenger Plane Crashs With 31 Aboard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands last graf to locate the crash cite relative to U.S. naval station at Guantanamo Bay. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban passenger plane with 31 people on board crashed near an airport in eastern Cuba today, two news agencies said. One of the reports said no one survived the accident. The Soviet-made turbo-prop went down near the Antonio Maceo Airport in Santiago de Cuba, a provincial capital, the official Cuban news agency, Prensa Latina, said. The report said the number of dead and injured had not been determined. However, the official Mexican news agency Notimex reported from Havana that no one survived the crash. Prensa Latina said there were 24 passengers and seven crew members aboard the flight. The two dispatches, monitored in Mexico City, gave no further information about the Cubana de Aviacion flight. Santiago de Cuba is about 50 miles from the city of Guantanamo and about the same distance from Guantanamo Bay, home of the U.S. Naval station. The crash site is about 560 miles east of Havana.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Criticizes New Army Leader, Once Accused of Torture
DOC.TEXT: Opposition groups today criticized the appointment of a new army chief who was accused of widespread torture during his days as a guerrilla fighter. The new army chief, Maj. Gen. Solomon Hawala, was a guerrilla fighter for the South-West Africa People's Organization, or SWAPO, in its 23-year independence battle against South African rule. SWAPO won elections last year and became the first government when Namibia became independent from South Africa on March 21. While SWAPO was in exile, Hawala was accused of supervising systematic torture of SWAPO members suspected of spying on the organization. Namibia's new democracy has been cited by foreign observers as an example of reconciliation, but the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, the official opposition, said the appointment could rekindle bitter wartime rivalries. It said Hawala had been ``condemned by almost the whole world for his rotten human rights record'' and called his appointment ``as shocking and disgusting as it is despicable.'' Former SWAPO members detained by the organization say hundreds of dissidents and suspected spies were arrested and remain missing. SWAPO has acknowledged that abuses occurred, but says all prisoners were released. President Sam Nujoma's government defended its decision to appoint Hawala as army chief, a post that has been vacant since independence. Information Minister Hidipo Hamutenya said South Africa also had been guilty of abuses during the war. Hawala was traveling today and could not be reached for comment. The National Society for Human Rights, a private group, said the appointment of Hawala was a ``clear indication that the (SWAPO) leadership ... approved of the torture, killing, rape and disappearance of so many innnocent Namibians in exile.'' A spokesman for the National Society for Human Rights, Phil Ya-nangolo, said his organization was contacting Amnesty International and other international human rights groups to register its concern. Ya-nangolo said that with Hawala as the army chief, the radical wing of SWAPO will have the upper hand in government. The Namibia Patriotic Front, another opposition group, also denounced the appointment. ``The NPF strongly feels that it is inopportune for Mr. Halawa to be appointment to a high public office until his name is cleared,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Student Marchers Seek More Government Spending, Better Security
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of high school students across France joined marches and rallies Wednesday, demanding that the government spend more on education and combat a wave of campus violence. At least 5,000 students participated in the largest march, in Paris. The youths walked through a light rain to the National Assembly, some carrying banners that said: ``End rape, theft and racketeering.'' The recent surge of crime at high schools has included the rape of a girl in a school lavatory, assaults on several teachers, and cases of extortion. Similar protests were reported in cities across France, including rallies involving about 400 students in Metz, 500 in Strasbourg, 1,000 in Nice, and 500 in Draguignan. The high school controversy was discussed at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, with President Francois Mitterrand referring to the ``sometimes deplorable'' state of certain schools. Mitterrand told the Cabinet that regional authorities were responsible for the budgetary decisions that could ease the problems of inadequate teaching staff and facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Crackdown Heightens With Monastery Raids, Arrests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with more monastery raids. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `On Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: Troops have arrested at least 40 more people for taking part in a Buddhist boycott of the military government, and the army is expanding raids on pro-democracy political parties, sources said today. Twelve members of the opposition National League for Democracy were arrested Tuesday night after authorities searched its headquarters and district offices in Rangoon, party members said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The League overwhelmingly won a national election in May, but the 2-year-old military government of the prime minister, Gen. Saw Maung, has arrested its leaders and refused to turn over power. The arrested League members included four members of its central executive committee. Also arrested were a member of the party's central work committee, two divisional leaders, and five youth members of the party, the sources said. Sources contacted by telephone from Bangkok said soldiers have been raiding temples in Mandalay, heart of the rebellion by Buddhist monks, and that the monks' nearly 7-week-old rebellion appears to be over. Monks were protesting government suppression of pro-democracy groups by refusing to hold religious services for soldiers in the mainly Buddhist country. Such treatment is the equivalent of excommunication in Burma. The state radio said troops searched six more monastries in Mandalay today, seizing raw jade, heroin, weaponry and literature from illegal groups including the Communist Party. On Tuesday night, Burmese government radio said troops searching the Masoyein Monastery in Mandalay found 34 rounds of rifle ammunition, typewriters, duplicating machines and anti-government pamphlets. Mandalay is 350 miles north of the Burmese capital, Rangoon. The broadcast said people connected with the ``incriminating materials'' were detained, indicating monks in the monastery had been arrested in the confrontation between segments of Burma's clergy and the military government. The sources in Rangoon said 40 people were arrested, but it was not immediately known how many were monks. Twenty monks were reported arrested on Monday. Meanwhile, political sources said raids on the headquarters of opposition political parties had been expanded nationwide, and that ``a couple offices have been sealed.'' Troops ``have been going into National League for Democracy offices all over the country,'' one source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. It was not certain if all the offices of the pro-democracy parties had been searched, but the raids were being made nationwide, the source said. ``They (soldiers) are looking for anything subversive.'' he said, adding that they were not damaging the offices. ``They are just looking for any material that can be labeled `incriminating.' '' The Rangoon headquarters of the National League for Democracy and the Democratic Party for a New Society were raided Tuesday and party documents were taken away, sources said earlier, also speaking anonmyously. Some regional offices of the two parties also were searched. Monks began their boycott in Mandalay on Sept. 6 following a protest Aug. 8 in which four people, including two monks, were killed, according to Western diplomats in Rangoon. The boycott quickly spread to other areas, including Rangoon. Over the weekend, troops ringed several monasteries and ordered the monks to end their boycott. A group of 29 monks yielded to the ultimatum but others apparently continued their defiance.

DOC.HEAD: Villagers Evacuated as Dam Springs Leaks
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 villagers were being evacuated from the area of a ruptured dam in northeastern Thailand, officials said Wednesday. The Civil Defense Department said residents of 44 villages were being moved from the vicinity of Lammoon Bon Dam, under pressure after heavy rains from recent tropical storms. Many provincial areas have been hit by flooding in recent weeks. Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan flew Wednesday to the area, about 125 miles northeast of Bangkok. The 26-foot-thick dam wall sprang a small leak Monday and a large hole was detected Tuesday, the Interior Ministry said. Officials said gates were being opened to reduce pressure on the dam wall and divers were trying to repair the holes.

DOC.HEAD: 300 Injured In Anti-Government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Protesters campaigning for the president's resignation clashed with police and government supporters, leaving 300 people injured, news reports said Wednesday. Violence broke out Tuesday at opposition-sponsored protests in at least 25 of Bangladesh's 460 rural districts, according to the United News of Bangladesh and the Sangbad newspaper. The demonstrations outside Dhaka, the capital, were intended to broaden the opposition's campaign for the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad and a general election under a caretaker government. The Sangbad reported that 250 people were injured in the north and northwestern areas of Mymensingh, Narail, Madaripur, Sirajganj, Ishwardi and Rajshahi. According to United News, another 50 people were injured in the southern district of Chittagong when students rampaged through the streets, damaging buses and cars and stoning police. Most injuries occurred when police used steel-tipped batons to disperse the students, it said. Eight protesters were killed earlier this month during rioting in the capital. Ershad, a former army officer, seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Veto, Never Overturned, Used To Win Concessions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf pvs bgng, `Bush's winning,' with 1 graf to UPDATE with civil rights veto sustained
DOC.TEXT: To the dismay of Democrats, President Bush has compiled a long list of successful vetoes and in the process has rewritten the civics-book definition of how to use them. Bush has wielded his veto pen 16 times, and he has never been overridden in a Congress ruled by Democrats. Just as importantly, the veto - and threats of a veto - have helped the president wrest compromises from reluctant lawmakers. Bush's winning streak remained intact today as the Senate narrowly sustained his rejection of a major civil rights bill. Supporters of the measure conceded in advance that they lacked the two-thirds majority needed to overturn the veto, but they came close. The vote was 66-34, just one vote short. ``Of the many vetoes of President George Bush, this may well be the unkindest and ungentlest yet,'' United Auto Workers President Owen Bieber complained Tuesday. Over the last three decades, only Gerald R. Ford had a higher veto rate, and he had a quarter of his vetoes overridden. Bush is using his veto power differently than many presidents who employed the veto simply to kill unwanted legislation or bills they deemed unconstitutional. In large measure, Bush uses vetoes to force compromises from Congress. It is a tactic that makes the White House a player at the bargaining table as bills move through the House and Senate. ``He has wielded the veto much less as a public relations weapon, much more as a quiet instrument of influence in the Congress,'' said American Enterprise Institute analyst Norman Ornstein. ``Richard Nixon often used to veto bills at press conferences, making a statement as much as anything else,'' Ornstein said. ``George Bush does it in a much more understated way.'' In dealing with lawmakers, Bush has a big problem. He has the smallest share of his own party members in Congress of any newly elected president in history. With a divided government, Bush does not have the clout to push a legislative program through Congress. Yet, there is enough GOP strength to sustain his vetoes when Republicans stick together. ``When you have two houses against you, you have no leverage, the odds are heavy against you,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``So you've got to use a sledgehammer going in that says, `We won't accept this.''' In his day, Ronald Reagan coyly refused to say whether he would veto a bill. Bush does it all the time, while also carefully spelling out options to make a bill acceptable. ``You try to get as much change as you can before a bill is passed,'' Fitzwater said. ``So by signaling early that you're going to veto, you tell them they need to seriously consider compromise.'' Bush established the pattern with his very first veto. Democrats wanted to raise the minimum hourly wage to $4.55 over three years. Bush said that was excessive and threatened a veto. Congress approved the increase anyway and Bush rejected the bill. When he was sustained, lawmakers and the White House struck a compromise. Tom Cronin, a political scientist at Stanford University, said the president is using his vetoes ``quite intelligently.'' ``He doesn't try to use the veto in a mean-spirited way. He just sees it as an instrument to try to get people back to the bargaining table,'' Cronin said. Bush vetoed three appropriations bill to force the deletion of abortion funding from otherwise acceptable measures. Three other measures, including one dealing with Chinese students, were rejected to prevent what he viewed as an erosion of presidential authority. Most recently, Bush vetoed a short-term spending resolution and shut down the government to force progress on deficit-reduction negotiations. Monday's veto of the civil rights legislation came only after months of negotiations between the White House and Congress. The president coupled his veto with a copy of a civil rights bill he would sign, but civil rights advocates denounced it as a sham. Democrats routinely decry Bush's vetoes but they haven't been able to stop him. Early in the administration, there was an understanding among Bush, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., Fitzwater said. ``They agreed that the only way they would have any clout in the Congress is if, when it was called for, they could hang together,'' the spokesman said. ``Basically, on most of these vetoes we've been able to hold together. It gets more dicey when you can't hold all your Republicans. You've got to try to pick up some Democrats.''
