DOC.HEAD: House Approves Volunteer Service Bill Despite Complaints Over Cost
DOC.TEXT: Pushing aside complaints about its cost, the House on Wednesday approved and sent President Bush a $287 million bill aimed at encouraging volunteerism and community service. The compromise National and Community Service Act passed the House on a 235-186 vote. The Senate approved the agreement last week after it emerged from a House and Senate conference. Rep. Gus Hawkins, D-Calif., the retiring chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, said he had been assured Bush would sign the bill. But it was condemned by Republicans, who said it amounted to unwarranted spending at a time when Congress is struggling with a tax bill and existing programs for children and the poor lack mone. ``Has the Congress of the United States gone bonkers?'' said Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. ``People wonder why the American public is upset with the Congress of the United States. I'll tell you why they're upset - because they don't understand this kind of drunkenness with new bureaucracy and new spending,'' he said. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said the bill would encouraging a new spirit of service among young people. ``This bill at least for now signals a change from the `Me Generation' of the 1980s to a community service ethic I hope will pervade America in the 1990s,'' he said. The bill authorizes spending $62 million in the current fiscal year, $105 million in fiscal 1992 and $120 million in fiscal 1993 for national and community service programs. A part of the measure is a $5 million authorization to begin a ``Thousand Points of Light Foundation'' to encourage volunteerism, taking its name from Bush's phrase for volunteers. Among the key elements: - A new part-time program encouraging community service by young people, established through schools and community organizations such as the YMCA or the United Way. It would encourage adults to volunteer in schools and community-based service programs. Money would go in grants to state education agencies, which would distribute it to schools and service groups. - An expansion of youth corps programs to increase fulltime service opportunities. Young people would be put in teams to work on projects cleaning the environment, helping the hungry and homeless and aiding the poor. Some 60 conservation or youth corps programs now are operating locally. - A program to encourage colleges to make community service programs available to their students. - A greatly reduced version of a civilian national service corps proposed two years ago by Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and Chuck Robb, D-Va. It establishes a test program providing $1,000 for higher-education assistance or a home down payment in exchange for a year of part-time civilian service.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Gag Order on Lawyers, Defendants in Sheriff's Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered participants in the trial of seven sheriff's deputies accused of skimming drug cash not to talk to the news media after one lawyer brought up what prosecutors called an irrelevant issue. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie issued the gag order Tuesday, telling lawyers and defendants not talk to reporters about anything with a ``substantial likelihood of materially prejudicing this proceeding.'' The deputies are charged with conspiracy, theft, racketeering and tax fraud for allegedly stealing more than $1.4 million in confiscated drug money over a two-year period. They are all on suspension. Defense attorney Harland Braun, who represents Deputy Daniel Garner, had told reporters his client would testify the CIA used stolen drug money to covertly fund Nicaraguan rebels in the 1980s. He would not elaborate on how that related to the case. Braun made the same claim Tuesday in filing a motion opposing the gag order. Rafeedie accused him of seeking to get inflammatory material on the public record. Prosecutors asked the judge to omit CIA evidence about drug money, saying it was irrelevant. Rafeedie did not immediately rule on the request but said he agreed in principle. The government's chief witness testified Tuesday that deputies were warned their homes would be searched by federal agents investigating the skimming allegations. Former Sheriff's Sgt. Robert Sobel said he learned about the searches in 1989 and warned the deputies, who were members of his narcotics unit. ``I told everyone on the crew,'' Sobel said. ``I told them I had just gotten information that someone ... was being worked, and that they should be careful.'' Sobel also testified that members of the Southwest Task Force, a multiagency narcotics unit, severely beat a drug suspect in 1987. Sobel, who entered a plea bargain with prosecutors, said he was allowed to retire from the force as a 20-year veteran with a $1,500 monthly pension. H pleaded guilty in March to conspiracy and tax evasion charges and faces a possible eight years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Digs Called `Six Flags Over Saudi Arabia'
LaserPhoto DHA3
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers in the desert find creature comforts any way they can. A water bag is turned into a shower. A 55-gallon drum and a block of ice converts into a cooler. An overturned stretcher is a card table. They may have no choice about being in a scorching desert, but the troops try small touches to make their hardscrabble home as comfortable as possible. ``This is either the world's biggest beach or the world's biggest ash tray,'' said Pvt. Scott Tenhagen, 19, of the 92nd Field Artillery. ``We're waiting for our grass to grow, but since we don't have a lawn mower, we hope it doesn't,'' Tenhagen, of Burlington, Ky., said from his tent. The division, normally based in the arid lands of central Texas at Fort Hood, has been encamped in Saudi Arabia's fierce desert for 10 days. The 2nd Platoon calls its area ``Six Flags Over Saudi Arabia,'' although it hardly looks like an amusement park. Their olive-colored military tents are one of the few green things sprouting from a tortured landscape that supports only the hardiest camels, goats and sheep. ``These guys really know how to adapt. They'll do anything they can to make life a little easier,'' said Lt. William Moore, 23, of Orange County, Calif. The platoon has erected wooden mail boxes outside their tent flaps. Inside, a section of canvas serves as wall-to-wall carpet to cover the sand. Gear is stored in cardboard boxes that once contained food rations. Nearby, the group has created a shower with a water bag hung from a tent pole and protected by two ponchos. A couple of planks serves a a floor. For recreation, the soldiers have a football, a volleyball court and playing cards. Soldiers are getting two hot meals a day and eat field rations for lunch. They say they're getting plenty of water and the mail is getting through. There's also training to keep them occupied. One morning, the battery practiced setting up two multiple launch rocket systems. The system uses radar to track incoming shells, then plots the trajectory back to its source so a rocket will hit it. The system is touted as faster, deadlier and more accurate than conventional artillery. Each system can fire 12 rockets in 36 seconds. The radar-guided system is accurate to within 24 yards of where incoming rounds are fired from. ``If you have a rocket land within 24 meters (yards), commit your soul to God,'' said Warrant Officer Francisco Merced, 36, a Dary, Ind. native who operates the system.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Aide, Former Aide Indicted; No Charges Against Assemblywoman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts grafs 2-3 to reflect that Netters was no longer an aide to Moore.
DOC.TEXT: Corruption charges won't be filed against an asemblywoman whose office was searched at the beginning of a long-running FBI investigation at the state Capitol, federal prosecutors said. But a legislative aide and a former aide were accused by a federal grand jury Tuesday of shaking down FBI undercover agents in exchange for help with legislation. They are the seventh and eighth people charged so far in the FBI's five-year probe. The assemblywoman from Los Angeles, Gwen Moore, chairs the Assembly Utilitiesaand Commerce Committee and is the author of special-interest bills that figured prominently in the investigation, U.S. Attorney David Levi said. The evidence, ``when viewed in its entirety,'' did not warrant any charges against Moore, Levi said. Moore's former top aide, Tyrone Netters, was indicted by the grand jury on nine counts, accusing him of racketeering, bribery, extortion, conspiracy, money laundering and filing a false income tax return. Netters, who now works for the Assembly Rules Committee, was placed on administrative leave Tuesday, said Bob Connelly, the Assembly's chief administrative officer. Darryl Freeman, a former Assembly aide and lobbyist, was indicted on conspiracy and extortion charges. Moore, who has represented a Los Angeles area district since 1978, said Levi's announcement made Tuesday a ``happy day for me and my family.'' ``For more than two years I have fully and completely cooperated with the FBI in its investigations,'' Moore said. ``I knew I had done absolutely nothing wrong and today that was confirmed by the U.S. attorney.'' Moore voluntarily testified before a federal grand jury in September. If convicted, Netters faces up to 163 years in prison and a $3.2 million fine and Freeman up to 40 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. The indictment also seeks repayment of nearly $15,000 that Netters allegedly received from FBI undercover agents.

DOC.HEAD: China Says It's Out of Serious Economic Slump
DOC.TEXT: China has pulled its economy out of a serious slump by pumping more funds into money-losing state factories and building up inventories, according to official statistics released Wednesday. Industrial output grew 5 percent in the third quarter of the year from 1989's third quarter, including a 7.5 percent jump in September, a spokesman for the State Statistical Bureau, Zhang Zhongji, told a news conference. Chinese industry went into a slump last year after two years of reduced state credit and purchases. Millions of small factories shut down and even some large state factories furloughed portions of their work forces. Worried about possible social unrest, the govenrment this year loosened limits on bank loans and resumed some construction projects. Zhang said the government spent $8.4 billion in subsidies to money-losing factories and $4.2 billion in price subsidies to control inflation during the first nine months of the year. Inflation remains at about 2 percent, and liberal economists have argued that the economy is healthy enough to resume the process of replacing central planning with market forces. However, top leaders in the ruling Communist Party remain in debate over the issue. They have been unable to reach agreement on a key document setting forth the next five years' economic program. The government subsidies helped restart production, but much of the new output simply went into warehouses. Zhang said state factories piled up inventories worth $25.3 billion by the end of September, 50 percent larger than their inventories one year earlier. Overall profits at state factories fell 57.9 percent, and profits at state-owned stores fell 73.7 percent, Zhang said. One-third of all state factories actually lost money, for total losses of $4.2 billion during the first nine months of the year. Zhang blamed sluggish consumer demand for the state sector's poor showing. However, earlier official reports have noted the tiny private sector and collectively owned factories in rural areas have consistently outperformed the state sector regardless of market conditions. About 5.6 percent of the work force is officially classed as unemployed, but Western economists say the figure could be much higher. Despite these problems, Zhang said, ``The economy is developing toward a more favorable direction.'' He predicted increases in production and construction from October through December.

DOC.HEAD: Souter, Marshall Said to Hit It Off
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice David H. Souter apparently is getting along well with his new colleague Thurgood Marshall, despite Marshall's biting comment about Souter's appointment last July. Justice Antonin Scalia, speaking to students at George Washington law school Tuesday, said Souter and Marshall have established a good rapport. ``They have met and they're getting along. There's no reason they shouldn't. They're both very likeable people,'' Scalia said. When Souter, a previously obscure New Hampshire judge, was picked by President Bush for the high court in July, Marshall hardly was enthused. In a televised interview, Marshall said he had never heard of Souter and said of Bush, ``I just don't understand what he is doing. This last appointment is the epitome of what he's doing. I think somebody's calling his shots.'' Scalia, responding to a question after delivering his lecture, said he also had not heard of Souter prior to the nomination and that's not surprising. ``If I had heard of him, it would be extraordinary,'' Scalia said. ``Why would one expect federal judges to have heard of state supreme court justices? If they are good judges, there is no reason why they are not deserving of consideration for the Supreme Court.' Souter, who replaced retired Justice William J. Brennan, shook hands with Marshall at the new justice's swearing-in ceremony on Oct. 9. They had met for the first time only moments before. While describing himself as a moderate conservative, Souter has expressed a high regard for Brennan and Marshall, both leading liberals. According to Souter's close friend, New Hampshire lawyer Tom Rath, Souter has called Marshall ``one of the giants of the century.'' Rath told reporters that Souter ``believes Thurgood Marshall as a man, as a person, has made a tremendous contribution to this country.''

DOC.HEAD: Huge Whale Free, Heads for Open Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, `A Coast...' to UPDATE with volunteers looking for whale this morning. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Humphrey last...'
DOC.TEXT: Freed from a mud-and-rock prison, Humphrey the wandering humpback whale headed toward the sea, thanks in part to the same song that lured him to open water during his famous visit five years ago. As thousands of onlookers cheered, the 40-foot, 45-ton whale floated away Tuesday from the shallows where he became beached a day earlier. Rescuers banged pipes to keep Humphrey away from shore and played tape recordings of whale sounds. The tapes, amplified with special underwater equipment, were of humpbacks feeding. A Coast Guard vessel and a boat with volunteers from the California Marine Mammal Center followed the leviathan as he made his way toward the sea. They quit trailing him at dark. Two Coast Guard boats carrying volunteers from the center resumed looking for Humphrey this morning, but no one spotted him. ``If he's not sighted, I think it would be safe to say he went out to sea,'' said Petty Officer Bryan Bender. Humphrey last was seen near the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, about five miles from where he had been beached and five more miles to the Golden Gate Bridge. ``At least he's headed in the right direction,'' said center spokeswoman Denize Springer. Rescuers also played whale sounds to lure Humphrey back to the Pacific in the fall of 1985 after his celebrated 25-day voyage through San Francisco Bay and other inland waters. Since then, Humphrey has been spotted in the ocean near San Francisco every August or September. Biologists identify him through tail markings that show a unique pattern, like a fingerprint. On Tuesday, he drew a crowd of thousands to a cove near Candlestick Park where he lay beached beside rocks bearing a no-trespassing sign. Marine biologists, veterinarians and Coast Guardsmen nudged Humphrey with their hands, splashed him with buckets of water, towed him with a harness and used an air compressor to suck mud from below him. ``Essentially we were trying to tease him off that mud rock,'' said Frank Griffith of the Marine Mammal Center. ``There's no amount of human beings that you could put out there to push him off like you'd push a car down the street. If he's stuck on the bottom by mud suction, you couldn't move him unless he puts some effort into moving himself.'' As afternoon high tide rolled in, Humphrey budged a bit from the mud, flipping his fins, raising his tail and blowing water through his spout as the crowd cheered. A short while later, Humphrey got stuck again, but with more work he freed himself. Nearly 200 children from nearby Bret Harte Elementary School watched Humphrey's return. ``The children are very worried. They wonder how he can survive. They said we should all get together and push him,'' said Swaraj Gujral, a fifth-grade teacher. ``I think he likes it here. He went away but he left his heart in San Francisco.''

DOC.HEAD: French Study Finds No Extra Leukemia Deaths Near Nuclear Plants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A study has found no extra leukemia deaths among young people living near nuclear plants in France, in contrast to reports from Britain. Scientists studied cancer deaths between 1968 and 1987 among people younger than age 25 who lived near six nuclear power or reprocessing plants. The researchers focused on populations living at distances of less than 3.1 miles, 3.1 to 6.2 miles, 6.2 miles to 8.1 miles, and 8.1 miles to 9.9 miles. Researchers found more deaths from Hodgkin's disease than expected, but said the difference was not statistically significant. The work is reported in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by researchers at the Gustave Roussy Institute in Villejuif, France. Previous reports found more leukemia deaths than expected in people younger than 25 who lived near the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant in England and the Dounreay nuclear complex in Scotland. Those results may be due to higher discharges of radioactive material than in France or other factors such as infections, the French researchers speculated. In September, National Cancer Institute researchers said they found no extra cancer risk in or near counties with nuclear installations in the United States. The study did not assess risk in more limited areas around the plants.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Student Angered by Grade Stabs Teacher
DOC.TEXT: Police charged an honor student with attempted homicide after he allegedly stabbed his high school physics teacher with a kitchen knife in an argument over a test grade. David Pologruto, a teacher at Taravella High School, was listed as stable at Coral Springs Medical Center, said nursing supervisor Linda Economou. The 16-year-old student, whose name was not released, had met with Pologruto, 41, in his classroom after school Tuesday, police said. ``That discussion turned into an argument where the student pulled out a large knife and struck the teacher with the knife,'' said Police Sgt. Jeffrey Maslan. School district spokeswoman Sisty Walsh said the straight-A student did not have a record of bad behavior. ``He was a good kid,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Women Get Pregnant After Menopause with Test-Tube Fertilization
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Older women can now get pregnant after menopause with the help of a method of test-tube fertilization that bypasses one of the seemingly absolute barriers of biology. With this technique, doctors remove eggs from a healthy donor, fertilize them in a lab dish with sperm and then implant them in the infertile woman's womb. Its developers say the new method should allow healthy women to routinely get pregnant and give birth after the change of life, even when they are in their 40s, 50s and perhaps 60s. ``The menopausal woman can have a family using this technology,'' said Dr. Mark V. Sauer of the University of Southern California, who was among the first to offer the method. Of course, because the mother does not provide the egg, she is not the genetic parent of her baby. Nonetheless, after she receives the fertilized egg, she undergoes a normal pregnancy and delivery. Sauer's clinic charges $8,000 for each fertilization. In addition, couples must pay $1,500 to the egg donor. This novel approach represents a way to circumvent the shutdown of the ovaries, usually around age 50, that ordinarily represents the end of a woman's reproductive life. But not any longer. ``The limits on the childbearing years are now anyone's guess,'' wrote Dr. Marcia Angell, executive editor of the New England Journal of Medicine. ``Perhaps they will have more to do with the stamina required for labor and 2 a.m. feedings than with reproductive function.'' Sauer reported his findings in Thursday's issue of the journal. It was the second report in two days offering the hope of pregnancy for infertile women. In Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association, doctors reported that a new device that opens blocked fallopian tubes with a tiny balloon can offer a simpler and cheaper method for helping some infertile women become pregnant than previously available. The implantation technique reported by Sauer has gone into widespread use among menopausal clients of fertility clinics across the United States during the past two years. Among the first treated was a 42-year-old patient of Sauer from El Monte, Calif The woman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, lost the use of her ovaries after she underwent chemotherapy for cancer four years ago. Her test-tube baby, a girl, was born eight months ago. ``I didn't think I would ever be pregnant when my ovaries quit working,'' she said. ``I was so happy. The baby seems like a miracle to me.'' Last week, she received the fertilized egg of what she hopes will be her second child. Sauer said that up to 10 percent of women go through menopause naturally by age 40. In his report, he described attempts to achieve pregnancy in seven women in their early 40s. After giving the women hormone treatments to prepare their wombs for pregnancy, doctors fertilized eggs from three donors and implanted them. Six pregnancies were established. One ended in miscarriage, and one was stillborn. Five normal babies were born, including a pair of twins. Sauer said the success rate appears to be about three times as high as in ordinary in vitro fertilizations, a technique that has become widely used during the past decade to help infertile couples. Typically, eggs are removed from a woman's ovaries, fertilized outside her body and then put into her womb. Sauer said he believes the donated eggs work better because they come from young women at the peak of their fertility and because the recipients have not been hormonally stimulated to produce their own eggs. It is possible that women approaching menopause could preserve their own eggs for implantation, but freezing human eggs is still experimental and it's unclear if it would work, doctors said. Dr. Howard Jones of Eastern Virginia Medical School, who performed the nation's first successful in vitro fertilization, said he has achieved pregnancies in 16 post-menopausal women over age 40 using the same techniques. ``The key thing here is the donor eggs,'' Jones said. ``The eggs are not as old as the mother. The pregnancies behave according to the eggs rather than the mother.'' Sauer said the major limit to the technique is the health of the mother, not her age. Women in their 50s who are free of heart disease, diabetes and other ailments may still be good candidates for pregnancy, and having children after 60 is possible though unlikely. The technique reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association is designed for a particular type of blockage, present among only 10 percent of the estimated 1 million American women who have blocked fallopian tubes. The procedure, which requires neither surgery nor general anesthesia, is similar to the use of balloons to open heart patients' clogged arteries.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officers Honored for Picnic Patrols
DOC.TEXT: A couple of police officers exasperated by drug dealing in their patrol area came up an idea they said closed some drug operations - at least during the lunch hour. Officers Mike Sharp and Brian Blosmo started the ``lunch bunch'' last summer in neighborhoods where residents complained of drug dealing. The uniformed officers pulled out lawn chairs and had picnic lunches on front lawns. ``Our first intent was for the drug dealers to see us,'' Sharp said. Sharp, Blosmo and other officers, honored Tuesday by the City Council for the idea, said suspected drug dealers did see them and closed up shop. ``They shut the doors and closed the windows,'' Sharp said. The officers said the lunches also provided a chance for neighborhood residents to interact with police. ``It gave people an opportunity to come out and talk to us and find out that we're not all that bad,'' Sharp said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi King Stands Firm; U.S. Considering More Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with 9 Americans in London. Pickup 4th, `Iraq's ambassador..' DELETES grafs 21-22, `The 14...on Thursday.' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,10,LON2,4,7,DHA1
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's king today denied reports that the Saudis are willing to accept territorial concessions to defuse the Persian Gulf crisis, and a U.S. senator said Iraq and the multinational force are headed for war. Thirty-two British hostages freed in Iraq on Tuesday returned to London today, and 14 Americans released in Baghdad the same day also headed home. One of the British hostages who was held at a strategic site in Iraq said he and his fellow captives briefly rioted when their guards refused to provide them with enough food or adequate toilet facilities. Nine of the Americans arrived in London today and will fly home Thursday. The other five flew to New York on a flight with a stopover in Amsterdam. The nine Americans had little to say on arrival at Heathrow Airport. ``They asked us very nicely not to say anything,'' said Peter Timko of Pennsylvania. John Charlton, 19, from Tampa, Fla., said the detainees didn't have much warning before they were told they could leave. ``It was just a few hours, pretty sudden. ... I am happy to be home in the West. We were treated fine as diplomats,'' said Charlton. ``I was never scared, except the invasion was a little scary, but that's about it.'' Iraq's ambassador to France said all French citizens in Iraq and occupied Kuwait could return to France within two days. Iraq's parliament on Tuesday endorsed Saddam Hussein's proposal to allow all French citizens in the country to leave, a gesture seen in Paris as an attempt to divide the West's anti-Iraqi alliance. The more than 300 French citizens in Iraq and Kuwait are among hundreds of Westerners prohibited from leaving by Saddam since his invasion of the emirate Aug. 2. Many are being held at strategic installations to deter a possible attack by the U.S.-dominated multinational force in the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon on Tuesday said the United States might send more troops to the region than the 240,000 who are there now or en route. ``The fact is that we're headed toward conflict,'' Sen. Richard Lugar, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said during an interview on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``If the Iraqis don't move they're likely to be pushed out, peace is not at hand,'' the Indiana Republican said in response to Saudi comments over the weekend that some interpreted as a peace overture to Saddam. King Fahd - for the second time in two days - today denied the Saudis would be willing to accept territorial concessions to Iraq to prevent war. The king stressed that the Saudis demand an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and the return to power in the oil-rich emirate of exiled Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who was deposed in the invasion nearly 12 weeks ago. ``The decisive and clear stand that the government of the kingdom set toward the Iraqi aggression on the state of Kuwait is firm and unchangeable, clear and unambigious,'' Fahd said in a statement distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency, monitored in Bahrain. On Sunday Prince Sultan, the Saudi defense minister, was reported to have raised the possibility of allowing Iraq to keep some Kuwaiti territory if it withdraws its hundreds of thousands of troops. Regarding the hostages, a jetliner landed outside London today with former British Prime Minister Edward Heath and the 32 Britons whose release from Iraq he had helped secure a day earlier. Jim Thompson, one of the freed Britons, told reporters on the flight that he and 14 other foreigners held as human shields at an Iraqi armaments factory had rioted to protest bad conditions. Thompson, 50, an engineering company manager, said they were held without enough food and with no proper toilets. He did not say if any Americans were in the group. ``We were in really bad shape. We told the guards, unless you do something ... we are going to have a disturbance,'' he was quoted as saying. He said when nothing was done, they tore down fences, broke windows, painted anti-Saddam remarks on walls and shouted anti-Saddam slogans until guards forced them back into their rooms at gunpoint. He did not say where the factory was located or when the incident happened. The number of Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait is estimated at 1,000. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington on Tuesday that of the 14 American men released Tuesday, six are ailing, two have critically ill relatives at home and six are students. She said 63 Americans with health problems have not been allowed to leave. Iraq's ambassador to Paris said all the French hostages held in Iraq and occupied Kuwait could be flown home within two days. Ambassador Abdul Razzak al-Hachimi told journalists that an Iraqi Airways plane could evacuate the hostages held in both countries. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said on Tuesday that U.S. officials were considering sending more troops to the region. That could give Operation Desert Shield a far greater offensive capability. Williams said the joint chiefs chairman, Gen. Colin L. Powell was consulting with U.S. and Saudi officials on possibly expanding the deployment.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Proposes System For Black Majority Rule
DOC.TEXT: The government offered a model for a new political system Wednesday, proposing a two-chamber parliament that would allow some black rule but preserve substantial power for whites. The report by the President's Council, a body controlled by the governing National Party, could serve as the basis for the white-led government's bargaining position in planned negotiations on a new constitution. President F.W. de Klerk has called for negotiations with black and white opposition groups on a new constitution that would end apartheid and give the black majority national voting rights. He also has spoken of a system of ``checks and balances'' in which all citizens have equal voting rights but the different branches of government hold power over each other to prevent domination by individuals or groups. Under the model presented Wednesday, the two chambers of Parliament would have equal power, and major legislation would require approval from both. One chamberwould be elected by voters throughout the country with all citizens having an equal vote. At present, most observers believe the African National Congress would get the most votes under such a system. The second chamber would be set up on an ethnic or regional basis, the report said. Whites and other minorities would be assured a certain number of seats and would be able to exercise veto power on any major policy issue. There was no immediate reaction from the ANC or other anti-apartheid organizations. However, they are certain to oppose a second chamber based on race. Most anti-apartheid groups demand a simple one-man, one-vote system with no special concessions to any minority group. The President's Council's report also recommended a bill of rights and the establishment of a National Conflict Management System to resolve disputes. The council is a presidential advisory commission. Since May, the government and the ANC, the largest black opposition group, have been meeting to try to clear the way for full-scale constitutional negotiations. De Klerk has promised to dismantle the apartheid system of segregation and white dominance. But he says a straight one-man, one-vote system would merely replace white domination with black domination. During a visit to the Netherlands, de Klerk said Tuesday he would be willing to serve in a government headed by ANC leader Nelson Mandela. ``I'll serve under any president elected under the new constitution,'' de Klerk said. However, he said any coalition between his National Party and the ANC was unlikely. De Klerk has until 1994 to draw up a new constitution or face another election under the current constitution, which bars the 30 million blacks from voting. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy. The main institutions still segregated are neighborhoods, public schools and the politics. Many other facilities have been integrated in recent years. Wednesday's report said partitioning South Africa into separate black and white countries was a ``last resort, only to be contemplated when all other options have failed.'' The report acknowledged problems with the government's decades-old plans to establish 10 ``independent'' black homelands. It said only one of the 10 was ``economically viable,'' and none of the four that accepted nominal independence had established ``legitimacy.'' The homelands, which comprise 13 percent of South African territory, were designed to give blacks political rights in tribal territory but prevent their participation in national South African politics. Four have been declared independent, but only South Africa recognizes their sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Compromise Appears Near
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; minor editing; deletes outdated material.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic congressional leaders said today they had dropped their demand for a surtax on the wealthy, apparently clearing the way to a deficit-reduction plan acceptable to President Bush and most members of Congress. ``We're going to get an agreement this week,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., ``Today, I hope. This week, I'm sure.'' The deficit-reduction plan coming into focus would, according to one Democratic leader: -Raise the top income-tax rate on the wealthiest Americans from the current 28 percent to 31 percent. -Phase out the personal exemption, now $2,050 per person, for the well-to-do while reducing the deductions they can claim by 3 percent. The income levels at which the exemption and deduction changes would apply had not been finalized. But it appeared likely that deductions would be reduced for people earning more than $300,000 yearly. The emerging deal also appeared to avert a possible, partial shutdown of government services at midnight. With the Democrats' shift, Congress seemed likely to approve by Saturday a five-year measure raising taxes on gasoline by about 5 cents a gallon while boosting levies on cigarettes, alcohol and airline tickets. Projected increases in Medicare spending would be reduced by somewhat more than $40 billion, and other cuts would be made in a broad range of benefit programs, including those affecting veterans and farmers. Of the dropped demand for a surtax on the wealthy, Foley said, ``It appears this is not something the administration will support.'' Asked if the new proposalwas likely to contain the higher top tax rate, the exemption phaseout and the deduction limitations, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said, ``That may be the outcome.'' Just Tuesday, about half of the House's Democrats indicated at a closed meeting that they preferred a plan placing a 7.5 percent surtax on people earning $1 million or more a year. But on Wednesday, Democrats said that with election day less than two weeks off they decided it was time for a budget agreement to be struck and for Congress to adjourn. ``Members have a feeling it's time to bring this Congress to a close,'' said one top Democrat. ``We've debated the issues for a long time. The time has come for a decision.'' Put another way, Rep. Tom Downey, R-N.Y., said, ``It's one thing to tax the people's pocketbooks and it's another thing to tax their patience.'' Oddly, signs that Democrats were ready to drop the surtax began surfacing even as some House Republicans were indicating a possible softening of their own opposition. ``It's a possible,'' House GOP Leader Robert Michel of Illinois said of the surtax after a party caucus. Michel and Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas went to the White House Tuesday night for what GOP sources said was an attempt to sell Bush on the surtax. Today, however, Dole spokesman Walter Riker said the visit had been held to discuss ``whether they should pull the plug on the whole process'' - whether to break off negotiations. ``In Senator Dole's view, the surtax is a dead issue,'' Riker said. He said Dole believes that the longer negotiations continue, the greater likelihood there is of a package that relies more on tax increases and less on spending restraint. The dispute over precisely how to put new taxes on the rich became the most difficult issue in the effort by lawmakers and the White House to pare $250 billion from the budget deficit over five years. Added to a package of cuts in military spending and interest expenses, the deficit would fall by a total of $500 billion over that period. Instead of a surtax, Republicans proposed the limitation on deductions. Until this week, that alternative had been supported by only about half the House's majority Democrats. Proceeds from higher taxes on the wealthy would be used to moderate proposed increases in the gasoline tax - likely about five cents rather than the nine cents passed by the Senate - and in patients' Medicare expenses. Lawmakers were under pressure from two deadlines: With the Nov. 6 elections less than two weeks away, leaders want to adjourn for the year by the weekend, and the government's authority to spend money for non-essential services expires at midnight. Bush has signed four stopgap spending extensions since the budget year began Oct. 1. He said Tuesday he had not decided whether he would go along with a fifth in the absence of a deficit-cutting agreement. Congress has yet to enact any of the 13 annual appropriation bills for the new year. Bush, campaigning for Republicans in New England, declared himself ``so frustrated by Congress' inability to do anything ... I don't know what I'm going to do.'' He urged Republicans to get behind a compromise agreement. Democrats were doing the same. Although Bush has abandoned his campaign pledge not to raise taxes, many GOP allies in the House are sticking to theirs; they want no part of any tax increase. Thus, Democrats were left with the choice of pushing through a deficit-reduction package of tax increases and spending restraints whose basic outlines have been endorsed by Bush, or drafting their own plan and hoping for reluctant support from senators and the presiden. Tuesday's negotiations indicated Democrats had abandoned hopes of winning support for a Republican-backed plan and are ready to move with their own. Any package likely to emerge from continuing negotiations will include tax increases on tobacco, alcoholic beverages, plane tickets, and expensive cars, furs and boats. Higher-income wage earners would have to pay more for Medicare coverage; retirees would have to pick up a bigger share of the cost of insurance covering doctors' bills. Democrats had said a surtax was the preferable way to tax the wealthy because it is easily understood and would be clearly viewed as taking back a portion of national wealth that flowed to the richest Americans during the last decade. Republicans insisted a surtax would be an invitation to special interests to begin petitioning Congress for special exclusions, and that within a few years the only recourse would be to pay for those exclusions by raising all tax rates.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Passes Fueling Test, Cleared for Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Atlantis passing test; picking up 3rd graf, `Atlantis, like...' SUBS 14th graf pvs, `To make ...' with one graf to UPDATE with no problems found in engine compartment.
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis today passed a fueling test that found the space shuttle to be free of dangerous hydrogen leaks, clearing the way for a November liftoff. ``We have a very tight vehicle at the pad,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``There are no indications of any excess leakage of liquid hydrogen.'' A small amount of hydrogen escaped into Atlantis' engine compartment, but was well within allowable limits, Buckingham said. No leakage was evident in fuel lines between the orbiter and external tank, the site of previous problems. ``We feel the leaks have been fixed,'' Buckingham said. ``The engineers are very happy.'' NASA began pumping liquid hydrogen into Atlants' new external tank early this afternoon, six hours later than planned. Engineers needed extra time to evaluate a broken fuel line sensor and a small dent in another line, which they decided would not affect the hourlong test. Atlantis, like Columbia, has been grounded by hydrogen leaks all summer. NASA plans to send Atlantis on a classified Pentagon mission around Nov. 9 or 10. A launch date will be set following a flight readiness review that begins Monday. Columbia, its astronomy flight postponed four times, will undergo a fueling test Monday. NASA is counting on a successful outcome to maintain the momentum from Discovery's smooth flight earlier this month and reduce mistakes by workers. Several mishaps occurred during the 5{-month gap between shuttle missions that ended with Discovery's liftoff Oct. 6 with a sun-exploring satellite. For example, technicians left a beam to bang around Atlantis' engine compartment when the shuttle was hoisted to an upright position on Oct. 3. Two days later, another beam crashed to the floor while being moved by a forklift. ``I hate to say it, but I think some of it has to do with the fact we're not flying and we're not paying as close attention as we should be,'' said Conrad Nagel, an official in charge of Atlantis' pre-launch operations. ``When you have delays and problems and people are not in their normal routine of processing, I think it has an effect.'' NASA officials said they will try to launch Columbia by the end of the year if Monday's fueling test goes well or if any remaining leaks can be corrected quickly. The shuttle was to have lifted off in May with an observatory. ``I don't think anybody around here feels we're on track until Columbia flies, after Atlantis,'' said Keith Hudkins, chief of the shuttle orbiter program. Since Atlantis' leaks were detected in June, NASA has replaced the external tank, fuel lines and valve seals. Five days after the repairs were completed, a 9-foot aluminum beam left inside Atlantis' engine compartment crashed into about 25 spots as the orbiter was being raised. A small section of liquid-oxygen plumbing had to be replaced. To make sure no damage remained from the beam, NASA pumped liquid oxygen into Atlantis as part of today's test. NASA officials said no traces of oxygen were found in the engine compartment. In the Oct. 5 accident, workers failed to secure a 60- to 70-foot beam that is part of a sling used to raise the orbiter, and the beam fell about 8 inches inside the assembly building. No injuries or damage were reported. J.B. Kump, spokesman for Lockheed Space Operations Co., NASA's prime contractor for shuttle processing, said disciplinary action is being taken against workers in both cases. Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center, said he met with workers last week and urged them to ``be a little bit more aware of what we're doing.'' Columbia's hydrogen leak, which is much more extensive than that of Atlantis, is at least partly due to worker error. Two seals were crushed when they were installed improperly after the shuttle's last flight in January.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Northern California, Nevada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf `The quake's ...' to CORRECT location of town.
DOC.TEXT: Huge boulders knocked loose by an earthquake blocked one road into Yosemite National Park today, and two of the three other highways leading into the park also were closed by rockslides. No injuries were reported from the quake, which was felt Tuesday night from San Francisco to Nevada and shook up casinos and hotels in South Lake Tahoe and Reno. It registered a preliminary 5.8 on the Richter scale, according to the United States Geological Survey. Six-foot-high boulders forced the closure of Highway 120 on the west side of the park. A three-foot section of the highway was gone and a retaining wall was lost. ``It's not a big pile of small rocks, it's a small pile of big rocks,'' U.S. Park Service ranger Kelly McClaskey said. A rockslide half a mile away closed Highway 140 into the park, but that was expected to be cleaned up today, ranger Scot Bowen said. State highway crews also were clearing away a slide on Highway 120 on the east side of the park. A road from the south was unaffected. The quake's center was in Lee Vining, a town of 400 people northeast of Yosemite National Park in the Sierra Nevada and about 190 miles southeast of San Francisco, said Pat Jorgenson, spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey. ``It was a rolling, strong jolt and lasted about 25 seconds,'' said Robin Bergmann, a resident of Manteca, about 120 miles from Lee Vining. ``We had lots of calls but no reports of injury,'' said Mono County Sheriff's Deputy Suzanne Sturdivant, who said the quake lasted about 45 seconds. Elaine West, a telephone operator at Caesar's in South Lake Tahoe, said the quake left ``a lot of frightened guests'' at the hotel and casino. ``In the gift shop, things started clinking around, and that's how the girls in the gift shop knew about it,'' she said. Syrena Styff, an employee at Harrah's in Reno, said guests reported feeling dizzy but didn't immediately realize a quake had struck. South Lake Tahoe is about 80 miles northwest of Lee Vining. Reno is about 40 miles north of South Lake Tahoe. The Richter scale is a measure of the magnitude of a quake according to ground motion. Every increase of one whole number represents a tenfold increase of magnitude. A quake of 7 is capable of widespread, heavy damage. The earthquake that hit Northern California on Oct. 17, 1989, registered 7.1 and claimed 67 lives.

DOC.HEAD: `Big Ticket' Sales Decline Again
DOC.TEXT: Factory orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods fell 1.7 percent in September, the government said Wednesday. Analysts said the report foretells a further production and employment slump in the industrial sector, which already has lost 500,000 jobs since January of 1989. ``It was another report indicating the economy is slowing down, probably ... that we're in a recession - but probably indicating the recession will be mild,'' said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York securities dealer. The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods - items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $124.9 billion last month. Transportation orders slid 6.8 percent to $32.8 billion, with declines in motor vehicles more than offsetting an increase in aircraft. ``The main message is that dealers are not ordering 1991 model cars,'' said economist Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. Durable goods orders have fallen three times in the last four months and, Commerce said, the August decline was even steeper than previously reported - down 0.8 percent rather than 0.5 percent. For the year so far, it said, orders were off 0.5 percent compared to the first nine months of 1989. Durable goods orders are a key barometer of manufacturing industry plans for production. A decrease in orders can result in production cutbacks and layoffs. In fact, the Labor Department reported earlier that 66,000 factory jobs were lost in September. Since reaching a post-recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost 500,000 jobs. ``The industrial sector is just muddling along,'' said Ms. Latta. ``I expect industrial output to decline in the fourth quarter because of a lack of orders.'' But Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist with Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said that while the report reflects continued softness in the manufacturing sector, it contains no ``confirming'' evidence that things will get worse. He noted that excluding the transportation category, orders inched up 0.3 percent. Orders in the key category of non-defense capital goods jumped 6.3 percent to $38.2 billion but faled to regain a 9.9 percent loss in August. While these orders often are a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize, Platt suggested that much of them may have come from overseas. ``The strength in exports probably will be one of the factors that will keep a recession relatively mild,'' he said. Orders for non-electrical machinery rebounded 5.4 percent to $22.5 billion from a 5.1 percent drop in August. Office and computing equipment had the largest gain. But orders for electrical machinery fell 7.7 percent to $19.1 billion after advancing 2.2 percent the previous month. Both communication equipment and electronic components were down sharply. Primary metal orders also declined, down 0.8 percent to $11.4 billion. They had fallen 2.5 percent in August. The often-volatile defense orders were off 9.6 percent, to $7.6 billion, following a 12.5 percent increase the previous month. Excluding defense, orders dropped 1.1 percent. Shipments of durable goods were down 3.0 percent to $124.7 billion, losing a 2.8 percent advance in August. Unfilled orders were unchanged at $499.5 billion following a 0.3 percent loss the previous month.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Leads To Fear of Arabs And Economic Distress
LaserPhotos JRL3,5
DOC.TEXT: Tractors stood dusty and idle at a Jerusalem construction site Wednesday, and a nervous Jewish shopkeeper kept a steak knife near his cash register. The scenes revealed an Israel suddenly fearful of the Arabs in its midst after a wave of attacks on Jews. The violence prompted the government to adopt the unusual tactic of sealing off the occupied territories. Roadblocks kept Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip out of Israel, while police swept out those left behind. Tel Aviv police said they fielded more than 1,700 calls from Israelis reporting on the presence of Arabs who should have stayed at home. The closure, ordered by Defense Minister Moshe Arens after a wave of Arab-Jewish clashes, virtually removed the backbone of Israel's blue-collar work force and disrupted many industries. Most Israelis, still shaken by the violence, were not sure the ban would work. ``People are afraid,'' said Charlie Maman, a grocer in Pisgat Zeev, a Jewish neighborhood wedged between two Arab districts of Jerusalem. He showed a visitor the steak knife he put next to his cash register. ``This is only to injure, not to kill,'' he added. Arab knife and hammer attacks have killed three Israelis and injured eight more in the past four days. On Tuesday, an Arab was killed by gunshots in an apparent vengeance attack, and another who stabbed and injured two unarmed women soldiers was beaten by civilians who caught him. He died in the hospital Wednesday. The atmosphere of communal violence elicited a despairing reaction from Zohar Shemesh, a Jerusalem clothing store owner. ``What are we going to do, close them off? Will that work? The solution is to get out of here, to go abroad.'' Police Minister Roni Milo said he hoped the closure of the territories would vacate some of Israel's more than 100,000 Arab-held jobs for Soviet immigrants. ``Let's not be ashamed that we want Jewish labor in the state of Israel,'' he told Parliament. Many construction sites, stripped of their Arab work forces, were almost idle. Ironically, they included housing projects being built for Soviet immigrants, who are pouring in at a rate of 20,000 a month. Aharon Sapir, deputy president of the Construction Union, said the situation was grave. ``We need a quick solution because the need for housing is urgent, both for the immigrants and the population, and we don't have the workers who can build,'' Sapir said in an interview. Professor Moshe Asimyonov of Tel Aviv University said that banishing the Arabs would create an ``unsettling atmosphere'' and damage industry, agriculture and construction, but not irrevocably. Israel says the ban is for a few days, until passions cool. But if it becomes permanent, Asimyonov said, the jobless Arabs ``will oil the wheels of the intefadeh,'' the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising. Many Arabs complained that they were being penalized for the violence of others. ``This is sheer starvation,'' said Shaher Saad, head of the Workers Union Federation in the West Bank. After Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip in 1967, it opened its borders and Arabs became an inexpensive work force of street sweepers, garbage collectors, waiters, cooks and construction workers. But idealists anguished over the damage being done to their vision of a Jewish state built and run by Jewish labor. Now the idealists see their chance to reverse the trend. Baruch Yonin, an immigrant from Leningrad, said low salaries deter even immigrants desperate for work. ``There is an absurd surrealistic situation here, where Arabs build houses for Jews in the territories,'' said Yonin, who came here seven months ago and works as a plumber on a construction site in Israel. ``Jews need to build for Jews,'' he said. ``But everyone has to hope to find something, a permanent job with a good salary. This job pays very little.'' Take-home pay on the site is about $650 a month, well under the national average wage of $1,000. Still, since the closure of the territories Jerusalem's state employment office has been flooded with calls from employers looking for maintenance, garage, restaurant, agriculture and supermarket workers.

DOC.HEAD: 29 Killed, Singh Says He'll Seek Confidence Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE death toll, details on fighting. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The general...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DEL2
DOC.TEXT: At least 29 people were killed Wednesday in clashes between Hindus and Moslems, and Prime Minister V.P. Singh said he will seek a vote of confidence to see if his government can survive. The deaths came during a nationwide strike called by the right-wing Hindu party, whose defection has jeopardized the future of the Singh government. Singh said his minority centrist government would survive despite the loss of support from the Bharatiya Janata Party. But other members of the prime minister's Janata Dal party were less optimistic. ``Only a miracle can save this government,'' said Chandra Shekhar, a veteran politician and frequent antagonist of Singh within the fractured Janata Dal. Singh called Parliament to reconvene 10 days ahead of schedule, on Nov. 7, and predicted he would muster the majority needed to keep him in power. Reports of violence during Wednesday's strike came from throughout the country. Clashes in Jaipur, the capital of the western state of Rajasthan, accounted for 18 deaths, United News of India said. News reports suggested the violence was sparked by clashes between Bharatiya Janata Party activists and Moslem residents. The general strike was called to protest the arrest of party president Lal Krishna Advani on Tuesday while he was leading a fundamentalist campaign to replace a 16th-century mosque with a Hindu temple. The Bharatiya Janata, or Indian People's Party, withdrew its support for Singh's government, ostensibly to protest the arrest and the government's vow to prevent the mosque's demolition. Most of the deaths were the result of either stabbings or police shootings in dozens of towns in the states of Rajasthan, Gujarat, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh states, which are predominantly Hindu but have large Moslem populations. News reports said businesses shut down and traffic stayed off the roads in most parts of the country either in support of the strike or for fear of violence. A curfew was imposed and army called out in several towns, the reports said. Press Trust of India and United News of India described the clashes as ``communal violence,'' a phrase that usually means Hindu-Moslem clashes. Indian news media avoid giving specific details in such cases, contending that the normally strained religious tensions would only be heightened. India's Moslem population of about 105 million is the second-largest in the world after Indonesia. But Moslems comprise only 12 percent of the 880 million population. Hindus have an 82 percent majority. The news reports said about 50,000 people have been detained across the country in preventative arrests. Such arrests are common in India, where the law permits people to be held without charge if the authorities believe public safety is in danger. ``The time has come for all secular forces to unite, irrespective of party affiliations, for the issues which are facing us today are larger than party consideration,'' Singh said in a statement. The appeal was apparently directed at Parliament members of the Bharatiya Janata Party and the opposition Congress Party in the hope that some of them would vote for the government on Nov. 7. Singh needs the support of 261 members in the 522-seat lower house of Parliament. At present he has the assured support of about 200 members. The Bharatiya Janata Party has 86 seats. Singh, who took office nearly 11 months ago, said in his statement that in the meantime, the government will work to stop the Hindu fundamentalists from beginning their temple construction on Oct. 30 in Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. At least 80 people were killed earlier this month in violence triggered by the temple campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Join in Super Collider Project
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Empact is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has agreed to join a consortium that hopes to build a large detector at the superconducting super collider in Texas, Stony Brook University officials said Wednesday. The Soviets will contribute $200 million to Empact-Texas, said Michael Marx, a physics professor at Stony Brook who is coordinating Empact's proposal. Others involved in the consortium are the Grumman Corp. and Martin Marietta. Three consortiums are vying to build two large detectors planned for the $8 billion atom particle smasher. Two are expected to be selected for final approval in December. Among other things, the detectors will be designed to search for the elusive ``higgs'' particle in proton-proton collisions. Physicists believe that higgs is the origin of mass. Marx said about 120 Soviet scientists from 12 institutions, including the Institute for High Energy Physics, would join the Empact consortium. The Soviet agreement, signed earlier this month, is the largest foreign commitment to the super collider to date, Stony Brook officials said. The super collider, scheduled for completion in 1998, will be housed in a 54-mile underground ring to be built south of Dallas. It will be used to study sub-atomic matter.

DOC.HEAD: Official Trade Unions Dissolve Themselves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with official trade union dissolving itself. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The 70-year-old Soviet national trade union organization voted today to dissolve itself and to form a voluntary association of unions, the state news agency Tass reported. The meeting in Moscow coincided with a congress of miners occurring in the Ukrainian city of Donestsk to form the nation's first independent trade union. During their weeklong conference the miners plan to consider a national strike to enforce their economic and political demands. The congress is an outgrowth of the nationwide coal strike that gripped the country in July 1989. With President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in attendance, 2,500 delegates to the Central Council of Trade Unions meeting in Moscow voted the council out of existence and formed an alliance of industrial and regional unions, Tass said. The council was an umbrella organization of trade unions representing an estimated 140 million Soviet workers. It was not clear whether the miners' union would be allowed or would want to join the newly reformed national trade union organization. Delegates to the national congress in Moscow, being held two years ahead of scheduled, moved quickly to break with the Communist economic system. Deputy chief Vladimir Scherbakov said the council ``increasingly lagged behind profound changes, acute and complex processes of real life, which inevitably prompted a crisis of trust in its structures.'' He said the revamped organization would no longer demand a monopoly on workers' loyalty. Tass said the decision to hold the official conference two years early was ``extraordinary.'' No official reason was given, but it appeared designed to coincide with the miners' meeting in Donetsk. The open bidding for workers' hearts, in a country that once hailed itself as a worker's paradise, demonstrated the political importance that organizers place on blue-collar labor as the political and economic system opens up. The miners' strikes, which started in the summer of 1989, began to protest working and living conditions and shortages of such basics as soap and medical care. The miners quickly escalated their demands to include regional economic autonomy for the main mine regions, such as the Kuznetsk Basin in Siberia and the Don River Basin in the Ukraine. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov persuaded the miners to return to work, promising to meet most of their demands. But most of the promises remain unfulfilled, an issue that has spurred new strikes. The strike committees, meeting at their first conference in Donetsk last summer, demanded the promises be honored. They also called for Ryzhkov's government to resign and urged workers in other industries to cut their ties with the government and official unions. The delegates at that congress proposed forming an independent trade union, but postponed its actual formation until now to allow the new government of Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin to deal with the economic crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Store Beefs Up Soup Kitchen After Heist by Meat Rustlers
DOC.TEXT: After 120 pounds of frozen, cajun-style beef disappeared from a soup kitchen, a nearby food warehouse replaced it within a week with fresh roast beef. Edwards Food Warehouse donated the 100 pounds of meat after a company executive read about the theft last week. The donated beef made a hearty stew that fed the whole lunch crowd Monday, soup kitchen coordinator David O'Sullivan said. Leftovers probably will make enough for another full meal, he said. ``It's always reassuring when we have a problem the community will rally around and help us out,'' O'Sullivan said. No arrests have been made. The soup kitchen feeds about 250 people each day, O'Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: Flea Market Browser Buys Pricey Print for a Song
DOC.TEXT: A flea market browser was surprised at her own luck when she plunked down $3 for an odd-looking picture that turned out to be a Peter Max silk screen worth $800. Max's penciled signature on the print of a neon-colored man in a brightly-hued coat was obscured by the frame. ``This may be the grand finale in the bargain department,'' said Lisa Smith, who got the last laugh on critics who dismiss flea markets and thrift sales as a dumping ground for junk. Smith found the print amid the bric-a-brac of Tampa's Junior League Thrift Sale in September. ``I was surprised someone would donate this to a thrift sale,'' she said. Tampa art dealer Lois Berghoff, who appraised the print, guessed the untitled work was created about 1972. Max, who is enjoying renewed popularity, created more than 300 limited edition graphics. He also has published 29 books, designed 160 posters and fashioned logos for more than 50 corporations. His style is distinguished by vivid colors and fairy-like characters associated with the so-called ``pop art'' of the late 1960s and early 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Gore Seeks Curbs On Genetic Screening
DOC.TEXT: Congress should safeguard workers' rights before employers begin widespread screening for genetic diseases, Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., said Wednesday. Gore released a report by the Office of Technology Assessment which showed that few U.S. companies now require genetic testing of their employees and applicants. But he said Congress should move now, before the practice becomes more widespread, to head off discrimination against workers on the basis of genetic characteristics. ``To a large extent there are few clear guidelines on how these tests can be used or how workers can be protected from having their rights violated,'' said Gore, who requested the report. Genetic screening can help save lives by alerting an employer to a worker's susceptibility to a particular occupational exposure, the report noted. But it expressed concern that employers might deny jobs to anyone whose tests show they are at risk of genetic disease and could prove a burden to a company's health insurance program. Genetic tests are available to detect sickle cell anemia, cystic fibrosis, Huntington's disease, hemophilia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy and other diseases. Future tests could screen for such things as hypertension, dyslexia, Alzheimer's disease and cancer, the report said. The OTA's 1989 survey of the nation's 500 largest companies produced responses from 330 companies. Twelve reported current use of genetic monitoring or screening and eight others said they had conducted these tests at some time since 1970. A similar OTA survey in 1982 elicited responses from 366 companies, with six saying these tests were in current use and 19 indicating past use. Margaret Anderson, project director, said it was not clear why more companies are not testing, but she said cost, ranging from $200 to $980 a person, is probably a factor.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Appeals To Shamir To Admit UN Investigators
With AM-Israel-Arabs Bjt

DOC.TEXT: President Bush has sent a personal letter to Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealing for cooperation with a United Nations investigation of the slaying of 19 Palestinian Arabs during a riot in Jerusalem, U.S. officials and other sources said Wednesday. The letter, delivyfield in Las Vegas, scheduled for 5-6 p.m. A photo should move by 8:30 p.m.

DOC.TEXT: After an out-of-court settlement, the Supreme Court has dismissed a case stemming from a $300 million lawsuit by a California woman who said the Taiwanese government plotted her husband's 1984 murder. The justices had been asked by lawyers for both sides to drop the case, in which Taiwan's government had argued that American courts lack the authority to hear such a suit. Helen Liu of Daly City, Calif., had contended in her suit that the government of Taiwan, formally named the Republic of China, ``carefully orchestrated'' a cover-up of a ``terrorist plan and scheme'' to silence her husband, Henry Liu. Gerard Harper, a lawyer for Mrs. Liu, said the Supreme Court case was dropped after Mrs. Liu and the government of Taiwan reached a settlement in which the government admitted no wrongdoing but paid her an amount of money. Harper said the size of the payment is confidential. The high court's order dismissing the case was dated Sept. 28. Born in China, Henry Liu fled to Taiwan in 1949. He lived there until emigrating to the United States in 1967, and became a U.S. citizen in 1974. A historian and journalist, Liu had written several articles critical of Taiwan's government. Liu was gunned down at his home by members of the Bamboo Union, an organized crime group based in Taiwan. Gangleader Chen Chi-Li confessed to plotting Liu's murder, and implicated two government officials, including Wong Hsi-Ling, director of Taiwan's Defense Intelligence Bureau. Wong was convicted and sentenced to life in prison. One of his aides, Chen Hu-Men, was sentenced to 30 months in prison. Mrs. Liu's suit said her husband began receiving threats in 1973, and that his published works were confiscated and suppressed in Taiwan. ``The threats did not daunt Liu, who continued to endorse a return to democratic rule in Taiwan,'' Mrs. Liu's lawyers had told the high court. ``He paid for those views with his life.'' Mrs. Liu's suit was filed in late 1985, nearly a year after the criminal convictions stemming from her husband's murder. Taiwan's government sought dismissal of the suit, arguing that the Act of State doctrine precluded U.S. courts from pursuing Mrs. Liu's theory of a government murder plot. A federal trial judge dismissed the suit but the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated it last December.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Bans News Organizations From Interviewing Jurors
DOC.TEXT: Two news organizations are challenging a judge's decision to bar reporters from calling jurors who delivered a $12.5 million verdict against white supremacist Tom Metzger. Multnomah County Circuit Judge Ancer L. Haggerty issued the ruling at the end of the trial late Monday, but said he would hold another hearing Friday to consider the challenge filed by lawyers for The Oregonian and KGW-TV. Haggerty told reporters they would be held in contempt of court if they tried to interview jurors about the verdict against Metzger, leader of White Aryan Resistance, his son, John, and others. The Metzgers were sued by the family of Mulugeta Seraw, 27, a black man from Ethiopia who was beaten to death by racist skinheads. The jury decided that Metzger incited Seraw's killers and was responsible for his death in November 1988. Before dismissing the jury, Haggerty asked jurors if any wished to appear at a news conference that evening. He later told reporters that no jurors wished to be involved. Haggerty said he told the jurors they were free to discuss the case, but that reporters could not call them. Charles Hinkle, attorney for The Oregonian, said the order violated state and federal constitutional free press guarantees. He also said the order was invalid because it was not in writing and because reporters did not have a chance to be heard before it was issued. Portland lawyer Elden M. Rosenthal, who helped represent Seraw's estate, said he thought the judge's order was appropriate. ``I think these jurors have gone far beyond the call of public service,'' Rosenthal said. He said he felt jurors in a highly controversial case ought to be allowed to ``melt back into the population'' at the end of their service. Intense security required for the two-week trial cost the Portland Police Bureau almost $300,000 in overtime, but the full cost of security still is being calculated and won't be known for several days, spokesman Dave Simpson said Wednesday. Concern about violence stemmed in part from the bombing of the federal courthouse in San Diego on Sept. 15. A previously unknown white supremacist group claimed responsibility and threatened further violence if the lawsuit against Metzger were not dropped. Morris Dees, the Southern Poverty Law Center attorney who sued Metzger, received a letter the same day threatening him. Police said Metzger received 20 death threat a day at his Portland message center. Police maintained 24-hour protection of Dees, Rosenthal and the judge. ``The Portland police deserve bouquets,'' Dees said. ``I mean I've had five or six guys around the clock since I hit this town two weeks ago.'' Metzger and his son spurned police offers and used their own bodyguards outside court, said Deputy Chief Dan Noelle.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Appeals Court Ruling Expands Drug Search Powers
DOC.TEXT: The Missouri Court of Appeals has expanded the power of police to make drug raids in response to an operation in which agents used mail-order records to nab more than 100 accused marijuana growers. The court Tuesday overturned a decision by Linn County Circuit Judge Robert DeVoy, who ruled that police had unconstitutionally searched the Prairie Hill home of Lisa Diane Shuck as part of operation ``green merchant.'' Shuck and another resident of the house, William Phegley, were charged in October 1989 with possession and production of marijuana. The charges carry a maximum sentence of 17 years in prison. Police obtained the warrant using records showing Phegley had bought hydroponic equipment, which enables plants to grow in water, from a company that advertises in ``High Times'' magazine. The New York-based magazine caters to marijuana growers and advocates legalizing marijuana. Police also presented evidence for the warrant that Shuck had draped blankets over her windows and used four times more electricity than her neighbors. Officers found more than 70 marijuana plants, marijuana seeds and growing equipment during the raid. Judges William E. Turnage and Donald L. Manford said in the ruling the search was reasonable. But Judge Robert W. Berrey warned in a dissent that police ``must be vigilant not to trample on our Bill of Rights to cure a momentary ill of our time. ``If the majority should prevail, no hydroponic horticulturist or African violet grower will be safe from unwanted intrusions,'' Berrey wrote. Jack Lukehart, Shuck's attorney, said he would appeal the decision to the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda Editor Offered to Resign, But Says He Was Told To Stay On
DOC.TEXT: The editor of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, facing a hostile staff and slumping circulation, said Wednesday he had offered to resign but was told by Mikhail Gorbachev and the Politburo to stay on. Ivan T. Frolov, who was appointed editor of Pravda a year ago, told a news conference that he offered to quit as a result of ``insulting'' remarks about him by Pravda staff members. Frolov also released figures showing a stunning drop in the circulation of the newspaper that for decades was viewed as the most important in the country. As of Oct. 1, Pravda had received only 504,000 subscriptions for next year, a huge drop from its current circulation of 7.7 million. The circulation drive, originally scheduled to end Oct. 30, has been extended to Nov. 15. Frolov did not say what insulting remarks the staff had made, but Pravda employees have said they are dissatisfied with Frolov's traditionalist views and his ties to hard-line politicians. The staffers voted three weeks ago to ask the party's Central Committee to review the newspaper's leadership. Frolov has called the vote a ``mini-coup attempt'' against him. Under Gorbachev's policy of ``glasnost'' or greater openness, other newspapers regularly publish articles on controversial political or historical themes, or on popular culture. Although Pravda has begun to print some articles critical of government officials and policies, it has changed less than other periodicals and is one of the most orthodox Communist newspapers. Its official owner is the party Central Committee, and it regularly carries front-page editorials praising and explaining party positions. Frolov attributed Pravda's plummeting circulation both to an increase in its cover price, which is rising from about 9 to 17 cents, and to its ownership by the party, which is blamed by many Soviets for the country's disintegrating economy and political structure. ``People's attitudes toward Pravda are connected with their attitudes toward the party,'' he said. Frolov said he offered his resignation on Tuesday to the party's highest bodies, the Central Committee secretariat and Politburo, headed by Gorbachev, who is the party leader as well as president of the country. ``I said I could not and did not want to work at this newspaper anymore,'' Frolov said. He added that he raised the issue himself, and received a ``negative response'' to his offer to step down. ``I received full support from the Politburo and the secretariat and, of course, I must and I will work at Pravda,'' he said. Frolov said he also received permission from the party leaders to set up a Pravda Association that could publish other newspapers, sell advertising and start new ventures to raise profits and offset Pravda's declining revenues. He said Pravda now makes a profit of about $18 million dollars a year, but probably would become unprofitable if its circulation slipped below 5 million copies. Given the current status of the subscription drive, it appears unlikely that Pravda will reach the 5 million level. But Frolov said he was confident it would continue to be published and have a sufficient circulation to ``remain a world-class newspaper.'' Pravda comes out seven days a week. Each issue is either six or eight pages long, with no advertising.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Destroying Geysers, Hot Springs at Yellowstone
DOC.TEXT: Vandals are destroying geysers and hot springs in Yellowstone National Park by throwing boulders, old shoes and other debris into the thermal channels, officials said Wednesday. Even the famous Old Faithful geyser has been hit. In the most recent case, someone earlier this month damaged the ``Rustic'' group of geysers near Heart Lake in the southern part of the park by clogging them with rocks and kicking in their conical rims. At least one of the geysers, the Rustic Geyser Vent, has been reduced to a trickle and may never erupt normally again, park officials say. ``It's just so senseless. There could have been no reason to do it except to just destroy the area and we have no idea why someone would want to do that,'' park spokeswoman Marsha Karle said. ``They are irreplaceable and priceless treasures.'' Since the park was created in 1872 the curious occasionally have tossed logs and rocks into geysers to watch the debris blow sky-high in the next eruption of steam and hot water from deep underground. Reports from the early days of Yellowstone tell of others who have even taken axes to some of the thermal features to chip mementos, and some people have carved their initials into the geyser cones of mineral deposits. ``For as long as people have been around, they've been throwing things into Old Faithful and other thermal features,'' Karle said. ``We've had trouble before with people throwing coins, small rocks, chicken bones, rifle shells, cigarette butts and bottles.'' Last May, a Billings, Mont., man was fined $525 for throwing a chemical into the ``Giantess'' geyser near Old Faithful. While the force of erupting geysers sometimes ejects the debris, Karle said some become so plugged they won't erupt again. Park rangers do their best to retrieve garbage from the vents, but most is too deep. ``Yellowstone's thermal features are fragile and easily damaged. Walking on them, carving or defacing them or removing souvenir pieces of formations destroys decades or centuries of intricate natural processes,'' Karle said. The roughly 10,000 geysers and hot springs that draw visitors to the nation's oldest national park ``take many, many years to build up and be created and just a few minutes for someone to destroy,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Imminent Decisions Could Signal Bush Intentions in Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush faces key decisions in the coming weeks that could signal whether he anticipates a lengthy standoff with Iraq's Saddam Hussein or wants American forces prepared to attack.
