Among the questions facing Bush: -Whether to add more troops and firepower to the U.S. deployment in the Mideast, now at 220,000 and scheduled to peak at 240,000 in three weeks. -Whether to withdraw some units that are not essential to defending Saudi Arabia, a decision which could serve to assuage growing public concern about the prospects of war without diminishing the force's defensive capabilities. -Approving a Pentagon troop rotation plan, now in the draft stages, that sources said should be ready for White House review in a week or so. -Whether to use his authority to extend 90-day Reserve call-ups for another 90 days. The U.S. deployment reached a symbolic juncture Wednesday with the arrival in Saudi Arabia of the final elements of the 11th Air Defense Brigade from Fort Bliss in Texas. It was the last combat unit scheduled for deployment in the region, Pentagon sources said. The only remaining troops scheduled to be sent to the area are in support units. They should all arrive in the next three weeks, bringing the total deployment to 240,000, said the sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ``As of now we're not planning for any additional buildup. We're planning to sustain the force that is present,'' one of the Pentagon sources said. But Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has discussed with ground commanders the possibility of changing the force size. He is due back from Saudi Arabia late Thursday. If Powell recommended, and Bush approved, adding to the force, Pentagon sources said the likely additions would be heavy armor units from the United States, Europe or both. Such orders also would necessitate sending several additional support units into the region as well, the sources said. ``That would ratchet up the pressure on Saddam and give the president the option of surprise if he decided to go on the offensive,'' one of the sources said. ``If a decision has been made to kick him out, then adding to the force first would make it more efficient in terms of loss of life.'' But, barring some development in the crisis that would prompt United Nations support for an offensive, Pentagon sources and military analysts think it far more likely that Bush will tinker with the force - but not dramatically, signaling continued resolve to allow economic sanctions against Iraq to take hold. ``We would have to double the force there to make an offensive palatable from a military standpoint,'' said Lawrence J. Korb, a former assistant defense secretary for manpower in the Reagan administration. ``I don't think that is very likely at all.'' By bringing some non-essential units home, Bush could ``show that we are prepared to stay there for the long haul'' as long as he articulated the reasons for the moves, Korb said. ``Saddam is waiting to see how long we can hold both the support of the American Congress and our U.N. coalition together. I'd set up a rotation plan but basically keep my troop level about where it is.'' If Powell recommends withdrawing forces, the sources said the 82nd Airborne Division, the first ground unit to reach Saudi Arabia, likely would be the first unit brought home. Such a move would not affect the defensive capability of the U.S.-led multinational forces, the sources said. But withdrawing the paratroopers ``would signal that we are going to hunker down and wait right along with Saddam,'' the source said. The withdrawal of even a few thousand troops from the Mideast could also help Bush, whom Korb said ``is obviously not as popular as he was when he started this.'' Said one of the Pentagon sources: ``We'd look good bringing some people home for Christmas, even if in the big scheme of things it didn't amount to much.'' At the same time, ``We have to be very careful about what kind of signal we send because perception is as important as reality in that part of the world and it's easy for things to get confused in translation,'' this Pentagon official said. ``Whether the decision is status quo, reduce or add, the White House is going to have to explain that and ensure that the diplomatic signals that are connected with the decisions are properly read by Saddam Hussein.'' The Pentagon sources said draft rotation plans call for six-month rotations for most units, which would mean the first large-scale substitutions beginning in February. Some units that are harder to replace ``may have to spend more time in country than we or they would like,'' one of the sources said. The sequence of the rotations is still under discussion, this source said. ``We know the soldiers and families are waiting with bated breath but there are some very complicated questions to be resolved.'' When heavy armor units are rotated, the Pentagon would have to decide whether to leave tanks and other equipment in Saudi Arabia or bring them home with the troops. Current thinking is to bring the equipment home, a huge logistical headache, because otherwise the troops would be unable to train at their bases for possible return to Saudi Arabia. Overall cutbacks in the military further complicate rotation planning. For example, the Army alone has to plan for 1.1 million moves in the next 12 months in a force numbering just over 700,000.

DOC.HEAD: US Deplores Violence, Meets With Syrian, Lebanese Leaders
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has put Syria on notice it has a ``special responsibility'' to curb violence in areas of Lebanon under Syrian control, the State Department said Wednesday. With the U.S. Embassy in Beirut closed, the United States is assessing blame for the mounting death toll since Gen. Michel Aoun, the last major Christian holdout, gave up his struggle against Syrian forces 11 days ago. The most recent prominent victim was Dany Chamoun, a Christian leader who also opposed Syrian influence. He, his wife and two small children were slain in their Beirut apartment last weekend. No one has claimed responsibility. ``We have seen the many press reports of atrocities carried out in East Beirut since the surrender of Gen. Aoun,'' Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said. ``We do not have firsthand knowledge which could confirm those reports. However, the reports themselves are enough to shock and horrify,'' The U.S. official added: ``if these reports are true, whoever is responsible the United States would condemn them in the strongest terms.'' The Bush administration had urged Aoun to end his resistance. Aoun has taken refuge in the French embassy. ``We have told the Syrians they have a special responsibility, given their control over parts of Lebanon, to ensure that such abuses do not take place in areas under their control,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, reading from a prepared statement. ``There is no ambiguity in the message we have sent to Syria on this point.'' Syria, which has influence over the Lebanese government headed by President Elias Hrawi, is a key Arab ally of the United States in its campaign against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Some 4,000 Syrian troops are in Saudi Arabia to help defend the kingdom against Iraqi attack. Ms. Tutwiler said Assistant Secretary of State John H. Kelly had met with Syrian Ambassador Walid al-Moualem here while Edward Djerejian, the U.S. ambassador to Syria, had met with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara in Damascus. Also, the spokeswoman said, Kelly met Tuesday and several times before then with the Lebanese ambassador, Nassib Lahoud.

DOC.HEAD: Polish President Vetoes Bill Allowing Sale of Land to Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: Wojciech Jaruzelski, using the veto for the first time since he became president, has rejected legislation that would have allowed foreigners to buy land in Poland from the state. The former Communist Party leader, who became president in July 1989 and will leave office after the Nov. 25 elections, generally has not used his presidential powers to block the Solidarity-led government's reforms. The land management law deeply divided Parliament. Many lawmakers fear Poland will be bought out by Western investors, particularly from neighboring Germany, who are attracted to the relatively low cost of Polish property. The state news agency PAP, which reported the veto, did not say what specific objections Jaruzelski raised. The Sejm, the lower house of Parliament, initially rejected allowing the purchase of state-owned land by foreigners. In late September, however, the Senate passed a version of the bill that permitted sales to non-Poles if approved by the Interior Ministry. That version was endorsed by the Sejm. Senators argued that Western investors would hesitate to establish badly needed new companies in Poland if they could not have the security of owning their own property. They also noted the anomaly that privately owned land can be sold to foreigners, but government-owned land cannot. Under the Communist government that ruled Poland from the end of World War II until last year, and in the economic upheaval that followed the Communists' dismissal, few Poles have accumulated enough capital to make large investments.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bomb Attacks Using `Collaborators' Leave Seven Dead
DOC.TEXT: The IRA killed at least seven people Wednesday in simultaneous attacks on two border checkpoints. The attackers forced alleged ``collaborators'' to drive bomb-laden cars at the targets. The dead were six soldiers and one civilian. Hospitals reported 35 other people injured, including two 9-month-old babies, in the pre-dawn explosions about 70 miles apart near Londonderry and Newry.Both checkpoints were on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. Patsy Gillespie, a man who was forced to drive to the Londonderry checkpoint while his family was held at gunpoint, was missing and feared dead. A body was discovered in that area at sunset. A third attack, on an army base in Omagh, failed when the bomb did not go off, police said. Police in the Irish Republic said five men were detained just across the border from the checkpoint near Londonderry where one bomb killed five soldiers. Another soldier was killed at the security checkpoint in Newry. The seven deaths brought to 16 the number of people killed so far this month in the British province's sectarian and political violence. The Irish Republican Army, whih is fighting to drive the British out of the province and unite it with the Irish Republic, claimed responsibility and said the men they forced to drive were ``collaborators'' who had performed construction work for the security forces. At Newry, the IRA took over a house, held the family at gunpoint and forced a 65-year-old man to drive a bomb to the checkpoint, police said. At the checkpoint, the man jumped out of the vehicle and shouted: ``There's a bomb in the van!'' but the device exploded before police, soldiers and the driver had time to get clear, police said. One of the man's legs was broken. In Londonderry, a sobbing Kathleen Gillespie told reporters that armed men broke into the house before midnight, took her 42-year-old husband away and released the rest of the family about four hours later. ``They assured me that nobody was going to come to any harm and that my husband would be back in half an hour,'' she said. ``I'm so angry, I'm so angry,'' she wept. ``This is the second time they've done this to me.'' She said armed men once commandeered her car, filled it with 300 pounds of explosives and made her husband drive it to a military installation. ``At least that time he came home,'' she said. She said her husband was not a construction worker but was employed by the Ministry of Defense doing odd jobs. The army said the five members of King's Regiment killed in the Londonderry attack were Lance Cpl. Stephen Burrows, 30 and Kingsmen Stephen Beacham, 20, Paul Worrall, 23, Vincent Scott, 21, and David Sweeney. Police identified the soldier slain at Newry as Pvt. Cyril Smith, 21, of the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Irish Rangers. Altnagelvin Hospital outside Londonderry admitted 13 men and 12 women wounded in the explosions, five in serious condition. A spokesman said 19 were released after treatment and two were to undergo surgery. Ten people were treated for minor injuries at Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry, said administrator Mervyn Ferris. In Dungannon, the body of Patrick Francis Hughes, 60, was found in a burned-out taxi, police said. A Protestant extremist group, the Protestant Action Force, has claimed it kidnapped a Dungannon driver in retaliation for the slaying of a Protestant driver outside a hospital in Belfast on Tuesday. Before Wednesday, eight people had died in sectarian and political violence this month, including an IRA member and an IRA supporter who were killed in an army ambush.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff's Deputy Shot Repeatedly Over Campaign Signs
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff's deputy was shot while hanging campaign posters in what authorities called a politically motivated attack. Irving Bell, 34, underwent surgery Tuesday after being shot in the back, abdomen and buttocks about 3 a.m. He was in critical condition. Police were questioning two individuals in the shooting, but no charges will be filed until the victim can be interviewed, said Deputy Chicago Police Supt. Edward Wodnicki. Wodnicki called the attack ``politically motivated,'' and added that the police investigation would be ``played right down the line.'' Bell and five other sheriff's department employees were posting signs for Democratic Alderman Michael Sheahan outside a South Side bar, said police Cmdr. Ronnie Watson. Sheahan is opposing Sheriff James O'Grady in O'Grady's re-election bid.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Feature Gingrich, Keating In Cloakroom Poster
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats have two new poster boys in their cloakroom off the House floor - Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia and indicted savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. ``What do these two men have in common?'' reads the caption on the large poster featuring photos of Gingrich and Keating. ``Nothing yet. It's payback time.'' Gingrich, whose intense partisanship has made him the Republican Democrats most love to hate, is described in a caption under his photo as ``the most corrupt minority whip in history.'' That's a takeoff on the phrase Gingrich used repeatedly in attacking former House Speaker Jim Wright, who resigned last year after an ethics investigation initiated by Gingrich. The poster also features the slogan: ``Make the 102nd (Congress) Newt Free.''
DOC.HEAD: Roberts Still Gaining on Frohnmayer
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Barbara Roberts has moved into a tie with Republican Dave Frohnmayer in the campaign for governor, according to a new poll. Forty-four percent of those surveyed said they planned to vote for Roberts, the secretary of state, while 40 percent said they would vote for Frohnmayer, the attorney general. The telephone poll of 608 registered voters has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points, meaning the race could be virtually even. It was conducted by TH Research for KATU-TV in Portland from Oct. 17 through last Sunday. Roberts has been consistently behind in the polls during the campaign.
DOC.HEAD: Symington Gains Ground in New Merrill Poll
DOC.TEXT: Republican Fife Symington has picked up ground in the governor's race but still trails Democrat Terry Goddard, according to a new poll. Goddard's lead over Symington was 40 percent to 30 percent, with 26 percent undecided, according to the poll conducted by Arizona State University pollster Bruce Merrill. The poll, conducted Oct. 21, consisted of telephone interviews with 600 voters statewide. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent. A Merill poll two weeks ago gave Goddard a 44 percent to 28 percent lead with 27 percent undecided.
DOC.HEAD: Bulger, Talk Show Host Fight Over Announcements
DOC.TEXT: State Senate President William Bulger's re-election campaign warned that broadcasters face a year in jail for announcing candidates' rallies, but talk show host Gene Burns says he isn't intimidated. Burns mentioned anti-incumbent speeches and rallies he plans to attend, including a `Beat Billy Bulger' rally at the Statehouse Saturday. Burns then got a letter containing the jail warning from Bulger's son, William M. Bulger Jr., a lawyer and manager of his father's campaign. ``It was a ham-handed attempt to try to shut me down, and it won't work,'' Burns said. ``Our attorneys checked with state campaign finance officials and told us we're within the law.'' Burns works for Boston station WRKO.
DOC.HEAD: Ford Challenger Boasts of Lack of Tattoos
DOC.TEXT: An absence of tattoos is just one of the reasons candidate Thomas Davidson says voters should select him for Congress over veteran incumbent Harold Ford. Other campaign strengths, in Davidson's view, include a fondness for the movie ``Mr. Smith Goes To Washington'' and a claim he has figured out who killed Laura Palmer on the TV show ``Twin Peaks.'' ``If I get elected, I'll tell,'' said Davidson, an independent candidate. ``That's one of my promises.'' Ford, a Memphis Democrat, is heavily favored to win a ninth term. In voting Nov. 6, he faces Davidson; fellow independent Issac Richmond, a perennial candidate, and Republican Aaron Davis, a 79-year-old political newcomer. With his first printing of a political handout, Davidson issued a list of reasons why the voters should send him to Congress. He proposes selling Texas to Japan to cover savings and loan losses, promises to support legislation making bingo the national pastime and pledges to persuade TV talk show host David Letterman to move to Memphis. Davidson, 48, owns a carpet-cleaning company and is making his first run for public office. Printing the handout cost $22, which cut heavily into his campaign budget of $27, Davidson said.
DOC.HEAD: Poll: Wellstone Gains Ground On Boschwitz
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Paul Wellstone has pulled virtually even with incumbent Rudy Boschwitz in their race for the U.S. Senate, according to a new poll. Forty-five percent of the 601 likely voters polled Oct. 19-21 prefer Wellstone, while 48 percent favor Boschwitz, according to the Star Tribune-KSTP-TV Minnesota Poll. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points, meaning the race could be deadlocked. Wellstone, a political science professor at Carleton College, has closed the margin by 15 percentage points since the Minnesota Poll last measured the two candidates less than two weeks ago. In an Oct. 8-14 poll, Republican Boschwitz was the choice of likely voters by a margin of 56 percent to 38 percent.

DOC.HEAD: To Bush, The Veto Threat Is a Big Club
With AM-Civil Rights, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's unbroken string ofsuccessful vetoes is built largely around a strategy of using the veto as a club to force concessions from Congress, say White House officials and political analysts. Bush kept his record intact Wednesday when the Senate, by a one-vote margin, upheld his veto of a major civil rights bill. The White House hailed the vote and prodded Congress anew to enact Bush's version of the bill. Bush has issued 16 vetoes; all have been sustained in the Democratic-controlled Congress. Over the last three decades, only Gerald R. Ford issued vetoes more frequently - and a quarter of his were overridden. Bush uses the power of the veto differently from many presidents, who employed the veto simply to kill unwanted legislation and bills they deemed unconstitutional. In large measure, Bush uses vetoes to force compromises from Congress. It is a tactic that makes the White House a player at the bargaining table as bills move through the House and Senate. ``He has wielded the veto much less as a public relations weapon, much more as a quiet instrument of influence in the Congress,'' said American Enterprise Institute analyst Norman Ornstein. ``Richard Nixon often used to veto bills at press conferences, making a statement as much as anything else,'' Ornstein said. ``George Bush does it in a much more understated way.'' In dealing with lawmakers, Bush has a big problem. He has the smallest share of his own party members in Congress of any newly elected president in history. With such a divided government, Bush does not have the clout to push a legislative program through Congress. Yet, there is enough GOP strength to sustain his vetoes when Republicans stick together. ``When you have two houses against you, you have no leverage, the odds are heavy against you,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``So you've got to use a sledgehammer going in that says, `We won't accept this.''' In his day, Ronald Reagan coyly refused to say whether he would veto a bill. Bush does it all the time, while also carefully spelling out options to make a bill acceptable. ``You try to get as much change as you can before a bill is passed,'' Fitzwater said. ``So by signaling early that you're going to veto, you tell them they need to seriously consider compromise.'' Bush established the pattern with his very first veto. Democrats wanted to raise the minimum hourly wage to $4.55 over three years. Bush said that was excessive and threatened a veto. Congress approved the increase anyway and Bush rejected the bill. When he was sustained, lawmakers and the White House struck a compromise. Tom Cronin, a political scientist at Stanford University, said the president is using his vetoes ``quite intelligently.'' ``He doesn't try to use the veto in a mean-spirited way. He just sees it as an instrument to try to get people back to the bargaining table,'' Cronin said. Bush vetoed three appropriations bill to force the deletion of abortion financing from otherwise acceptable measures. Three other measures, including one dealing with Chinese students, were rejected to prevent what he viewed as an erosion of presidential authority. Most recently, Bush vetoed a short-term spending resolution and partially shut down the government to force progress on deficit-reduction negotiations. Monday's veto of the civil rights legislation came only after months of negotiations between the White House and Congress. The president coupled his veto with a copy of a civil rights bill he would sign, but civil rights advocates denounced it as a sham. Democrats routinely decry Bush's vetoes but they haven't been able to stop him. Early in the adiinistration, there was an understanding among Bush, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., Fitzwater said. ``They agreed that the only way they would have any clout in the Congress is if, when it was called for, they could hang together,'' the spokesman said. ``Basically, on most of these vetoes we've been able to hold together. It gets more dicey when you can't hold all your Republicans. You've got to try to pick up some Democrats.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Confirms High-Level Delegation Going to Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican confirmed Wednesday that Vietnam has agreed to a visit by a high-level delegation next month for talks on church-state relations in the communist country. The delegation will be led by Cardinal Roger Etchegaray of France, who heads the Vatican's Justice and Peace Commission, and include two of the Vatican's Asian experts. The visit, sought for some time by the Vatican, was first reported Tuesday by Vietnam's official news agency. The Vatican said the delegation will leave on Nov. 6. The invitation by the Hanoi government is considered a major step forward in Vatican-Vietnamese relations. While restrictions on Roman Catholics and members of other religions have eased in recent years, Vatican officials say a number of issues must be resolved. They include the appointment of archbishops for vacant posts in Hanoi, Hue and Ho Chi Minh City. There are about 4 million to 5 million Catholics among Vietnam's largely Buddhist population of 63 million. Last year, Cardinal Etchegaray made the first official visit by a Vatican representative to Vietnam since the 1975 communist takeover. He returned in May for the funeral of the archbishop of Hanoi.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of major legislation and issues yet to be resolved as Congress heads toward adjournment of the 101st session:
DOC.HEAD: BUDGET PACKAGE
DOC.TEXT: Democratic and Republican budget figures continue negotiating a deficit-reduction agreement that can pass the House and Senate and be acceptable to President Bush. The achievement of this package of tax increases and spending cuts is the top priority of lawmakers trying to return to their districts for the national elections Nov. 6.
DOC.HEAD: APPROPRIATIONS BILLS
DOC.TEXT: The Congress must complete action on 13 annual appropriations bills before adjournment, and each chamber continues to work on the various spending measures. On Wednesday, the Senate passed a $15.5 billion foreign aid appropriations bill and sent it to a House-Senate conference.
DOC.HEAD: CLEAN AIR
DOC.TEXT: Backers of a wide-ranging clean-air bill are pushing to get final congressional approval before adjournment. The measure seemed likely to arrive on the House and Senate floors no later than Friday.
DOC.HEAD: CHILD CARE
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of legislation providing new government assistance to Americans with child care needs have said they want to get the bill passed before Congress leaves town. But members of the House have problems with a version of the legislation worked out by Senate leaders and administration figures.
DOC.HEAD: CRIME BILL
DOC.TEXT: Wide-ranging anti-crime legislation that would establish new categories of federal offenses for which the death penalty could be applied is awaiting clearance by a conference of House and Senate members.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Bombs Suspected PLO Bases in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: In a rare night attack, Israeli warplanes on Wednesday bombed a suspected PLO missile base in response to artillery attacks in Israel and its self-proclaimed ``security zone,'' reports said. No casualty figures were immediately given by the Palestine Liberation Organization or Israeli military following the 20-minute assault around the Rashidiyeh refugee camp near the southern port of Tyre. A PLO communique said four aircraft dropped bombs and strafed positions manned by guerrillas from Fatah, the PLO's mainstream faction headed by Yaser Arafat. It was the first Israel air raid into Lebanon since July 9 and the 15th this year. Israeli officials say they have attempted to avoid attacks in Lebanon since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It was also the first attack since Syria, a longtime Israeli foe, expanded its control in Lebanon by helping government troops oust rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun almost two weeks ago. In Israel, the military command claimed the target was ``a terrorist launching pad'' for Soviet-made Katyusha rockets fired into Israel the past two weeks. The last of the rocket attacks was Oct. 16 when a barrage landed in northern Israel, causing no damage or injuries. Five days earlier, six rockets landed inside Israel's security zone in south Lebanon, according to Israeli reports. Rashidiyh is about 50 miles south of Beirut and 10 miles north of the Israeli border. Israel carved out the 440-square-mile security zone in 1985 during the withdrawal the bulk of its army from south Lebanon following a three-year occupation of the region. Previous Israeli air raids have killed 20 people and wounded 62, police said. Israel's air force usually strikes in daytime, but helicopter gunships often range into Lebanon during night to rout guerrillas. Earlier Wednesday, the Lebanese police said Israeli-affiliated militiamen killed two guerrillas of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, in a south Lebanon firefight. But the Israeli army said members of an elite paratrooper brigade, not militiamen of the South Lebanon Army, killed the guerrillas. A Lebanese police spokesman, who cannot be named under regulations, said three other fighters of the Shiite Moslem Hezbollah were wounded in the clash near the village of Kfar Houneh. The battle occurred 15 miles north of the Israeli border, which is deeper into Lebanon than normal for Israeli troops seeking guerrillas. The Lebanese police spokesman said South Lebanon Army gunners later pounded the area around Kfar Houneh and Hezbollah-controlled villages of Mashghara and Maidoun. Hezbollah returned fire with salvoes of Katyusha rockets, he added. He said a casualty report on the missile exchange was not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Sets Side-Impact Crash Protection Rule
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner on Wednesday announced new standards to protect car occupants during side-impact collisions, saying the regulation would prevent 500 deaths a year. The action ends more than a decade of haggling over how manufacturers should reinforce cars to help riders withstand side collisions. More people die that way than in any other kind of automobile wreck except frontal collisions. ``It's been a long time coming,'' Skinner said at a news conference outside the Capitol. He stood near a demonstration car with its driver's side crushed inward and a crash dummy seated behind the wheel in a graphic illustration of the danger of side collisions. Manufacturers must meet the new standards in 10 percent of their new cars by 1994.es to 25 percent in the 1995 mod The minimum risel year and 40 percent in 1996. By the 1997 model year, all new cars must comply. The changes will boost the average car's cost by about $50, ``a small price to pay for the prevention of the immense loss of life and suffering as a result of these side impacts,'' Skinner said. The regulation is designed to reduce deaths and serious injuries caused by chest and pelvic injuries. About 8,000 people die and 24,000 are hurt seriously each year in side crashes. Rance Institute for Highway Safety said the regulation was ``a long-overdue first step'' but was inadequate because it excludes protections from head injuries. ``A substantial proportion of the most serious injuries that occur in side impacts are head injuries,'' said Brian O'Neill, the group's president.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Editors and 3 Others Are Honored
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by soure.
DOC.TEXT: The editors of a weekly newspaper for Haitians in Miami were among the five winners announced Wednesday of the annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for journalism that advances inter-American understanding. The editors, Marc ``Marcus'' Garcia and Elsie Etheart, are the first Haitians to be awarded gold medals in the 52-year history of the prizes. They founded the French- and Creole-language Haiti En Marche in 1986 and also produce Creole radio news programs in southern Florida. Other winners, to be honored in ceremonies at Columbia University on Thursday night, were Richard Boudreaux, Los Angeles Times bureau chief in Managua, Nicaragua; Alma Guillermoprieto, Latin America correspondent for the New Yorker magazine and other publications, and Huascar Cajias Kauffmann, founder and columnist of Presencia, a daily newspaper in La Paz, Bolivia. The Cabot prizes, a gold medal and $1,000 to each winner, were established by Godfrey Lowell Cabot of Boston as a memorial to his wife. They are awarded by the trustees of Columbia on the recommendation of the university's School of Journalism. Garcia and Etheart, radio journalists in Haiti in the 1970s, were arrested and jailed in 1980 for reporting on the activities of the secret police. They were expelled as subversives by dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier. Their newspaper in Miami is read in Canada and Haiti and their news broadcasts reach nearly all the 120,000 Haitians in south Florida. Boudreaux, 42, has been a reporter 20 years. He worked for The Associated Press for 16 years in New York, Argentina, Mexico, Chile and Bolivia before joining the Los Angeles Times. Guillermoprieto, 41, a dancer before embarking on journalism, performed with the Ballet Nacional de Mexico in her native land and with Harry Sheppard, Elaine Shipman and Twyla Tharp. She began reporting in 1978, as a Central American stringer for Latin American Newsletters, The Guardian of London and The Washington Post. She was Newsweek's South American bureau chief from 1986 to 1987 and has written a book, ``Samba,'' about Brazil in addition to contributing long pieces to the New Yorker. Cajias, a champion of press freedom in Bolivia, founded Presencia in 1952 and edited it until four years ago. He also is a lawyer and has been a professor of both criminology and journalism in La Paz. He was his country's ambassador to the Vatican from 1986 until last year and served as a delegate at international gatherings in Vienna to discuss ways to combat drug trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Attend Chamoun Burial; Lebanon Tries to Disband Militias
DOC.TEXT: DEIR AL-KAMAR, Lebanon (AP) - Thousands of people, many holding red carnations, attended the funeral Wednesday of slain Christian leader Dany Chamoun, his wife and two young sons as they were buried in his hometown. In Beirut, meanwhile, President Elias Hrawi's government held talks with militia leaders about withdrawing their forces from the city under a peace plan aimed at ending Lebanon's 15-year civil war. Chamoun, 56, and his family were gunned down at their apartment in Beirut's eastern suburb of Baabda on Sunday. No group has claimed responsibility for the slayings, which were branded by both Christian and Moslem leaders as an attempt to derail the peace efforts. Chamoun, leader of the right-wing Christian National Liberal Party, was a staunch ally of defeated rebel Gen. Michel Aoun. His murder occured eight days after Syrian and Lebanese troops crushed Aoun's 11-month mutiny in an eight-hour assault that left 550 dead and more than 1,200 wounded. Aoun has taken refuge in the French Embassy. He had opposed the peace plan because it provided no timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops, 40,000 of whom are deployed in Lebanon. On Wednesday, black flags fluttered above the stone houses of the ancient mountain town of Deir Al-Kamar, southeast of Beirut, as the four coffins were driven to the cemetery after a four-hour service. Chamoun, his wife Ingrid and their two sons, Tarek, 7, and Julien, 5, were buried next to the tomb of his father, former president Camille Chamoun. The elder Chamoun died a natural death in August 1987. Mourners were frisked by heavily armed Druse militiamen of Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party, who control Deir Al-Kamar. ``Lebanon has lost a promise of peace,'' an elderly woman sobbed at the funeral. ``May God give us strength to end this horrible war once and for all.'' In Beirut, the government issued a statement saying it intended to ``spread state authority'' over the capital and its environs in line with a peace plan endorsed by parliament Aug. 22. It did not set a deadline for carrying out the plan to create a militia-free ``greater Beirut.'' ``The army would be in charge of all streets and government utilities. All militia offices and centers would be closed,'' said the statement, which was issued after a three-hour meeting chaired by Hrawi. Greater Beirut extends along a 15-mile coastal strip and covers the city's eastern and southeastern suburbs. A government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said efforts to withdraw militias from the capital and its environs were ``now on a hot burner.'' The development followed a visit to Beirut on Tuesday by Syrian Vice President Abdul-Halim Khaddam, the Syrian army chief of staff, and the chief of the army's military intelligence in Lebanon. The government source said a two-man government committee handling talks with militia leaders was instructed to ``work out the mechanism for the militia withdrawal from greater Beirut.'' For years, Moslem and Christian militias have battled for control of the region. The source said the militia leaders ``did not register any serious rejection of the greater Beirut plan,'' adding that it might be implemented as early as next week. ``All the militias realize that if they don't withdraw peacefully, the example of crushing rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's mutiny would be repeated,'' the government source said. Meanwhile, police said the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, withdrew from positions on the former Green Line along the eastern edge of south Beirut and handed them over to Hrawi's army. A police spokesman said Hezbollah maintained its stronghold in the south Beirut slums of Bir Abed, Hay Madi and Moawad. Other militias that maintain strongholds within the area are the right-wing Christian Lebanese forces of Samir Geagea, the mainstream Shiite Amal Movement of Nabih Berri and Jumblatt's Druse militia.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Criticizes U.S. Aid to Israel
With AM-Israel-Arabs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syria on Wednesday accused the United States of encouraging aggression by providing arms and money to Israel. It was the first time the government has criticized the United States since the two nations joined in the multinational military buildup to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Syria's criticism, while not jeopardizing the alliance, underscores its fragility. In making the criticism, Syria was reacting to a U.S. announcement this month that it was providing Israel with anti-missile Patriot missiles. Syrian officials are also apparently angry over reports that U.S. officials had delayed a new U.N. resolution to condemn Israel for the killing of 19 Palestinians by security forces this month. In Wednesday's remarks, the government also called on Arabs to ``thoroughly'' discuss U.S. aid to Israel. It did not make a specific proposal but called for ``appropriate action'' by Arabs in response. The criticism came in the official Syrian Arab News Agency, which said it was quoting an ``authoritative source.'' Such commentaries are usually made by a ranking member of the Syrian goverment or the ruling Baath Party, reflecting official stance. Syria has committed up to 15,000 troops to the multinational military buildup in the Persian Gulf. It was the first time that the United States and Syria, a spearhead of Arab radicalism, agreed on a Middle East conflict in nearly 20 years. ``Everyday, the U.S. comes up with a new kind of support to extend to Israel. Only very recently it decided to provide Israel with Patriot missiles and new ammunitions,'' the source was quoted Wednesday as saying. Earlier this month, U.S. officials announced they were providing two batteries of Patriot missiles to Israel on an emergency basis. Wednesday's commentary also complained of U.S. aid to build housing for Jewish immigrants. The source was quoted as saying that U.S. aid to Israel ``cannot achieve peace, nor can it be aimed at achieving peace. Rather, it strengthens aggression and occupation, and encourages invasion and expansion.''

DOC.HEAD: Largest Collection of AIDS Tests Yet Shows Most Infection Rates Low
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials' largest collection yet of AIDS test surveys shows the nation's AIDS infection rates are highest at drug treatment clinics and lowest at blood donor centers. The Centers for Disease Control on Thursday will publish the results of AIDS virus test surveys from a variety of settings nationwide: health clinics, hospitals, the Job Corps, the military and other places where large numbers of blood samples could be analyzed. The separate surveys were considered in the absence of a nationwide survey for infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. ``Overall, the survey data indicated the widespread yet extremely varied distribution of HIV,'' the CDC reported. ``By far, the highest prevalence rates were found among persons known to be at risk'' - specifically, gay and bisexual men and users of intravenous drugs. Of nearly 150,000 AIDS cases reported in the United States, 59 percent have occurred among gay or bisexual males and 21 percent were among IV drug abusers. An additional 7 percent of AIDS patients fell into both categories and were counted separately. The HIV prevalence surveys involved testing blood samples collected as far back as 1986. Settings ranged from military recruitment centers to large urban hospitals to American Red Cross blood donation centers. HIV infection rates in all categories were relatively low; the worst was a median of 4.1 percent among clients at 54 drug treatment centers - where, by definition, many are at high risk for AIDS. Federal health officials estimate that between 1 million and 1.5 million Americans are infected with HIV, for an estimated national rate of about 0.05 percent. One survey found the infection rate quite high in one separate classification. ``High ... prevalences were observed among homosexual and bisexual men in all geographic regions,'' the CDC reported. At 103 sexually-transmitted-disease clinics surveyed across the country, infection rates among gay and bisexual patients ranged from 15 percent in two Salt Lake City clinics to 64 percent in two Newark, N.J., clinics, with a median of 36 percent. Generally, infection rates were higher for men than women and for the Northeastern and Southern states. More of the surveys' findings: - Among about 4 million American Red Cross blood donors in the second half of 1989, the infection rate was 0.0084 percent, or about 8 in 100,000. That indicates not just a low number of infected people giving blood but also the removal of infected donors from the repeat donation list. - Among nearly 2.5 million applicants for military service, the infection rate was 0.12 percent, or 12 of 10,000. The low rate is not necessarily surprising, as homosexuals and drug users are unwelcome in the military. - Among 1.2 million childbearing women, the estimated national infection rate was 0.15 percent - 15 of 10,000. - At 39 large, urban, acute-care hospitals where patients' blood samples were analyzed, the median infection rate was 0.7 percent, or 7 in 1,000. There was, however, a 70-fold variation among individual hospitals, which ranged from 0.1 percent to 6.9 percent. Rates were five times higher for men than women - 1.5 percent to 0.3 percent - and somewhat higher for blacks, 1 percent, than for whites or Hispanics, 0.7 percent. - In about 100,000 blood samples annually at a large diagnostic laboratory, the HIV infection rate was 0.89 percent, or about 9 in 1,000. - Among an annual 60,000 Job Corps entrants - most of them disadvantaged young people - the infection rate was 0.36 percent, or about 4 in 1,000. - At the 103 sexually transmitted disease clinics, the median infection rate for 205,000 patients was 2.2 percent. - At 187 women's health clinics, the median infection rate for 156,000 patients was 0.2 percent, or 2 out of 1,000. - In 20 metropolitan tuberculosis clinics, the median infection rate was 3.4 percent. TB is a frequent complication of HIV infection.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Pulls `Hull High' From Its Schedule
DOC.TEXT: NBC has canceled the new series ``Hull High,'' a high school-based musical that critics liked and audiences didn't, network officials said Wednesday. The last episode of the hour-long show aired Sunday night. According to season-to-date ratings from the A.C. Nielsen Co., ``Hull High'' ranked 84th, the lowest among Big Three network shows, with a 5.9 rating and a 10 share. A rating point equals 931,000 TV households. A share is the percentage of television sets in use that are tuned to the show. All told, the series pilot and three episodes aired. On Oct. 29 the medical drama ``Lifestories,'' followed by ``Sunday Night with Larry King'' will air in the time period. On Nov. 4, NBC will broadcast its documentary series ``The Story Behind the Story'' in the time period.

DOC.HEAD: `Roseanne' Enters Syndication for 1992
DOC.TEXT: ``Roseanne,'' the top-rated ABC situation comedy starring comedian Roseanne Barr and John Goodman, is being launched into syndication for 1992. ``No other series available today comes close to having the impact of `Roseanne,''' Dennis K. Gillespie, a Viacom Enterprises executive, said Wednesdasy. ``We know it can be a dominant and enduring cornerstone of any station schedule.'' Viacom will license the sitcom for a 4{-year term, with 1 year of weekly broadcast and 3{ years of weekday ``stripping.'' The series will be offered market-by-market, with first presentations in New York and Los Angeles. New York City-based Viacom Enterprises is one of the leading independent distributors of TV programming.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Condemned by UNESCO Executive Council
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: UNESCO's executive council Wednesday voted 38-1 to condemn Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait for violating human rights and trying to wipe out the national culture. Iraq cast the only dissenting vote. The council asked Director-General Federico Mayor to send an envoy to Kuwait to investigate the condition of threatened cultural, scientific and educational institutions. Kuwait's chief delegate, Faisal Al Salem, testified that Iraq had destroyed schools, pillaged museums and stolen archives since the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraq's delegate, Aziz Al Hajj Ali Haidar, described the allegations as lies or rumors, and protested the ``politicization'' of UNESCO. He said items had been moved from museums to be stored safely in the event of bombardments. The resolution adopted by the council expressed concern for ``the painful losses suffered by the Kuwaiti people ... particularly those which concern the disruption of education, deliberate damage to scientific and cultural institutions, and the annihilation of the Kuwaiti people's national cultural identity.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Said to Make Nuclear Test in Barents Sea
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union carried out a nuclear test Wednesday at islands in the Barents Sea, despite protests from Norway and environmental groups, a seismic institute reported. The blast at the Novaya Zemlya test site had a yield of 20 kilotons to 90 kilotons, the Swedish Hagfors observatory said in a telexed statement. A kiloton has the explosive force of 1,000 tons of TNT. The atomic bomb dropped Aug. 6, 1945, on Hiroshima, Japan, had a force of 13 kilotons. Wednesday's reported blast was apparently set off in underground rock. The islands are about 370 miles from Norwegian territory. ``We strongly disapprove of what the neighboring state now has done,'' Norway's Prime Minister Jan P. Syse was quoting as saying of the Soviet Union. His remarks were carried in the Norwegian national news agency NTB. ``We are very disappointed over the blast and that the Soviet Union has not listened to the many protests,'' Syse was quoted as saying. Two environmental groups, Greenpeace and Bellona, had said the Soviets planned to resume tests at the ecologically sensitive site after a 2-year interruption. The islands were a primary Soviet nuclear test site from 1958-1963. In September and earlier this month, the environmental groups sent ships towards the islands in protest. Both ships were intercepted by Soviet coast guard vessels.

Two women who went public with the stories of their rapes returned to the courtroom on Wednesday for closing arguments in the fourth trial of the man they say attacked them almost decade ago. Sue Kremelberg and Susan Sweetser took the unusual step of identifying themselves publicly as rape victims earlier this year because they were angry at how long it took their cases to go through the court system. The women were raped in 1981. ``I want people to know the outrage,'' Ms. Kremelberg, a resident of Morristown, said recently. Robert Percy, of Elmore, Vt., is accused of raping Ms. Kremelberg while out on bail after raping Ms. Sweetser, an attorney from Essex, just weeks earlier. In both cases, a lower court convicted Percy of raping the women. In both cases, the Vermont Supreme Court sent the cases back for retrial. The state's highest court recently upheld Percy's second conviction in the Sweetser case. Vermont Attorney General Jeffrey Amestoy wrote a note to Ms. Sweetser the day the court upheld the conviction. ``Nine years late,'' he wrote. ``May my daughters have your courage and may they have a fairer and faster criminal justice system.'' Percy does not deny raping Ms. Kremelberg. But he says he was insane at the time, suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and reliving a Vietnam War flashback. On Wednesday, closing arguments in the case were heard in Windsor District Court in the second trial on her attack. Defense attorney James Dumont pointed to psychiatrists' testimony, which he said showed Percy was ``wounded in the brain'' by his Vietnam experience. ``These are fusions, mixtures of nightmares and reality,'' Dumont said. ``He was in one world and she was in another.'' But prosecutor Phillip Cykon said in his closing argument that Percy was in control of his actions during the attack. ``The defendant was acting in a way that was his continuing anti-social behavior. They were the actions of a defendant who was in control,'' Cykon told jurors. ``The Vietnam War is not on trial here,'' Cykon added. ``Post-tramatic stress disorder alone is not enough to excuse criminal behavior.'' Last week, Ms. Kremelberg recounted for the jury her nine-hour ordeal the night of Jan. 16, 1981. That evening, her stop for diapers for her baby son and gasoline for her car brought her in contact with Percy, an attendant at the Mansfield Garage in Stowe. Her voice calm, but at times in tears, Ms. Kremelberg testified that Percy told her to back her car to the air pump, located in a darker section of the station, because her left tire looked low. Once at the pump, she said Percy jumped into her car. ``I said, `What is this, a joke? Get out of my car. I have to get home to my husband and baby.' And he said, `Lady, shut up and drive,' '' she said. ``At that point, he pulled a gun out, and I was so scared I just drove.'' Ms. Kremelberg said Percy tied her hands behind her back with tape, blindfolded her and raped her. After driving to Connecticut, he raped her again. Before that assault, she said she struggled for the gun and told Percy, ``I'd rather be dead than do this again.'' Ms. Kremelberg escaped in Brookfield, Conn., and police there arrested Percy. Percy was convicted of the rape in 1982. But the state Supreme Court reversed the decision, giving Percy a new trial.

DOC.HEAD: Wet In The Northeast, Winter-like In Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Wet weather was widely scattered over the eastern half of the nation Wednesday, with snow on part of Lake Superior's Michigan shore, and some rivers in the Northeast ran high after a night of heavy rain. Afternoon showers were scattered from southwestern Missouri across northeastern Missouri into west-central illinois, over northern Maine, east-central Florida, eastern Ohio and northwestern Pennsylvania. Snow, rain and rain mixed with snow were scattered over western Upper Michigan, which sits against the shore of chilly Lake Superior. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.36 inches at Caribou, Maine; 1.29 inches at Limestone, Maine; 1.25 inches at Bangor, Maine; 1.17 inches at Houlton, Maine; and 0.91 of an inch at Mount Washington, N.H., the National Weather Service said. Levels of small streams fell in the Northeast as water from heavy rain Tuesday and during the night drained into larger rivers, which were rising. Flood warnings were posted for some streams in eastern New York state. The arctic coast of Alaska had blizzard conditions as wind near 35 mph with stronger gusts caused blowing and drifting snow along with uncomfortably low wind chills. Deep drifts closed some roads in the Barrow area, the weather service said. On the opposite corner of the continent, Miami warmed to a record high of 90 degrees. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 16 in Wyoming at Douglas and Yellowstone National Park. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 34 at Ironwood, Mich., to 97 at Oceanside, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Ms. Bhutto Makes Political Comeback Amid Ruins of Her Party
With AM-Pakistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Before marking her ballot Wednesday morning, Benazir Bhutto visited the grave of her father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown in a 1977 coup and hanged two years later. But it was later in the day that the 37-year-old ousted prime minister choked back tears, accusing the government of rigging her party's overwhelming defeat. ``This election is a fraud,'' said Ms. Bhutto, who apparently won one of her two races for a National Assembly seat. Ms. Bhutto, the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation, also faces corruption charges in which she could be jailed and banned from politics if convicted. Her husband, businessman Asif Ali Zardari, is jailed on kidnapping and extortion charges. Early results showed the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance with a strong lead over Ms. Bhutto's populist, center-left Pakistan People's Party in races for 214 National Assembly seats. Reports also indicated her party trailing badly in all four provinces, especially Punjab, the most populous province and the major battleground of the election. She had earlier predicted her party would win up to 120 seats in the assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minister. Ms. Bhutto singled out President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who led her Aug. 6 dismissal on charges of corruption, nepotism and incompetence. ``He has shown his partiality. He is not the president of Pakistan,'' she said at her sprawling family home in Larkana, about 500 miles southwest of the capital of Islamabad. She claimed the 73-year-old president advanced the campaign of her opponents. ``The president has made a mockery of the elections,'' she said. Ms. Bhutto predicted she and her husband will be the subject of a ``witch hunt'' following the elections. Ms. Bhutto's opponents portrayed her 20-month government as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history and said the elections displayed the peoples' anger. Since her dismissal three months ago, Ms. Bhutto had repeatedly compared her sacking to her father's overthrow. After her father's death, Ms. Bhutto, the eldest of four children, was jailed and placed under house arrest. She eventually fled to self-imposed exile in Britain. Groomed for politics by her father, Ms. Bhutto returned to Pakistan in 1986 promising to drown military dictator Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a tide of support from the country's poor and downtrodden. For days, millions of people cloggged streets for a glimpse of Ms. Bhutto. The nation's first free elections in 11 years were held after Zia died in a mysterious plane crash in 1988 that also killed several top Pakistani generals and U.S. Ambassador Arnold Raphael. Her party captured the largest bloc of votes with 93 assembly seats, but failed to win a majority. Even supporters say Ms. Bhutto struggled unsuccessively to make the transition from the oppressed champion of democracy to the leader of 110 million people, most of whom are illiterate and earn less than $400 a year. Several analysts say her downfall was accelerated by her political inexperience and what her detractors have called the ``arrogance of the Bhuttos.'' She faces seven charges of misconduct and abuse of power before special one-judge tribunals set up by the president. Conviction on any of the charges could deny Ms. Bhutto a seat in Parliament and banish her from politics for seven years. Ms. Bhutto's husband faces charges of kidnapping a Pakistan-born Briton and extorting $800,000. He has denied the charges, claiming they were orchestrated by the government.

DOC.HEAD: USSR Defense Chief: NATO as Military Organization Must Go
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet military chief of staff, saying the Warsaw Pact ``threatens no one in the East or West,'' called Wednesday for the dissolution of NATO as a military organization. ``We need to see a willingness to create a common security structure'' for Europe, Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev told a gathering of 400 Belgian army, navy and air force officers. ``Military organizations must cease to exist.'' Noting the Soviet Union will withdraw its troops from all Eastern European allies by 1994, Moiseyev said: ``There will no longer be a Warsaw Pact as a military organization. ``What remains is NATO. What is the purpose of the Atlantic alliance?'' Moiseyev said, in an address at the Higher Royal Defense Institute. Moiseyev expressed concern that the Western European Union, a defense group of nine European NATO members, was being positioned to supplant NATO. What is needed is a pan-European group that ensures the security of East Europeans, he said. Moiseyev was to address a meeting of the chiefs of staff of the 16 NATO nations Thursday, and Friday meet with U.S. Gen. John Galvin, the current NATO military commander. The new Soviet defense doctrine ``relies on the use of force only as a last resort. The Warsaw Pact threatens no one in the East or the West,'' he said, in comments translated into French by an interpreter. Moiseyev said all Soviet troops will be removed from Czechoslovakia and Hungary by 1991 and from Poland and Germany three years later. The Soviet Union's defense will be organized within its own boundaries only, he said. Moscow plans to reduce the military draft, he said. The Navy will begin creating a partly volunteer force in 1993 and reduce the period of obligatory military service from three years to two. ``I do not exclude that the draft for the other services will be cut from two years to one,'' he added. The Warsaw Pact and NATO have agreed on a conventional arms agreement, to be signed next month, involving deep cuts in battle tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles and combat helicopters across Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Chances Evaporate for Seafood-Inspection Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House virtually eliminated any chance of fish inspection becoming federal law this year by approving a bill Wednesday that sharply contrasts with companion legislation passed by the Senate. ``We don't have time for a conference,'' said Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, who tried unsuccessfully to win House approval of a measure similar to the Senate's. ``The bill is dead,'' said a Senate aide. ``The president's veto threat killed it.'' No one questioned the need for inspection. With seafood consumption up and about 60,000 people becoming ill in one year from eating fish, even the industry wanted it. The problem was who should do the inspection. Members from the Agriculture Committee insisted that it belonged with the Agriculture Department, which inspects meat and poultry. Members of the Commerce Committee and the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, which oversee the federal agencies related to the fishing industry, said the farm concerns didn't know enough about fish. ``We're arguing about rules and turf fights,'' said Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., a member of the agriculture committee trying to win the inspection program for USDA. ``Or what should be surf and turf fights in this particular instance.'' But Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., chairman of the Merchant Marine subcommittee on fisheries, said the agriculture committee's bill failed to recognize that shellfish are the main cause of illness related to eating seafood. He and Commerce Committee Chairman John Dingell, D-Mich., argued successfully that the FDA's current fish-inspection program, which concentrates on shellfish, should be expanded rather than moving the process to USDA. Dingell said he had a letter from Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, Health and Human Service Louis Sullivan and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu saying they would recommend a veto if the Dingell-Studds plan was not adopted. The House approved the plan by a vote of 277-153 when it was submitted as a substitute for de la Garza's bill. ``The issue is not whether we want to inspect seafood,'' said Rep. Billy Tauzin, D-La. ``The issue is whether you want the Agriculture Committee, which may not understand the difference between a chicken and a crawfish, to undertake that effort.'' The Senate approved legislation last month that gives the Agriculture Department primary responsibility by putting the inspection process under its wing. The Senate bill requires the Food and Drug Administration to set limits on the level of contamination in fish that would be acceptable for human consumption. It instructs the Commerce Department to monitor the waters in which fish are caught. Although Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said the differences in the House and Senate bills could be worked out in conference committee, aides said the differences were too great to be resolved in the waning days of the 101st Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Yelena Bonner Criticizes Gorbachev's Peace Prize
DOC.TEXT: Soviet dissident Yelena Bonner said Wednesday that her late husband, Nobel Peace Prize laureate Andrei Sakharov, would have been uneasy with Mikhail Gorbachev winning the same prize. ``I doubt that Sakharov would have approved,'' Bonner was quoted as saying. The remarks, carried by the Norwegian news agency NTB, were her first public comment on the award of the 1990 Nobel prize to the Soviet president. The Oslo-based Peace Prize Committee announced Oct. 15 that Gorbachev was selected because his reforms and glasnost policies had helped ease international tensions. Most Western leaders welcomed the selection. But Bonner told NTB that the committee had either been unaware or chose to ignore conditions inside the Soviet Union. She was referring to criticism at home that some of Gorbachev's reforms have led to ethnic rioting, food shortages and demands by most Soviet republics for more independence from Moscow. ``The Nobel committee has also not taken into consideration the fact that we are living between the second and third World Wars. In the gulf crisis, totalitarian and democratic values are standing against each other,'' said Bonner. Considering the tensions provoked by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, ``no one deserved the prize,'' she said in the agency's translation of her remarks. She said it seemed strange that a Soviet leader could win a peace prize when his country had supplied arms and military advisers to Iraq. The Soviet Union has since denounced Iraq for invading Kuwait, but it has not provided soldiers to stand beside U.S. forces opposing Baghdad. Sakharov, a physicist and human rights activists, was awarded the Nobel award in 1975. Soviet officials did not allow him to come to Oslo for the prize that year, ut he picked it up last year shortly before his death. Bonner, who was in Oslo to promote a Norwegian edition of Sakharov's memoirs, said her husband at first trusted Gorbachev, then lost faith. She said Gorbachev, shortly after reaching power in 1985, took some positive steps such as allowing freedom of the press, freeing such dissidents as Sakharov and withdrawing Soviet forces from Afghanistan. ``But after 1988, he concentrated on building up his own power,'' she was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 10 Killed, 21 Hurt in Cuban Passenger Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with report of at least 10 killed, 21 injured, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban passenger plane crashed before dawn Wednesday near an airport in eastern Cuba, killing at least 10 people and injuring 21, the official Mexican news agency Notimex reported. The twin-engine, Soviet-made turboprop plane went down about 1:46 a.m. near the Antonio Maceo Airport in Santiago de Cuba, 560 miles east of Havana, the Cuban capital. Notimex said the flight originated in Havana and stopped in Camaguey City en route to Santiago de Cuba, about 50 miles from the U.S. Naval station in Guantanamo Bay. Ten Spanish tourists were among the passengers and at least five of them were badly injured, according to the Spanish Embassy in Havana. It was not immediately known whether the other Spaniards survived the crash. There were no reports about the remaining passengers and crew aboard the Cubana de Aviacion flight. Notimex said there were 31 passengers and two crew members on board. It attributed the death and injury figures to Cuba's National Information Agency. Prensa Latina, an official Cuban news agency, said there were 24 passengers and seven crew. It did not give casualty figures. Prensa Latina and Notimex said a government commission was investigating the crash. On Sept. 3, 1989, a Cubana de Aviacion jetliner crashed after takeoff in Havana, killing all 126 aboard and 26 people on the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Official Trade Unions Dissolve National Umbrella Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional quotes from Gorbachev and miners. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The national trade union organization voted to dissolve itself Wednesday, as coal miners gathered in the Ukraine at the same time and announced plans to create the first mass independent union in Soviet history. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev attended the meeting in Moscow of the government-sponsored National Congress of Trade Unions, whose 2,500 delegates voted to reconstitute the 70-year-old organization as a voluntary association of unions. Gorbachev told the meeting that he favored ``strong and independent'' unions, the state news agency Tass reported. A meeting of the umbrella group, representing about 140 million workers, was called for this week, two years ahead of schedule. The dissolution of the organization appeared to be an effort to defuse the emergence of the radical miners' union. The miners, holding their congress in the Donetsk Coal Basin, 600 miles south of Moscow, have been threatening a repeat of the nationwide strikes that threatened to cripple the nation in July 1989. Miner delegates from Western Siberia, Kazakhstan and the far north said they would not call a strike pending consideration of their complaints by the legislature of the Russian republic, now in session in Moscow. But they said they would create an independent union. ``We will adopt a draft, and we will go from here as the first members of an independent trade union,'' said Alexander Adanidi, a member of Kuznetsk Basin Workers' Committee, which started the 1989 strike. Adanidi and other Siberian miners complained that Coal Minister Mikhail Shchadov, whose agency owns all mines and associated industries across the country, had tried to undermine the legitimacy of the congress by contributing nearly $70,000 to it. Shchadov was scheduled to address the congress Thursday. He was shouted down and driven from the hall when he spoke to a similar miners' congress last summer. At the congress of the government-sponsored trade union association in Moscow, Gorbachev urged delegates ``to keep in touch with all sections of the working people.'' He urged them to support his reforms, which he said were aimed at creating ``a society of democratic institutions and mechanisms that preserve and maintain law and order. But we are still far from it.'' It was not clear whether the miners' new union would be allowed or would want to join the newly reformed national trade union organization, whose leaders acknowledged they were losing the support of workers. Deputy chief Vladimir Scherbakov said the revamped organization would no longer demand a monopoly on workers' loyalty. The bidding for workers' hearts, in a country that once called itself a workers' paradise, shows the political importance that organizers place on blue-collar labor as the political and economic system opens up. The miners' strikes of 1989 began in protest of working and living conditions and shortages of such basics as soap and medical care. Demands quickly escalated to include regional economic autonomy for the main mining regions, the Kuznetsk Basin, the Don River Basin in the Ukraine, Vorkuta in the far north and Karaganda in Kazakhstan. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov persuaded the miners to return to work, promising to meet most of their demands. But most of those promises remain unfulfilled. The strike committees, meeting at their first conference in Donetsk last summer, called for Ryzhkov's government to resign.

DOC.HEAD: Second Convicted Officer Freed After Priest Killing
DOC.TEXT: The second of four secret policemen convicted of the 1984 slaying of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a pro-Solidarity priest, has been released from prison, the prosecutor general said Wednesday. Lt. Leszek Pekala originally was sentenced to 15 years in prison after a three-month trial that ended in February 1985. But his term was reduced in 1987 to six years, and he was freed Tuesday under a law that allows releases after a prisoner has served two-thirds of his sentence. The release was confirmed at a news conference by Prosecutor General Aleksander Herzog. Popieluszko, a charismatic 37-year-old Warsaw priest whose sermons bolstered the Solidarity labor movement when it was outlawed, was abducted Oct. 19, 1984. His beaten and bound body was pulled from an icy river 11 days later, shocking the nation and galvanizing the anti-Communist opposition. Pekala and Wlademar Chmielewski were found guilty of committing the murder with ringleader Grzegorz Piotrowski. Their superior, Adam Pietruszka, also was convicted. The public was never satisfied with the determination that no higher-ups were involved in the murder or its coverup. On Oct. 6, the post-Communist Interior Ministry reopened the case by arresting two former police generals on charges of masterminding the slaying. The four convicted officers all had their sentences reduced by the former Communist authorities, and Chmielewski has already been paroled. Piotrowski now is serving a 15-year term due to end in October 1999, and Pietruszka's 10-year sentence is to end in November 1994, Herzog said. The prosecutor said the government is reviewing the Supreme Court decisions reducing the sentences and ``some irregularities'' are being analyzed. However, an extraordinary reopening of the case would be required to reverse the sentence reductions, and ``the problem ... is very difficult,'' Herzog said.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Int'l Protests U.S. Plan to Broaden Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Wednesday urged President Bush not to sign proposed legislation broadening use of the death penalty. In a letter to the president, the international human rights group said that if the proposal becomes law, ``social justice may be simply ignored in the desire to seek vengeance.'' The letter said Amnesty was aware of ``at least 23 innocent people'' executed in the United States this century. ``Amnesty International is opposed to the death penalty in all cases, based on our conviction that no authority has the right to deny anyone their most basic and fundamental human right - the right to life itself,'' the letter said. David Bull, British section director of Amnesty, delivered the letter to the U.S. Embassy in London on Wednesday. The congressional proposals would extend the death penalty to some nonhomicidal offenses under federal law. Amnesty said such a move ``represents a dangerous departure from the U.S. Supreme Court ruling in 1972, which stated that the death penalty would be `cruel and unusual' when applied to offenses which did not result in death.'' A total of 138 people have been executed in the United States since the court in 1976 allowed states to resume use of the death penalty. Fifteen states have done so. In its plea to Bush, Amnesty referred to ``the self-evident racial bias in death penalty sentencing and the carrying out of such sentences.'' The Bush administration strongly supports the death penalty, but it has threatened a veto over attempts by some congressmen to allow defendants to fight the death sentence by showing racial bias. Many opponents of the death penalty argue it is unfair because it is more often applied to blacks than whites. Amnesty also said studies have shown the death penalty is not an effective deterrent to violent crime or murder. It further argued that execution methods are ``cruel and barbaric.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Refuses to Sign Truce Pact
DOC.TEXT: A cease-fire accord signed by two of Liberia's three warring parties was rejected Wednesday by the largest faction in the 10-month-old civil war. A spokesman for rebel leader Charles Taylor said the disagreement centered on the composition of a multinational task force dispatched in August to end the fighting, which has claimed more than 5,000 lives and destroyed many sections of Liberia's capital Monrovia. Taylor spokesman Tom Woewiyu said the rebel commander wants the task force expanded to include soldiers of governments sympathetic to his movement, including Ivory Coast and Burkina Faso. The five-nation force includes troops from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia. The talks in Banjul were the first time in months the three factions met together. Taylor is opposed by remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's forces, who still hold the executive mansion in Monrovia, and a splinter rebel group led by Prince Johnson. Both groups have cooperated with the multinational force and approved the cease-fire agreement. Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Christmas Eve seeking to oust Doe, who was captured and killed Sept. 9 by Johnson's troops. Wednesday's cease-fire agreement was negotiated after three days of talks mediated by the Economic Community of West African States, which sent the task force to Liberia. The last attempt to end the conflict broke down in late September when the task force attacked Taylor's men for refusing to relinquish control of the Liberian capital. Using fighter bombers and tanks, the regional force has pushed Taylor's army out of the city. But Taylor's rebels have overrun most of the rest of the nation and Taylor has set up headquarters in the central city of Gbarnga, declared himself president and announced plans to hold elections. Also opposed to Taylor is an interim government chosen by exiled Liberian politicians, clergymen and businessmen at a conference organized by the West African organization. Taylor has said he is entitled to run a temporary government as the spoils of war, and has denounced the interim government as a puppet of West African governments that sent soldiers to Liberia.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Food-Labeling Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 9th graf: ``The Ralph,'' with one graf bgng: ``The Center,'' to CORRECT by deleting reference to Ralph Nader
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday approved a bill designed to let consumers know what's in the food they eat. The legislation would require food manufacturers to list on labels the amount of nutrients, calories, fat and salt for most packaged foods. Claims such as ``low salt'' and ``light'' would be clearly defined and disease-prevention claims would have to be government-approved. The bill, passed by unanimous consent, will go back to the House, which passed a similar version in late July and was expected to accept the Senate's changes. ``Labeling will guarantee that advertising claims are supported by the facts, and that consumers have the information they need to make wiser choices about their health and diet,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. and chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The Bush administration has proposed food-labeling regulations similar to the provisions of the legislation. Because the administration says the matter can be handled with regulations, it has said in a policy statement that it opposes the bill. However, the administration has not threatened a veto. The Food and Drug Administration had hoped to issue final food-labeling regulations by next spring, requiring industry compliance a year later. But because of differences between the legislation and the regulations have forced the FDA to rework parts of its plan. ``It will delay what we had been doing, but we won't have to go back to square one,'' said Edward Scarbrough, acting director of the FDA's Office of Nutrition and Food Science. One difference between the proposed regulations and the legislation is that Congress would require much of the nutrient labeling to be uniform nationwide. The FDA had requested comment on whether states should be allowed to supersede the federal regulations with stronger rules. The Center for Science in the Public Interest gave the Senate plan ``a qualified hurrah.'' Bruce Silverglade, legal director of the group, said ``the days of misleading nutrition and health claims for most foods are coming to an end.'' But he said he was concerned that cities and states would be unable to impose their own labeling requirements. The National Food Processors Association, however, was pleased with the uniformity requirement. ``We did not get all we wanted in terms of federal preemption, but we have a strong federal nutrition labeling law that will help maintain our national food distribution system and permit nationwide food label education programs,'' he said. Under the Senate measure, the secretary of health and human services would set guidelines defining such labels as ``low salt'' and ``light.'' Food makers would have to adhere to the guidelines to use those terms. Also, companies would need FDA approval to make disease-prevention claims. Restaurants would be exempt from the labeling requirements, and foods such as fresh produce and seafood could provide nutrition labeling with a sign or brochure at the site of sale.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate for Reunion with Soviet Moldavia
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 Romanians demonstrated Wednesday for reunification with Moldavia, the largely ethnic Romanian area that was annexed by the Soviets during World War II. The demonstrators, who included some opposition party leaders, marched along the capital's main boulevard shouting nationalistic slogans. They massed in front of the Soviet embassy on the outskirts of the city, where they handed embassy officials a written protest declaiming the alleged infringement of Romanian rights in Soviet Moldavia. The region, known by Romanians as Bessarabia, was ceded to the Soviet Union in 1940, but still has a Romanian-speaking majority of more than 2 million. Romanian was restored as its official language last year, and cultural ties between Bessarabians and Romanians have been strengthened. The Romanian government, however, has been reluctant to openly side with those demanding the area back for fear of bringing about other claims on present Romanian territory. ``It's an obvious fact that Bessarabia is Romanian,'' declared Ion Puiu, president of the Free Christian Democrat Party. ``We are here to fight what's left of Soviet imperialism, which is attempting to deprive us of our sacred land,'' said Free Republican Party leader Nica Leon. Other groups represented at the rally were the Free Democrat Party, the Independent Peasant Party, the Pro-Bessarabia Cultural Association and the Student League. The demonstrators shouted ``Moscow, don't forget, Bessarabia does not belong to you!'' and ``Bessarabia is Romanian land!'' Several dozen policemen were present during the three-hour demonstration. There were no incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Antigua Children with Dreadlocks Won't be Allowed in School
DOC.TEXT: Children with dreadlocks will not be allowed to attend public schools, the education minister of Antigua and Barbuda announced. Education Minister Reuben Harris made public his position Tuesday to members of the Rastafarian community while discussing the question of their children attending local schools. The Rastafarians are a religious group who foster black consciousness and their African background and wear their hair in small plaits known as dreadlocks.
