Many smoke marijuana as part of their religious practice. ``I know some people think I'm colonial, but I must tell all that I will support the colonial way of life if it promotes discipline and cleanliness,' Harris said. A spokesman for the Rasta said the minister's position is discriminatory and that they would seek a meeting with the Cafarian communitybinet of Prime Minister Vere Bird to discuss the issue. ``We feel that this day and age this action by the minister is a violation of one's rights under the constitution,'' spokesman Ras Franki said. About 77,000 people reside in the two east Caribbean islands, which are 250 miles southeast of Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Files $6.5 Billion Damage Suit Against Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Noriega was...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE that Noriega wasn't served with lawsuit. SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Noriega attorney...,' with 1 graf to CORRECT name to Jon sted John. Pick up 12th graf pvs, ``This isn't...
DOC.TEXT: The government of Panama filed a $6.5 billion racketeering lawsuit Wednesday against its former military ruler, charging Manuel Noriega looted the nation's treasury and tortured and killed his opponents. ``We have long waited for justice, and justice is beginning to happen here,'' said Eduardo Vallarino, Panama's ambassador to the United States, who accompanied the lawyer filing the suit. ``We have a duty to the people of all the world to show that dictatorship and tyranny doesn't ultimately pay.'' The Panamanian government's lawsuit contains 11 charges against the toppled dictator for alleged misconduct during his 28-year military and political career. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District court, says Noriega participated in assassination, torture, drug trafficking, money laundering, embezzlement, sale of visas and passports and other abuses while he was head of the Panama Defense Forces. A process server sent by Panama's attorney Gregory Craig failed Wednesday in an attempt to serve papers on Noriega at the Metropolitan Correctional Center southwest of Miami, where he has been held on drug-trafficking charges since the December 1989 invasion of Panama. Prison spokeswoman Dena Davion said the process server was turned away for security reasons, and that a judge would have to order the U.S. Marshals Service to deliver official notice of the suit to Noriega. The final years of Noriega's reign deflated Panama's gross national product by 20 percent through corruption and misrule, Vallarino charged. Panama estimated those damages at $500 million, which can be tripled under U.S. racketeering law. The Panamanian government also is seeking $5 billion in punitive damages. But Vallarino, who was appointed ambassador by the government of President Guillermo Endara, said the damage to Panama went beyond economics. ``We are also talking about murders,'' the ambassador said, mentioning the bloody torture slaying of opposition leader Hugo Spadafora. ``Many other persons were blatantly and openly murdered in the streets of Panama.'' The United States holds $20 million frozen in international bank accounts, some of which has been earmarked for Noriega's criminal defense attorneys, but Craig said Panama was asking for an injunction to stop any release of Noriega's money. The Panamanian government estimated Noriega earned a total of $700,000 in the military, but Craig said Noriega still he has $300 million to $500 million in assets that have not been attached by the U.S. government. Noriega attorney Jon May said the lawsuit was an attempt to interfere with his client's consitutional right to a fair trial, including the right to choose and pay his own attorneys. ``This isn't about money,'' May said of the lawsuit. ``This is simply an attempt to keep General Noriega from having sufficient assets to be able to defend himself.'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen acknowledged a conflict existed over the money involved in the criminal case assigned to U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler and the civil case assigned to U.S. District Judge Edward Davis, but not an insurmountable one. ``As we have said in court to Judge Hoeveler several times, the United States government is not the only government that has made claims on that money,'' he said. ``When we release our claim ... to pay defense counsel here, we do not of course control foreign governments.'' Lehtinen said he did not believe the lawsuit would interfere with Noriega's criminal prosecution on drug-trafficking charges. The criminal charges accuse Noriega of turning Panama into a way station for Columbia's Medellin cocaine cartel and accepting $4.6 million in bribes to protect their smuggling. Hoeveler has said he would not allow Panama's long-expected lawsuit to sidetrack Noriega's prosecution. Craig said he could not identify Noriega's 20 co-defendants in the civil case because they have not been served. But previous reports listed other targets as Marcos Justines, noriega's chief of staff jailed in Panama City; Carlos Duque, the 1989 presidential candidate of Noriega's Revolutionary Democratic Party; Michael Harari, a former Israeli military officer; three former ambassadors; Noriega's wife, Felicidad; his mistress Vicki Amado and others.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Passes Law to Reassert Control over Republics
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet parliament sought to arrest the collapse of central authority by passing legislation Wednesday saying its laws supercede those of conflicting measures in the 15 Soviet republics. Three republics immediately challenged the parliamentary move. The sponsors of the national bill said it is designed to end the ``war of laws'' between the national and republic governments, but there seemed to be little way to enforce it and no promise it would end the jurisdictional disputes. In defending the measure, Soviet lawmaker Yuri Kalmykov was quoted as saying, ``We are neither declaring war on the republics nor bringing pressure to bear on them. ``The republics should understand that this legal act is in the interests of all,'' he said, according to the state news agency Tass. Kalmykov is chairman of the parliamentary committee on legislation in the national Supreme Soviet, the parliament. Despite his comments, the two largest Soviet republics, Russia and the Ukraine, on Wednesday passed their own laws overruling national legislation, Tass said in separate dispatches. In addition, the parliament of the Baltic republic of Latvia, which declared independence this year, passed a law saying state-owned property belongs to the republic and not to the national government, Tass said. The Latvian law overturned an Oct. 19 decree by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. He ordered that 51 percent of state-owned industries and businesses be sold to workers on a joint-stock basis and the remaining 49 percent stay in the hands of the national government. In its action Wednesday, the Russian Republic legislature, meeting in Moscow, gave preliminary approval to laws limiting the authority of the national government in the republic and abolishing the state monopoly on land ownership, Tass said. The Ukrainian legislature, meeting in Kiev, proclaimed the precedence of the republic's laws over national laws on Ukrainian territory. National laws will enter into force in the Ukraine only after they are ratified by the republic's parliament, it said. The fragmentation of Soviet power was also deepening in the republic of Moldavia, where an emergency session of parliament was called for Thursday, Tass reported. Moldavian President Mircha Snegur said the session was needed because the ``social and economic situation in the republic has reached the boiling point'' due to declarations of independence by two tiny corners of Moldavia, a southwestern republic. The so-called Gagauz and Dneister republics are seeking to separate themselves from Moldavia. Nearly all the 15 Soviet republics have declared independence or autonomy from the central government. In Moldavia, Georgia and the Russian Federation, smaller regions have sought to distance themselves from republic authorities. The law passed Wednesday by the national legislature appeared to be a fruitless effort suspend the constitutional crisis until completion of a new treaty of union that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is seeking to persuade the republics to negotiate. Gorbachev has had little success starting formal talks to replace the treaty of union, which forms the legal basis of the national federation. Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and other radical reformers want to negotiate bilateral treaties on political and economic cooperation before agreeing to a new treaty of union to form a federation or confederation. National legislators heatedly debated Wednesday's law. Their dispute centered on a clause giving Gorbachev the right to fire local officials who disregard national law, Tass said. One house of the national legislature, the Council of Nationalities, approved the law without the clause. The other house, the Council of the Union, approved it with the clause. They later agreed on a compromise that apparently left the issue undecided.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Die, Israel Seals Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 4 grafs SUB for grafs 18-21 `Police officials' to UPDATE with police say death under investigation. Picks up 22nd graf, `Meanwhile, Salim. . .'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Arabs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians stayed home from jobs in Israel Wednesday as troops sealed off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in an effort to stem a wave of Arab-Israeli revenge attacks. The latest victim, a Palestinian accused of stabbing two unarmed Israeli women soldiers, died Wednesday of head injuries reportedly suffered when he was kicked and beaten by Israelis after the attack. In Jerusalem, meanwhile, the death of an 18-year-old Palestinian set off a general strike in the city's Arab sector. On Tuesday, Defense Minister Moshe Arens ordered the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip banned from entering Israel, where many of them work. The ban, which began Wednesday, was in response to a string of attacks on Jews that left three people dead and eight wounded since Sunday. A 30-year-old Palestinian laborer was also killed, and three of his cousins were wounded by gunshots fired from an Israeli civilian car. Other Arab workers driving in Israel have had their cars stoned during the violence. Police Minister Roni Milo said the closure of the territories, expected to last several days, was meant to teach Arabs a lesson. ``The state of Israel must make it completely clear that we will not permit ... the attacking of Jews and stabbing of women soldiers or civilians. We will not allow this to happen without response,'' he said on army radio. In the Israeli Parliament, legislators called for making the closure permanent. Surprisingly, some of the strongest arguments came from left-wing politicians who normally argue for making peace with the Arabs. ``If there's any chance of reaching political dialogue it's by disengagement of the two peoples,'' Chaim Ramon, a leftist member of the Labor Party, told Israel television. Israeli fear over the attacks was evident Wednesday. There was a reported run on gun shops, and thousands of Israelis called police to report Arabs still present in Israel. Sarah Benjamin, head of police operations in Tel Aviv, estimated that she and her colleagues got 1,700 such calls from the coastal city and its suburbs. The Palestinian accused of stabbing the two women soldiers on Tuesday, Omar Shawaneh, 39, died at Rambam Hospital in Haifa, hospital officials said. One of his victims was reported in serious but stable condition with a chest wound on Wednesday. The other suffered a superficial knife wound in the back. Israeli television and radio both carried accounts of Israeli citizens who said they helped capture the suspect, describing how he was punched, kicked and beaten. There was initial confusion over how Shawaneh was injured because a police statement said he was questioned before being hospitalized and the radio said he told police he came to Israel to carry out an attack. But Shawaneh, from a West Bank village near Jenin, was later reported unconscious and in critical condition in Rambam's neurosurgery ward. Northern district police spokesman Danny Ramati, reached by telephone, said Shawaneh's death was under investigation. Ramati confirmed that Shawaneh was taken to a police station before being hospitalized, but said the blows Shawaneh suffered were from soldiers and civilians ``during the struggle in the field . . . while he was putting up stiff resistance to arrest.'' Also Wednesday in Jerusalem, Faisal Husseini, a leading pro-PLO figure, was released on $2,500 bail. He was arrested on suspicion of inciting the riot that led to the Oct. 8 Temple Mount police shootings, in which at least 19 Palestinians were killed. Husseini denied any incitement, saying he was trying to calm things down. Meanwhile, Salim Awad Khaldi died of a bullet wound to the chest, becoming another victim of the violence on Oct. 8. Initial reports said he was shot in the Temple Mount clash, but Arab reporters and police sources later said he was wounded by gunfire from an Israeli civilian on a nearby street. News of his death sparked a general strike in Arab east Jerusalem. The deaths Wednesday brought to 766 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli troops and civilians in the 34-month Palestinian uprising. Fifty-one Israelis also have been slain in the violence. In the West Bank, the body of a 50-year-old Palestinian was found stabbed to death near Tulkarem, and Arab reports said he was suspected of collaborating with Israel. During the uprising, 287 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as allegedly collaborators.

DOC.HEAD: Special Prosector Accuse Attorney General of Abuse
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh charged Wednesday that the CIA and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh abused secrecy procedures to frustrate the prosecution of a former CIA agent. ``The attorney general and the CIA not only frustrated the public development'' of evidence against former CIA agent Joseph Fernandez, ``but did so in a manner that exasperated the district court and dragged out the resolution of this issue in unproductive litigation,'' Walsh said in a rpeort on the case. Walsh issued his report nearly two weeks after Thornburgh formally ended the prosecution by stating he would not withdraw his affidavit blocking the release of secrets the judge ruled Fernandez was entitled to disclose in the case. On Oct. 12, the attorney general stuck by a previous decision blocking the release of documents showing the location o CIA facilities in Central America and detailing agency operations in Costa Rica. The Justice Department quoted an administration official as saying release of such information would strike a ``devastating'' blow to national security. The judge in the case had ruled that Fernandez, former CIA station chief in Costa Rica, was entitled to disclose the information to defend himself against charges he lied about his role in helping ship arms to the Nicaraugan rebels. Thornburgh's action marked the first time that an attorney general had invoked a provision of the Classified Information Procedures Act to block a prosecution. It capped a 15-month legal battle during which, Walsh charged, Thornburgh forced two ``fruitless appeals'' to the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va., on secrecy issues. The appellate court in September upheld U.S. District Judge Claude Hilton's dismissal of the charges because Thornburgh had refused to allow Fernandez to use evidence needed to defend himself. ``If the information could not be revealed without grave damage, why did he force two appeals rather than reach this conclusion 15 months ago? If the potential danger is, as he reports, `devastating', why did he promise to reconsider his decision if the dismissal of the case was affirmed on appeal?'' Walsh wrote. The Bush administration's actions in the Iran-Contra cases ``underscore the need for objective standards to govern the release of classified information in criminal prosecutions,'' Walsh said. ``This is particularly true when there is an appearance of conflict of interest because the agency refusing disclosure is itself a subject of investigation,'' Walsh said in a reference to his continuing probe of CIA involvement in the Iran-Contra affair and the subsequent coverup. Walsh called ``disingenuous'' Thornburgh's assertion the independent counsel's strategy in dealing with the classified information problems forced him to block the release of all secrets. A Justice Department letter to Congress, released Wednesday, said that Walsh's acquiesence to a court review of categories of documents rather than an item-by-item examination of the material complicated Thornburgh's decision. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for Walsh, said that when Thornburgh filed his affidavit last November blocking the release of secrets, he did not object to the category-by-category procedure. Belcher said Walsh's office ``did not acquiesce in the category-by-category rulings'' suggested by Hilton. ``We strenuously argued for specific review of documents after the categories were ruled on,'' she said. The Justice Department letter also noted that ``those who are familiar with the case asset it as a relatively weak one which would not have been brought had Fernandez been willing to cooperate with the investigation.'' ``We obviously disagree that it was a weak case,'' said Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for Walsh.

DOC.HEAD: Dollars Detailed
With AM-Budget-Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The budget bills in Congress are designed to reign in deficit spending which, if unchecked, would add more than $1 trillion to the national debt in the next five years. That would continue the pattern of the 1980s, during which the Treasury was forced to triple its borrowing. The national debt is now $3.195 trillion. The White House estimates the deficit for the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, will be $294 billion dollars. The budget legislation before Congress would trim that by roughly $40 billion, so only another $254 billion will get added to the long-term debt.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Chief Of Staff Nominee Says Fired Predecessor Made Honest Mistake
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to note that Dugan spoke on the record with reporters for 15 hours.
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force general named to replace the chief of staff fired for public comments about U.S. contingency plans against Iraq said Wednesday his friend made an ``honest mistake.'' Gen. Merrill A. McPeak told the Senate Armed Services Committee his colleague erred in discussing issues within the president's bailiwick and speaking on the record with news reporters for 15 hours straight. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney fired Gen. Michael Dugan on Sept. 17, one day after Dugan's statements about contingency plans to unleash massive air raids on Iraq and target Saddam Hussein personally appeared in several newspapers. Cheney said Dugan had violated Pentagon rules by publicly discussing likely military targets inside Iraq and disclosing classified information about the size of U.S. forces in the gulf area. ``It was an honest mistake on his part, nevertheless a mistake. I'll certainly seek to avoid making the same mistake,'' McPeak told the panel at his confirmation hearing. Lawmakers indicated no opposition to the nominee, a 54-year-old native of Santa Rosa, Calif., who is commander-in-chief of forces in the Pacific region. While serving as a fighter pilot in 1961, McPeak said he struck up a friendship with Dugan, a fellow lieutenant. ``Mike Dugan is probably my closest friend in the U.S. Air Force,'' McPeak said. The nominee backed a number of steps Dugan took during his brief term, in particular his attempts to improve frosty relations between the Air Force and Congress and the media. ``I think he was right about an awful lot of things he started to do during his tenure as chief, in particular his initiative toward greater openness,'' McPeak said. ``I endorse that.'' The Air Force general said Dugan made a mistake in ``expressing an opinion about military options that are really a decision for the president to make.'' Dugan remains at the Pentagon as a special assistant to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice. He is currently overseeing studies on the future needs for pilots and navigators as well as the officer evaluation system.

DOC.HEAD: Jews, Catholics Attend `Remembrance and Reconciliation' Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with concert held, further quotes. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Jews and Roman Catholics met to pay homage to a nearly disappeared culture Wednesday, capping the event by attending a stirring concert in a synagogue scarred by neglect and Nazi defacement. ``Being here and listening to the music of our people is a way to tell the world that we go on living,'' said Irene Weingarten, a certified public accountant from Houston, one of about 250 American Jews who flew to Krakow, a southern Polish city rich in Jewish history, to attend the event. Gilbert Levine, maestro of the Krakow Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted the concert inside the Temple Postepowa, a 100-year-old synagogue virtually unused since World War II. Poland's Jewish community, which once numbered 3.5 million, was nearly wiped out by the Holocaust. Despite the fact that fewer than 10,000 Jews remain, anti-Semitism has resurfaced in recent months. Pope John Paul II, archbishop of Krakow before being named pontiff in 1978, heartily endorsed the concert as a vehicle for reconciliation between the faiths, said Levine, who was received by the pope at the Vatican. The chief of Krakow's tiny Jewish congregation, Czeslaw Jakobowicz, said he found the concert ``sad but very nice.'' ``You know, we all lived together, Catholics and Jews, in this society for hundreds of years,'' Jakobowicz said. ``There is no reason it can't be like it used to be.'' Levine said several high-ranking church officials had been invited to the conciliatory event for two faiths, including Krakow Archbishop Franciszek Marcharski. But local priests were the highest church representatives in attendance. A letter from Macharski read before the concert quoted John Paul's words: ``We are all children of the same God.'' It closed with ``Shalom,'' the Hebrew word for peace. The program opened with the national anthems of Poland, the United States and Israel, followed by the Kol Nidre, a traditional lament of Jews sung during the Yom Kippur holiday. The program also included works of Beethoven, Bruch and Dvorak. The dark apricot walls and gold filigree arches and columns of Temple Postempowa reflected five decades of neglect, but the concert's audience of 400 people sharing the small space with the orchestra was moved by the music. Many wiped away tears. Before the concert, members of both faiths joined to raise a Star of David atop the synagogue, replacing one torn down by the Gestapo in November 1939. ``This will be a concert of rememberance, because you can't forget what happened in Poland 50 years ago, and of hope for reconciliation,'' said Levine, who has headed the philharmonic since 1987, the first American to direct an orchestra in eastern Europe. Only a handful of Jews live in Krakow today; their average age is 70. The synagogue stands in a neighborhood that has had a Jewish presence since the 1300s. In recent years, Catholic-Jewish relations in Poland have been strained by the presence of Carmelite nuns at the Auschwitz concentration camp, 36 miles from Krakow. Over Jewish protests, the nuns built a convent adjoining the camp where 1.5 million Jews were murdered by the Nazis. The church first promised to remove the convent in 1987, and renewed the promise last year, but so far it has not done so. This year also has witnessed anti-Semitic acts in newly democratized Poland, as well as elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Nazi slogans and anti-Jewish slurs have appeared on bus stops and even the memorial at Umschlagplatz, the site in Warsaw where hundreds of thousands of Jews were sent to concentration camps. Levine, whose grandfather emigrated from Warsaw in 1895 and whose wife's mother survived Auschwitz, said the concert presented an opportunity to overcome some of the bitterness that has overshadowed recent dialogue between Catholics and Jews in Poland. ``Music can serve a tremendously important purpose to wordlessly express emotions,'' Levine said. ``But you have to have hope and a desire for reconciliation and for dialogue. That at least goes some of the way toward achieving it.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs, final passage of Commerce-Justice-State bill
DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Foreign Aid Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday approved a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill that includes a cut in El Salvador's military aid and debt forgiveness for Egypt, after an abortion controversy over the bill evaporated. The Senate voted 76-23 for the bill, sending it to negotiations to work out differences with a House-passed version. Since last week, the measure had been stalled because of a dispute over whether to reverse a 6-year-old policy that bars U.S. aid to international population control agencies that offer abortion as an option. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., ended his push for the change in the face of a filibuster threat by anti-abortion forces, including Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo. Wirth did not want to jeopardize the entire foreign aid bill in the waning days of the 101st Congress, an aide said. The bill provides aid to U.S. friends and allies around the world, including $3 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt, the two biggest recipients. Both the House and the Senate versions of the bill include a 50 percent cut in military aid to El Salvador, intended to give incentives to both the government and the leftist FMLN rebels to end their decade-long civil war with a negotiated settlement. The bills provide that military aid would be cut to half its current level of $85 million in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. If the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front walk away from U.N.-sponsored peace talks, the aid could be restored. But if the government fails to pursue peace, it could lose the other half of its military aid. The language represents a major change in U.S. policy toward El Salvador, which has received aid at a rate of nearly $1 million a day in recent years. Bush's top advisers have threatened to veto any bill that contained such an aid cut. But the bill also contains a powerful incentive for the president to sign: forgiveness of $6.7 billion in past military loans Egypt owes the United States. Bush has sought to erase the debt as a reward to Egypt, which has been among the staunchest U.S. allies in opposing Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Administration officials have argued that a substantial reward is due President Hosni Mubarak, who took a serious political risk by leading Arab opposition to Iraq. Mubarak's continued tenure could well depend on a tangible American gesture, they contended. In addition to the cash aid for Israel, the Senate version of the bill also included authority for the president to give Israel at least $700 million worth of Pentagon weaponry. That provision was pushed by supporters of Israel who argued it was needed because of the increased threat to that country from Iraq and the increased costs of Israel's high military alert. It also appeared designed to counterbalance the likely debt forgiveness for Egypt and a $7.5 billion arms sale approved for Saudi Arabia. In other action on spending bills, the Senate and House approved and sent to President Bush a $19.3 billion bill providing fiscal 1991 money for the departments of Commerce, Justice and State, and for the Judiciary branch. The measure includes full payment of U.S. dues to the United Nations, as well as 20 percent of dues that had been withheld in prior years because of U.S. dissatisfaction with the world body. It also includes $105 million for prosecution of savings and loan scandal cases and $694 million for the Drug Enforcement Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Military Dictator's Son Wins Big in Pakistan
With AM-Pakistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Huge posters of a fallen dictator draped in black festooned the campaign headquarters of parliamentary candidate Ijaz ul-Haq, who fought and won Wednesday's elections on the memory of his father. Hours after polls closed, Ijaz was being declared the unofficial winner over favored candidate Shahed Zafar, production minister under ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Boisterous celebrations began early at Ijaz's headquarters in the heart of the Rawalpindi. Horns blared and music roared from loudspeakers atop beat up Suzukis, antiquated British-made Morris cars and horse-drawn carts. ``It's only for Zia ul-Haq,'' said campaign worker Amjad Hussain of the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance, known by its Urdu-language initials IJI. Zia overthrew Ms. Bhutto's father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, in a bloodless coup in 1977. Two years later, Bhutto was hanged on controversial charges of conspiring to kill a political foe. Zia ruled Pakistan until his death in an August 1988 plane crash. Thirty others also died, including senior generals and U.S. Ambassador Arnold Raphael. The cause of the C-130 crash in a desert in Punjab Province remains a mystery. Ijaz blames a militant group of Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party, Al Zulfikar, named for her father. Zia's death paved the way for Pakistan's first free elections in more than a decade. Zia twice promised elections, but later reneged. Ms. Bhutto, capitalizing on her father's memory, won the largest bloc of votes in 1988 but failed to win a majority. Ijaz and Ms. Bhutto are at opposite ends of the political spectrum - she to the left and he to the far right - but there are similarities. Both studied in Europe and the United States. Ijaz received his masters of business administration from the University of Illinois. Ms. Bhutto studied at Oxford and Harvard. Both claim their father was a martyr - hers for democracy, his for Islam. Like Ms. Bhutto, Ijaz waged his election campaign on the memory of his dead father. His slogans mirrored hers. Ms. Bhutto reminded followers that the founder of the People's Party worked for the downtrodden and poor. Ijaz recalled his father's middle-class roots and his concern for the poor. ``The vote is not for IJI. It's not a vote even for Ijaz, it's really a vote for Zia,'' said Hussein. ``People have respect for Zia.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Rebels Kill a Top Army Figure in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels on Wednesday shot to death an army officer on the joint military command near his house in this capital, defense sources said. In Ayacucho, the Andean city where Maoist Shining Path rebels launched their movement, the government lifted a state of emergency. It was imposed in December 1982. The military sources said Lt. Col. Oscar Caballero Castillo was gunned down as he was getting into his car near his house in a middle-class Lima neighborhood. The sources said they were unsure which of Peru's two guerrilla groups killed Caballero. At least three rebels, including a woman, took part in the attack, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The assassination, however, was typical of the Shining Path. The much smaller Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement has not committed many assassinations. Caballero was shot in the head, neck and leg. He died in a military hospital hours after the attack. Before being assigned to the joint military command in Lima, the 42-year-old officer served in Ayacucho. Though the state of emergency was lifted there, the measure was extended in rural areas surrounding the city, as well as in nine other departments. More than half of Peru's population of 22 million people live under a military state of emergency. Under the measure, authorities can restrict the freedom to travel and assemble. They can also detain people without hearings and search houses without warrant. Violence has decreased drastically in Ayacucho the last three years as the Shining Path spread its operations into other parts of the country. The rebels are now thought to base many of their Andean operations in Huancayo, 120 miles east of Lima. Another rebel stronghold is the Upper Huallaga Valley. Rebels there receive guns and money in exchange for allowing drug traffickers to operate in the coca-rich area. More than 20,000 Peruvians have died in political violence in the 10 years since the Shining Path first took up arms.

DOC.BYLINE: Council Hears Arguments On New References for God ^By STEVEN K. PAULSON
DOC.TEXT: A committee revising prayers and rituals for the United Methodist Church disagrees about whether to refer to God as anything but a masculine deity, a bishop told the church's high court on Wednesday. Bishop Susan Morrison of Philadelphia asked the church's Judicial Council to rule on petitions from the committee revising the ``Book of Worship.'' Ms. Morrison heads the committee. A minority of committee members disagree with proposals to replace the existing reference to the Trinity as ``Father, Son and Holy Spirit'' with such non-gender specific references as ``Creator, Redeemer and Sustainer,'' Ms. Morrison said. ``We're honoring the Trinity language,'' said Ms. Morrison, who sides with the majority. ``But in other places, sometimes we use ``Father'' and other times we use other Biblical metaphors such as creator. ``We don't want to use any one image of God. Sometimes we use female images, such as the mother who nurtures her young,'' she said. The church, which has nearly 9 million members, is revising its official ``Book of Worship'' for the first time in 20 years. Each congregation would be allowed to decide whether to use traditional references to God, or to adopt the references included in the revised ``Book of Worship,'' Ms. Morrison said. The Judicial Council - made up of five lawyers and four ministers - asked few questions about the debate during the hearing. The council was expected to meet again within several days. Council members indicated that at that time, they could delay a final decision until next year, when the church's General Assembly is expected to rule on the matter.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Wednesday Night's Issues Detailed
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators faced several key tax issues Wednesday night as they worked on a compromise deficit-reduction bill. Here are some of them, according to a proposed compromise incorporating elements from both parties. Exact figures could change in the course of further negotiations. RATES: The 28 percent top income tax rate on the wealthiest 600,000 Americans likely would be raised to 31 percent; they would get a tax increase. Effective rates could even be higher, depending on exemptions and deductions. About 4 million couples and individuals who now pay a top rate of 33 percent would pay a maximum 31 percent and get a tax cut. DEDUCTIONS: A couple or individual could write off only 97 percent of otherwise allowable itemized deductions on any portion of adjusted gross income exceeding $100,000. Thus, a high-income taxpayer would lose $300 in deductions for each $10,000 of income above $100,000. This has the effect of raising the top marginal tax rate on those people to 32 percent. EXEMPTIONS: Benefits from the $2,050 personal exemption allowed each taxpayer and dependent would be reduced as taxable income exceeds $100,000 for single people and $150,000 for childless couples filing a joint return. The exemption would be fully lost once income tops $225,000 for single individuals or $275,000 for a couple filing jointly. Each exemption lost would raise the effective marginal tax rate by one-half percentage point; the bigger the family, the higher their marginal rate. Thus, a couple with two children would pay a top rate of 34 percent on part of their income: the regular 31 percent rate plus 1 percentage point because of the limit on deductions and 2 points by losing their exemptions. CAPITAL GAINS: The maximum tax rate on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of assets such as investments, would be 28 percent, even though wages and other income would be taxed as high as 31 percent. This would benefit those who pay a top 33 percent rate on income, including capital gains, under present law. GASOLINE: The 9-cent-a-gallon tax would be increased by 5 or 6 cents. ALCOHOL: Negotiators already have settled on higher taxes on alcoholic beverages, tobacco, airplane tickets, furs and jewlery and expensive cars.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Food Prices Will Climb with Temperature Rise
DOC.TEXT: Global warming will create food shortages that could eventually drive up prices by as much as 20 percent, a leading climate expert said Wednesday. Climatologist Martin Parry, a member of the U.N.-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, forecast that higher temperatures and drier conditions will reduce food production globally by an average of 5 to 10 percent. His report, ``Climate Change and World Agriculture,'' was put out by Earthscan, a publisher of books on Third World issues, poverty and the environment. ``The nearly 1 billion people who already suffer from malnutrition and famines ... would face an even greater threat to their survival from the combined effects of decreased agricultural production ... and the effects of higher prices for imported food,'' Parry told reporters at a news conference at the Royal Geographic Society. Parry said farming production could fall as much as 30 percent in the mid-latitude breadbasket regions of the world such as the midwestern United States, Canadian prairies, northern European lowlands, Soviet Ukraine and Argentine pampas. The regions most at risk, however, are those least able to cope, such as North and West Africa, Central America, Southeast Asia and eastern Brazil, Parry said. His report was released five days before delegates from 100 nations meet in Geneva at the second World Climate Conference to discuss what to do about reducing carbon dioxide and other ``greenhouse'' gases. Such gases increase the atmosphere's ability to trap heat, like a greenhouse. Hundreds of the world's top scientists working on the U.N.-sponsored climate panel have concluded that if the world continues emitting the gases at the current rate, global avrrage temperatures could rise a couple degrees over the next four decades. But the actual temperature increase might be even higher in some regions, with the largest rises in higher latitudes, said Parry, a professor at Birmingham University. In the wheat and maize regions of Europe and North America, production could be cut by 20 percent with a 2 degree centigrade rise in temperature. The result could be increased costs of food for consumers in those regions, smaller cereal crops for export, and higher prices in the world cereal market.

DOC.HEAD: Tree Trimmer Dies after Being Trapped in Palm Fronds
DOC.TEXT: A tree trimmer suffocated under a heavy palm fronds that fell on him as he working 25 feet up in the tree, authorities said Wednesday. Neighbors heard the man's screams for help, but he died by the time rescuers were able to free him and get him to the ground about 80 minutes later, fire officials said. Reynaldo Medrano, 36, was working alone Tuesday afternoon on a palm tree in a back yard, said fire Capt. Kevin Boyle. Medrano died of suffocation, the Maricopa County Medical Examiner Office said Wednesday. Firefighters used a ladder to reach Medrano, who initially was conscious but struggling to breathe, Boyle said. A ring of cut fronds, possibily weighing hundreds of pounds, had ``slipped down like a hula skirt,'' said Boyle. The weight kept Medrano pinned, even after firefighters had cut his safety chain, he said. By then, the captain said, Medrano was falling in and out of consciousness. By the time rescuers got him to the ground, he was dead. Falling palm fronds suffocated two workers in separate accidents in 1987, one in Phoenix and the other in suburban Scottsdale. Palm fronds grow to six feet or more in length and resemble a huge fan blade.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Determines Large Circles on Venus Are Hawaii-Like `Hot Spots'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Magellan is...,' to ADD that Magellan has a more sophisticated radar to eliminate implication that Soviet craft used some method other than radar to map the planet.
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft found that 600-mile-wide circular features on Venus are mile-high volcanic bulges created as molten rock bubbles up from inside the planet, a scientist said Wednesday. From a bird's-eye-view, the bulges look like nested sets of concentric rings. Called coronas, the rings are ridges and valleys that form huge circles. Numerous volcanoes and lava flows dot the coronas. The coronas are formed by the same kind of upwelling of underground plumes of molten rock that created the Hawaiian Islands, said Ellen Stofan, a geologist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``They're definitely formed by some sort of thermal pulse from the interior of the planet'' that lasts hundreds of millions of years, she said. In 1983 and 1984, the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft identified about 30 coronas that measure from 75 miles to more than 600 miles across. But the Venera orbiters couldn't determine if they were upward bulges or depressions in the ground caused by the impacts of gargantuan meteorites. Magellan is examining the planet with a more sophisticated radar, which makes much more detailed pictures and also is able to calculate surface topography. It found five more coronas and determined they rise as much as one mile above the surrounding terrain. Stofan said that shows they are hot spots rather than impact craters. One corona that's 150 miles wide seems to be in the early stages of bulging upward, suggesting that some of its small volcanic domes and lava flows may be actively erupting, she said. Magellan won't be able to confirm the presence of active volcanoes until the middle of next year, when it passes over the same part of Venus a second time and can look for landscape changes resulting from any ongoing eruptions. NASA engineers, meanwhile, said the sun will almost block Earth's view of Magellan and Venus on Nov. 1 when Venus, the sun and Earth will be oriented in almost a straight line. That will cause a nine-day halt - starting sometime between Saturday and Monday - in Magellan's use of radar to peer through Venus' clouds and map the planet, said Phil Allin, administrative assistant to Magellan's project manager. The astronomical lineup, called ``superior conjunction,'' also may make NASA completely lose contact with Magellan for up to three days, although engineers disagree on whether that will happen, Allin said. The sun won't completely block Earth's view of Venus and Magellan during the planetary lineup, but activity from the sun already has impaired some communications, he said. Engineers twice lost touch with Magellan in August due to a yet-unidentified problem. If that happens again when the Venus-sun-Earth alignment also makes communication difficult or impossible, ``we worry about how quickly we would get things back to normal,'' Allin said. Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and arrived at the second planet from the sun on Aug. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Reportedly Turns Down Fresh Bush Appeal Before U.N. Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with U.N. vote against Israel. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Shamir's spokesman ...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir rejected President Bush's appeal to cooperate with a U.N. probe of the slayings of 19 Palestinians and avoid a second anti-Israel vote by the security council, Israel television reported Wednesday. Later Wednesday, the United States and other Security Council members voted 15-0 to rebuke Israel for its refusal to support the investigation of the Oct. 8 shootings. It was the second vote against Israel the past 10 days by the United States, which in the past normally exercised its veto and shielded Israel from U.N. censure. Shamir's spokesman Avi Pazner could not immediately be reached for comment. The television, referring to a letter from Bush that was delivered Tuesday to Shamir, said, ``Shamir sees no possibility of changing his position.'' Shamir's Cabinet voted last week to refuse to cooperate with a U.N. probe into the killings. The Cabinet said cooperating with the U.N. mission would compromise Israel's rule over the city including the Arab sectors Israel annexed following the 1967 Middle East war. ``If we put a loophole in our claim to sovereignty in Jerusalem, the Arabs will exploit it at every future opportunity,'' the television said, quoting an unnamed government official. Israel captured the Arab sectors of Jerusalem in 1967. The television, quoting unnamed sources in Washington, also said Bush, in the letter, ``begged'' Shamir to accept at least a personal envoy from U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. This would compromise a Security Council resolution ordering a three-member delegation to investigate the slayings. The television report did not say whether Shamir gave Bush a written reply or conveyed his message via diplomatic channels. Israel is conducting its own investigation into the shooting deaths of at least 19 Palestinians by Jerusalem police during a riot at the Temple Mount, a site holy to Moslems and Jews. The results are expected to be published later in the week. Jerusalem, a focal point of the Arab-Israeli conflict, is home to 350,000 Jews and 150,000 Arabs.

DOC.HEAD: Familes of Slaying Victims Crusade Together Against Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Two families who suffered casualties of violent drug trafficking in one of the nation's most active drug-smuggling corridors joined to observe a national week of anti-drug activities. ``More people are hurt by drugs than just the users,'' said Helen Kilroy, whose 21-year-old son, Mark, was slain by a cult of drug smugglers during spring break. Kilroy and her husband, James, joined the mother and sister of drug agent Enrique Camarena, who was tortured and killed by drug traffickers in Mexico in 1985. Camarena's mother, Dora Camarena, and his sister, Myrna Camarena, participated with the Kiloys in the Lower Rio Grande Valley's observance of the national ``Red Ribbon'' week on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. ``Lives have been lost and homes have been broken, leaving families suffering,'' Dora Camarena told the mostly teen-age crowd in Spanish. Tina Guerra, assistant district supervisor with the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission in McAllen, brought the two families together. ``You should have seen it when these families met for the first time,'' Guerra said. ``Fate brought them together. You can't describe it.'' Camarena's 1985 slaying inspired the Red Ribbon campaign, sponsored by the National Federation of Parents. Drug traffickers abducted him in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he worked for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. His death inspired the best-selling book, ``Desperados,'' and a television movie. Myrna Camarena, an office manager with the DEA in the San Diego, Calif., area, translated her mother's brief speech. ``We're hoping to cause an impact on the community locally and to help stop the flow of drugs from Mexico,'' she said. James Kilroy, who wrote a book about his son's death, says he'll donate the book's profits to the Mark Kilroy Foundation, a drug-awareness organization the Kilroys formed. ``We really want to do something about this drug problem,'' he said. ``It's getting worse all the time.'' The drug smugglers accused of killing Mark Kilroy reportedly sought occult protection from authorities and rival smugglers by sacrificing humans. Kilroy, who disappeared in the border city of Matamoros, Mexico, was found buried near the bodies of 14 other people believed to have been killed by the drug ring. The cult's leader, Miami-born Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, and an associate were killed in a shoot-out with Mexican police in May 1989. Other alleged members of the ring are currently being tried in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: President To Skip Fund-Raisers In Albuquerque, Phoenix
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will skip political fund-raisers in Albuquerque and Phoenix on Thursday in order to stay here to deal with the budget crisis, the White House announced Wednesday night. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater expressed optimism that a deal would be reached with congressional Democrats to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years and avoid a Wednesday night shutdown of government operations. Even if the deal is struck Wednesday night, Bush wants to stay in Washington to encourage Republicans to vote for the package, Fitzwater said. Bush still hopes to leave for Irvine, Calif., later Thursday to spend the night there and resume the rest of a five-day trip to California, Hawaii and Oklahoma, he said. Bush spent Tuesday on the campaign trail in New England. One of the Republican congressmen he campaigned for, Rep. Peter Smith of Vermont, emphasized his disagreements with Bush on civil rights and taxes. Another, Rep. Bob Smith, the Senate candidate in New Hampshire, failed to attend the fund-raiser with the president.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects New Anti-Obscenity Curbs on Arts Endowment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 27th graf: ``Sens. Mark,'' with non-voters
DOC.TEXT: The Senate decisively rejected a move Wednesday to slap tough new anti-obscenity curbs on the National Endowment for the Arts and voted instead to penalize artists whose federally subsidized works are deemed obscene by the courts. Ignoring charges by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that the endowment is financing obscenity produced by ``sleazeballs'' at the taxpayers' expense, the Senate approved scrapping current restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for federal support. On a 73-24 roll call, the Senate embraced a bipartisan compromise offered by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, that would require the endowment to recoup its money from grant recipients who are subsequently convicted of violating obscenity or child pornography laws. Guilty artists would be barred from receiving any new federal grants for three years. The House approved a similar proposal last week as part of its $11.9 billion version of a fiscal 1991 appropriations bill for the Interior Department and several other federal agencies, including the NEA, the Forest Service, the Smithsonian Institution and some Energy Department programs. The Senate version, totaling $11.7 billion and including the NEA compromise, was approved Wednesday night on a 92-6 roll call. The Senate bill contains $170 million for the arts endowment, $5 million less than President Bush had requested and a slight reduction from the NEA's $171 million budget last year. The House had voted to boost endowment spending to $180 million. Differences between the two measures will have to be reconciled by House and Senate negotiators before a final bill is sent to the president for his signature. Hatch said his proposal was aimed at ``protecting taxpayer funds and artists' freedom of expression at the same time.'' He said Congress must continue to encourage artistic excellence and diversity through the federal arts agency, and ``I believe we can do this without compromising the bounds of good taste.'' Earlier, on a 70-29 roll call, the Senate rejected a Helms amendment that would have forbidden the endowment to finance works that ``depict or describe, in a patently offensive way, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' Helms argued that his proposal was aimed at halting ``this slime, this sleaze'' allegedly produced by artists who receive federal grants. ``The American people are darn well sick of this,'' said Helms, who grabbed the spotlight as the Senate began debate on a proposed $170 million appropriation for the fedeal arts agency in the 1991 fiscal year which began Oct. 1. ``What is really at stake is whether or not America will allow the cultural high ground in this nation to sink slowly into an abyss of slime to placate people who clearly seek or are willing to destroy the Judaic-Christian foundations of this republic,'' he said. Before the fight was over, the Senate approved a Helms proposal to forbid the NEA to support any work that ``denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion. But Helms was defeated by voice vote in an a separate attempt to block endowment grants to affluent artists, which his formula defined as any individual whose annual income is $94,665 or more. During the debate, Helms was backed by Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who proposed abolishing the endowment for what he called its subsidies of ``frivolity and decadence'' at a time when Congress is struggling to reduce huge budget deficits. Opposing the Helms amendment, Hatch and Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said it would amount to prior restraint on endowment grant recipients and probably would be ruled unconstitutional. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said that at a time when the walls of oppression are falling in Eastern Europe, ``it would be shameful to erect new barriers to freedom of expression'' in America. ``We must resist the call to censorship,'' Kennedy said. Helms read his colleagues a list of offensive paintings and theater performances he accused the endowment of subsidizing. He said they included a woman who performed ``disgusting live sex acts'' on a New York stage and an artist who portrayed homosexuals engaged in ``ultimate excretory acts with one another.'' Helms said senators who voted for his amendment would be ``voting against the vilest, most crudest material, or the funding of it.'' He said his ban would not censor artists but only order them not to ``try to dip into the public trough to pay for it.'' The emotional floor battle over the ``obscene art'' issue was fought over the Senate appropriations bill that earmarked nearly $6 billion for the Interior Department, its biggest beneficiary. It omits a House-approved one-year moratorium on oil and gas leasing in many sections of federal offshore waters of the Outer Continental Shelf. On Tuesday night, the Senate rejected a move to bypass the Endangered Species Act so logging could continue in Pacific Northwest forest regardless of the impact on the threatened northern spotted owl, and also rejected a move to cut the Forest Service road-building effort in half. The only votes against the bill came from Helms, Humphrey and Sens. Christopher Bond, R-Mo.; Alan Dixon, D-Ill.; Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, and William Roth Jr., R-Del. Sens. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., did not vote. The current obscenity ban, adopted a year ago under pressure from Helms and his conservative allies, forbids endowment financing of works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism, the sexual exploitation of children or ``individuals engaged in sex acts.'' The Senate bill also would allow endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer to continue his requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge not to produce obscene work. The pledge has caused widespread protests among artists and resulted in three lawsuits challenging its constitutionality. By contrast, the House voted to ban Frohnmayer's pledge and to omit any explicit anti-obscenity restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: 14-Year-Old Convicted of Setting Boy on Fire
DOC.TEXT: A neighborhood bully was convicted Wednesday of attempted murder for setting a 12-year-old boy on fire after forcing him into the basement of an abandoned building and binding him to a pipe. The victim, David Opont, survived but will be scarred for life. The 14-year-old defendant, whose name was withheld because of his age, was found guilty under juvenile law of attempted murder, kidnapping, assault, robbery, and attempted robbery following a non-jury trial before Judge Joseph A. Esquirol Jr. ``There could be no other conclusion than he secreted (David), tied him hand and foot and he set him onfire,'' the judge said. He said the boy ``intended to and did in fact severely and permanently disfigure David.'' The teen-ager could be locked up in a juvenile hall for three years, but the sentence could be extended each year until he was 21. He was also ordered to undergo a series of psychological tests. The March 7 incident was a shock to the city and evoked an outpouring of sympathy and get-well messages from across the country. While in the hospital, David was visited by former President Reagan, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and entertainment and sports figures. The defendant, who is large for his age, sat impassively at Wednesday's hearing, occasionally wagging his head from side to side during the hour-long proceeding. He was returned to the Spofford Juvenile Detention Center in the Bronx where he has been held since his arrest on the evening after the attack. David and his parents weren't in the courtroom when the judge returned his verdict. The boy later issued a statement through his family that he was glad to finally put the attack behind him. ``I am looking forward to my life and all the challenge it brings,'' the statement said. At the trial, David identified his attacker and testified the bully had accosted him and his friends a day earlier on a street in their neighborhood in the borough of Brooklyn. On the morning he was burned, David said, the same boy stopped him and a companion as they walked to school and searched their pockets for money. The older boy then made David go with him into an abandoned building, bound his hands behind him and set him on fire after David refused to smoke something the assailant offered him, David testified. David, who moved with his family from Haiti two years ago, suffered severe burns over much of his body and was initially given less than a 50 percent chance of survival. After several skin grafs and a strong recovery, he was released from the hospital in August. He is still undergoing rehabilitation and will always bear scars from the attack, the judge said. Police initially said David had been torched because he refused to smoke crack with his assailant, but they later said robbery was the motive for the attack. The teen-ager was known in his neighborhood as a vicious bully who taunted smaller children and stole their lunch money and other property.

DOC.HEAD: Alaskan Hopes To Find Market for Glacier Ice
DOC.TEXT: Galen Cook figures glacier ice from his native Alaska is just what Hawiians and their guests need to keep cool - or at least to keep their drinks cool. Cook has shipped 25 tons of glacier ice to Honolulu to test the market. The city's Waikiki resort area was an ideal test site because of the large number of Japanese tourists, Cook said. Glacier ice became a popular novelty item in Japan a couple years ago. Glacier ice, compressed over thousands of years, has a clear prism-like sparkle and is denser than ice produced by refrigerators or ice machines, Cook said. The density means it melts more slowly and doesn't water down drinks as quickly as regular ice cubes, he said. The product has been well received by customers, who say it doesn't change the taste of their drinks, said Sean Ellis, food and beverage manager of the Sheraton Moana Surfrider Hotel. The Sheraton was Cook's first big customer. He has since contracted with another Waikiki hotel and a nightclub. Cook charges $1 per pound for the ice, which raises the cost of drinks by about 15 cents a glass, Ellis said. Cook said he doesn't know of any other vendors of glacier ice and his main competition is the ice machine, which can provide large quantities of ice faster and more cheaply. Cook's partner, Al Schafer, has a permit from the state of Alaska to harvest the free-floating ice that falls from a glacier near Seward, Cook said. The idea came from a term paper Cook wrote at Chaminade University, where he is working on a master's degree in business administration. ``This is an exercise in marketing mystique,'' Cook said. ``It's from Alaska, it's from a glacier, and it's from a different time zone.''

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto's Party Routed in Pakistan; She Claims Vote Was `Stolen'
LaserPhotos LAR1,ISL1,ISL3
DOC.TEXT: Benazir Bhutto's party suffered a stunning defeat at the hands of her right-wing foes in parliamentary elections Wednesday, according to partial returns. The electoral rout was widely seen as a verdict on her dismissal as prime minister. She refused to concede defeat late Wednesday, and accused President Ghulam Ishaq Khan and the army-backed caretaker government of large-scale vote-rigging in what most analysts and opinion polls predicted would be a close contest. ``This election is a fraud,'' Ms. Bhutto said, fighting back tears. Her opponents dismissed the charges. ``She's a sore loser,'' said Hussein Haqqani, a spokesman for the caretaker government. ``She's finding it hard to accept that she's no longer on the pedestal and that she is no longer the heroine of democracy. After a few days she'll have to accept it.'' Ms. Bhutto herself ran for two seats. She overwhelmingly won re-election in Larkana in southern Sind Province but suffered a humiliating defeat in the northern city of Peshawar, losing by nearly 12,000 votes. She faces trials before special tribunals on corruption charges and could be denied her seat and banished from politics for seven years if convicted. A spokesman for a 40-member group of international poll watchers refused comment on the election until the group assembled. Their assessment could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in vital U.S. economic and military aid. ``I'm angry and shocked at the way elections have been rigged,'' Ms. Bhutto, 37, told reporters in Larkana. ``The president has made a mockery of these elections. It wasn't even subtle.'' Ishaq Khan dismissed her government on Aug. 6 after she held power 20 months. He accused her of heading the most corrupt and inept government in Pakistan's history. Ms. Bhutto said Wednesday, ``Had the counting been done in front of polling agents, I would have accepted the results. But since the polling agents were not present and ballot boxes were stolen, I cannot accept these results.'' She predicted ``a witch hunt'' against her and her supporters would follow. At least nine people were killed and 66 injured in clashes between rival parties during the balloting, despite unprecedented security. Election officials said turnout among the estimated 50 million eligible voters was unusually light - in many places less than 10 percent. More than 1,300 candidates vied for 217 seats in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that will choose the next prime minister. Two independent candidates were elected unopposed. One race was postponed after a candidate was killed in campaign violence. Ishaq Khan and the caretaker government of Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi portrayed Ms. Bhutto as an enemy of Islam, a traitor who sold state secrets to neighboring India and an American puppet. Their actions seemed to cast her as the victim of ``kangaroo courts,'' halted her declining popularity and helped galvanize her party. But with 126 of the 214 races declared, the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance won 61 seats. Ms. Bhutto's center-left Pakistan People's Party and its allies got 26. The rest went to smaller parties and independent candidates. Unofficial reports indicated her party trailing badly in all four provinces. Jatoi and two leaders of the Islamic Democratic Alliance - Nawaz Sharif and Mohammad Khan Junejo - won their races. Hours before results began coming in, Ms. Bhutto predicted her party would take 120 seats. Before voting, she visited her father's grave. Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was overthrown in a bloodless coup in 1977 and was hanged two years later. Ms. Bhutto repeatedly compared her unceremonious dismissal to his ouster. She complained that ballot boxes were stuffed and said she would meet party leaders this week to decide whether to call street demonstrations or boycott Parliament. Jatoi, in a broadcast announcement before results were announced, warned that anyone instigating trouble would be ``dealt with a stern hand.'' Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, who has been jailed for nearly three weeks on kidnapping and extortion charges, won his bid to represent the sprawling Karachi slum of Lyari in Parliament but lost his hometown of Nawabshah. He was defeated there by Murtaza Jatoi, Jatoi's son. Nusrat Bhutto, her mother and a former senior minister, easily won re-election, even though she has been in Britain since her daughter's dismissal. Wednesday's election was the fifth since Pakistan was created as a homeland for Moslems in the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule of the Indian subcontinent. Nearly 100,000 soldiers, paramilitary troops and police patrolled the most volatile areas Wednesday to prevent violence. The People's Party and three smaller allied parties were pitted against the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 parties united by their dislike for Ms. Bhutto but strained by individual ambitions. The Western-educated Ms. Bhutto became the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation in December 1988 following the first free elections in Pakistan after a decade of military rule.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Arrested For Allegedly Locking Daughter In Closet For 10 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with parents being charged. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The girl...
DOC.TEXT: Jenifer, 2nd graf; Joann, 19th graf, are cq.

A 12-year-old girl was found locked in a filthy closet and her parents were charged Wednesday with child endangerment for allegedly keeping her confined most of her life, police said. The girl was found Monday night in a reeking, cockroach-infested closet kept closed by a bent nail, said Sgt. Jenifer Kauffman. Joseph and Sandra Sauceda were charged with felony child endangerment, and the father also was charged with felony child abuse, Ms. Kauffman said. Police were tipped by a relative. When they asked the Saucedas to show them the girl, they took officers to the closet, Ms. Kauffman said. Officers said the girl was lying in her own feces and wore a urine-stained sweatsuit. ``Obviously, it's a terrible, traumatic condition,'' said Sgt. Bob Evans. ``It will probably take years to recover from.'' The couple was held in this city 60 miles east of Los Angeles in lieu of $50,000 bail each. Arraignment was set for Thursday. The girl and her six brothers and sisters, ages 2 months to 15 years, were turned over to the county Child Protective Services. There was no evidence that the other children were abused, Ms. Kauffman said. Police said they didn't know why the girl apparently was singled out for alleged abuse. Joseph Sauceda, 33, denied that he and his 31-year-old wife abused their daughter. He said te closet was not a cell and that his family was a loving one. ``My other girl was playing with her and I guess she locked it by accident,'' he said in an interview at the county jail Tuesday. Police said the child, whose name was withheld, was unusually thin and bruised after being kept in a 4-foot-by-5-foot closet in a back bedroom. Investigators believe the child rarely left the closet and probably had been kept locked up at other homes where the family lived during the past decade, Ms. Kauffman said. Police based their belief on comments from relatives and other evidence at the home, she said. ``She was apparently taken out on occasion, but it was not a consistent activity,'' Ms. Kauffman said. ``For example, recently she was taken out once a day to go to the bathroom and do some chores.'' Although malnourished and slightly bruised, the girl was in fairly good shape, she added. The discovery shocked arresting officers. ``This little girl really got to me. I normally don't get emotional, but what I saw there ... I was not able to tolerate,'' said Cpl. Steve Filson, a 13-year police veteran. ``Both myself and my partner there virtually gagged when the room was opened. There was a very strong urine smell.'' Neighbors were stunned. ``This is making me sick,'' said 18-year-old Joann Banchetto. ``They were good people. I never saw them beat their kids. They've always treated their kids right.'' But Ms. Banchetto said some things didn't seem right. ``They said they had seven kids,'' Ms. Banchetto said. ``But we always saw only six. When you'd talk to them, they would barely peek out of their window.'' The Saucedas had rented the home for at least seven months, neighbors said. Neighbor Lorina Finley said she once heard a young girl's plea for food. ``I heard a lot of screaming and crying in there. She was just crying, `I'm hungry, I'm hungry,''' she said. Ms. Finley said she also heard Joseph Sauceda shout, ``Shut up!'''

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Turns Down New Bush Appeal; U.S. Voting Against Israel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with four grafs to reflect U.N. vote taken; picks up 4th graf: ``The U.S.,'' editing changes to conform
DOC.TEXT: Israel rejected an appeal by President Bush to cooperate with a United Nations investigation, prompting another U.S. vote against Israel in the U.N. Security Council, U.S. officials and other sources said Wednesday. The vote was on a resolution deploring Israel's rejection of the inquiry into the slaying of 19 Palestinian Arabs on the Temple Mount. U.S. officials, declining to be identified, said all other members of the Security Council were notified ahead of time that the United States would not veto the resolution. The vote was 15-0 in the Security Council, marking the second time in 10 days the United States voted against its ally. The resolution was sponsored primarily by Yemen and other non-aligned nations. A U.S. veto would have killed the resolution. The U.S. decision shows the growing rift between two friendly governments. The United States, through the years, mostly stood by Israel in rebuffing attacks on its policies and actions in the United Nations. But after 19 Palestinians were killed by Israeli police in a riot Oct. 8 the United States drafted a resolution condemning Israel and calling for an investigation under the supervision of Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The Israeli Cabinet declined to cooperate. Bush on Tuesday sent a letter to Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealing for cooperation with the investigation, U.S. officials and other sources said Wednesday. While the Israeli leader did not reply in writing, it was made clear to American diplomats in Washington and in Jerusalem that Israel's position had not changed, the sources told The Associated Press. Israel's initial decision to rebuff the U.N. inquiry was based on two principles that still stand, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They were that the U.N. Security Council had already reached its conclusions, condemning Israel before making a factual judgment, and that the inquiry conflicts with Israel's sovereignty, the sources said. This position was conveyed to U.S. Ambassador William Brown, who delivered Bush's letter Tuesday in Jerusalem, and by Zalman Shoval, the new Israeli ambassador, in meetings in Washington with Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser; Robert Kimmitt, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, and Dennis B. Ross, head of the policy planning staff of the State Department. The letter represented a last-ditch attempt by Bush to persuade Israel to admit the investigators lest it face sterner treatment from the U.N. Security Council. Israeli television, reporting on the letter, quoted unidentified sources in Washington as saying Bush ``begged'' Shamir to accept at least a personal envoy from the secretary-general. The United States was the principal drafter of the initial resolution, which condemned Israel for the Oct. 8 slayings. The Israeli government has initiated its own investigation. The sources, declining to be identified, confirmed an account of Bush's letter published in the New York newspaper Newsday. Later, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, confirmed Bush had written to Shamir about the U.N. inquiry. She said Bush also expressed condolences about the violence between Israelis and Palestinian Arabs and told Shamir it was ``important to all of us to have the focus back on Iraq.'' She said if Israel complied there would be no point in having a second resolution approved. ``If Prime Minister Shamir agreed to let the Secretary-General's mission come in it would make null and void the necessity of having a second resolution,'' she said. The Palestinians were slain after police used tear gas and rubber bullets in an unsuccessful attempt to stop the stoning of Jews praying at the Western Wall. The attack on the Jews was not condemned in the resolution. The administration, in urging Israel to cooperate with the inquiry, says it is the only way for the facts to be sorted out. A U.S. official, insisting on anonymity, said if Shamir refused to cooperate ``the mood of the council will be less solicitous than if they did.'' However, he said no resolutions apart from the renewed request had been prepared for council action. Among Israel's reasons for rejecting the investigators is concern the United Nations is trying to get a foothold in Jerusalem, the nation's capital. East Jerusalem, the older, predominantly Arab section of the city, ruled by Jordan for 19 years, was captured by Israeli forces in the 1967 Mideast war and annexed. The United States and nearly all other nations do not recognize Israeli sovereignty over East Jerusalem. Several Jews and Arabs have been killed and wounded in the city since the Oct. 8 melee. Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Tuesday barred Palestinians from traveling to Israel from the West Bank and Gaza, which were also held by the Arabs until Israel's victory in the 1967 Six-Day War. Ms. Tutwiler said, ``we hope that the situation will rapidly calm down so these measures can be lifted and Israelis and Palestinians can go about their lives in peace and security, as they both deserve.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Generals Implicated in Repression Leave Chile's Army
DOC.TEXT: Three army generals linked to human rights abuses under the former military regime are stepping down, officials and news reports said Wednesday. The generals each headed the National Information Center, the disbanded secret police force known by its Spanish acronym CNI. The agency has been linked to human rights abuses including the killing and torture of dissidents and illegal arrests. In a brief statement, the army announced the ``voluntary resignations'' of a total of six army generals. The statement did not identify the officers, but the local media gave six names. Three of the officers, Gens. Hugo Salas, Gustavo Abarzua and Jorge Iturriaga, headed CNI at different times during the military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who led the 1973 coup that ousted Salvador Allende Gossens, an elected Marxist. Pinochet dissolved the CNI shortly before he stepped down in March and was replaced by his elected President Patricio Aylwin. Abarzua was the last head of the CNI; when it was disbanded he was named chief of army intelligence. Salas' last position was army chief of staff, and Iturriaga was a division commander. Also Wednesday, unidentified military sources quoted by local new reports said 16 officers were ousted from the army after an internal investigation showed they participated in an illegal loan and credit institution. Defense Minister Patricio Rojas said the inquiry, ordered by Pinochet, had ``confirmed the participation of army personnel'' in the illegal scheme, details of which were unavailable. News reports said hundreds of officers lost money. The state television said that at least 35 other officers are still being investigated and face ``serious sanctions for breaking military ethic codes and disicipline.''

DOC.HEAD: Meandering Whale Swims Under Golden Gate and Out to Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Humphrey swimming under the Golden Gate and out to sea. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Humphrey, a...' Denize cq in 8th graf; Gibeson cq in 14th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Humphrey the wayward whale swam under the Golden Gate Bridge Wednesday and headed toward the open sea, ending a four-day visit that saw one wrong turn after another. The 45-ton humpback whale passed under the span about 5 p.m., escorted by a flotilla of small boats, Coast Guard vessels and private cruisers. People on the bridge cheered as Humphrey swam by. He headed back to the ocean where he belongs a day after he was freed from a stranding on mud flats along the shore of San Francisco Bay. For a time, the mammoth mammal seemed to be re-enacting his 1985 tour of San Francisco bay. Then, the wayward whale was tracked by legions of well-wishers as he meandered, far from the open ocean where he belongs, for 25 days. Anxious rescuers tracked the whale through the day as he seemed to be headed anywhere but out to sea. First he was seen south of the bridge, then away to the north. Rescuers mobilized to intercept the 45-ton whale and try to induce him to head out to sea, she said. After the 40-foot Humphrey was freed from the mud flat Tuesday evening he seemed to have gotten his bearings, raising hopes he would join the rest of his kind, which feed in the bay sometimes, but seldom stay for long. ``He was swimming well and going toward the Golden Gate,'' Denize Springer of the California Marine Mammal Center said early in the day. ``Well, he wasn't really going in just one direction. Whales tend to meander.'' Humphrey, for some reason attracted to San Francisco Bay, has a history of meandering. In 1985, when the news media gave him his name, he went through the bay and up the Sacramento River, with much of the nation tracking his wanderings. On Sunday, Humphrey veered off course again, turning left into San Francisco Bay as his fellow migrating whales continued south along the West Coast. He spnnt about 24 hours stuck on the mud flat before the Coast Guard, the incoming tide and a crowd of cheering spectators helped shake him loose Tuesday afternoon. Experts could only speculate about why Humphrey went off course. ``Your guess is as good as mine. But my guess is something's wrong with this guy,'' said Brian Gibeson, a marine biologist at the California Academy of Sciences. It could be that a parasite has affected his brain or rudimentary inner ear, Gibeson said, making Humphrey ``like a car with his wheels out of alignment.''

DOC.HEAD: Love Canal Dumper: Responsible or Reckless? Trial Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 6th graf pvs, `The company...,' to UPDATE with witness testimony. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Eugene Martin-Leff...'
DOC.TEXT: The company that created the Love Canal toxic-waste dump ignored its own employees' warnings and sold the filled-in site to a school board without explaining the dangers, a state lawyer charged Wednesday. Also at the start of a trial over liability for cleanup costs, the president of that company's parent apologized for the problems the dump created. But a company lawyer argued it didn't hide conditions at the site. Hooker Chemicals & Plastics Corp. built the dump in 1942 and sold the land to the Niagara Falls school board in 1953.
