DOC.HEAD: Noted Religious Researcher Leaves Hint of Mainline Turnabout
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Several days before his recent death, noted religion statistician Constant H. Jacquet Jr. said of the longtime decline in mainline Protestant membership: ``It's turning.'' He was ill at home at the time and didn't have at hand comparative figures to document his point. He suggested waiting until he got back to his office. But he didn't make it. He succumbed to cancer that he thought he had overcome. Consequently, his annual compilation of religious data, the 1990 Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches, can be reported this time only without his further clarifying, analytical comments. It shows that the latest U.S. membership figures for churches and synagogues has increased to 145.4 million from 143.8 million a year earlier, a gain of about 1.1 percent, or slightly outstripping the population growth of 1 percent. That means active religious affiliation amounted to 58.7 percent of the American population, a proportion that had inched downward in recent years, but which this time was up fractionally. While the total grew, including the two largest denominations - the 14.9 million Southern Baptists and 57 million Roman Catholics - membership in most mainline Protestant bodies continued to slip, but to a lessening degree. That lessening was the basis of the ``turning'' comment by Jacquet, researcher at the National Council of Churches for 37 years and editor of its annual yearbook, the only comprehensive summary of American religious data. Most mainline Protestant bodies have been losing members since the late 1960s, amounting to millions of inactives dropped from the rolls, but the steep losses of the '70s have moderated since the mid-'80s. That leveling trend, furthered in the latest figures, was seen by Jacquet as presaging a turnabout in the long decline, although he didn't get a chance to detail the statistical pattern of the shift. Jacquet, 64, had undergone surgery for lung cancer last summer and had returned to work, seeming to have overcome the problem. But recently cancer was found to have invaded his spine. His death on Oct. 16 stilled a key voice in measuring the status of American religion for news media, other researchers, reference books and U.S. government departments. Among the denominations still suffering slight losses in his latest compilation, the decreases this time were around 1 percent, often less. It was only a fraction of that for larger denominations such as the 9 million United Methodists, 2.4 million Episcopalians, the 5.3 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and 2.6 million-member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod. However, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) dropped 1.25 percent to 2.9 million, the American Baptists fell 1.22 percent to 1.5 million and the United Church of Christ decreased 1.07 percent to 1.6 million. The latest totals are for 1988, reflecting the regular two-year time lag in accumulating the combined figures. Several later reports from individual denominations show further fading of the prolonged shrinkage. Whiled losses persisted for some denominations, others such as Southern Baptists and Roman Catholics stayed on the upgrade, as did most smaller evangelical denominations. That resulted in the overall increase outpacing population growth. The overall increase in U.S. religious membership was in contrast to the total for Canada, whose inclusive membership dropped about 153,000 to 16.8 million. The yearbook also cited other indications of greater religious activity. These included Gallup Poll findings that weekly worship attendance rose to 43 percent of the population in 1989, up three percentage points from two years before. It means that about 107.5 million Americans attend worship services each week. Teen-age attendance also reached a high mark of 57 percent, compared to 54 percent three years before. Later 1990 Gallup surveys indicate 74 percent of Americans have made a commitment to Christ, up from 66 percent in 1986. However, giving to American churches increased an average of only 3.5 percent, lagging behind the 4.4 percent inflation rate for 1988, resulting in decreased real income. Jacquet, known as ``Connie'' to friends, had been working before his death at compiling figures for next year's yearbook, but associates without his long perspective or experience will have to finish the job. ``Over the years, reporters across the continent knew that Constant Jacquet was their best source for statistical information about American religion,'' said the Rev. J. Martin Bailey, the council's communication director. ``He carried an enormous amount of historical data in his head.''

DOC.HEAD: Talking Taxes: There's Always a Fight About What's Fair
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Jimmy Carter used to call the income tax system a disgrace to the human race. Republican Ronald Reagan said it was so complex, frustrating and unfair as to be un-American. Then the system was overhauled, and when Reagan signed a tax reform bill the Democrats helped fashion, he said equity and certainty had been restored. Not for long. Four years later, the fairness issue is back, sharply drawn by Democratic insistence that the rich haven't been paying their share. The sole surviving certainty about the reformed tax system is that there will be more pressure for changes, meaning increases, next time the government faces a budget crisis. That next time is almost inevitable, and in fewer than the five years the 1990 deficit deal was designed to cover. The $500 billion in deficit reduction it is supposed to produce is based on economic forecasts so optimistic as to be almost euphoric. That includes a forecast of sharply declining interest rates, especially after 1991. Economic growth would have to surge over the same period to meet its revenue estimates, and inflation would have to decrease steadily. Budget negotiators insisted the numbers are not phoney, even though they may not prove correct. By now, that's the pattern. Deficit forecasts have been far from results during the past five years. Those estimates were computed one year at a time, not five, and the major reason they missed was that economic estimates were overly optimistic. Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, said nobody could look people in the eye and claim to know what's going to happen over the five-year span. Nor, he said, could there be any guarantee that the government won't have to address the same problem again. Safer to guarantee that it will be back for another round over taxes, spending and the federal deficit. The economy is slumping, not surging. In the best of circumstances, the projected five-year plan would only reduce the rate of increase in the national debt, not the debt itself. Explaining his grudging agreement to accept tax increases, Bush said Tuesday that Reagan had to compromise, too, because he also had to deal with Democrats in Congress. ``...President Reagan found, same thing, 1982, go back and look at the record, the rhetoric was about the same,'' Bush said during a campaign stop in Manchester, N.H. ``That in spite of his aversion to taxes, the only way to govern was to accept a compromise. ``But Reagan swallowed hard and the economy moved, and interest rates came down ... when he did what he had to do,'' Bush said. His own administration had struggled to avoid compromising on tax rates, trying to hold one of the lines Reagan left, a 28-percent top bracket, set in the 1986 tax reform law. Instead of raising the rate, Republicans wanted to restrict deductions, a disguised, and more complex way of imposing more taxes. Both a higher rate and deduction limits on the wealthy wound up on the table. Governors in both parties complained about restrictions on federal income tax deductions, saying that would restrict their ability to raise state revenues, and would set a precedent that could lead ultimately to eliminating the deductibility of state and local taxes. Senators and House members from states that levy high income taxes said the impact would be uneven and unfair. The counter-argument: Congress took away the deduction for state and local sales taxes in the 1986 law, and that had a disproportionate impact on states that rely most heavily on sales taxes instead of income taxes. That's the way one season's reforms become fodder for the next season's tax debate. Fairness is always in the eye of the political beholder. The tax code and tax rates will be at issue as long as there are politicians to talk about them and Congresses to change them. Before this round, the top tax rate had been changed 10 times in 30 years. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Congressional Outsider Looks to Join Establishment
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Rep. John Conyers was a fiery rebel who disdained the establishment for much of his first quarter-century in Congress. Now he's joining the other side. ``I get some kidding about the fact that now I'm one of the institutional leaders that I used to criticize so much,'' he said in a recent interview. ``But my goals haven't changed that much.'' The black Democrat from Detroit is completing his second year as chairman of the House Government Operations Committee. It might seem a confining assignment for a civil-rights champion who stood with Martin Luther King Jr., slept on sidewalks with the homeless and raised the possibility of impeaching President Reagan over the Iran-contra affair. But Conyers, 61, insists he will not abandon the causes he has supported since his activist days in the 1960s. Rather, he can pursue his social agenda as an insider, substituting deal-making and quiet persuasion for the searing rhetoric of old. The son of an auto worker and union organizer, Conyers was interested in politics and civil rights from his youth. He chose law school over his other passion - jazz - after his father insisted he not become a musician. ``He thought that was unthinkable ... wasn't steady work and wasn't responsible work as far as he was concerned,'' Conyers said. ``I had a dickens of a time working out an arrangement to buy a trumpet because he thought that would start me out on the wrong way.'' But Conyers remains a big jazz fan. He's even sponsoring legislation to forgive the $1.6 million tax debt of band leader Woody Herman's estate. Conyers says an unscrupulous business manager gambled away Herman's money and didn't file his taxes for six years, leaving Herman penniless before his 1987 death. Unpredictability and a fierce desire for personal privacy are other Conyers traits. He ended his lifelong bachelorhood in June, marrying 25-year-old Monica Ann Esters without telling his closest friends, political associates - or even his brother. ``I've never gotten into his personal or social life,'' said Eugene Gilmer of Detroit, a friend since 1942. ``It's just always been hands off.'' Conyers is continuing to evolve into a congressional insider a year after what some considered a potentially fatal blunder: his 1989 bid to unseat veteran Detroit Mayor Coleman Young. His error-plagued, poorly organized campaign flopped and he finished third in the Democratic primary. He was a charismatic figure on the campaign trail, dapper in suspenders and colorful handkerchiefs. But he often showed up late for appointments or missed them altogether. On one occasion, aides tried to rush him to an engagement but he insisted on stopping at a restaurant for soul food. After that defeat, Democrats spoke openly of challenging Conyers's re-election to the House. Instead, he was renominated for his House seat without opposition and is a heavy favorite to defeat Republican Raymond H. Shoulders in the general election. ``You don't really lose any clout here (in Congress) if you run for another office and don't win,'' Conyers said. ``There are lots of guys walking around that tried to run for governor or mayor.'' Conyers became chairman of the Government Operations Committee - which has jurisdiction over nearly all government programs and agencies - when Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, moved to the Judiciary Committee helm in early 1989. Since then, Conyers has conducted hearings and introduced legislation on topics as diverse as the drug war, environmental protection, the military budget and privacy of genetic information. He sponsored legislation, which became law this year, requiring the FBI to compile statistics on crimes motivated by bigotry. Another Conyers bill that would register people to vote when they obtain a driver's license has cleared the House. Conyers also is using the committee as a platform to air blacks' grievances against the government. He prodded the FBI to investigate charges that black agents were being harassed. And he has promised an investigation of complaints that black officeholders are being singled out for criminal investigations - the subject of a shouting match earlier this year between Conyers and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. ``All-out sleazy tactics are being used to entrap black officials by any means that can be imagined,'' Conyers complained at a committee hearing. ``I trust our judicial system'' to treat people fairly, Thornburgh said. ``I used to believe that,'' Conyers retorted. ``I don't believe that any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Coming Soon to Your Grocer's Shelves - Your Local Bank
DOC.TEXT: Along with a special on tuna on Aisle 7 and a sale on cat food on Aisle 4, don't be surprised if your local supermarket features a nice deal on checking accounts. Supermarket banking, something of a novelty when it first appeared in the 1970s, has been rapidly gaining popularity over the last five years. With banks under the gun to cut costs in a rocky economy, there may be a lot more of them soon. It's much cheaper for a bank to set up a branch at a grocery counter than to operate in a tradional brick and mortar bank building. And they're apparently popular with customers. There are currently 847 supermarket bank branches nationwide, with most of them in the Southeast and Southwest, said John W. Garnett, executive vice president of Norcross, Ga.-based International Banking Technologies, a consulting firm that helps banks open and operate these facilities. Garnett admits that at first blush, it looks mighty strange to see a banker holding court amid the produce and frozen pizza. ``People are accustomed to seeing a 400,000-square-foot branch,'' he said. ``When you walk into a supermarket and see a 400-square-foot branch - there is a perception you have to overcome. ``We explain (to customers) that it's backed up by the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.), that the bank is sound. Then it's not a problem.'' The grocery branches are full-service operations that can do virtually anything a traditional bank location can do. However, they usually stay open into the evening and also do business on Sundays, Garnett said. Garnett's company entered the supermarket bank business in 1983, and now has 350 branches across the country. IBT had $20 million in revenue last year, he said. Garnett said the unconventional operations provide a great opportunity to attract new customers. ``In a traditional bank . . . 95 percent of your walk-ins are already customers or coming in for a specific reason,'' he said. ``Ninety-five percent in the supermarket are not your customers - they're not coming in for banking, they're coming in to shop.'' So employees at the grocery branches have to be aggressive marketers. These bankers walk the aisles and solicit business, Garnett said. The chief attraction for the bank business, Garnett said, is cost-cutting. Where it costs an average of $1 million up front to open a traditonal style bank, it takes only $200,000 to open a grocery branch, he said. Ongoing costs vary from location to location, said Garnett, whose exhibit drew a respectable crowd this week at the American Bankers Association convention. He declined to give an average of monthly operating costs. In the Atlanta area, Bank South has branches in 36 Kroger stores, Garnett said. IBT recently signed a deal with Pittsburgh's Mellon Bank to open 21 locations, he added. ``Not everybody's crazy about supermarket banks but some are,'' said Dallas banking consultant Don Wright. ``They seem to work quite well if you put them in the right location.'' Garnett said IBT's clients include banks as well as savings and loans, though S&L interest has stalled since the thrift industry has come under seige. In the last two years, additions to the grocery list have been almost exclusively commercial banks, Garnett said. About 64 percent of all supermarket facilities are banks, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marion Cunningham Brings Fannie Farmer into the '90s
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Turn to page 225 of the 13th edition of ``The Fannie Farmer Cookbook'' to learn how to truss a chicken, page 628 to bake a batch of brownies. Or just soak in the spirit of the book, which is only partly about food. It also is about ``an act of giving and receiving, because the experience at table is a communal sharing; talk begins to flow, feelings are expressed, and a sense of well-being takes over,'' Marion Cunningham writes in the 13th edition of Fannie Merritt Farmer's guide to the American kitchen. A valuable cookbook also reflects its time, and the previous edition - Cunningham's first, published 11 years ago - already was losing its relevancy when she set out three years ago on the new edition. ``I tell you, things are different, really different. It was only looking recipe by recipe that I could see how dramatic our changes have been,'' she said in an interview in New York. Testing every recipe in the 12th edition, Cunningham dropped 200 and added 325, for an appropriate total of 1,990. Fat was reduced when it worked, and recipes sometimes dropped when it didn't. There's no kipered herring in cream or crabmeat terrapin, for example. There are new chapters on microwave cooking (which surely won't prompt any manufacturers to ask her to be a spokeswoman), outdoor cooking and vegetarian foods, such as zucchini pancakes and a winter vegetable cobbler that ``will win any contest.'' All sorts of ethnic ingredients are used. Raw fish is out, as is steak tartare. Salt generally is left up to the cook. And there are warnings about raw eggs and fish and other safety problems. ``Those were the issues that were very hard to reconcile,'' Cunningham said. ``To act responsibly and not destroy the feeling that cooking and eating are ... well, certainly one of the better human endeavors.'' While Farmer aimed ``The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book,'' published in 1896, at families who had help in the kitchen, the newest edition of ``The Fannie Farmer Cookbook'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $24.95) is intended to capture the way ordinary people actually eat. So along with the instructions for making pasta from scratch are recipes for a ham and cheese sandwich, for making popcorn, hotdogs and macaroni and cheese. Cunningham tells how to improve the flavor of canned broths, and offers suggestions for leftovers. ``Everyone clamors'' for the simple cheese spread in the appetizer chapter, she writes. There is plenty of practical advice, too. Of olive oils, for example, she says, ``Money does not always buy the best, and I have found the terms `virgin' and `extra virgin' not very meaningful.'' Both inside covers have all sorts of nifty facts - things you've been told dozens of times but can't seem to keep straight, such as how to tell if an egg is stale and whether cream whips better cold or at room temperature. Farmer would, Cunningham concluded, wholeheartedly embrace today's health movement. Cunningham, too, thinks we ought to know what we eat. ``But in concentrating so much on the negative aspects of eating, we are making ourselves overly fearful and we are missing the pleasure that a good meal provides,'' she writes. ``Instead of stringent diets, eliminating almost all fats, all salt, all sugar from our diets, and bloating ourselves with high-fiber products, I believe that the best possible approach for the average person is to eat a wide variety of foods and to eat sensibly, in moderation.'' While there is plenty of low-fat food, this is no diet book. Along with the turkey patties and vegetable soups and green salads, there is a ``carpetbag steak,'' a beef and oyster dish from the ``improvident days'' of the 19th century, and chicken fried steak served with milk gravy. Cunningham delivers a storehouse of basic information - and a pep talk. Come on, now, just get up and go in the kitchen. Taste the food, experiment. It's fun, it's homey and it tastes good. Don't let your failures stop you. ``Cooking is a dandy way to solve a lot of problems,'' said Cunningham. Besides, she said, ``It's harder to learn to drive a car.'' Cunningham, 68, began the 12th edition of Fannie Farmer in 1974, with no writing experience and no famous name. She had been a full-time homemaker, and two years earlier had met the late American cooking icon James Beard. ``Jim Beard recommended me. I didn't think I had any qualifications,'' said Cunningham, sitting on a hotel bed with her legs drawn up under her, gray hair pulled straight back into a short, neat ponytail. The choice made sense to Judith Jones, Cunningham's editor at Knopf. ``For one thing, she had worked with Beard and his classes on the West Coast. He thought she really typified the good home cook in America and had natural good taste, and that's just what Fannie Farmer needed,'' Jones said. Cunningham was charged with ``restoring the old-fashioned principles.'' ``It made me so happy to have something to focus on. I've really loved it,'' she said. ``I loved it from the beginning.'' Her pale blue eyes still express a little awe at her success more than a decade later, during which she also has written ``The Fannie Farmer Baking Book'' and ``The Breakfast Book'' and worked as a restaurant consultant. Her husband, a man she'd known since kindergarten and who she says gave her the support and encouragement to become a professional, died three years ago. Their son and daughter are grown. So except for a yellow labrador named Rover and a cat, she lives alone and cooks for herself in Walnut Creek, Calif. Besides Beard, she uses ``Joy of Cooking'' and the early American cookbooks she collects: ``I turn to a lot of them, wonderful recipes, simple to make.'' Like three-quarters of American families, she has a microwave. The ``speedy, clean and silent'' oven did not fare well under Cunningham's scrutiny, although she includes more than 50 recipes specifically for it. ``The microwave has promised a lot more than it can deliver,'' she said. It was, she wrote, no faster than the stove for many of the vegetables she tested. Meat becomes ``pallid and the texture is not appealing.'' While Cunningham experimented with the new in equipment and ingredients, sometimes she found the old to be far superior. Lobster thermidor and newburg, for example, did not work with milk instead of cream, and with cream they stayed. ``People can read about them if they don't want to make them,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bible Scholar on Dual Track as Both Methodist and Roman Catholic
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Convinced it's now warranted, the Rev. William R. Farmer is both a United Methodist and a Roman Catholic. The combination contrasts with the separate institutional postures, but he says there is firm basis for it. His rare, joint allegiance puts into effect for an individual the ecumenical movement's unifying goal for the churches. They haven't yet made it formally, but he says the way has opened for it on essentials. Consequently, he said, he acted to ``live a reality that is here, but that still is hidden to most people'' - even though Protestant-Catholic dialogue teams have found sufficient mutuality for it. ``You have to act proleptically, to see something coming, and act now as if that which is coming is already here,'' he said in an interview. ``It's apparently not going to happen in my lifetime. ``So I've taken steps to actualize it in my own life in a practical way. It works for me. I don't see any need to wait for official bodies 100 years from now to iron out some of these minor things.'' Farmer, 69, a longtime New Testament professor at Southern Methodist University's Perkins School of Theology, joined Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Dallas last Jan. 25, but he also kept his Methodist affiliation. His unusual step has raised some canonical questions in both denominations that still are to be clarified. He said he has had a ``lot of reaction, the gist of almost all of it positive.'' ``I don't regard it as a conversion, or that I've put away my Methodist heritage at all,'' he said, noting that he continues his Methodist university post and serves as an assistant pastor at St. Luke's Community Methodist Church in Dallas. At the same time, Farmer said, at the Catholic Holy Cross parish led by a longtime friend, the Rev. Timothy Gollop, he was seen as ``bringing into that church a very rich Methodist heritage.'' ``I'm trying to be fully in both congregations in a single ministry, and in the whole church, recognizing its oneness, above all in matters of race,'' Farmer said. Both he and Gollop are white. The two congregations on Dallas' south side are made up largely of blacks and Hispanics. Farmer said that ``the new age of ecumenism'' is taking place in concepts of God's ``option for the poor.'' ``It's grass roots ecumenism,'' he said. ``It's happening all over the world, in homes, in churches. Officials don't know what to do with it. Accordingly, there are no provisions for it and no restrictions against it. ``It's best not to cause scandal, but go ahead and do it, being sure you're doing it in good conscience and doing it in obedience to the Gospel.'' Temporarily, Farmer is on leave as resident theologian at the Methodist Mission Resource Center at Emory University in Atlanta and as a research scholar at Columbia Presbyterian Seminary there. He said that when he returns to his teaching post and ministry in Dallas in January, it will be up to the Roman Catholic and United Methodist bishops there to adjudicate his special status. ``They're studying it,'' he said. ``It doesn't mean we're out of the woods. I don't know what the outcome will be. A lot of good friends in both churches have been very encouraging. It remains to be seen what the bishops will do.'' Farmer said Catholic dialogue teams with Methodists, Lutherans and Episcopalians have found concurrence on most major issues, including a modified papacy, with the pope as presiding officer over a representtive council. He said basic accord also has been found on Christ's ``real presence'' in Holy Communion. ``Basicially, Roman Catholic understanding of it is very close to that of (Methodist founder) John Wesley,'' Farmer said. ``There still are differences and some are important, but they're not great enough to justify our not being able to share the Lord's Supper,'' he added. ``It's a scandal that we're divided at the Lord's table. ``We ought to be ashamed at the excuses we use. It must be very painful to Christ.'' Farmer said that as assistant pastor at St. Luke's, he does not preside in celebrating Holy Communion, but receives it both there and in the Catholic church. Catholic rules generally bar Protestant reception in Catholic services. With his dual membership surmounting that barrier personally, Farmer said the churches ``should find some way of taking communion together on an officially approved basis.'' Most rank-and-file church people, both Protestants and Catholics, ``still are living with stereotypes of the past,'' in which the two Christian branches are seen as contradictory, he said. ``But when you get together, and look at the living Gospel, you find those contradictions disappear,'' he said. ``You find out that essentially they are the same faith.''

DOC.HEAD: Netherlands Becoming Less of a Haven for Refugees
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The Netherlands is tightening the rules on asylum because it hasn't enough money, housing and jobs for all the poor refugees flooding in. Holland is a historic haven for the oppressed. It sheltered the Pilgrims, who fled religious persecution in England, before they sailed for the New World. A decade ago, in 1980, only 1,330 people claimed refugee status in the Netherlands. This year, the number is expected to reach 20,000 and the government threatens to jail aliens who make unjustified requests for asylum. Dutch officials contend most asylum seekers are economic refugees looking for easier lives in this high-tech welfare state. Hundreds of people have come from economically depressed Eastern Europe in recent months, and the government fears a new rush of arrivals if the Persian Gulf crisis turns into war. The Netherlands subscribes to the U.N. definition of political refugees as those fleeing persecution on ideological grounds, and is reluctant to stretch its welfare resources in a time of economic uncertainty. Jobs, housing and tolerance are getting scarce, and only about 13 percent of asylum requests are approved. ``This is one of the most densely populated countries in the world,'' said Maurice van Hezik, spokesman for the Justice Ministry. ``There's pretty high unemployment among the non-Dutch population. If you were to admit people who only come to work, that would make the problem worse.'' One asylum seeker, Sara Amini of Iran, claims she was persecuted at home for being a member of a small opposition party in Iran. When she arrived last summer with her husband and two children, she expected the free housing and allowances that used to be given nearly all asylum seekers. Instead, they were jammed into a 15-foot-square room at a former convent school in Rijsbergen, one of 23 refugee camps in Holland. ``I heard people in the Netherlands were very friendly, very helpful compared to other European people,'' She said in an interview. ``I didn't expect it to be like this.'' People seeking asylum in the Netherlands used to be taken to government-subsidized housing projects and given social welfare payments equivalent to about $800 a month. In 1987, however, an influx of ethnic Tamils fleeing the civil war in Sri Lanka gave rise to what critics call the ``bed, bath and bread'' program. The government opened 15 refugee camps, including Rijsbergen, to house asylum seekers during processing. Aad Kosto, deputy justice minister, said this summer he would jail those who sought asylum without good reason and might flee the camps and try to lose themselves in the population. Only a few people have been jailed, but the practice is expected to become more common in the effort to stop rejected asylum seekers from joining the estimated 50,000 to 60,000 illegal aliens in this nation of 14.6 million. Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers summoned the mayors of eight towns and villages in September and told them each would be host to a new refugee camp. He said the first busloads of people were on their way. Seven more camps are planned by the Welfare Ministry, which is buying 500 mobile homes. Van Hezik said some people admit they've only come for jobs, and others offer ``the strangest stories.'' He cited the case of a Third World refugee who claimed to have arrived on a ship bound for Switzerland, which is landlocked. Van Hezik said the man apparently hoped to be expelled to that country. In early August, Romanians began pouring into Eindhoven in southern Holland. Radio Free Europe, the U.S.-sponsored station, had described the city as hospitable to strangers, van Hezik said. Hundreds of East Europeans have made their way to the Netherlands and the Persian Gulf may provide the next source of refugees, said Jan Tielemans, director of the Rijsbergen camp. ``We'll probably be noticing the side effects . . . the Indians, the Sri Lankans who are huddling in Jordan, Eygptians too,'' he said. ``We won't know for another few months. ``Some of these people are simply looking for a living, and they think one of the ways they'll get it is by asking for asylum.'' A 26-year-old Iraqi at Rijsbergen said he deserted Saddam Hussein's army days before it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I was sick and tired of it all,'' said the man, who identified himself as an artillery sergeant born in Yemen but would not give his name. ``I just wondered what would happen if I deserted.'' He said he hid in a helicopter belonging to the Red Crescent, the Moslem version of the Red Cross, which took him from his position near Basra in the south to the Kurdistan region of northwestern Iraq, then crossed into Turkey. The Iraqi said he reached Amsterdam by ship, and acknowledged he stood ``very little chance'' of being accepted as a refugee. ``If they're willing to listen, I'll tell my story,'' he said. ``If not, the world is big enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Hard Fight for Polish Presidency
DOC.TEXT: It's a tough campaign for president, barbed with Polish humor, between the earthy shipyard worker who founded Solidarity and the somber, laconic intellectual he chose as prime minister. What do Poles think of the contest between Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in their first popular vote for the presidency? Some call it Cham vs. Hamlet. Cham, pronounced ``ham,'' is Polish for bumpkin. Others have asked: Will Mazowiecki declare his candidacy before or after the election? Then there's the story of a problem Walesa had when he wanted to reserve a burial site in Jerusalem next to Jesus Christ. He found the cost was $150,000, it goes, and said to his top aide: ``I don't know, Krzysiek. Is it worth it for only three days?'' The duel between Eastern Europe's first non-Communist head of government and the man who gave him the job has rekindled interest in politics after months of hand-wringing by commentators over post-Communist apathy. Nearly all conversations turn sooner or later to the question of which one will occupy Belweder Palace, seat of Polish presidents. A man was even killed in a drunken dispute with his son-in-law over who would be the better president, the state news agency reported. Poland held parliamentary elections in June 1989 that were largely free and democratic local elections in May, but this is the first real contest because Solidarity candidates swept the earlier votes. Surveys indicate the two former Solidarity allies are running about even. Other candidates have ventured into the ring, including Roman Bartoszcze of the Peasant Party and Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz of the Social Democrats, formerly the Communists, but only Walesa and Mazowiecki are given a real chance. If neither gets 50 percent of the votes Nov. 25, a runoff will be held Dec. 9. Part of the fascination stems from their contrasting styles. Walesa is electric, speaking rapidly, seeming to bob and weave through questions thrown at him from the crowd. Mazowiecki is ``grey on grey'' in the words of one newspaper, shy and ponderous in speech but exuding character and moral authority. Walesa declared early and began an aggressive campaign immediately with meetings at factories, where he is strong, and with academics, Mazowiecki's turf. In the first three weeks of October, Walesa visited nine cities, saw more than 100,000 people and was seen by millions more on television. Local Solidarity chapters organize his Western-style rallies, held outdoors or in large arenas with banners, brass bands and deafening loudspeakers. Mazowiecki made his first campaign appearance Oct. 14, two weeks after Walesa, in the Krakow Philharmonic Hall, which seats only 800 people. Instead of direct questions from the crowd, he took written ones that were rephrased by his campaign spokesman. The prime minister seems hesitant about contact with strangers. Hundreds of people waited outside the hall in Krakow for two hours and Mazowiecki rewarded them with only a few minutes on the balcony, his stilted words of thanks barely audible through a bullhorn. His dedication to his job, evident in his tired, careworn appearance, earns sympathy even from people who say they will vote for Walesa. After becoming prime minister in August 1989, Mazowiecki set a considered, pragmatic course that won respect abroad and gave Poles a sense of security against the sudden shocks of revolutionary change. To many, however, Mazowiecki's government has seemed to drag its feet, allowing former secret police to destroy records and keeping Communist ministers in the government half a year after the party dissolved. In his campaign, Walesa advocates faster change and has been quoted as intending to use a ``sharp axe'' to chop away vestiges of the old system. He and Mazowiecki also appear to disagree about policy toward the Communist leadership. When he took office, the prime minister spoke of drawing a line between present and past, but Walesa has said he wants to ``settle accounts'' with those who have injured Poland or stolen from it. If Walesa becomes president, Mazowiecki says, he will join the opposition. Walesa replies that he already has five other candidates for prime minister. Critics accuse Walesa of currying favor with the mob, promising easy solutions he cannot deliver and becoming a demagogue who could abuse the still-fragile democracy and frighten off Western investors. ``I'll vote for Mazowiecki because, under his presidency, I can sleep peacefully,'' Adam Michnik, a former Walesa adviser, told a rally. ``If someone knocks at my door at 5 in the morning, it can only be the milkman.'' ``Walesa is as suitable to be president as I am to be a radio announcer,'' Michnik, now editor of Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's leading daily newspaper, said in a recent broadcast. Michnik spoke with his usual stutter. Walesa wished him luck in radio.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs Nov 2

DOC.HEAD: Leath Looks on 12 Years in House
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Marvin Leath came to Congress from the heart of Texas with a country musician's soul and a banker's sense. But after a dozen years in the House, Leath is calling it quits - frustrated by the ability of an individual congressman to make a difference. ``You see so much written in the media and so forth about people, incumbents, who get these jobs and they never leave and they're an institution,'' said the Waco Democrat. ``...People say nobody walks away from that job. Well somebody did,'' he said. ``And maybe that gives a little bit of faith to people who think the system is so totally corrupt and bad. It really isn't.'' In the early 1980s, Leath was a part of the group of conservative Democrats called the ``Boll Weevils'' that supported a stronger defense and tax reform. But he said defense spending ran amuck under President Reagan and the deficit's growth from $40 billion to more than $300 billion ``deeply distresses'' him. ``Most of the things I hoped to do ... the big issues, we did something about but we did in excess,'' Leath said. ``I really thought the 80s was going to be the decade that was the most critical in the country's history,'' he said. ``Perhaps it was. But I think if you look back on that, I have to think that as a government, we blew it.'' Reagan didn't exert the leadership to make hard choices, Leath said, noting the government wasn't designed for Congress to make laws alone. The hundreds of interests reflected by Congress also frustrate its power, he said. ``You can't expect (Congress) to develop national policy,'' Leath said. ``You've got to have a strong president, willing to take the political risks to solve the problems. Bush is much more prone to do that than Reagan.'' Leath, who made his fortune as a banker in Marlin and Waco, is known as a pretty fair country music crooner and host of a popular annual barbecue. ``You don't see a whole lot of those kinds of parties around here,'' said Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, who was elected in 1978 from a neighboring district and was also a ``Boll Weevil.'' ``This guy has star potential,'' Congressional scholar Norm Ornstein said of Leath's singing. Leath's friend Willie Nelson has encouraged him to cut an album. But, Leath said, ``I'm a little bit old to go on the country music circuit.'' At 59, Leath is only two years older than Nelson. In Congress, Leath closely followed the problems of the budget and financial industry from a seat on the House Budget Committee. He voted against thrift deregulation in 1980 and argued that crisis in thrifts, banks and insurance companies was caused by lawmakers' ``foolish mistakes.'' ``Those of us who understood what the banking system was, understood why we had some of the rules we had for 50 years. We felt very reasonably assured when you destroyed those things that were necessary foundations, this would happen,'' Leath said. ``But you couldn't get anybody to listen to you.'' Leath will take about $484,000 in leftover campaign funds with him when he leaves. He'll keep some for himself to repay expenses from that first campaign, he said. The rest will go to charity and political candidates. ``I think that gives me a good way to stay involved in the system,'' Leath said. He worried some about leaving constituents in the lurch, particularly while fighting the Army's decision to deactivate one of two armored divisions at Fort Hood in his district. ``You can always say, `I've just got to do another term.' First thing you know, you're a doddering old man,'' Leath said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Oct. 29

DOC.HEAD: Teaching Dealers a New Way To Sell Used Cars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also running on financial wires.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jim DeVoe's down-home, deep voice and pot belly exude friendliness. He's also pretty smart, with an MBA under his belt. And he's good with numbers, having worked in commercial loans for a big Chicago bank. The question is: Would you buy a used car from this man? So many people have that used-car dealer DeVoe is now selling his sales techniques to others. Every month, dozens of dealers nationwide travel to this General Motors Corp. factory town to hear the successful 46-year-old native Hoosier explain how they can make money selling used cars to customers with bad credit. The three-day course outlines DeVoe's ``buy here-pay here'' philosophy, a trade practice by which dealers provide the financing for customers the banks have turned away. ``The car dealers today are having plenty of trouble, and they need extra help,'' said DeVoe, who owns a Chevrolet-Cadillac dealership. Domestic car sales were off around 5 percent through early October over the previous year. The prospect of a recession, declining consumer confidence and high gasoline prices make it unlikely sales will rebound any time soon. They are conditions that make buy here-pay here all the more attractive, DeVoe said. He said as many as half of all car customers have some flaw in their credit profile that gets them rejected by banks - perhaps they've missed a loan payment or spent too little time in a community or on a job. Dealerships can set up their own lending operations that can finance a car purchase by these customers without as great a risk as a bank faces, DeVoe said. He gives this example involving a car selling for $2,800: After taxes and a $300 downpayment, a $2,500 loan may be needed. If the borrower doesn't pay, the bank may get as little as $300 when the recovered car is resold and be stuck with a $2,200 loss. Using that same example: A dealer, who may have paid only $1,000 for the car to begin with, has only a $700 risk after taxes and downpayment. With the car recovered and resold, even at $300, his potential loss is only $400. With a paying borrower, the bank will profit from interest on the loan, but the dealer gets interest plus the $1,800 profit on the car at the time of the sale, DeVoe said. While customers get to buy a car when all seems lost, they also pay dearly for the privilege. Interest rates many car dealers charge are well above market rates. Devoe said financing - with consumer loan-type rates as high as 25 percent - is structured so the customer makes weekly or biweekly payments for one to three years on cars ranging in cost from $2,995 to $5,995. DeVoe, an MBA from Indiana University who worked in commercial loans for Continental Illinois Bank & Trust in Chicago, has been selling cars for more than two decades. He got his big break at his father's dealership in Marion. DeVoe was attending a meeting in 1978 when another dealer told him about the buy here-pay here plan and how it sold a lot of extra cars. The idea became more appealing a year later when a recession began to set in. DeVoe says an initial $19 newspaper ad grossed $8,000. As cash flow grew, DeVoe's dealership graduated from cheaper cars and low sales volume to better cars and more profits. ``We had to reinvent the wheel one spoke at a time during those 10 years. My God, there's a lot to learn and a lot of mistakes to be made,'' he said. He started sharing those experiences with other dealers in his Auto Credit Seminars beginning in 1986. He estimates more than 400 dealer organizations and more than 2,500 dealers have attended them. For a $6,295 fee, a dealership can send as many employees it wants, can return at any time and gets start-up support. A tour of the local GM stamping plant is thrown in for free. Ron Tonkin, former president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said he was skeptical when he he first attended DeVoe's program two years ago. But he says he now has nine buy here-pay here lots at his 10 dealerships in the Portland, Ore., area. It took him 18 months to break even, but now he's seeing profits. ``Anybody that is contemplating going into this, I would definitely recommend they go to DeVoe's school,'' Tonkin said. DeVoe took his buy here-pay here concept a step further last year when he created J.D. Byrider Systems, a national buy here-pay here company with 20 dealer franchises from Wilmington, Del. to Greeley, Colo. Franchisees pay a $29,000 fee, a 3 percent royalty fee and 2 percent for advertising. ``With our experience in the business, many of the dealers could use more support, more training, field men, marketing programs done for them, better operations manuals, and so we feel like there's a big potential in franchising,'' DeVoe said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct 28

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Movie Shakes Actress into Disaster Preparation at Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lucile in 14th graf is cq
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Joanna Kerns took her work home with her when she was filming the NBC miniseries ``The Big One: The Great Los Angeles Earthquake.'' Her house is now earthquake-proofed, she says. Miss Kerns plays a U.S. Geological Survey seismologist who fights to make public her evidence that a great earthquake will strike Los Angeles within a few days. The four-hour show will be broadcast in two parts Sunday and Monday. Miss Kerns, who also stars in the ABC series ``Growing Pains,'' said she strongly identified with her character in the miniseries because she was torn between duty and cnncern for her family. After the temblor strikes in the miniseries, Miss Kerns sets out on foot across the ravaged city to find her daughter. ``I was on stage during the Whittier quake,'' she said, recalling an earthquake that measured 5.9 on the Richter scale and killed eight people in October 1987. ``My daughter Ashley was visiting me on the lot,'' she said. ``All the stage lights started shaking. Everybody ran offstage. A stage is a bad place to be because of all the heavy overhead lights. All I could think of was, where was my daughter? When something like that happens, you go back to basics.'' Making the miniseries nearly two years later helped her turn fear into resolve: to be prepared for any future disaster in earthquake-prone Southern California. ``I had my house bolted to the foundation,'' Miss Kerns said. ``I had the hot water heater and all the heavy furniture bolted down. I bought earthquake insurance. I think people will learn a lot from this show. It's very responsible without hitting you over the head.'' ``The Big One'' also features Ed Begley Jr., Dan Lauria, Richard Masur, Joe Spano, Brock Peters, Lindsay Frost, Clarence Gilyard Jr. and Alan Autry. Miss Kerns, in the role of seismologist Claire Winslow, predicts a devastating earthquake, but city officials fear an announcement will cause mass panic. A real estate tycoon also tries to silence her long enough to unload his endangered property. It's compelling television despite the employment of every cliche in the disaster genre: the husband whose career is jeopardized by his wife's outspokenness, the overzealous assistant, the television reporter who twists her words into new meanings, and the weasel-like official trying to conceal the prediction. It also has an overlapping crisis with the attempted assassination of a man likely to become the first black prime minister of South Africa. What could have been an interesting subplot soon becomes ludicrous when the would-be assassin, like Wile E. Coyote, just won't give up no matter how many buildings fall around him. Miss Kerns said she modeled her character on Lucile Jones, a U.S. Geological Survey seismologist in Pasadena, Calif. ``When the last quake occurred, Lucy had to drop her child off at a day care center so that she could go to work,'' she said. ``She's very dedicated and believes in preparation.'' Miss Kerns spent what she calls ``a relentless nine weeks'' working on the miniseries last summer. ``It was a tough shoot,'' she said. ``In recent times, I've done `The Preppie Murder,' `Blind Faith' and `Those She Left Behind.' I directed a play. I'm in `Deadly Intentions II,' which will probably come on in February. I play the second wife with Harry Hamlin. But with this, we had such technical dialogue. It has to roll off your tongue.'' Miss Kerns is in her sixth season of ``Growing Pains,'' in which she plays working mother Maggie Seaver. The show also stars Alan Thicke as her husband and Kirk Cameron, Tracey Gold, Jeremy Miller and twins Kristen and Kelsey Dohring as the baby sister. ``I never thought they would cast me as the mother of a 15-year-old,'' she said of her ``Growing Pains'' role. ``I was too young. I'd rarely done sitcoms. I was a dramatic actress. Now I have the best of both worlds. I have a choice of what I want to do. ``The kids on the show are growing up and out of the house. It's hard to hide the fact that they're growing up when Jeremy's now taller than I am.'' Miss Kerns is unmarried in real life, but said with a laugh: ``I'm looking for a great guy, with a great sense of humor, who likes that I'm an actress.'' Not long before ``Growing Pains,'' Miss Kerns thought she might become a writer. She and a partner, Becky Ayers, have written a script for the show, and she now is working on several writing projects. ``I was tired of playing the dumb blonde,'' she said. ``I dyed my hair brown and did a lot of character roles. I decided to write because I wanted something I could control. I guess letting go helped, because I got the series `The Four Seasons.' After that, things began to happen for me.''

DOC.BYLINE: Cable's Battle of the Barristers To Start Next Year ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: For many of us, the law is a giant firm called Whereas, Habeus & Big Fee, full of dark mystery, talk in strange tongues and blood oaths never to use a simple declarative sentence. But help is on the way: Next year, two new cable channels will debut - one tentatively called American Courtroom Network, the other definitely called In Court. The channels likely will disappoint ``Perry Mason'' fans used to watching a trial reach a critical phase and then hearing a prosecution witness suddenly shriek: ``Yes, I killed him, the swine! And I'd do it again!'' But they may enlighten viewers about our legal system. Both channels will televise criminal and civil trials, live and on tape, and try to explain the law to civilians. The coverage won't be restricted to state courts, either. Limited coverage of federal civil court trials also is in the wings. There'll be no Judge Wapners here: Presiding anchor for ``Courtroom'' - Fred Graham, lawyer and former law correspondent for CBS News. Presiding analyst for ``In Court'' - Arthur Miller, Harvard law professor, and contributor to ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' While each channel will do its best to keep things interesting, it is a fact that even the most sensational murder case has long moments of mundane. And it remains to be seen whether the public, already used to TV coverage of key cases in state courts - particularly by local stations and Cable News Network - is ready for cable's new, heavy double dose of the living law. The public may get some real-McCoy law on at least one of the networks, too, albeit in a far smaller portion. CBS News is considering a half-hour series, ``On Trial,'' a taped, condensed version of a trial from start to finish. All this comes at time the four networks are rife with the make-believe variety of lawyering. Viewers can choose from CBS' ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill,'' ABC's ``Gabriel's Fire,'' NBC's ``Law and Order'' and ``L.A. Law,'' and Fox Broadcasting's ``Against the Law.'' Be that as it may, In Court, which says it plans to begin operations early next year, will start with 14 hours of programming a day, beginning at 6 a.m. Eastern time. It plans to become a 24-hour operation in 1993. On weekends, it will replay highlights from the previous week. Courtroom will offer law 24 hours a day, though its chief, Steven Brill, won't say when next year it will start. The nighttime half of Courtoom will be a taped replay of each day's coverage, says Graham, a genial Tennessean who is doubling as the operation's managing editor. Although the channel is for ``people, not lawyers,'' he says, with a perfectly straight face, it will set aside Saturday and Sunday mornings for ``our legal ghetto'' - shows ``basically by lawyers for lawyers.'' ``I don't know,'' he says, when asked if there's room for two channels devoted to the same topic. ``I certainly have heard plenty of people say that the logic runs against having two.'' There is anti-logic precedent. The same question was raised last April when Viacom's HA! took on HBO's The Comedy Channel in a multimillion-dollar chuckles contest. Neither has folded yet, and the battle continues. It helps, though, that each is backed by corporations with deep pockets. The same applies in the coming court fight on cable. The owner of In Court is a major cable company, Cablevision Systems Corp. Courtroom is a venture of Time Warner, Inc., another major cable player, and Brill, an attorney, journalist and publisher of 11 magazines, including American Lawyer. Their limited partnership is called American Lawyer Media. ``The meat and potatoes of what we're going to do is cover real courtroom trials,'' says Graham. ``It will be a mix of live and taped.'' The service won't confine itself to trial coverage, though, he says. ``We're going to be in all kinds of nooks and crannies of the judicial system,'' he says, from small claims court to liquor license hearings. In Court general manager Dennis Patton says his service primarily will offer live ``gavel-to-gavel'' coverage of important trials. But it also will have non-trial segments on legal matters and issues, hosted by veteran actor E.G. Marshall. In Court also will start each weekday with a preview of the day's coming cases, and report state, federal and international legal news in sort of a ``Today'' show of law, Patton says. Both services already have begun taping trials, some well-known, some not. The latter includes a date-rape trial that Courtroom taped in Atlanta. In Court covered the recent trial of 2 Live Crew, and each caught Cincinnati's equally publicized Mapplethorpe obscenity trial. Forty-five states now allow some form of TV coverage of courts, although some allow cameras only in appellate courts, Graham says. Not all the states are equal in permitting trial coverage; some are more restrictive than others. For that reason, he says, his channel is concentrating on ``a core of about 13 states'' - including California, New York, Florida, Nevada and Massachussetts - ``that are quite liberal in letting us in.'' Next July, the beady electronic eye of TV also will be allowed in federal courts in a limited three-year test run, the first break in a 53-year ban on cameras and sound gear in those courts. But only civil cases can be televised, and only in six selected trial courts. Cameras also will be allowed in two federal appeals courts. Despite the restrictions, Graham, who covered the Supreme Court during his 15 years at CBS, sees even the limited TV peeps into federal court as a hopeful sign. He even thinks TV may enter the nation's highest court, the Supreme Court, possibly by 1994. As preparations of the court channels continue, so does a sort of reverse voir dire process in which the jury - the nation's cable system operators - questions the opposing parties to decide if they want to carry either channel. These jurors can challenge the cable petitioners for cause - 'cause advertising revenue is down everywhere, 'cause their profit margins keep shrinking, or 'cause their systems lack the capacity for yet another new service. ``All those factors make it especially difficult,'' says Erica Gruen, a cable analyst. But hope springs eternal, and not just in the court channels. About 12 new cable channels, from the Cowboy Channel to a 24-hour talk show channel, plan start-ups from the fourth quarter of this year through next spring, says Gruen, a vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. Why? Despite the trying times of cable now, she says, ``the potential is tremendous - that's what truly draws people in.'' She still recalls a friend who a decade ago ``thought the idea of CNN was stupid. He said, `Who wants to watch news all day long?' '' Begun in 1980 by Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based 24-hour channel now is seen in 57 million homes and offices and, CNN says, in 100 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Former Stasi Agents Mourn Passing of Privilege and Power
DOC.TEXT: They joined because it paid well, offered them a fine education and a nice home, put them in a position of power and privilege. To many, working for the East German secret police was a glamorous and exciting way to make a living. No longer. The fear and obedience the so-called Stasi once instilled have been replaced by open hostility. The profession's prized perks have slipped away. Peter Kuntze now shovels coal on the college campus where he was once a highly paid professor of criminology, an elite member of an exclusive club. For 16 years he worked as a Stasi detective who dissected information on his countrymen. For nearly two decades after that, he trained new generations of Stasi officers. Now Kuntze is a 54-year-old laborer working in the boiler room that supplies heat to the old Stasi spy school, now a teacher's college specializing in language and music. ``I don't regret my work for the Stasi,'' said Kuntze, a father of five. ``I only regret that I put my heart and soul into it. I'm now in a position where I can only do unskilled labor.'' Dietrich Fischer, 52, once specialized in tracking down Western spies, a ``very analytical'' job he found quite exciting. Today, the former Stasi colonel works as headmaster of a kindergarten. Instead of foreign agents, he keeps track of squealing children. ``Everyone thinks it's comical,'' he says, smiling. Because of the stifling hold they kept on society, because of the paranoia and dread they created, the hatred for these people remains intense in what was East Germany. What to do with them is one of the deep social dilemmas confronting the united Germany as it brings the old Communist society - the oppressed and the oppressors together - into a free world. Contrary to popular belief, most Stasi agents are not hiding. Most are still out there, mixing in the new society, holding jobs or looking for them. After years of serving as a government's iron fist on a cowed society, however, it is the once-feared Stasi who now fear the people. One of the most cloistered pockets of this privileged elite used to be the old Stasi officers' college outside Golm, a small village about 25 miles southwest of Berlin. The school was a top-secret, invitation-only training center that offered a broad education to only the brightest young officer candidates. About 30 gray, block-like buildings stand on the end of a winding, secluded road. The campus is an incongruous, icily intimidating mix of ivy-covered walls and high-security fences. The school was closed in January and turned over to the teacher's college in nearby Potsdam. Much of the old faculty still lives in a 30-house neighborhood near campus, a horseshoe-shaped complex of neat homes with spacious yards and private car ports. The people here say the land has been put in public trust to be sold. Their offers to buy their homes have been spurned. The telephone system has been removed. Most of them personally deny the allegations of Stasi brutality and corruption now chronicled daily in the German press. All nations have secret services, they say. ``If someone says something against us, it's impossible to prove it wrong,'' says Kuntze. ``People can say whatever they want.'' Kuntze joined the Stasi in 1956 because the pay and opportunities were so good, he said. He specialized in collating information, weighing its accuracy and value. As a teacher, he taught prospective Stasi officers how to develop informants. ``It was part of the work, nothing negative,'' he said. ``Unofficial sources were necessary to any secret service.'' One of the Stasi's jobs was to check the pulse of public sentiment. But Kuntze said this information often was ignored, or lost in labyrinthine bureaucracy. ``If the information had been exploited in the right way, there would have been changes'' that would have precluded last autumn's revolution, he said. Of the 85,000 people who worked for the Stasi, about 45,000-50,000 were actual field agents, each of whom had two or three paid informants in workplaces or schools, he said. Former agents say potential Stasi recruits were singled out early, often as young as 13. They were watched for years. Kuntze said people were excluded if they demonstrated an inordinate amount of fear, gossiped too much, or had relatives in the West. Ullrich Heidenreich followed such a career path. Fashionably dressed and lounging in a handsomely furnished living room, the 34-year-old Heidenreich and his wife, Martina, could be any upwardly mobile young couple. The son of a police officer, he was recruited when he was 16 and joined two years later. He worked as a Stasi guard on the Czechoslovak border, then as an operative in Karl Marx City. Like other top recruits, he was sent to school. He was trained as a lawyer and became a professor at the Stasi school. Unlike other teachers, he found a job in his field after he was fired. Heidenreich now teaches law at a police academy in Potsdam. He teaches West German law, which he spent nine months studying. He does not expect to keep this job once a united German government takes a closer look at the people on its public payrolls. But he's optimistic about finding new work. ``People who are competent hold positions of responsibility,'' he said. ``People who are incompetent want us out. Those who have nothing try to drive the bright ones out by shouting `Stasi.' '' The couple are prepared to move West to advance their careers. ``This virulent campaign against the Stasi is really a symptom of the East,'' he said. ``In the West, people are more realistic. Here, there is too much emotion.'' The former Stasi captain has no qualms about shifting his ideology, nor apologies about his past. ``As long as you are socially well off, you don't ask questions and you don't rock the boat,'' he said. ``I'm not saying I was convinced that what I did was wrong. When I worked for the Stasi, I believed it was right,'' he said. ``I'm only saying that I can learn the new way.'' Communist Party and Stasi officials were well paid, with tremendous perks and fine homes. Heidenreich said he and his wife have ``a lot of money, but not as a much as people think.'' Kuntze, Fischer and Heidenreich all made about 3,000 marks (about $1,950) a month as teachers, more than triple the average East German wage. Kuntze and Fischer say they make about one-third that now. Heidenreich makes about 1,900 marks ($1,250). Some have not done so well. Juergen Kanis, 34, has a law degree in a legal system that no longer exists, a Marxist-Leninist philosophy doctorate in a capitalist nation - and no job in a free market. Kanis, a father of two, says he has lost three jobs in the last year because of his Stasi past. The Stasi recruited him as farm boy and sent him to Karl Marx University. It gave him a job and turned him into a teacher of the ideology that created it. That was the way things were in those days, Kanis said. ``If the CIA came to you, would you say no?'' he asks.

DOC.HEAD: Facts and Figures About East Germany Spy Network
With BC-Stasi Stigma
DOC.TEXT: Few sectors of East German society scaped the scrutiny of the Stasi. The Communist secret police created an aura of paranoia that still lingers. More than 85,000 people were members. More than twice that number were informers who worked in factories, businesses and schools. East German workers and students were broken down into small, manageable work groups. Former agents say each such group contained at least one paid informant. About 9,000 Stasi members monitored telephone conversations. People considered to be nonconformists were denied good jobs and housing. Their mail was disrupted. Many were jailed on trumped-up charges, others beaten. Border guards, all Stasi members, killed people who tried to flee the country. Stasi agents regularly interviewed government officials and factory bosses. The conversations were taped, transcribed and filed. Many former Stasi officials and Communist Party functionaries are believed to have a disproportionate share of the wealth, property and businesses in what was East Germany. David Gill of the committee overseeing the Stasi's dissolution said most members are working in factories, on pensions or unemployed, but many run established businesses or have parlayed connections and money into new ones. Lawmakers are debating whether to grant amnesty to some Stasi members and prosecute others. The Stasi foreign unit acted as an espionage agency. About 60 Stasi spies have been arrested in recent months in what formerly was West Germany. Erich Mielke, former chief of the Stasi, is in jail awaiting prosecution on charges of corruption, harboring leftist terrorists and other crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats in Tough Races in Nation's Largest States
DOC.TEXT: Democrats expect to improve their hold on the nation's governorships this year, but they face tough battles to wrest control of the largest states from the Republicans. Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, the head of the Democratic Governors' Association, predicts a net gain of one to four governorships for his party this year. Republicans, who gained eight seats when many of these same governors were up four years ago, would be content just to hold their own this time. Democrats have the upper hand in the nation's statehouses going into the elections, controlling 29 governorships to the GOP's 21. But the party that controls the biggest states will be pleased no matter the outcome of the rest. ``Much more important than the raw number of gains or losses is which states go which way,'' says political analyst Charlie Cook. ``Unlike House or Senate seats, all governorships are not created equal, and it is the megastates this year that really count.'' The reason is redistricting. Legislatures will draw new congressional district lines next year that may change of face of their U.S. House delegations. Both parties would like to hold the veto stamp in states facing big gains or losses in their congressional delegations. Republicans control the governorships in four of the biggest states that are up this year: California, Texas, Florida and Illinois. California's legislature will figure out how to distribute as many as seven new congressional seats next year, based on the state's population gain in preliminary Census figures. Democrats control the legislature there, and Republicans say they need the governorship to ensure a fair map. Texas and Florida will gain new House seats too, while Illinois stands to lose two seats. In only one of those states, Florida, is the incumbent seeking re-election. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez has come from behind to a virtual tie with Democratic challenger Lawton Chiles, the former senator. The high-stakes California race is considered deadlocked too. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson faces Democrat Dianne Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian is retiring after two terms. In Texas, flamboyant Republican Clayton Williams has held a lead over Democrat Ann Richards. Richards has pulled closer in recent polls, however, and has accused Williams' campaign of encouraging reports she once used drugs. In Illinois, Republican Jim Edgar once led in his bid to replace retiring Gov. Jim Thompson. But in a reversal of normal tax rhetoric it is the Democrat, Neil Hartigan, who has trumpeted a no-tax pledge to turn the race into a tossup. Among the Democratic governors who control big states, Michigan's Gov. Jim Blanchard has a substantial lead in his bid for a third term. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo is a sure thing for re-election. So is Pennsylvania Gov. Bob Casey, the most prominent anti-abortion Democrat. In other contested states that Democrats now control: - Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis retires reviled just two years after leading his party to presidential defeat. Democrat John Silber, a university president, won the nomination in a repudiation of Dukakis. He leads his GOP opponent, although Republican William Weld is within striking distance. - Republican George Voinovich, the former Cleveland mayor, leads in the Ohio governor's race, where Democrat Celeste is retiring. The Democratic candidate, Anthony Celebrezze, has tried to make his support for abortion rights a deciding issue. But Celebrezze has been criticized for his dramatic switch from an abortion opponent late last year. - Minnesota was a state Republicans had hopes of reclaiming from Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich. But Republican Jon Grunseth has been rocked by allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls at a party nine years ago. Grunseth has backed up his denials with a polygraph test but he trails in the polls. - Democrats are in danger of losing Connecticut, where Gov. William O'Neill is retiring. The Democratic nominee is running third behind former GOP Sen. Lowell Weicker, who is running as an independent. - In Oregon, another state where a Democrat is retiring, the race between Republican Dave Frohnmayer and Democrat Barbara Roberts is close. Republican incumbents are in danger in at least four states: Rhode Island, Nebraska, Kansas and Maine. Worst for Republicans is Rhode Island, where Gov. Ed DiPrete is far behind Democrat Bruce Sundlun, who lost to DiPrete in the last two elections. Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr and her Kansas neighbor, Mike Hayden, both have been in trouble for tax increases, but both have narrowed the gap by which they trailed Democratic challengers. Hayden has rebounded as his Democratic opponent, Joan Finney, has struggled to explain her opposition to abortion. Recent polls have shown Hayden winning the women's vote. Maine's Republican Gov. John McKernan has also made a partial recovery in the polls but still faces a tough race with Joseph Brennan, a former governor who replaced McKernan in Congress four years ago. Among other Republican incumbents, Alabama's Guy Hunt and Iowa's Terry Branstad both hold leads against strong challengers. Republicans face uphill battles to hang on in Oklahoma and New Mexico, where GOP incumbents are retiring. Democrats expect to hang on to the Arizona seat, which they took over when Republican Gov. Evan Mecham was impeached. In Alaska, the entry of former GOP Gov. Walter Hickel as third-party candidate has confused a toss-up race. Former GOP Gov. Richard Snelling leads in Vermont, where the Democratic incumbent is retiring. Democratic incumbents have leads in polls or are rated likely winners in Colorado, Hawaii, Maryland, Nevada, Tennessee, Idaho and Wyoming. Republican incumbents are rated favorites in South Carolina, South Dakota, Wisconsin and New Hampshire.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Marginal Shifts in Democratic-Controlled House
DOC.TEXT: With voter outrage high and Congress appearing incompetent, House incumbents face the 1990 elections with anxiety. Political experts predict no more than marginal shifts in the Democratic-controlled House, but caution that this year's voting could hold some surprises. ``There's clearly a pretty strong sense of anger out among the voters, and it is directed both at politics and politicians as much as incumbents,'' said Geoff Garin, a pollster with the Democratic firm of Peter Hart. ``There is a sense that people in government only care about politics, and not about what's right and wrong,'' he said. Neil Newhouse, a pollster with Richard Wirthlin's Republican firm, was more blunt: ``The political environment is going to hell in a handbasket.'' Most of the action in the nation's 435 congressional districts will be in the 29 races where there is no incumbent seeking re-election. Democrats have a lopsided advantage in that category. They are defending 11 of the open seats, while Republicans must try to hang on to 18 districts. The GOP openings include 11 districts where otherwise safe Republican House members decided to run for Senate seats or statewide office. There could be volatility among incumbents as well. Several already are threatened by association with the nation's savings and loan scandal: Denny Smith, R-Ore.; Charles Pashayan, R-Calif.; and Frank Annunzio, D-Ill. Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., is in trouble over using his official credit card to charge for hundreds of dollars worth of long-distance phone calls to a woman who worked for a lobbying company. Reps. Craig James, R-Fla., and Stan Parris, R-Va., have been targeted by strong Democratic challengers who made an issue of their opposition to abortion. The political year for incumbents has been a roller coaster of changing issues, complicated by Congress' inability to finish its work and adjourn. That has had the effect of compressing the campaign season to its shortest length since World War II. Early in the year, experts were pointing to strong pro-choice votes on Capitol Hill and a newly invigorated women's lobby as signs that abortion would be a dominant issue in the elections. In quick succession, that issue was followed by politicking over the savings-and-loan scandal, flag desecration, congressional ethics and campaign finance, environmental protection vs. jobs and the Persian Gulf crisis. Then came the government's paralysis over the budget, leaving a bad taste that was likely to remain with voters even after final agreements were worked out for trimming the federal deficit. ``The whole budget process has given voters a focal point ... for the frustration with government and politicians,'' Newhouse said. Both parties predict a Democratic pickup of fewer than 10 seats, padding the majority party's current 258 to 176 advantage. But the volatility of the season could yield a far greater shift if angry voters go to the polls in a throw-the-bums-out mood. Among the hottest contests to watch on Election Day: - In Washington's 3rd District, freshman Rep. Jolene Unsoeld has been squeezed by her stand for the endangered spotted owl, and against the cutting of old-growth forests that are its home. To mollify angry loggers, she assumed the lead on an anti-gun-control issue in the House backed by the National Rifle Association. Republicans believe their candidate, former state Rep. Bob Williams, has an even shot at defeating her. - Analysts say the fate of GOP Rep. Peter Smith in Vermont will be a good gauge of voter anger. Smith supported an early budget proposal that included heavy new taxes on home heating oil, anathema in the Northeast. And his opponent, socialist former Burlington Mayor Bernard Sanders, was campaigning as an anti-Washington populist even before it became fashionable. If he pulls it off, Sanders would be the first socialist in Congress in six decades. - Another bellwether of anti-incumbency will be in Massachusetts, where Rep. Chester Atkins is known as an abrasive and aloof figure. Atkins' role as chairman of the Democratic Party in a state that is in open revolt against its establishment cannot help. Republicans have high hopes for their challenger, state Rep. John MacGovern. - Several incumbents of both parties are in trouble simply because they represent politically polarized districts: Republicans James Inhofe of Oklahoma and John Hiler of Indiana, and Democrats James Clarke of North Carolina, Bill Sarpalius of Texas, George Brown of California and George Sangmeister of Illinois. Political analyst Charles Cook predicts that most of the undecided vote this year will go against incumbents, which could hurt those in marginal districts. - Former Cincinnati Mayor Kenneth Blackwell stands a good chance of being the first black Republican in the House since 1935. Blackwell is in a tight race with current Mayor Charles Luken, whose Democratic father, Rep. Thomas Luken, is retiring. - The Idaho seat of Republican Rep. Larry Craig, who is running for the Senate, is up for grabs. Polls show Democrat Larry LaRocco, a stockbroker and former Senate aide, deadlocked with GOP state Sen. C.M. ``Skip'' Smyser in a district that leans Republican.
