DOC.HEAD: Ballots Feature Bitter Medicine for Taxes, Schools, Politicians
DOC.TEXT: Angry voters have loaded state ballots with the most citizen initiatives in 76 years, aiming to slash taxes, clean the environment, improve schools and limit the terms of politicians. Their often-snappy nicknames - ``Big Green,'' ``Son of Jarvis,'' the ``Two Percent Solution'' - belie the unusual stringency of many of the tax revolt, environmental and political term limitation proposals to be decided on Nov. 6. ``Citizens across the country are feeling anger toward the way government is performing, nd they are expressing that anger through the initiative process,'' said John Keast, who monitors ballot measures for the Free Congress Foundation, a conservative research group in Washington, D.C. In all, voters in 43 states and the District of Columbia will decide 236 ballot questions, according to the foundation. The majority were referred to the ballot by state legislators. More tellingly, 67 are citizen-initiated ballot measures - the most since the Progressive Era in 1914 when a record 90 appeared on state ballots. Voter wrath could be most keenly felt in Massachusetts, where passage of Question 3 would result in the largest voter-initiated state tax cut in history: $2 billion, or 15 percent of the state's budget. Opponents argue it would bankrupt poor school districts, seriously damage others, and lead to tens of thousands of state layoffs. Polls, nonetheless, show broad support. Taxing and spending limits appear on ballots in ten other states, including Nebraska, where a proposed ``Two Percent Solution'' would impose a 2 percent lid on state and local budget increases. Colorado and California voters will decide whether to limit the length elected officials can serve. A proposed state ethics panel is also on the California ballot. Kansas City, Mo., residents may limit City Council terms. Arizonans will decide whether their state legislators deserve a raise to $24,000 from $15,000. Californians face their usual prodigious load of statewide measures: 28 in all, including questions ranging from saving ancient redwoods to raising alcohol taxes. By far the most closely-watched initiative is Proposition 128, a sweeping environmental issue called ``Big Green'' by backers including Robin Williams, Sylvester Stallone and many other Hollywood stars. It would phase out pesticides known to cause cancer, ban oil development in state waters, ban chemicals that harm the ozone, and require a dramatic reduction in emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. Important environmental issues are being considered in other states: -Washington voters could require that state to set up boards mandating local land use planning; -Oregonians may impose strict recycling codes and force the shutdown of the state's only nuclear power plant; -Missourians consider sweeping protections for Ozark mountain streams; -New Yorkers decide on a $2 billion environment bond; -South Dakotans may limit Black Hills mining and restrict garbage dumping; -Arizona and Minnesota may dedicate portions of state lottery proceeds to preserving the environment. Another potentially explosive California measure, dubbed ``Son of Jarvis'' in memory of Howard Jarvis, father of Proposition 13, would forbid any tax increase without a two-thirds legislative or electoral majority. Among noteworthy local California issues, Santa Clara County will consider whether to finance a new stadium to lure the San Francisco Giants, Sacramento voters will decide on a city-county merger that would make it the nation's seventh largest county, San Franciscans will consider a ``domestic partners'' measure allowing non-married live-in couples, including homosexuals, to register their relationships with city officials, while affluent Pacific Grove may float a $1.2 million bond for a butterfly habitat. Meanwhile, the course of school reform could be on the line in several states. The most crucial in the eyes of the nation's educators is Oregon's ``choice'' initiative allowing parents a $2,500 tax credit for educating their children in anywhere they wish, including private or parochial schools, or even at home. The Bush administration applauds choice as a key to better schools. But teacher unions and others in the education establishment are fighting to keep the measure from passing, fearing it would unleash similar measures around the country to the detriment of public schools. Nebraskans will decide whether to repeal a tax reform passed last year aimed at shifting the burden of school financing from the property tax by increasing sales and income taxes. In Arizona, Proposition 103, the Classroom Improvement Initiative, would require the legislature to increase public school spending by $100 per pupil in each of the next 10 years. The pricetag has been estimated at up to $6 billion. In Kansas, voters will settle a political tug of war by deciding a proposed amendment that would, in effect, give the state legislature near-total control over school governance, stripping the state board of education and board of regents of much of their independence. Elsewhere: -Oregon and Nevada take up abortion rights issues; -Arkansas considers a proposed lottery; -Staten Islanders decide whether to study a possible secession from New York City; -Alaskans may recriminalize marijuana; -Montanans may make their cigarette taxes the nation's highest; -Florida could require a three-day wait for handgun purchases; -Arizona may end a 15-year tiff over a proposed Martin Luther King paid holiday; -and Maine mulls a repeal of one of the nation's toughest blue laws. ---

DOC.HEAD: The Face of Congress To Be Decided in Key State Races
DOC.TEXT: The partisan makeup of the House for the next decade rests largely with voters in a dozen states this year. A they choose governors and state legislators, these voters will be picking the powerbrokers for major redistricting battles. The arcane redistricting process draws little attention from voters. But national political parties are pouring millions of dollars and advice into state legislative races that often are ignored in Washington except in years ending in zero. Redistricting occurs once a decade after the Census Bureau completes its decennial head count. The population figures are used to redistribute U.S. House seats among the 50 states and to redraw congressional district lines. Some 19 House seats are expected to shift as a result of the 1990 Census. Most of them will move from the Democratic-leaning Northeast and Midwest to the more conservative South and West, where Republicans have enjoyed success in congressional and presidential elections but lag behind Democrats at the state level. Democrats enter the redistricting process with a decided edge and hope gains this year will serve as a springboard to 1992, when the party will try again to wrest control of the White House from the GOP. Republicans for most of the 1980s touted their ``1991 Plan'' as the means of escaping their nearly 40 years as minority party in the House. But the GOP now finds itself scrambling to defend its major redistricting power bases against formidable Democratic challenges. Already, the GOP is threatening to press legal challenges to partisan plans it expects the Democrats to craft. ``We're in position this year to successfully defend most if not all of our redistricting strengths and then peel off a few if not more from the Republicans,'' said Tim Dickson, executive director of the Democratic Party's redistricting arm, Project 500. At stake is nothing less than control of the House through the year 2003; even modest Democratic gains would cement Republicans as the minority party for the foreseeable future. Party operatives say new computer analyses that mix Census demographics with voting records will allow anyone with a monopoly on redistricting to fashion no-lose districts. ``You can slice up a state and preordain the results with incredible accuracy,'' said Ben Ginsberg, the Republican National Committee's chief counsel. The Republicans hoped for big gains after 17 seats shifted from the Frost Belt to the Sun Belt after the 1980 Census. But Democrats controlled much of the map drawing and ended up with a net gain of three seats. The shifting is called reapportionment, the Census Bureau term for deciding how many of the 435 House seats go to each state. Once that's done the states - in most cases their legislatures - take on the task of redistricting, literally redrawing the lines of each congressional district. There are 6,144 legislative seats up for election in 46 states. There are no legislative races this year in Virginia, New Jersey, Mississippi and Kentucky. After years of exhaustive research, the parties have narrowed their targets to a handful to a dozen races in each of the major redistricting battlegrounds - primarily states that are gaining or losing seats. Fourteen of the shifting seats - and their accompanying electoral votes in presidential elections - will be gobbled up by California, Florida and Texas. In those states, Republicans now control the governor's office but face stiff challenges this year. At the legislative level in those states, only control of the Florida Senate appears in question; Democrats enjoy sizeable advantages in both chambers of the Texas and California legislatures and in the Florida House. Republicans are mounting an aggressive effort to pick up the four seats they need to control the Florida Senate, which would give the GOP a voice in redistricting should Republican Gov. Bob Martinez lose his re-election bid. Democrats are cautiously optimistic they will retain their edge. The fight in the state destined to be the biggest redistricting loser, New York, focuses on the state Senate, where Democrats need a net gain of four seats to win a monopoly on redistricting. ``If that happens what you will see is blatant political gerrymandering,'' said the RNC's Ginsberg. He won't get an argument from Democrats on that point. ``The process is inherently political,'' said Democratic National Committee redistricting guru Mark Bohannon. ``It was designed that way, to benefit winners.'' President Bush has visited New York to help the GOP's state Senate effort, and Gov. Mario Cuomo is working hard for the Democrats. New York likely will lose three of its 34 House seats. Democrats also are spending heavily in hopes of gaining redistricting monopolies in Pennsylvania, Indiana and Michigan. They hope to capture the senates in Pennsylvania and Michigan and both chambers in Indiana, where the GOP has two-seat majorities in the House and Senate. With the Ohio gubernatorial contest leaning Republican, Democrats also are targeting the Ohio Senate, where they need a gain of three seats to win total control of the state legislature. The party has realistic shots at those goals but faces uphill odds in trying to erase slim GOP majorities in both chambers of the Arizona legislature and the Colorado House. Democrats find themselves playing defense in the Florida Senate contests as well as in Illinois, where Republicans need to gain two seats to capture the Senate. Republicans also are trying to take over the lower chambers in Pennsylvania and Oregon, needing a gain of three seats in each state. The Pennsylvania, Michigan, Illinois and Ohio contests are particularly important because each of these states is likely to lose two congressional seats. Control over redistricting will decide which incumbents get squeezed. The other likely losers are Massachusetts, New Jersey, West Virginia, Kentucky, Iowa, Louisiana, Kansas and Montana. Those eight states will lose one seat each, according to preliminary Census data. The redistricting winners are led by California, which should gain seven seats and see its House delegation grow to 52. Florida's expected gain of four would bring its House delegation to 23. The likely pickup of three seats by Texas would swell its representation in the House to 30. Together, these states would supply 24 percent of House members and hold 105 Electoral College votes - 38 percent of the 270 needed to win the White House. The other gainers, expected to pick up one seat each, likely will be Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Washington. Heading into the elections there were just four states - Idaho, Kansas, New Hampshire and South Dakota - in which Republicans have outright control over state government and none of them are considered major redistricting battlegrounds. Democrats, on the other hand, hold the governor's office and control both legislative chambers in 15 states and at least two of the three seats at the redistricting table in 23 others.

DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp., one of the oldest and financially weakest U.S. airlines, will sell important trans-Atlantic routes and other assets to larger rival UAL Corp. for $400 million, the companies announced. The agreement announced Tuesday came months after fruitless efforts by Pan Am to find a merger partner or buyer for the airline, which pioneered world air travel more than a half-century ago but lost hundreds of millions of dollars over the past decade of heightened competition inspired by airline deregulation. It also marks a major expansion by UAL, the parent of Chicago-based United Airlines, which bought Pan Am's prized Pacific routes five years ago for $750 million and has since become a key airline in that part of the world. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil prices stabilized after a record drop the day before took futures prices below $30 per barrel. Light sweet crude for December delivery settled at $29.37 per barrel Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down $1.04 from the previous day's December bid. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The sharp fall in oil prices has wiped out most of the ``war premium'' whipped up by the Persian Gulf crisis, but consumers shouldn't expect much of a break at the gas pump immediately. Home heating oil will probably be even slower to fall at the retail level, analysts said Tuesday as critics of the oil industry renewed their cries of price-gouging. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - U.S. personal income growth slowed during the second quarter, with incomes declining in Iowa and Nebraska, the Commerce Department said. A study by the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis showed national income growth decelerating from 2.1 percent in the first quarter to 1.3 percent from April through June. It weakened in five of the nation's eight regions. The report was a reflection of the sluggish growth of the general economy, which dipped from 1.7 percent in the January-March quarter to 0.4 percent in the next. Many economists believe the nation is headed for a recession, if it is not already in one. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The House Banking Committee voted to trim the Bush administration's request for as much as $57 billion more for the savings and loan bailout to $10 billion. Both Democrats and Republicans on the panel suggested that Congress should deny more money for the bailout in view of President Bush's assertion a year ago that ``never again'' would taxpayers be tapped for it and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's refusal to testify why that has changed. But warned by regulators the bailout's total costs might swell another $250 million to $300 million in the next three months without the funds, the committee approved just enough money to keep the program going through February. --- BURBANK, Calif. (AP) - Walt Disney Co. has formed a film production financing partnership worth at least $600 million, backed largely by Japanese investors. The new partnership, Touchwood Pacific Partners I, will become the company's main source of finance for all live-action films at Disney's three studios: Disney, Touchstone and Hollywood Pictures. The $600 million financing will be based on $180 million raised from Japanese investors. Another $420 million will take the form of a line of credit from a consortium of banks led by Citicorp's Citibank. --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - Warner Bros. will pay $125 million for video rights to many MGM-UA films, with the money helping to fund Pathe Communications Corp.'s buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co., the companies announced Tuesday. The deal puts into place another piece of the complex sale of MGM-UA to Pathe, headed by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. --- DALLAS (AP) - Southland Corp., the nation's largest convenience store chain, appeared to have lost its fight to avoid bankruptcy, although enough creditors had agreed to speed the company's reorganization process. The parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain had asked creditors to approve either a debt swap or a so-called ``prepackaged'' Chapter 11 bankruptcy plan. Early indications Tuesday were that the restructuring had fallen far short of the 95 percent approval Southland had sought, but a majority of creditors had agreed to go along with the bankruptcy option. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The former president of a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. customer said that Michael Milken offered him a personal investment in a 1985 takeover after his company bought a large stake in the deal. The testimony by Richard Grassgreen Tuesday was the first indicating Milken may have directly given favors to big clients consisting of an interest in the lucrative leveraged buyout of Storer Communications Inc. ---

The stock market lost ground Tuesday after struggling to hold onto spotty gains for most of the session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.03 points to close at 2,494.06. The dollar was mostly higher against other major currencies. Gold prices rose. Bond prices weakened as traders reacted to economic uncertainty and the ongoing federal budget talks.

DOC.HEAD: Falling Oil Prices Won't Immediately Help Consumers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: The sharp fall in oil prices has wiped out most of the ``war premium'' whipped up by the Persian Gulf crisis, but consumers shouldn't expect much of a break at the gas pump immediately. Home heating oil will probably be even slower to fall at the retail level, analysts said Tuesday as critics of the oil industry renewed their cries of price-gouging. Those who follow the pricing of oil and refined petroleum products say that although rising crude prices usually bring rapid increases in consumer prices, drops in crude usually don't work their way into the retail level for a few weeks. ``Product prices tend to lag,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``People who have established those high prices tend to give them up grudgingly.'' Oil prices in the futures market have tumbled from a peak above $40 to less than $30 per barrel as signs of a peaceful solution to the Gulf standoff have proliferated. Light sweet crude for December delivery was pegged at $29.37 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange at the close of trading Tuesday. Dodge predicted retail gasoline prices will dip a bit in the near future, while home heating oil might even go up, largely for seasonal reasons. ``On gasoline, normally it would come down at this time of year anyway,'' Dodge said. ``Heating oil would be the reverse.'' Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, retail gasoline prices have gone up about 30.5 cents per gallon, according to an American Automobile Association survey Tuesday that showed pump prices were rising even as crude oil was falling over the past week. Home heating oil costs in the Northeast are likewise running about 30 cents to 40 cents per gallon higher than they were at the same time last year. ``I can't imagine much decrease,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. ``It's usually a lag of about two or three weeks.'' Big oil companies say they are not to blame for any price-gouging at the pump, because they can't control what gas stations choose to charge. ``There have been quite clear indications that the price of gasoline has not gone up quite as rapidly as crude oil,'' said Gus Ensz, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, the leading industry group. ``Some of the marketers have been saying they have not been making what they should be making. ``If that's the case, it might not be surprising if they wait a little before they try to cut their prices,'' Ensz said from API's headquarters in Washington. Critics nonetheless contend that oil compnnies are taking advantage of consumers. At Buyers Up, a Ralph Nader consumers group in Washington, research director Christopher Dyson said home heating oil prices have remained virtually unchanged after oil took its big fall. ``Prices have gone down 1 cent a gallon, here in the greater Washington area, even though crude oil prices have gone down about $10 a barrel so far,'' Dyson said. ``It may drop more, but they're taking their time. A lot of it is just sort of gouging. Prices should fall more than a penny after a $10 drop.'' Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., calls the recent high oil prices ``a theft of billions of dollars from workers and businesses across the country.'' Lieberman has organized a series of Senate Government Affairs Committee hearings into oil pricing that will begin Thursday in Washington. He hopes to outlaw price-gouging during times of national economic emergencies. The industry believes investigations into pricing will shoot down any allegations of gouging. ``The testimony will demonstrate that a free market has been at work,'' Ensz said.

DOC.HEAD: United: Airline Furthering Its `Strategic Plan' with Route Purchase
With PM-UAL-Pan Am, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Freed from years of takeover offers, United Airlines is now moving ahead with its long-term strategy and focusing attention on its position in the changing industry. United's agreement to buy some of Pan Am's trans-Atlantic routes followed an announcement in early October that United parent UAL Corp. had rejected an employee buyout bid. The takeover proposal was the latest of four offered directors in as many years. On Oct. 16 United announced it was planning what could become the largest wide-body aircraft purchase in history - $22 billion worth of planes. The company said it also had won authorization to fly the coveted non-stop Chicago-Tokyo route. Two days later, UAL announced it had made peace with its largest shareholder, Coniston Partners. Coniston had threatened to oust directors unless a union-led buyout was approved. UAL agreed to add two officials from the New York investment firm to its 13-member board, and Chairman Stephen M. Wolf said then that by putting the uncertainty over ownership behind, the company could focus fully on the airline's long-term plans and opportunities. The agreement announced Tuesday with Pan Am marks a major expansion by UAL. It bought Pan Am's prized Pacific routes five years ago for $750 million and has since become a key airline in that part of the world. ``This announcement culminates a series of major events over the past nine days furthering United's strategic plan,'' United said in a statement. Earlier this year United became the biggest carrier across the Pacific Ocean, suprpassing Japan Air Lines and Northwest Airlines. Pacific travel now accounts for 24 percent of United's business. The Pacific expansion has given United a slight edge over arch-rival American Airlines in monthly revenue passenger miles since June.

DOC.HEAD: New ABA Head Takes Over at Difficult Time for Banking Industry
DOC.TEXT: Richard A. Kirk once donned a Star Trek costume and played the part of Capt. Kirk to lead a chamber of commerce campaign in his hometown of Denver. As the new president of the American Bankers Association, he is walking into a situation that may make him wish he was in another universe. Kirk, who was installed as ABA president Tuesday, becomes the chief spokesman for an industry that is suffering from a weakened economy, losses by some of its most hallowed institutions, eroding consumer confidence and the likelihood of tougher government regulation. ``I think it's going to be a particularly challenging year,'' Kirk said in an interview at the ABA's annual convention, a five-day affair that concludes today. Kirk, chairman of the United Bank of Denver, said one of his main tasks is to take steps to restore confidence in the banking industry. He maintains that the industry is fundamentally sound, and its problems have been exaggerated in the public eye since the banks having serious problems include some of the nation's most well-known institutions. Kirk said the banks also have been unfairly tainted by the savings and loan crisis. ``My primary agenda item is to work on confidence in banking. It's an area I feel strongly about.'' Kirk is annoyed by the suggestion that banks are going through one of the worst times in the industry's history, an opinion that has been frequently aired in the media in the wake of third quarter earnings reports that showed losses for many banks and sharply declining profit levels for others. ``That is clearly incorrect,'' he said. ``Banks may have been in worse shape in 1985 . . . there were more failures, agriculture was having problems.'' He said his home state is an example of an area that is now showing economic improvement. ``We had an eight year recession in Colorado. Denver is now on a rebound'' Kirk said. ``The Southeast and the Northeast are having problems. They can be dealt with.'' With the national economy teetering on the brink of a recession - or, as some economists say, already there - Kirk said confidence in the banking system is imperative. ``It appears to me when the public reads in the newspapers about the real estate bust, about the problems large banks are having, it starts to raise questions: what's my bank like? That's a very serious situation,'' Kirk said. ``I don't think it's healthy for the nation to worry about their banks being in good condition.'' Kirk's Star Trek get-up came in 1987 for a Greater Denver Chamber of Commerce membership drive. He said he doesn't plan any such gimmicks for the ABA, though he wants to spread the word that the industry is healthy. Kirk said he hopes ABA members will spread that message in their own communities. Kirk said banks are in far better shape than the savings and loan industry. Banks, he said, have more capital, better regulation and stronger insurance. ``It's very important for us to keep people aware of those differences,'' he said. The federal government wants banks to increase their capital as a cushion against bad loans. That is just one of several regulatory areas apt to be changed on Kirk's watch at the ABA. Kirk, whose association has one of the nation's most powerful political action committees, said he's unfazed by the prospects. ``It's almost a sure bet we will get some significant banking changes in Congress next year, maybe earlier,'' he said. ``We're well positioned to deal with these issues.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Drexel Chief Testifies Against Former Junk Bond Leader
DOC.TEXT: Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. chief Frederick Joseph testified against the man who led the firm to Wall Street stardom as the government finished the second phase of its pre-sentencing case against Michael Milken. Also Tuesday, the former president of an important Drexel junk-bond customer said Milken offered him a personal investment in a 1985 takeover after his company bought a large stake in the deal. The testimony by Richard Grassgreen was important because it was the first indication Milken may have directly given big clients equity in the leverage buyout of Storer Communications Inc. Taking the stand nearly four years after Drexel and Milken were linked to wrongdoing in the government's insider trading probe, Joseph said Milken may have violated company policies related to Storer investments and misled him. Government charges against Milken are being aired at a pre-sentencing hearing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. Prosecutors claim Milken broke the law beyond criminal charges to which he has pleaded guilty and deserves a lengthy prison term. The hearing is to resume Thursday with testimony on the last of three alleged illegal transactions, involving trading in Caesar's World Inc. securities in 1983. A sentencing date has not been set. Grassgreen, formerly president of Kinder-Care Inc., testified as part of his own agreement to plead guilty to two felony charges related to pocketing up to $500,000 from investments made by his company. Tuesday's testimony focused on the $2.5 billion buyout of Storer by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., for which Drexel provided financing in late 1985. Prosecutors claim Milken misappropriated valuable Storer equity warrants, or rights to purchase Storer stock, and used them to lure customers into buying riskier Storer securities. Under questioning from Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll, Grassgreen said that after committing Kinder-Care to buying $5 million in preferred stock in Storer he was told by a Drexel executive about the warrants. When Grassgreen asked whether Kinder-Care could buy some of the warrants, he said Milken told him, ``No, it's for you and Perry,'' referring to Kinder-Care chairman Perry Mendel. Grassgreen testified he believed he was offered the warrants because of his longstanding relationship with Drexel and the company's role in the Storer deal. But Grassgreen contradicted testimony last week by Drexel executive Thomas Connors. Also, none of six government witnesses on Storer directly backed the bribery charge against Milken. Grassgreen said under cross-examination by defense lawyer Arthur Liman that Milken was unaware of Grassgreen's lawbreaking and that all investments made with Drexel in a relationship dating to 1978 were based on merit. Grassgreen has agreed to plead guilty to pocketing commitment fees paid by Drexel to Kinder-Care for investing in four takeover deals and to failing to disclose his personal stake in Storer to his company. He resigned last week as president of Montgomery, Ala.-based Enstar Group Inc., Kinder-Care's successor. Milken, 44, pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to illegal trading and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces a maximum 28 years imprisonment. Joseph testified under Drexel's agreement to cooperate with the government in settling criminal charges last year. Drexel now is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. He said he did not learn about a Drexel-related investment partnership known as MacPherson Investment Partners that was formed out of the Storer deal until 1988. MacPherson consisted of Drexel clients, money fund managers, Drexel employees and a trust in the name of the children of both Milken and his brother, Lowell, who also worked for Drexel. Joseph said the stake for the trust for the Milkens' children should have been disclosed to executives of the firm because of Drexel's role in creating and trading the securities. Disclosure was required to ensure the investment complied with federal and firm rules. Joseph said he believed the decision to give partnership stakes to fund managers whose institutions bought risky Storer securities also violated Drexel guidelines against giving ``favorable treatment'' to institutional investor accounts. Joseph also said that he asked Milken in the fall of 1988 whether any fund managers had invested in Drexel partnerships and Milken said no. Under cross-examination, Joseph said that Drexel employee partnerships had taken equity stakes in other leveraged buyout deals. Joseph also conceded that Milken was not responsible for determining whether investments needed to be disclosed and that Milken routinely consulted Drexel executives about personal investments.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines Plans To Expand San Juan Hub Despite Shaky Times
With PM-UAL-Pan Am, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines is planning expansions of its hub in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and some other Caribbean operations despite economic conditions that have left its 1990 performance shaky. ``Even in the worst of times, there are opportunities to be found out there,'' American chief executive Robert Crandall said as he announced the $100 million expansion Tuesday. ``The Caribbean has been strong for us in good and bad times,'' he said. Over the next four years, American plans to add 10 gates for a total of 25 at Luis Munos Marin International Airport and a customs facility capable of processing 5,000 passengers an hour. Its terminal area will total more than 1 million square feet when the expansion is done, up from 260,000 square feet. A looming recession and higher jet fuel prices are likely to dent American's 1990 earnings, Crandall said last week when the company's third quarter profit drop of 52 percent was announced. Unless fuel prices decrease significantly, Crandall warned, a fourth-quarter loss was almost assured and could be large enough to wipe out the company's $175.5 million profit in the first three quarters. But American's vice president for the Caribbean, Peter Dolara, said air traffic in that region will likely remain strong even if it slows in the continental United States. The demand for air travel is less elastic in the Caribbean because a large share of passengers live in the region and are flying to visit friends and relatives on other islands, Dolara said. Few of them have other travel options besides flying, he said. In addition, continental U.S. passengers who vacation in Europe typically turn to the Caribbean as a less costly alternative during a recession, Dolara said. Lee Howard, chief executive officer of Airline Economics Inc., said American is one of the few carriers that can make a substantial capital commitment, such as the San Juan expansion, in a recession and fuel crisis. ``American will emerge probably a relatively stronger carrier because some of the weaker ones will have gone by the wayside in the same time frame,'' Howard said. United Airlines, which jockeys with American as the nation's largest carrier, also made a major capital commitment Tuesday. United will spend $400 million to purchase most of Pan Am's routes between the United States and London. American began service in 1986 to the Caribbean and the region now accounts for about 12 percent of its routes and slightly more than 12 percent of its revenues, Crandall said. When new route additions are completed in December, American will have 58 daily flights to 26 destinations from San Juan. American Eagle, its regional affiliate, will have 68 daily flights to 15 destinations. The airline eventually may operate 200 flights daily in San Juan, Crandall said. In addition to the terminal improvements in San Juan, American will also help pay for a roadway expansion and new control tower at the airport. The company plans smaller capital improvements at St. Thomas, Santo Domingo, St. Croix, St. Maarten, Puerto Plata, Montego Bay and Kingston. The airline recently opened a $10 million reservations office in San Juan that eventually will employ 200 people.

DOC.HEAD: Canadians Blurt Out The Bad News - Recession
DOC.TEXT: Canadians abhor being seen as following in American footsteps, and this time they got out in front by officially tumbling into recession on their own. The United States, however, may nt be far behind. Finance Minister Michal Wilson, after weeks of dodging the dread ``R'' word, finally acknowledged to a House of Commons committee Monday night that Canada had slipped into a recession, though he expected it to be short. The country's largest bank, the Royal Bank of Canada, also predicted negative growth for the third and fourth quarters of this year, saying a slow recovery would begin next year. Wilson said the current recession would be nothing like the 1981-82 version, which involved a precipitous drop into a ``black hole.'' ``The partial information that is now available for the third quarter, together with some major work stoppages, the crisis in the Middle East and the weakening U.S. economy, suggest a further decline in output,'' Wilson said. ``However, we do not expect this to be a severe recession.'' Dr. Edward Neufeld, chief economist at the Royal Bank, said the current situation differed from the 1981-82 recession in that the economy since 1988 has slipped slowly into economic malaise and will work its way out slowly. Neufeld said the Canadian economy has never gone into recession when the American economy did not ``no matter how far back you want to look.'' Some economists says the U.S. economy already is in recession, others say it will hit recession in the fourth quarter of this year, and still others predict the United States will escape recession by a narrow margin. The opposition in the Canadian Parliament has blamed the conservative government's policy of high interest rates - an effort to cure inflation - for the recession. Recession usually is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth. The Canadian economy shrank 0.4 percent in the second quarter of 1990 and Wilson predicted there would be negligible growth for four quarters. ``Consumers will be looking over the next year or so at no increase in their standard of living,'' Neufeld told a group of reporters at an economic briefing. He said it would be a period when consumers pay ``tremendous attention to managing their financial affairs,'' and a time to focus on ``keeping your job if you have a good one.'' Canadians seem to have the word already. Retail sales in August were down 0.2 percent from July as consumers spent less on big-ticket items such as vehicles, furniture and appliances, according to Statistics Canada, the government's number crunchers. The Royal Bank's forecast said unemployment probably would rise from the current 8.4 percent to about 9 percent at the peak of the downturn. Statistics Canada figures showed a drop in the composite leading indicator for the sixth straight month. Corporate profits have plunged 23 percent below a year ago, and personal bankruptcies are 37 percent above 1989. Canadian inflation has dropped from 5.5 percent in January to 4.1 percent in August, but that at the cost of extremely high interest rates. The rates have been edging down a bit recently. The prime lending rate has gone from 14.75 percent to 13.75 percent. Various business groups have been pleading with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's government to get a handle on the deficit. The latest plea came this week from the Canadian Manufacturers' Association which has created a new ``competitiveness index'' measuring labor productivity, wholesale prices and exports. Laurent Thibault, president of the association, said much of the prosperity of the 1980s ``has been built on an accumulated mountain of debt.'' The last Canadian budget forecast a deficit of $24.2 billion (U.S.) for the 1990-91 fiscal year. Wilson said recently it will be $850 million to $1.3 billion higher than that. ``The majo policy issue in the United States and Canada is the fiscal deficit,'' said the Royal Bank's Neufeld. In addition to that, ``We are building up a load of debt to foreigners that is finally becoming uncontainable.'' The government and the country' biggest bank agree the present slowdown is the price to pay for a decade of prosperity and that the shallow economic dip should be over by the end of 1991. All the predictions, however, assume there will be no shooting war in the Middle East. ``A disruption of Middle East oil flows would have a devastating effect on the economy and you could forget all my forecasts,'' said Neufeld.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Files For Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp. filed early today for protection from its creditors along with a reorganization plan that would clear the way for selling control of the nation's largest convenience store operator to a Japanese group. The parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain said its debt and preffered stock holders have approved the so-called prepackaged reorganization plan which is being submitted for confirmation by the federal bankruptcy court. The company has been trying to avoid filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws since March, when it announced it would sell a majority stake to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., its Japanese franchisees. The Japanese investors would provide $430 million in new cash in exchange for a 70 percent stake in common stock in the reorganized company. The restructuring would leave the creditors with far less than they loaned the firm in 1987 when the founding Thompson family took the company private. Dallas-based Southland has struggled under the debt incurred in the $4.9 billion leveraged buyout. The company also faces increasing competition from proliferating convenience stores run by major oil companies. The company said today that a syndicate of lenders has agreed to provide Southland up to $400 million in debtor-in-possession financing. Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Stubbs Norwood said the company intends to use the funds as working capital to purchase necessary inventories and to continue the company's other normal operating activities. The company said that of those security holders voting on the prepackaged reorganization plan, about 89 percent of the outstanding principal amount of debt securities and approximately 90 percent of the outstanding shares of preferred stock were voted in favor of the plan. Southland has asked for a bankruptcy court hearing on Dec. 10 for the confirmation of the prepackaged reorganization plan. Ms. Norwood said the proposed prepackaged bankruptcy plan consists of two parts - exchange offers and a cash infusion by the Japanese partners. Under the exchange offers, existing shareholders - primarily the Thompson family - would retain a 5 percent equity position. Bondholders would receive 25 percent of the common stock and the Japanese would purchase 70 percent of the company's common stock, she said. Creditors reportedly like the bankruptcy plan because they believe it could bring a quick resolution to their uncertainty. Companies have begun using such prepackaged plans to shorten the time it takes for them to emerge from bankruptcy. The company also said it is immediately filing motions in bankruptcy court to seek approval to assume existing 7-Eleven franchises and area licensee agreements; pay employee salaries and wages and continue existing employee benefit plans and pay pre-petition debt in full to all suppliers who agree to provide the company with customary credit terms during the bankruptcy case. ``In the light of the results of the exchange offers and the high level of support we have received for our prepackaged reorganization plan, we believe this is the best alternative to complete a financial restructuring quickly,'' said Clark Matthews, Southland's chief financial officer. ``We hope to obtain court approval of the prepackaged reorganization plan as soon as possible.'' ``Upon confirmation of our plan and consummation of our new Stock Purchase Agreement, we will go forward with a more manageable debt load, as well as the capital we need to remain at the top of the competitive convenience retailing industry,'' Matthews added. Members of the Thompson family were not available for comment, Ms. Norwood said. Southland operates about 6,800 7-Eleven stores and other convenience outlets in the United States and Canada, with another 6,000 stores in the United States and 21 other countries run by licensees, of which Seven-Eleven Japan is the largest.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Talks Continuing; Thursday Deadline in Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, UAW President . . . with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Detroit newspaper reports. Picks up 10th graf: There have ...
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union negotiators bargaining with Chrysler Corp. were pleased to learn that Canadian Auto Workers union officials think a contract with Chrysler's Canadian subsidiary may be near. The UAW and the Canadian Auto Workers are pressing Chrysler and its Chrysler Canada Ltd. subsidiary to agree to contracts mirroring agreements already reached with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and their Canadian operations. Chrysler and its Canadian subsidiary have hinted they may not be able to agree to a pattern agreement ratified by GM and Ford workers. On Monday, Chrysler Canada gave the CAW an economic proposal CAW President Bob White called ``a great relief.'' The CAW has set a midnight Thursday deadline. Analysts said the proposal from Chrysler Canada may signal that the parent corporation is more willing to go along with the UAW pattern agreement than it had indicated. The CAW represents about 10,000 Chrysler workers in Canada. On Tuesday, a UAW official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, ``I didn't see any long faces around here'' after White's remarks. Company spokesman Lee Sechler declined to say Tuesday if negotiators had made headway in the talks. The UAW has set no deadline for its talks with Chrysler. The union represents about 63,000 active Chrysler workers in the United States. The Detroit Free Press today quoted unidentified union officials as saying that a Monday strike deadline could be set today. Meantime, The Detroit News reported today UAW President Owen Bieber told union bargainers he's hoping for a settlement by the first of next week. The News said neither Bieber nor UAW Vice President Stan Marshall, in charge of the union's Chrysler Department, said anything about setting a strike deadline. Bieber set up shop Monday morning at Chrysler's headquarters in the Detroit enclave of Highland Park. He met with Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John, said the UAW source. There have been no formal sessions at the main negotiating table, company and union officials said, as negotiators have been bargaining in subcommittees that focus on specific provisions in a contract. Chrysler and its Canadian subsidiary have said for months that meeting the pattern agreement reached with the other two automakers would be difficult. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca and other executives, while falling short of demanding concessions, have said the struggling company needs special consideration. Chrysler is expected next week to report a third-quarter loss that may wipe out the $251 million it earned in the first six months of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Former CBOT Chief Mahlmann Takes Job In London
DOC.TEXT: Former Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann is going to England as chief of the London office of the Rosenthal-Collins Group, a Chicago-based futures brokerage. Mahlmann resigned as leader of the world's largest commodities exchange in August amid problems at Stotler & Co., the now-defunct brokerage he headed. Rosenthal-Collins is run by Leslie Rosenthal, a political opponent of Mahlmann who opposed him in last year's exchange chairmanship election. Rosenthal and Mahlmann said Monday that their political differences have never interfered with their friendship. ``The poor guy's been punished enough,'' Rosenthal said. ``His life savings were tied up in a firm that went down the drain. At 53, he's starting over again.'' Rosenthal said he believes Mahlmann's assertion that he had nothing to do with the problems at Stotler, which collapsed due to a lack of cash. Mahlmann has not been accused of wrongdoing by federal regulators in a lawsuit that charges a Stotler affiliate defrauded investors. Mahlmann's successor at the Board of Trade, William F. O'Connor, announced Monday he will seek re-election as chairman in the Dec. 12 election. Former Board of Trade Vice Chairman Patrick Arbor also is running for the exchange chairmanship.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 5 Percent Decline in Third-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Norfolk Southern Corp. said Wednesday its third quarter earnings declined 5 percent from a year ago, citing increased diesel fuel costs and expenses related to a stock buyback. Net income for the third quarter was $142.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in the third quarter compared to $150.5 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. Arnold B. McKinnon, chairman, president and chief executive, said income from operations rose 6.5 percent depite a 24.7 percent in diesel fuel costs due to price increases. He said other income fell 53.7 percent because of a combination of investment-related transactions and increased interest expenses on debt incurred to finance the stock repurchase program. Revenue rose 2.9 percent to $1.18 billion in the quarter from $1.14 billion a year earlier. Coal revenue rose 9.8 percent while general merchandise revenue was essentially flat. Net income for the first nine months of 1990 was $439 million, or $2.68 a share, down 4.1 percent from $458 million, or $2.61 a share, in the first nine months of 1989. Nine-month revenue rose 1.9 percent to $3.49 billion from $3.43 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bankers Arrested in Tax Case
DOC.TEXT: Two former bank employees and two customers have been arrested on charges of evading millions of dollars in income taxes on profits made in an alleged stock manipulation scheme, prosecutors said Wednesday. It was the second set of arrests involving major Japanese finaniial institutions in connection with stock manipulation linked to Koshin, a group under investigation for the last two years. A former Sumitomo Bank branch manager was arrested earlier this month for allegedly providing illegal loans to the group. Two top bank executives resigned over the case, and the bank ordered six-month salary cuts of up to 50 percent for a dozen other executives. Arrested Wednesday were Tsunetaka Seto, 48, a former branch manager of Mitsui Trust and Banking Co.; Haruki Matsuo, 40, one of his staffers, and two of their customers - Nobuyuki Ito, 43, a licensed tax accountant, and Taisuke Kobayashi, 52, a business executive, the Tokyo District Prosecutor's Office said. The prosecutor's office said the four failed to report a total of more than $23.4 million in income between 1986 and 1988, evading $14.1 million in taxes. It said it raided some 10 sites, including residences of the four. Prosecutors said the four opened disguised accounts under relatives' names for transactions in manipulated stocks, such as those of Tobishima Corp. and Kokusai Kogyo Co. Local news reports said the four acquired insider stock trading information from Mitsuhiro Kotani, the Koshin group's leader. Kotani was charged earlier this year with manipulating share prices. Mitsui Trust spokesman Kazuo Shibui told a news conference after the arrests Wednesday: ``We see this case as a result of their personal activities, which have nothing to do with our company.'' But he said the arrest of former bank employees was ``extremely regrettable for a financial institution'' and added, ``We apologize for the fact that we caused trouble to the public.'' Shibui said the bank had fired Seto in April 1988 and Matsuo in February 1990 following an internal investigation, and demoted two branch managers. He said Mitsui Trust cut the salaries of 12 top executives by 10-20 percent between May and August.

DOC.HEAD: Export Hopes Lift Corn, Wheat Futures
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and corn futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid speculation the Soviet Union wants to import more grain. Soybean futures were mostly lower. The expectations of new grain sales to Moscow stem in part from reports the Soviet Union has chartered freight vessels that now are situated off the U.S., Canadian and Argentine coasts, said William Biedermann, director of research with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. He said there was talk in the markets that the Soviets were considering buying 600,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Soybeans edged lower in quiet trading inspired more by technical factors than supply-and-demand fundamentals, Biedermann said. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64 a bushel; corn was { cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.32\ a bushel; oats were } cent higher across the board with December at $1.24} a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1 cent lower with November at $6.14 a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were mostly lower. Live cattle were .03 cent lower to .35 cent higher with December at 77.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .10 cent higher with October at 87.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .38 cent lower with December at 53.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 66.30 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Reports Loss; Will Trim Payroll By 3,000
DOC.TEXT: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. today said it planned to cut 3,000 jobs by mid-1992 as part of a restructuring, spurred on by a depressed tire market and a $61.4 million loss in the third quarter. Goodyear's loss amounted to $1.06 per share in the third quarter. In September, the company warned various factors would lead to a loss for the quarter. Goodyear earned $70.5 million, or $1.22 per share, in the 1989 third quarter. The loss reflected $51.7 million, or 89 cents per share, in unusual charges for restructuring. The costs resulted from realignment of European tire marketing; phase-out of medium and heavy truck tire production in Quebec; $22.2 million in environmental cleanup costs; and depreciation of the All American Pipeline System. About 3,000 jobs will be cut to reduce Goodyear's worldwide staff to 106,000 by mid-1992 as part of the restructuring, Chairman Tom H. Barrett said in a message to shareholders. The company also blamed the loss on increased selling, administrative and general expenses; severe competitive pricing in the tire replacement market; reduced auto and truck production, and production cutbacks to reduce inventories. Third-quarter revenue rose 8.2 percent to $2.9 billion from $2.68 billion a year earlier. For the first nine months of 1990, Goodyear reported a loss of $49.9 million, or 86 cents per share. The company earned $192.1 million, or $3.33 per share, during the first nine months the previous years. Worldwide sales rose 4 percent in the first nine months to $8.46 billion from $8.13 billion a year earlier.

Sears blamed the weak third-quarter performance mainly on lower gains from property sales in its Coldwell Banker real estate subsidiary. The company's struggling retailing division posted a 7.6 percent gain in the third quarter after suffering a decline in the second quarter and a loss in the first. Total revenues rose 5.9 percent to $13.96 billion from $13.18 billion in the third quarter of 1989. Coldwell Banker's operating income fell tlittle sense because the poor don't have any money. If they had money, they wouldn't be poor. Republicans who cry out against ``class warfare'' are not against class warfare when it involves the middle class being forced by law to subsidize the rich. They oppose warfare (or even unpleasantness) against their own class because it might result in losing a few bucks. Raising the income tax will not remove the motivation to be rich. If we don't do something soon, there won't be any arguments over guns vs. butter. There will be none of either. Our money will go straight to our creditors, like a family with 100 credit cards, all past due. --- Oct. 22 Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth on the budget: President Bush personally and members of Congress collectively are losing the confidence of the nation as they drag out their feuding and quarrelling over a deficit-reducing budget. The Democrats say tax the rich. The Republicans say cut federal expenditures. We would go with the Republicans, but both may be a little right. The nation's wealthiest taxpayers are being taxed at a much smaller percent of their total incomes than they were a decade ago. Meanwhile, as Congress debates, the federal deficit continues to rise. Interest rates remain high. And this massive federal borrowing is depleting the economic vigor of America. Why not cut the military? The Cold War is over. The Soviet Union, with its failing economy, is in far worst shape than the United States. The Soviets obviously are not bent on military confrontation with the West. Why more than 300,000 U.S. troops in Germany? World War II has been over for 45 years. Germany, an economic powerhouse, has reunited. The Soviet Union intends to withdraw its troops from what used to be East Germany and the Germans are going to pay for the withdrawal. Moreover, while Europe was exhausted and in ruins after World War II, today Europe is stronger than ever. Through the European Community the nations of Europe are prospering. So why are U.S. troops needed to protect a dynamic Europe? It is true the military operation in the Persian Gulf will require a substantial expenditure so long as it lasts. We are still assuming, however, that this is not a permanent military commitment, that it will be worked out in time and the U.S. troops will come home. --- Oct. 18 The Daily Journal, Elizabeth, N.J., on the budget: As U.S. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., points out, this budget crisis didn't happen overnight. The executive and legislative branches have ignored a growing deficit for more than a decade, and now facing the catastrophic results of Gramm-Rudman, they snivel and bicker. Bradley estimates that we could easily cut $250 million from defense spending over the next five years and still maintain a strong military in a regional crisis like the Persian Gulf. But Congress resists. The House has delayed by two years Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposal to shut down 35 bases in the U.S. and 12 overseas. The move affects more Democratic districts than Republican and thus parochial House representatives undermine the deficit reduction process. Over the next few days, the president and Congress must discard hidden agendas, special interests and partisan politics. They have a job to do, and America tires of their stall tactics. --- Oct. 20 Las Cruces (N.M.) Sun-News on inflation: Inflation is a lot like flu. Even when it's not around, there's a feeling that it's lurking somewhere, just waiting for an opportunity to strike again. For two months now the cost of living has risen sharply. If the situation worsens we could return to the days of double-digit inflation. Usually inflation can be blamed on a number of factors. But its recent upsurge could largely be attributed to one single villain - Saddam Hussein. The inflation spurt was caused largely by the jump in the price of oil, which was precipitated by Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. The future does not look promising. Still, we have blundered our way through other messes. The U.S. economy is under siege, but it is still a very tough customer. At this point, we can still keep our fingers crossed and hope for the best. ---

DOC.HEAD: Beating The High Cost of Delivering: Magazines Doing it Themselves
DOC.TEXT: Magazine publishers say they've found a way to beat the high cost of delivering: They're doing it themselves. A few small alternative magazine delivery systems have popped up over the last few years, but now one of the industry's heavy hitters - Time Warner Inc. - has entered the picture. The publishing industry says if Time's system prospers, more companies could follow and eventually provide significant competition for the U.S. Postal Service. ``There's no question what the motivation here is,'' said George Gross, an executive vice president of the trade group Magazine Publishers of America. ``By building a distribution system you are saying to the Postal Service that while there is no alternative now, in time there will be.'' The magazine industry has been complaining for year that rising postal rates have been cutting into their profits. Postmaster General Anthony Frank has acknowledged that postal rates have increased beyond general inflation, and he has vowed to slow the pace. But the Postal Service maintains it can do a better job of delivery than alternative systems such as Publishers Express, for which Time Warner is the managing partner. Eight other equity partners are involved in the project. Begun in Atlanta last year on a trial basis, Publishers Express now is delivering more than 100,000 magazines, catalogs and advertisement packages a month to more than 80,000 households within five ZIP codes. The company has set a goal of 200,000 pieces a month to 100,000 households by the end of the year. From a suburban Atlanta facility, delivery crews sort 24 titles - including Time, Sports Illustrated, TV Guide, the Atlantic Monthly and Playboy - and deliver them in sealed packages before dawn each day. Publishers Express cannot use mailboxes under federal law. The magazines and catalogs are delivered to doorsteps or left at the base of a mailbox. ``If you look at the magazine business, distribution is the only cost we don't have control over,'' said Howard Rosen, president of Publishers Express. ``But it's very tough to tell the post office you don't like their pricing structure. They'd say, `Fine, but you've got nowhere else to go.' '' Since 1970, Rosen said, the cost for second class postage - which is the rate for newspapers and magazines - has risen 811 percent compared to a general inflation rate of 209 percent over that time. Third class postage - the rate for most catalogs - has gone up 364 percent, he said. The Postal Service puts the figures a bit lower: 767 percent for second class and 247 percent for third class. Nonetheless, Rosen said, ``It's too cost prohibitive to distribute our products through the post office.'' In addition to titles published by Time Warner, the distribution service has contracted with other magazines and catalogs to deliver their products, Rosen said. The titles in the designated ZIP code areas are automatically distributed through Publishers Express, though consumers may request that the Postal Service take over their service. Postal Service spokesman Bob Hoobing said costs may be higher but service is reliable. ``The fact of the matter is, we have people who are career workers delivering the mail. We think we're more reliable,'' he said. Hoobing declined to speculate on the impact of such alternative delivery services. He said about 6.5 percent of the 161.6 billion pieces of mail handled last year by the Postal Service was second class. If future postal rate increases continue to pinch, ``there will be more magazines saying (to Time) we want to join you,'' said Gross, of the Magazine Publishers of America. Kofie Q. Dadzie, an assistant marketing professor at Georgia State University who specializes in distribution systems, said an operation such as Time's would have to handle an enormous amount of material to make its costs competitive with the post office. ``I'd be interested in finding the cost analysis that said it would be cheaper,'' Dadzie said. ``I'm surprised.'' Rosen declined to disclose Publishers Express' income, but he acknowledged the distribution system must expand if it is to do the job of the post office at a lower cost. ``Clearly at the scale we're at, we are not in a competitive price situation with the post office,'' he said. ``We need to double our volume. It can be reached within the next year or two.''

DOC.HEAD: Posts Profit Decline in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Wednesday its first quarter earnings slipped 1.6 percent from results a year ago that included a big settlement in a legal fight over a cookie patent. The consumer products giant earned $555 million, or $1.57 a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $564 million, or $1.59 a share, a year earlier. Procter & Gamble won the $125 million settlement - $81 million after taxes - from a lawsuit it filed alleging that competitors Frito-Lay, Nabisco and Keebler had infringed on P&G's patent for Duncan Hines ready-to-serve cookies. Excluding the settlement, earnings for the July-September period in 1989 were $483 million, or $1.36 a share. Procter & Gamble said it had $6.65 billion in first quarter sales worldwide, up 16.3 percent from $5.7 million a year earlier. Chairman Edwin L. Artzt said he was pleased that unit volume and earnings excluding the settlement have ``continued to grow at a dopuble-digit pace despite the uncertain times in which we are operating.'' The company said it had restated its July-September 1989 financial results to include operations of Noxell Corp., the personal-care products maker based in Hunt Valley, Md., which P&G absorbed in November 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Rise 29 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. said Wednesday its third quarter profit jumped 29 percent on slightly higher sales of its beauty goods. Avon earned $44.6 million, or 63 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared to $34.6 million, 46 cents a share, a year earlier., Sales rose 5.9 percent to $830.8 million from $785.1 million in the same quarter of 1989. For the first nine months of 1990, Avon's profit rose 34 percent to $107.3 million, $1.42 a share, compared with $80.3 million, 97 cents a share, a year ago. Nine-month sales jumped 3 percent to $2.33 billion from $2.27 billion in 1989. ``Our strong third quarter reflects continued profit improvements in the U.S. and the Americas, continued reduction in interest expense and a lower tax rate,'' said James E. President, president and chief executive officer of the New York-based company. Third-quarter sales in the company's international unit jumped 8 percent while those for Avon's domestic unit rose 2 percent. The company cut its debt during the quarter to $603.3 million, down from $1.09 billion at the same time last year and $838.1 million at the end of 1989. Avon is trying to sell half of its 60 percent interest in its Japanese subsidiary and should know soon if the transaction can be completed this year, Preston said.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Reports Drop in Third Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Du Pont Co. on Wednesday reported a 3 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, with increases in its petroleum operations offset by slower growth in the company's chemicals businesses. The company reported net earnings of $533 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $547 million last year. Earnings per share were flat at 79 cents, and reflected a lower number of shares this year due to a buyback program. Sales for the quarter were up 16 percent at $9.9 billion, compared with $8.6 billion last year. ``Third-quarter results reflect strong performance from our petroleum operations,'' said Du Pont Chairman Edgar S. Woolard Jr. in a statement. ``Petroleum results have benefited from higher crude oil prices, which will provide a hedge to rising feedstock costs in our chemical operations. ``At the same time, earnings in several of our chemical businesses continued to be adversely affected by the slowdown in the U.S. economy,'' Woolard said. Du Pont said the improvement in petroleum earnings was due partly to higher oil prices, which soared after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August. The company said 70 percent of the overall improvement was due to operations overseas, where there was a strong demand for petroleum products and greater efficiency at the company's refineries. It said higher crude prices also led to an increase in U.S. earnings, although the company did not fully pass on increased costs at the gas pump. Du Pont also said its quarterly results include gains of 8 cents a share from the sale of an interest in a North Sea oil property and an instrument systems business. Net income for the first nine months fell 8 percent to $1.8 billion or $2.71 per share, compared with $1.9 billion or $2.82 per share for the first nine months of 1989. Sales for the first nine months were $29 billion, up 9 percent over $26.5 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Dial Earnings Up Despite Drop in Revenues
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Dial Corp. said Wednesday it increased its third-quarter earnings despite a drop in revenue, but still posted a nine-month loss as a result of the bankruptcy of its former bus line. Net income totaled $31.99 million or 80 cents a share on revenues of $875.93 million for the period ended Sept. 30. That compares with $30.19 million or 75 cents a share on revenues of $906.2 million a year earlier, the company said Wednesday. For the nine-month period, revenue totaling $2.65 billion produced $88.04 million in income from continuing operations, or $2.19 per share. But there was a net loss of $11.96 million or 32 cents a share in the period because of a $100 million after-tax loss provision taken in the second quarter as a result of the bankruptcy of Dallas-based Greyhound Bus Lines, the company said. Greyhound Dial sold the bus company in 1987 but retained an interest in it. The current nine-month figures compare with revenues of $2.67 billion a year earlier, when income from continuing operations and net earnings were $80.67 million or $2.05 per share. John W. Teets, chairman, president and chief executive officer, said the company's financial group was performing well, with no major problems in its corporate finance or real estate operations. A statement said operating income was up 21 percent in the consumer products segment, while income rose 7.5 percent in the services sector. Revenue from transportation manufacturing and service dropped sharply, however, because of a new model start-up problem that caused ``severe production delays with a major transit bus order,'' the company statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Yes, Investor, There is a Future
DOC.TEXT: When the stock market decline becomes too much to take, it may be time to look into the future, to dream a bit of wonderfully bullish times when you can awaken each day to prospects of profits. It has been many months since people enjoyed such days and it might be a long time before they experience them again. The economic base that stock prices reflect has serious and maybe worsening problems. Still, history declares that somewhere out in the future are better times. How far out depends on your sense of time. If you view a few months as a long time you might be disappointed. If you think in terms of years you won't be. Did you know that even in the decade of the 1930s, when stocks floundered after the great crash of 1929, the annual loss from equities was 0.1 percent, barely into the minus column? Purists will point out, of course, that much of the collapse occurred in the final year before the decade of the 1930s, but historians counter by pointing to another downturn in 1931, and still another in 1938. In no decade since then has the average annual return been a minus - that is, the total return for the decade broken down to an annual basis. In each of those decades, however, prices bounced like a golf ball on a highway. In all, there have been 11 bear markets since the 1930s, including the present one and another that spanned the turn of the decade from 1939 to the spring of 1942. In each one, prices fell sharply - 48 percent in 1973-1974 - but only one lasted more than three years. That was the 37-month bear market from May 1946 to June 1949. In each instance, of course, prices resumed their rise. Wright Investors' Service arrived at the 0.1 percent loss for the 1930s by using this calculation: It started with an earned return of minus 0.2 percent a year from 5.5 percent annual dividend income and a 5.7 percent decline of earnings. To that was added an increase of 0.1 percent a year in price-earnings ratios. Using the same formula, the return for the 1940s averaged 9.2 percent a year, rose to 19.4 percent in the 1950s, fell back to 7.8 percent in the 1960s and to 5.9 percent in the 1970s, but then leaped to 17.5 percent in the 1980s. You are not convinced by the historical record? Nothing unusual about that. Such despair is one of the identifying traits of a bear market, as surely as unjustified optimism identifies a bull market heading to a disastrous finale. Equity investments require faith as well as information. They are risky, simply because nobody knows anything for certain about the future, very little about the present and probably only slightly more than that about the past. That said, here are Wright's projections for the period through 1995: Dividend income will grow an average of 3.4 percent a year and earnings 8.1 percent, giving an earned return of 11.5 percent. P-E ratios, however, will be lowered by 2.6 percent a year, leaving an annual return of 8.9 percent. Based partly on those estimates, Wright projects the Dow Jones industrials to average 2,750 points in 1991, rising to 2,975 in 1991, to 3,175 in 1993, to 3,413 in 1994 and to 3,625 points in 1995. Nothing like the period 1985-1990, when the average almost doubled from 1,547 points, but a relatively serene sea nonetheless for those investors who in 1990 saw their stocks engulfed in the maelstrom.
