DOC.HEAD: Earnings Slide Again But Retail Unit Improves
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. reported sharply lower net income Wednesday for the third straight quarter but said its struggling retail unit has improved under the direct supervision of Chairman Edward Brennan. Overall earnings plunged 30 percent in the third quarter, mainly due to lower gains by the Coldwell Banker real estate subsidiary, Sears said. Earnings from the Allstate insurance unit also declined but the Dean Witter financial services group showed great improvement over the third quarter of 1989. Chicago-based Sears reported net income of $179.2 million, or 53 cents a share, for the three months ending Sept. 30 compared with $257.5 million, or 75 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenues rose 5.9 percent to $13.96 billion from $13.18 billion in the third quarter of 1989, Sears said in a statement. Coldwell Banker's operating income fell to $1.8 million from $81.2 million in the third quarter of 1989, when the division sold partial interest in several shopping centers. Sears said after-tax gains from property sales in the latest quarter totaled $18.1 million compared with $87.2 million a year earlier. ``The decline was the result of the timing of property sales as well as the soft residential market,'' Sears said. The Sears Merchandise Group, which accounts for more than half of Sears revenues, posted a 7.6 percent gain in third-quarter operating income after suffering a 32 percent decline in the second quarter and a $37.4 million loss in the first. Operating income from the retailing division totaled $89.2 million, Sears said. Revenues rose to $7.8 billion from $7.6 billion. Brennan, who was given direct oversight of the merchandise group in early August, said encouraging results in home appliances, electronics, automotive, and women's apparel reflected the effectiveness of new retailing strategies that Sears began implementing in March 1989. But Brennan said the performances of Sears' catalog, home fashions, home improvements, children's clothing and men's apparel departments remained sluggish. Retailing analyst Walter Loeb of Loeb Associates in New York, said the weakness in such traditional Sears strongholds as home improvement and home fashions indicated the merchandise group is still having trouble. But Sears said retailing revenues rose faster than selling and administrative expenses, which suggests Brennan's cost-cutting efforts are working. The cost-saving measures include a 20 percent reduction in the company's catalog division staff, as well as the offering of severance packages to 600 workers at Sears' corporate headquarters in Chicago. Both steps took place last month. ``It's too early to be conclusive about it, but I think this will be a successful program,'' Loeb said. Allstate's operating income fell nearly 14 percent to $108.7 million in the third quarter, reflecting catastrophic losses greater than historical levels. Dean Witter's operating income soared 60 percent to $57.2 million. The results included a 37 percent increase in brokerage income and 27 percent rise in income from Discover Card operations. For the first nine months of 1990, Sears earned $523.4 million, or $1.53 per share, on sales of $40.4 billion. That compares with earnings of $906.4 million, or $2.56 per share, on sales of $38.6 billion in the first nine months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Maytag Reorganizes its Hoover Operations in Britain
DOC.TEXT: Maytag Corp. on Wednesday named a new managing director to its Hoover appliance business in Britain as part of what it called a major reorganization of the European business. Hoover's appliance and floor care operation in the United Kingdom has been a drain on Maytag profitability since Maytag acquired the business in a 1989 takeover of the Chicago Pacific Corp. Daniel Krumm, Maytag's chairman, announced the latest in a series of steps to shore up the British operations in remarks to employees at Hoover production facilities in England, Scotland and Wales. He said the plan is designed to achieve the ``rebirth, rejuvenation, stability and return to profitability'' of Hoover UK. Krumm named veteran labor relations executive William Foust to succeed Anthony Williamson as managing director of Hoover UK and to head a task force to speed organizational changes and implement production efficiencies. Foust is the senior vice president of human resources at Maytag and a former officer of the Magic Chef Co., another Maytag subsidiary. Krumm said Foust will serve full time in South Wales until he completes the special assignment, then return to Maytag's headquarters in the central Iowa community of Newton. Williamson, who has worked for Hoover for more than 30 years, announced he intends to retire but will continue to serve as a director and to represent Hoover with various industry associations. The shakeup was no surprise, said analyst Russell Leavitt, who follows Maytag for the New York investment firm Salomon Brothers. ``That business has suffered in the last year or two, essentially since they got it,'' Leavitt said. He said Maytag executives were dissatisfied with the performance of Hoover UK but probably needed time to understand industry conditions in Britain, which has been hit by a major slump in its appliance business. Maytag, which does not disclose results from Hoover UK, last week reported a $15.7 million operating loss from European operations for the first nine months of the year, compared with an operating loss of $8.3 million a year earlier. The Hoover UK operations were a big contributor to the operating loss, said Maytag spokeswoman Lisa Mendheim. The operating loss came despite a 24 percent increase in sales, to $340.1 million from $273.7 million. Maytag had net earnings of $86 million on sales of $2.33 billion for the first nine months of 1990, compared with profit of $91.7 million on sales of $2.29 billion in the same period a year earlier. The reorganization followed capital improvements and cost-cutting programs in Britain. Maytag said earlier this year it will invest about $22 million in a major renovation in Wales. Hoover reduced its work force by 17 percent in the United Kingdom in 1989 and cut 700 additional jobs this year. It still has 4,500 workers in Britain out of a global work force of approximately 25,000.

DOC.HEAD: Grains Rise Slightly, Soybeans Slip
DOC.TEXT: Export sales rumors lifted corn and and wheat futures prices Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade but soybean futures fell slightly. Talk of Soviet interest in U.S. corn continued to support the grain markets, analysts said. Reports that the Soviet Union has chartered freight vessels were regarded as an indication that Moscow soon will be shopping for grain, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. He said the grain markets also were supported by slow sales of newly harvested corn. ``The farmers are really unhappy with these prices and are just storing it,'' he said. Soybean futures were pressured by a government report showing larger-than-expected soymeal and soyoil stocks, Karlin said. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64} a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2} cents higher with December at $2.32} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $1.24\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4 cents lower with November at $6.10{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: USG Reports $11 Million Loss, Plans Significant Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: USG Corp., a building materials manufacturer, said it will lay off a significant part of its work force after suffering a third-quarter loss of $11 million. The company declined to say how many jobs would be cut. Most of the impending layoffs will be white-collar, salaried workers at its Chicago headquarters and across the United States, said USG spokesman Matthew Gonring. The company has trimmed its work force in the last two years from 21,000 to 14,000 by selling assets and eliminating jobs. ``It's a difficult decision, and we regret having to make it,'' Gonring said of the new layoffs. ``But it's being brought on by the decline in housing, the savings and loan crisis and most recently the problems in the Mideast.'' USG said it has suffered from low prices for its gypsum wallboard. The 20-cents-per-share loss, announced Tuesday, compared with a profit of $9 million, or 16 cents a share, reported a year earlier. Sales for the quarter that ended Sept. 30 slid 4 percent to $538 million from $560 million a year earlier. For the nine-month period, the company reported a loss of $2 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a $21 million profit, or 38 cents a share, in the same period of 1989. Nine-month sales fell 6 percent, to $1.6 billion from $1.7 billion, USG said.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Files $560 Million Lawsuit Against Woods
DOC.TEXT: Federal bank regulators have filed a $560 million lawsuit against the former owner of Western Savings Association, contending he defrauded the failed thrift of at least that much money. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. also accuses Jarrett E. Woods Jr. of spending $7 million of depositors' money on himself during the thrift's final months in 1986. The lawsuit is one of the largest ever filed by the government against a savings and loan owner. It was filed Friday in Dallas but not released until Tuesday. The suit accuses Woods and Western Capital, a corporation he controlled, of engaging in fraud and violating contracts. The government alleges that in the four years Woods controlled the thrift, he squandered its deposits on high-risk and fraudulent investments and improper loans. ``The losses suffered by the institution appear to exceed $1 billion, at least $560 million of which was the preventable result of the policies and practices implemented at Western by Jarrett E. Woods Jr. and Western Capital Corporation,'' the suit states. Woods is accused of using thrift money to refinance his home, funnelling millions into his children's trust funds, paying off a personal loan and paying himself an $800,000 bonus and a $41,667 monthly salary. When federal regulators closed Western in September 1986, examiners found ``deficient or non-existent appraisals, inadequate loan documentation, inaccurate accounting and shoddy record-keeping,'' the lawsuit states. Woods disagreed with the regulators' contentions. He claimed that the thrift was not insolvent and that he had tried to find solutions to the examiners' concerns. Woods has an unlisted home telephone number and could not be reached for comment Wednesday. No criminal charges have been filed against him.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers End Convnetion Dominated by Concerns Over Confidence in Industry ^With AM-Bankers-Kirk
DOC.TEXT: Bankers went home Wednesday after fve days of ``I'm OK, You're OK'' reassurance among themselves. Now they'll try to persuade the public. Though beset by problems resulting from the slowing economy, industry leaders maintained that banking remains fundamentally strong. Restoring public confidence by preaching that message was a dominant theme of the concluded American Bankers Association convention. Bankers were exhorted by the ABA leadership to become aggressive champions of the industry in their hometowns. ``The key issue ... is the confidence the people place in banking,'' said ABA President Richard A. Kirk. Kirk and others emphasized that banking is in much better condition than the savings and loan industry. Banking's problems should be viewed entirely separately than those of the thrifts, they said. The 4,500 conventioneers heard more than cheerleading, however. In a particularly blunt speech on Tuesday that the ABA brass had requested to be toned down, Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke said that confidence in the industry is at its lowest point in 50 years and bankers are partly to blame. ``This is not a time to be kidding ourselves,'' Clarke told the convention. Clarke, the nation's top bank regulator and well-known in the industry for his frankness, said the industry is in trouble on Main Street, Wall Street and on Capitol Hill. Among other things, Clarke faulted the industry for putting too many eggs in its real estate basket. The downturn in real estate is chief among the reasons many banks are suffering either losses or smaller profits. Clarke told reporters that there had been concern that his speech was too harsh when a draft copy of it was circulated among some people on Monday. He said he revised one paragraph to clearly show that he supported the survival of the industry. Clarke joined other federal banking officials in calling for more capitalization in the industry. In a forum that concluded the ABA convention Wednesday, a panel of three economists agreed that the nation is on the brink of a recession. That's bad news for the banking industry, though the economists said they expect the recession to be relatively mild. Participating in the forum were Arnold A. Dill, chief economist at Citizens and Southern Corp. in Atlanta; Tucker Hart Adams, chief economist at Central Banks of Colorado in Denver; and William B. Conerly, vice president of First Interstate Bank of Oregon in Portland. ``There's a fair chance we won't reach the technical definition of a recession,'' said Ms. Adams. ``I consider it very mild.'' Also dominating discussion at the ABA convention was how Congress may deal with the banking industry next year. Many believe Congress will enact sweeping reforms. ``Clearly, our industry is in the throes of major change, even perhaps a major restructuring,'' the ABA's Kirk said. Edward L. Yingling, executive director of the ABA's government relations group, said he expects Congress to act on deposit insurance reform, capital requirements, products and services reform and interstate banking. He also predicted a fierce lobbying effort by the banking industry and other concerns over the direction of the legislation. What the ABA wants in particular is the abolition of the ``too big to fail'' philosophy that governs bank regulation and legislation permitting banks to enter other lines of business. The traditional regulatory policy ensuring large institutions against failure gives big banks an unfair advantage over smaller ones, the organization believes. The bankers want permission to move into other businesses, such as the sale of securities, insurance and real estate, so they can compete more effectively with other financial services companies. Under the ABA's scenario, such services would be provided by separately regulated divisions, creating a ``wall'' that would not threaten the security of insured deposits, Yingling said.

DOC.HEAD: No Deadline Yet in Chrysler Talks
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union officials so far are holding off on setting a deadline for reaching a national contract with Chrysler Corp., a union official said Wednesday. In Canada, however, negotiators for Chrysler Canada Ltd. and the Canadian Auto Workers union bargained through Tuesday night to beat a midnight Thursday deadline for a new pact covering about 10,000 Canadian workers. The UAW and the CAW are pressing for contracts similar to those they negotiated separately with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and those companies' Canadian operations. ``It's doubtful if a contract completion date will be set today,'' UAW spokesman Bob Barbee said Wednesday. ``There's still lots of stuff that has to be done before anything like that.'' He added that by week's end, the union might set a deadline for reaching a contract with Chrysler. Setting a deadline increases pressure on negotiators. The UAW has about 63,000 members at Chrysler's U.S. operations. Earlier this fall, the unions reached a contract agreement with GM after setting a deadline. The unions and Ford then negotiated a contract without a deadline. Before talks with Chrysler intensified this week, there was speculation that a bumpy road was ahead of UAW and company negotiators, and a deadline might be set quickly. But on Monday, Chrysler's Canadian subsidiary gave the CAW an economic proposal union officials said was close to the GM-Ford Canadian patten agreement. Analysts viewed that move as encouraging for the U.S. talks. A Chrysler official, speaking Wednesday on the condition of anonymity, said main negotiators, including UAW President Owen Bieber and Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John, met twice Tuesday, but no similar meetings were scheduled for Wednesday. ``They might have to digest everything,'' the official said. Union and company officials also said work continued in bargaining subcommittees, which focus on specific areas of negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Announces Offer of Drastic Tariff Cut in Uruguay Round
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Wednesday offered drastic across-the-board tariff cuts in the Uruguay Round trade liberalization talks and called on other negotiators to reciprocate. The chief U.S. delegate, Warren Lavorel, told a committee meeting that the offer, if fully implemented, would represent a reduction of 43 percent in the average trade-weighted tariff. He noted the offer was considerably higher than the 33 percent target set in Montreal at the mid-term review of the 4-year-old talks. Lavorel said the offer covered all product areas, including domestically sensitive items such as textiles. He said continued U.S. support for the offer would depend on the reactions of other trading partners. A summary of his statement was reported by a meeting source who declined to be identified. Briefing reporters on the general discussion at the Trade Negotiating Committee, the source said the European Community again came under criticism for its delay in submitting a formal proposal on cutting farm support in the Uruguay Round. The EC's proposal, yet to be formalized, would cut subsidies by 30 percent, a reduction described as totally insufficient by the United States and other leading farm-exporting countries. According to the source, Argentina's Leopoldo Tettamanti said negotiators had already lost two weeks waiting for the Community offer. Tettamanti warned that the talks would enter into a ``deep crisis'' because the EC's offer might not lead to ``any meaningful negotiation.''

DOC.HEAD: Beech Slowing Production Because of Uncertainty
DOC.TEXT: Beech Aircraft Corp. said it will slow production of some models and stop hiring new workers because of the possibility of a shrinking marketplace. The company's actions take place as fuel costs have risen due to the crisis in the Middle East. ``In response to this situation we are taking a number of preliminary actions while we evaluate our current market situation,'' Jim Gregory, director of corporate affairs for Beech, said in a written statement Tuesday. Gregory said Beech was not trying to influence Congress' consideration of a luxury tax to help reduce the federal deficit. ``These actions are being taken in response to a slowing marketplace,'' he said. House negotiators Wednesday appeared to have accepted the Senate version of the proposed 10 percent tax, which would apply to the excess cost of any airplane above $250,000. Gregory said Beech was making ``production-rate adjustments on some models and reducing overtime.'' Beech has quit advertising for new employees, halted pre-employment training for some prospective workers and is ``reconsidering our plans to add a significant number of new employees by year-end,'' Gregory said. He did not detail the company's plans and declined comment on the possibility of layoffs. But an industry source said layoffs may occur because Beech had been adding employees in anticipation of strong sales and increased production rates. At a trade convention in New Orleans three weeks ago, Beech officials said the company had a bright sales outlook and was planning to add 500 jobs within the next 12 months, as many as 300 by the end of the year. Officials of two other Wichita-area aircraft makers, Cessna Aircraft Co. and Learjet, said that although they are concerned about the uncertainty in their business, they had not made any changes in operations.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup Reports Loss
DOC.TEXT: The holding company National Intergroup Inc. said Wednesday it lost almost $1 million in the second quarter after settling with shareholders in a takeover bid. The $4.2 million settlement brought on a loss of $988,000, or 11 cents a share, on revenue of $700 million in the quarter, NII said. That compared with a profit of $8.6 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenue of $561.5 million for the same 1989 period. In the first six months ended Sept. 30, NII posted a $282.7 million loss, or $13.12 per share, on sales of $1.3 billion. The loss was partly due to $239.5 million set aside during the first quarter to cover anticipated losses from the sale of the company's Ben Franklin and Permian Corp. subsidiaries and a $26.7 million charge associated with closing NII's Pittsburgh office. The company is moving its headquarters to Dallas. In the first six months of 1989, NII's earnings totaled $21.5 million, or 87 cents a share, on sales of $1.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Winnebago Goes to 4-Day Week, Layoffs Planned
With AM-Durable Goods Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With a gasoline rebate offer yet to recharge stalled motor-home sales, Winnebago Industries Inc. has cut back to a four-day work week and says it will begin laying off white-collar workers. The recent moves by the recreational vehicle giant are a dramatic illustration of how a business already hurting from softness in the economy has been walloped by the unexpected, in this case a stunning rise in fuel prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait nearly three months ago. An industry analyst said Winnebago appears to be taking the right steps to return to profitability once the gasoline price outlook and the nation's economic prospects brighten. Analyst Michael Sabbann, who follows the recreational vehicle industry for the Minneapolis investment firm of Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, also said Winnebago is not alone and that other manufacturers are in a bind. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that orders to U.S. factories of durable goods, such as appliances and vehicles designed to last three years or more, fell 1.7 percent in September. Transportation orders fell 6.8 percent. Winnebago, with products priced at $27,000 and up, has reported five straight quarterly losses and had a record $17.8 million loss in the fiscal year that ended Aug. 25 as sales fell 23 percent from the previous year. In May, directors suspended semiannual dividends to shareholders. In late September, Winnebago began layoffs and temporary factory shutdowns. Earlier this month, it began offering rebates to new buyers, guaranteeing to reimburse gasoline expenses above $1 a gallon for the first 12 months or 12,000 miles of ownership, whichever came first. Sheila Davis, a Winnebago spokeswoman, said Wednesday that the rebates have not led to any noticeable increase in sales. ``It's a little too early to tell'' about the success of the program, she said. She said company factories in the Iowa communities of Forest City, Hampton and Lorimor have been on Monday-to-Thursday schedules since last week, with 1,000 production workers idled each Friday. The four-day week will continue indefinitely, she said. An additional 500 workers were laid off since the end of September with no plans to recall them. Later this week, an austerity program will be announced that will include layoffs among the ranks of 800 office workers, supervisors and executives, she said. ``Unfortunately, those are the things that have to be done,'' Sabbann said. ``The whole industry cycle has turned against them.'' But he said Winnebago is in a good position to regain ground once the economy improves. He noted the company's claim to more than 60 percent of the market in sales of micro-mini motor homes, a more fuel-efficient recreational vehicle that has taken a growing share of the RV business. Forest City Mayor Paul Jefson said the company's travails are as serious as he can recall for Winnebago, the major employer in the community of 4,300. Jefson's memory goes back to when the factory burned down in September 1964. Counting workers now laid off, the company has about 2,600 employees. When Winnebago is in trouble, so is Forest City, Jefson said, and as problems began surfacing earlier this year ``we knew it's important that we live within the means of the city. It will affect us.'' Robert Rollefson, a broker at the Forest City office of the investment firm R.G. Dickinson & Co. and veteran Winnebago watcher, said the company is faced with its most serious challenge since the early 1970s. That's when an Arab oil embargo and the first oil price shock left the company with acres of unsold motor homes. ``Everywhere you looked, there was an ocean of white aluminum,'' Rollefson said. The company formed convoys of vehicles and drove them across country until they were sold, sometimes at prices way below cost. Winnebago is in better financial shape today, but ``the outlook now and the outlook then may be about the same,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply Wednesday amid continuing dismay over the health of the U.S. economy and lawmakers' ongoing haggling over the federal budget. Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, one troy ounce of gold rose $2.30 to settle at $373.50. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $372.75 an ounce, up $1.50. The dollar fell in overseas trading and continued to lose ground when activity shifted to the United States. A Commerce Department report showing a 1.7 percent decline in September orders for durable goods - the third decline in four months - offered fresh evidence that the U.S. economy is weakening. The report ``refocused the market's attention on the deteriorating fundamentals,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA. Investors also did not want to hold dollars because of uncertainty over the the federal budget, even though there were indications that a compromise on a deficit-reduction bill could come before Thursday. The Federal Reserve has hinted it would be inclined to lower interest rates once a budget package is in place. Lower interest rates would spur the economy but also would lessen the value of dollar-denominated securities, thereby reducing investors' need for the U.S. currency. Trading was active, with much attention focused on the Japanese yen, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. No particular piece of news emerged to push the yen higher, and some traders attributed its advance to technical factors. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 128.38 Japanese yen from 127.13 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London, it fell to 128.05 yen. In New York, the dollar fell further to close at 126.49 yen, down from 128.15 yen on Tuesday. In London the pound rose to $1.9550 from $1.9461 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.9590 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.9435. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5067 German marks, down from 1.5180; 1.2695 Swiss francs, down from 1.2817; 5.0440 French francs, down from .0820; 1,128.25 Italian lire, down from 1,137.25, and 1.1683 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1721. DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Downgrades Chemical Bank Debt
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp., one of the nation's two major credit-rating agencies, on Wednesday downgraded its rating of $5 billion worth of debt of Chemical Banking Corp. and several subsidiaries. The downgrade of the nation's sixth-largest banking company followed a similar rating reduction last month by S&P affecting No. 2 Chase Manhattan Corp. S&P said its downgrade of New York-based Chemical reflected its ``expectation of further moderate deterioration in loan quality in a continued difficult operating environment.'' However, the rating agency tempered its concern with optimistic statements about Chemical's prospects. `The company has the liquidity and financial flexibility to deal with the expected loan problems,'' it said. It added that Chemical's recent decision to reduce its dividend payment ``should help it rebuild capital after the heavy losses of the past few years.'' Chemical spokesman Charles Salmans said the company was disappointed by the action. ``S&P in its own announcement notes the quality of Chemical's loan portfolio and the steps we have taken to build capital,'' he said. S&P lowered by one notch the senior debt rating of parent Chemical Banking and subsidiaries Texas Commerce Bancshares and Chemical New York. It also lowered by one degree its rating on certifas soon as possible.'' U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold C. Abramson Wednesday set a Dec. 14 hearing on the confirmation plan and company spokeswoman Cecilia Stubbs Norwood said Southland hoped to emerge from court supervision before the end of the year. Ms. Norwood said store operations would not be affected by the filing and the company had commitments for $400 million in financing while it proceeds through the bankruptcy process. Southland has been struggling since 1987 when the founding Thompson family, fearing a takeover by the Belzbergs of Canada, took the company private in a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout. The LBO, second highest ever at the time, became more expensive on Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 508 points. The crash made it more difficult and more expensive to arrange financing for the deal. Southland first proposed its restructuring in March of this year, acknowledging that dwindling profits would make it impossible to meet the debt brought on by the 1987 buyout. In April, Southland revealed a fourth-quarter loss of $1.01 billion as it wrote off ``goodwill'' from the buyout. The company denied the writeoff proved the Thompsons paid too much in the buyout, but only reflected a decline in the value of the company assets. At first, Southland proposed selling 75 percent of the company for $400 million to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., its Japanese franchisees. The Thompson family would keep 15 percent and the creditors would get the rest, along with new securities. But enough bondholders would not go along. In July, the Japanese agreed to take a smaller piece of the company, 70 percent, and provide more money, $430 million. The Thompsons also agreed to cut their holdings to 5 percent, while creditors got 25 percent of the reorganized company in addition to improved terms on their bonds. However, creditors forced Southland to require that 95 percent of the bondholders go along before they would agree to the swap, and the threshold proved too high to meet by this week's deadline. Although the reorganization plan mirrors the restructuring proposal, it now must be approved by a bankruptcy court and could still face objections. If it succeeds, it will end the Thompson family's control of the company. None of the three brothers who run Southland would comment on the bankruptcy, Ms. Norwood said.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Pilot Elected Head of National Pilot Union
DOC.TEXT: Capt. J. Randolph ``Randy'' Babbitt, a 44-year-old Eastern Airlines pilot from Oakton, Va., was elected president of the Air Line Pilots Association Wednesday. Babbitt will begin his four-year term Jan. 1, 1991, becoming ALPA's sixth president in its 60-year history. He will succeed Capt. Henry A. Duffy, a Delta Air Lines pilot who has led the pilot organization since 1983. ``The changing face of the airline industry has compelled the pilots to take a principles stand against unprincipled managements,'' Babbitt said after being elected by 266 pilot delegates during an ALPA board meeting. ``I look forward to leading the 42,000 pilots of the Air Line Pilots Association forward - unified and revitalized - to face the challenges we know we'll have to face.'' Babbitt, a DC-9 captain, joined Eastern in 1966. He is currently on leave to work full-time at ALPA. Babbitt joined in the nine-month strike by Eastern pilots last year, honoring a machinists strike that continues today.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Ford and Financial Units
DOC.TEXT: Moody's Investors Service Inc. on Wednesday downgraded by a notch $45 billion worth of debt by Ford Motor Co. and some of its financial subsidiaries, saying the company is vulnerable to dips in the economy. The sluggish economy, continued buyer incentive programs that cut into profits, softening vehicle demand in Europe and fuel costs ``heighten the uncertainties concerning Ford's operating returns and cash flow during a period of heavy capital spending,'' Moody's said. Even with the downgrade, securities issued by the nation's No. 2 automaker remained well within Moody's investment grade. General Motors Corp. securities are at the same rating as Ford, and Chrysler Corp. securities are below both, but still within Moody's investment grade. Ratings issued by Moody's and other companies, such as Standard & Poor's Corp., are used to measure the credit worthiness of a company or a subsidiary. A lower credit rating can force a company to pay higher interest rates when it borrows money. Ford spokesman Tom Foote declined to describe the size of Ford's capital spending program this year. But he said Ford planned to spend more in the next five years on plants and products than the $22.2 billion it spent in the last five years of the 1980s. ``We believe that our ability to maintain a substantial capital spending program in the present economic environment reflects the strong financial position of Ford,'' said a statement from Ford Vice President and Treasurer David McCammon. Through Oct. 20 of this year, sales of Ford's domestic cars and trucks were 8.6 percent below last year's pace. Next week, Ford is expected to announce third-quarter earnings of about half the $477.1 million the company earned during the same period last year. Moody's also downgraded securities linked to First Nationwide Bank, a Ford-owned savings and loan institution with headquarters in San Francisco. The ratings agency said First Nationwide was particularly vulnerable because of its extensive holdings in a softening commercial real estate market. ``We are pleased with First Nationwide's operating performance this year in the face of a depressed commercial real-estate market,'' McCammon said. ``Additionally, we believe the ratings fail to recognize the strong overall performance of the Ford Financial Services group which provides an important element of stability during this period of relatively weak vehicle demand,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices edged higher Wednesday in a drifting session that did nothing to break the indecisive pattern of activity since the start of the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had slipped 26.73 points Monday and Tuesday, rose 10.15 to 2,504.21. Advancing issues just barely outnumbered declines in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 762 up, 728 down and 490 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 149.29 million shares, against 146.30 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 181.59 million shares. The price of crude oil for December delivery climbed more than $1.50 a barrel, to the neighborhood of $31 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said that helped to put a damper on buying interest in the stock market, along with persistent worries about the economic outlook. The Commerce Department reported that new factory orders for durable goods dropped 1.7 percent in September, on top of a downward-revised decline of 0.8 percent in August. The latest decrease stemmed mainly from a drop in transportation orders, which are often subject to wide short-term fluctuations. But brokers said it still came as something of an unpleasant surprise to investors. Observers also said the market was on hold awaiting signs of some resolution of the budget impasse in Washington. It is generally agreed that traders' hopes for a relaxation of the Federal Reserve's credit policy are unlikely to be fulfilled until some sort of a budget agreement has been reached. Wednesday's gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1~ at 108|; Philip Morris, up \ at 48\; Eastman Kodak, up [ at 39~, and Westinghouse Electric, up ~ at 25~. MCA plunged 8~ to 50 and Matsushita Electric dropped 3 to 141. Late in the day Matsushita denied reports of a breakdown in merger talks with MCA. Compaq Computer jumped 4[ to 47{. The company reported third-quarter earnings of $1.38 a share, up from $1.01 a share in the corresponding period last year. Sun Microsystems, by contrast, fell 4] to 15} as the most active issue in the over-the-counter market. Quarterly earnings reported by the company on Tuesday came in well below expectations. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $1.70 billion, or 0.06 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks eked out a .10 advance to 170.60. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose .42 to 367.61, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up .24 at 312.60. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .11 to 340.98. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 292.69, down .28.
