DOC.HEAD: Stores Prepare For a Bleak Christmas
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: When Halloween decorations come down this week and stores start putting up Christmas trees and wreaths, retailers will begin what is expected to be their bleakest holiday season in years. The faltering economy and the Persian Gulf crisis already have put a big crimp in consumer spending, with retail sales falling dramatically in August and September. No one realistically expects shoppers to put caution aside when they start looking for gifts. ``It's going to be a tough Christmas,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail industry analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc. ``The only question is, `How bad is it going to be?' '' Daniel Barry, of Kidder Peabody & Co., was more blunt: ``I think this is going to be one of the worst Christmases in two decades.'' Retailers also are expecting a difficult season. Kenneth Macke, chairman of Dayton Hudson Corp., said his company, like most retailers, is planning conservatively to meet the uncertain mood of American consumers. ``They've got job insecurity and oil prices are up,'' Macke said of consumers. ``If they had a definite answer to some of these things we'd be better off.'' Christmas has been something of a guessing game in recent years, with consumers shopping later in the season and the outcome not certain until after all the receipts are tallied. Many observers believe there won't be any suspense this year, especially since late summer sales - considered a harbinger of the Christmas season - were so poor. For instance, Macke's stores, which include Dayton, Hudson, Marshall Field, Target and Mervyn's, suffered a 2 percent drop in sales in September. ``We have a consumer that's really pulling back,'' said Walter Loeb, a retailing consultant and analyst. ``He doesn't like $2 a gallon gas. He doesn't like higher taxes. He doesn't like unemployment.'' There are more Americans out of work now than there were a year ago - the unemployment rate was on an upswing in September, rising to 5.7 percent, while last December, it was holding steady at 5.3 percent. A consumer who is not working is not going to spend a lot on Christmas gifts. Even those with secure jobs are scaling back gift-giving plans. Since oil prices shot higher following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Americans have been shelling out more money for gasoline and heating oil and have less for extras like gifts. ``About the only thing that would keep Christmas from being a disaster is an end to the Mideast crisis'' and a drop in oil prices, said Barry, the Kidder Peabody analyst. Macke said department stores, which generally have more upscale merchandise, could be more vulnerable to sluggish sales. ``Our experience is that the consumer has tended to trade down,'' he said. That means there likely will be more ties, books and sweaters bought this season than stereo sets and expensive jewelry. Apparel retailers may also find themselves in a bind. They were among the hardest hit as sales dropped in late summer. For example, J. C. Penney, whose business grew modestly in the late spring and early summer, saw its sales fall 2.4 percent and 3.4 percent respectively in August and September. Specialty apparel retailer Limited Inc., which posted moderate increases in the spring, managed only a 1 percent gain in August and suffered a 3 percent decline in September. One segment of the industry likely to fare somewhat better this Christmas is toy retailers. Parents may scrimp on gifts for adults so their children find plenty of presents under the tree on Dec. 25. ``Santa Claus gets first priority on the dollar,'' said Macke. Inventory will be a key to how successful this Christmas will be. Macke said his stores have bought conservatively and focused on the kinds of merchandise that are expected to be the biggest movers. But a wild card that can make or break the season is how much retailers are forced to take price markdowns. Markdowns have become almost commonplace in the last few years, and most analysts expect there will be price-cutting again this Christmas. Edelman, the Barclays de Zoete Wedd analyst, predicted markdowns would not be quite as severe as in Christmas 1989. Last year, units of Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. reduced prices sharply to bring in cash in a futile attempt at avoiding bankruptcy court. Other retailers were forced to follow suit to compete, and bottom lines that quarter - the most crucial earings period for retailers - were the casualties. Barry took a more pessimistic view of markdowns in the upcoming season and had this advice for consumers: ``Do your Christmas shopping late, there'll be plenty of merchandise at bargain prices.'' If Dayton Hudson's sales appear to be falling short of projections, Macke said his stores will try to avoid heavy markdowns by reducing expenses. Yet in spite of the so-far glum outlook for the season, some say it is still possible retailers will be pleasantly surprised. Karen Sack, an analyst with Standard & Poor's Corp., said that while ``consumers have definitely cut back spending, I suspect they will spend for Christmas.'' Macke, despite his conservative outlook, said, ``I wouldn't be a the threatened northern spotted owl, and also rejected a move to cut the Forest Service road-building effort in half. The current obscenity ban, adopted a year ago under pressure from Helms and his conservative allies, forbids endowment financing of works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism, the sexual exploitation of children or ``individuals engaged in sex acts.'' The Senate bill also would allow endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer to continue his requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge not to produce obscene work. The pledge has caused widespread protests among artists and resulted in three lawsuits challenging its constitutionality. By contrast, the House voted to ban Frohnmayer's pledge and to omit any explicit anti-obscenity restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Earnings Unchanged, Unocal Up 53 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Exxon's earnings and revenue figures to billions, sted million, in grafs 3 and 9
DOC.TEXT: Higher crude oil prices lifted Unocal Corp.'s third-quarter earnings 53 percent, but couldn't boost Exxon Corp.'s earnings over last year's levels. Los Angeles-based Unocal reported Wednesday that earnings for the period ending Sept. 30 totaled $121 million, or 52 cents per share, on revenue of $3 billion. That compared with after-tax profit of $79 million, or 34 cents per share, on revenue of $2.8 billion for the same 199 period. Exxon, based in Irving, Texas, said earnings were unchanged from the third quarter last year, totaling $1.07 billion or 85 cents per share, on revenue of $29 billion. Revenue for the third quarter last year totaled $23.6 billion.

Unocal's crude oil prices jumped $4.60 a barrel to an average of $20.22 in the third quarter, said Richard J. Stegemeier, Unocal's chairman, president and chief executive officer. Crude oil prices rose sharply due to the Persian Gulf crisis. But Stegemeier said earnings from Unocal's refining and marketing operations fell because the company was unable to pass the full price on to consumers. Earnings dropped to $34 million from $39 million in the same 1989 quarter. For the first nine months of 1990, Unocal reported a 27 percent earnings jump to $363 million, or $1.55 per share, on revenue of $8.4 billion. That compared with $286 million, or $1.22 per share, on revenue of $8.5 billion for the same period last year. Unocal's nine-month increase included a $132 million after-tax gain from the sale of the company's wholly owned oil and gas subsidiary in Norway.

Exxon said earnings from its refining and marketing operations dropped 55 percent to $246 million, also blaming an inability to fully recover the crude price increases. Both companies' chemical operations suffered earnings declines, although Unocal's 2 percent drop was a far cry from Exxon's 75 percent reduction. Exxon said higher costs for raw materials and a sluggish industry combined for the steep decline. The company's nine-month earnings increased 14 percent to $3.4 billion, or $2.73 per share, on revenue of $81.8 billion. That compared to after-tax profit of $3 billion, or $2.37 per share, on revenue of $69.5 billion for the same period last year. Last year's nine-month earnings included a provision for the Valdez accident off the shore of Alaska and an accounting change.

DOC.HEAD: Raytheon Names New CEO
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Co.'s board of directors on Wednesday chose Dennis J. Picard to succeed Thomas L. Phillips as its chairman and chief executive officer. Phillips retires March 1, 1991, after 42 years with Raytheon, the nation's fifth-largest defense contractor. Picard, 58, became president of the company on Aug. 1, 1989. He previously was senior vice president and general manager of the Missile Systems Division. Succeeding Picard as president is Max E. Bleck, head of Raytheon's largest subsidiary, Beech Aircraft Corp., since May 1987. Bleck, 63, was also elected to the Raytheon board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Back on Rise As Peace Hopes Fade
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil rebounded sharply on the futures market Wednesday to move back above $30 per barrel as traders placed less faith in speculation that peace was likely in the Persian Gulf. ``Perceptions are hardening here, with the Saudis and U.S. officials indicating we are still a long way from having a settlement with Iraq,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``I think there's no fear of peace, but likewise no fear of hostilities. There's a perception that a stalemate could persist for a while,'' Baker said. Light sweet crude oil rose $1.71 to $31.08 for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. All other contract months traded higher. Crude's move up erased part of a steep decline that had stripped away more than half of the ``war premium,'' which pushed oil to $40 per barrel in the weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``It was down about $10 in three or four days, so you were due for a bit of a bounce anyway,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Speculators were responding to news that the Pentagon may deploy more U.S. troops to the Gulf, as well as a statement from Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., that the nation appears headed toward conflict in the region. Prices also strengthened an American Petroleum Institute report, released Tuesday evening, that showed the nation's supplies of crude oil and gasoline went down last week, as did refinery operations. API showed a slight increase in the stockpile of home heating oil. Refined petroluem products traded higher along with crude Wednesday, with gasoline taking a bigger jump than heating oil because of the API statistics. Unleaded gasoline for November delivery rose 5.49 cents to 85.39 cents per gallon, with later delivery months all trading higher. Heating oil rose 4.06 cents to 85.12 cents a gallon for November delivery, with all other contract months higher. Natural gas fell 8 cents to $2.44 per 1,000 cubic feet for December delivery, with other months also dropping. After oil's record fall of $5.41 per barrel on Monday that pushed it below $30 for the first time in weeks, trading turned confused, with prices moving in different directions as buyers and sellers tried to figure out what would happen next in the Mideast standoff. When oil shot back up Wednesday, it left traders wondering whether they had seen only a correction from the earlier slide or the beginning of another steady climb.

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Shows Loss For Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. Wednesday blamed a depressed tire market and continued restructuring for a third-quarter loss of $61.4 million, or $1.06 per share. The company also reiterated plans to eliminate 3,000 jobs, most of them salaried positions. Most of the cuts were announced in June and September. In September, the tiremaker warned shareholders about a possible loss for the quarter. Goodyear earned $70.5 million, or $1.22 per share, in the third quarter of 1989. The 1990 quarterly loss reflects unusual charges of $51.7 million, or 89 cents per share, for restructuring. The costs were incurred from a realignment of European tire marketing, the phasing out of medium and heavy truck tire production in Quebec, $22.2 million in environmental cleanup costs and depreciation of the All American Pipeline System. The company also blamed the third-quarter loss on increased expenses, severe competition in the tire replacement market, reduced auto and truck production, and production cutbacks to reduce inventories. Worldwide sales increased 8.2 percent in the third quarter to $2.9 billion. Goodyear ranks second to Groupe Michelin in sales, according to the trade magazine Tire Business. As part of the restructuring, about 3,000 jobs will be cut to reduce Goodyear's worldwide staff to 106,000 by mid-1992, company Chairman Tom H. Barrett said in a message to shareholders. The total includes 1,200 jobs to be eliminated in a European restructuring Goodyear announced in September, and 1,100 jobs that will be lost in a domestic restructuring announced in June, said Hank Ruppel, a spokesman in Goodyear's Akron headquarters. Goodyear began making some cuts in July and will continue phasing out the other jobs until mid-1992, he said. Some of the cuts will come through attrition. For the first nine months of 1990, Goodyear reported a loss of $49.9 million, or 86 cents per share. The company earned $192.1 million, or $3.33 per share, during the first nine months of last year. Sales rose 4 percent in the nine-month period to $8.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck Apply to be Placed in Administration
DOC.TEXT: Polly Peck International PLC, the troubled British food and electronics conglomerate, asked for court assistance Tuesday to sort out its $1.95 billion debt woes. The decision to apply for a court-appointed administrator followed weeks of wrangling with creditors over financing. The company, which was forced to suspend trading of its shares on the London stock market Sept. 20, said in a brief statement its board ``resolved'' to take the action. A Polly Peck spokesman added, ``The company believes that taking this step will result in the survival of the company and its operations as going concerns.'' Court administration is a form of bankruptcy which enables the company to reduce its debt in an orderly fashion with the guidance of the British courts. It does not always mean the company concerned will be liquidated. The court administrator will decide whether Polly Peck's debts can be serviced through existing operations or through a partial or full liquidation of the company. Company officials held a series of meetings with bankers throughout the day Wednesday. In the past week Polly Peck chairman and chief executive Asil Nadir has tried to round up financial support in Turkey and northern Cyprus. Polly Peck, which has operating subsidiaries in the United States, urkey and Japan, has been operating under a temporary debt standstill agreement since Oct. 5. The company sought the moratorium after creditors withdrew about 100 million pounds, or $195 million, in short-term financing and pressed for answers on the financial status of the company after its share suspension. The moratorium was scheduled to expire Nov. 9. Nadir has been dogged in the British press by allegations of links to a reputed Polly Peck share-support scheme. The company and Nadir, who was questioned by the Serious Fraud Office Sept. 20, have denied any knowledge of wrongdoing. Bankers have called Polly Peck's troubles a crisis of confidence. They said in the early stages of talks that they were inclined to give the company time to sort out its financial troubles. Polly Peck's status, however, deteriorated sharply in recent days as bankers pressed the company for answers about Nadir's finance-hunting trip to Turkey and northern Cyprus. Their growing unease was signalled by calls for early repayment of outstanding debts, and more significantly by the move of National Bank of Canada on Monday to petition the British courts to liquidate the company to meet its debts.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Drop, Precious Metals Gain As Oil Prices Surge
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Wednesday, ending a four-day runup, and precious metals rallied as a bounce in oil prices rekindled worries about the economy. On other commodity markets, orange juice futures surged; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 1.4 cents to 3.5 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery at $1.29 a pound, down 3.2 cents. The sell-off erased more than half of Tuesday's gains, which had been fueled by fears of a tight supply and perceptions that easing crude oil prices meant the U.S. economy might not be heading into a severe recession. The copper market tends to respond to economic signals because copper is used widely in construction and manufacturing. But oil prices leaped Wednesday after U.S. and Saudi Arabian leaders reaffirmed their position that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally. Analysts said oil futures also were supported by Sen. Richard Lugar's comment that ``we are very close to conflict'' in the Persian Gulf and by an industry report Tuesday showing a larger-than-expected drop last week in U.S. crude suplies. Tim Evans, a copper trader with Deak International Inc., said copper's decline also reflected profit-taking after a gain of about 9 cents a pound in four days. Deak Vice President Anne Orton said Far East demand for precious metals had increased as the dollar declined in value against other major currencies in the last few weeks. Gold futures settled $2.10 to $2.30 higher on the Commodity Exchange with the spot price at $373.50 a troy ounce; silver was 0.2 cent to 0.4 cent higher with October at $4.223 a troy ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil futures ended $1.68 to $1.95 higher with December at $31.08 a barrel; heating oil was 4.05 cents to 4.55 cents higher with November at 85.12 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4.1 cents to 5.49 cents higher with November at 85.39 cents a gallon. Orange juice futures rose sharply in their fourth straight daily advance on the New York Cotton Exchange as the market continued to rebound from a collapse precipitated by an Oct. 11 government prediction for a bumper Florida orange crop. Orange juice rallied despite a prediction from the Florida Department of Citrus that retail prices for orange juice will drop nearly 12 percent during the coming year because of high Florida production and record world supplies. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures ended 3.25 cents to 4.10 cents higher with November at $1.19 a pound. Export sales rumors lifted corn and and wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade but soybean futures fell slightly. Reports that the Soviet Union has chartered freight vessels were regarded as an indication that Moscow soon will be shopping for grain, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 1} cents higher with December at $2.64} a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.33 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $1.24\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 3} cents lower with November at $6.10} a bushel. Cattle futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, boosted by strong cash fundamentals including reports that steers fetched prices as high as $80.50 per hundredweight in western Kansas. Lower prices for pork products contributed to a drop in pork futures prices, analysts said. Live cattle settled .12 cent to .47 cent higher with December at 77.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .40 cent higher with October at 87.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .38 cent lower with December at 53.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.33 cents lower to .30 cent higher with February at 66 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Compaq Third-Quarter Profit Up 42 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Compaq Computer Corp. said Wednesday its profit rose 42 percent in the third quarter. Earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30 totaled $124 million, or $1.38 a share, compared with $87.1 million, $1.01 a share, in the same quarter last year. Per-share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 29. Revenue at the personal computer maker totaled to $863 million, a 26 percent jump over 1989 third-quarter revenue of $683 million. ``Excellent sales growth during this quarter can be attributed to continued European strength and increased momentum in the North American market,'' said Rob Canion, president and chief executive officer. The third-quarter profit included a one-time, pre-tax gain of $27.1 million from an increase in the carrying value of Compaq's investment in Conner Peripherals Inc. This increased earnings per share by 20 cents after taxes. Profit in the 1989 quarter included a gain of $13.7 million, or 10 cents a share, also from the investment in the computer disc drive maker, and a gain of $7.6 million, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of Conner stock. Compaq said its profits were improved during the most-recent quarter by lower material costs, factory efficiencies and lower exchange rates for the dollar, which boost the value of overseas sales in dollar terms. International sales comprised 53 percent of Compaq's revenue during the quarter. For the year's first nine months, Compaq said it earned $320 million, or $3.63 a share, up from $254 million, or $2.97 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue totaled $2.6 billion, vs. $2.1 billion.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES in 7th graf with S&P downgrading Continental debt
DOC.HEAD: Continental Considered Bankruptcy, May Sell Assets
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines' board of directors briefly considered filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but decided instead to seek other ways to return to financial health, a spokesman said Wednesday. Unidentified sources quoted in Wednesday's editions of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal said a team of lawyers worked through the weekend to prepare Chapter 11 papers to be filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court after a board meeting on Monday. Continental responded to the reports by issuing a statement Wednesday saying it had no plans to file for protection from creditors. ``We have streamlined our management, and like the rest of the industry, are considering other prudent business steps to assist during the fuel crisis,'' the airline said. ``However, Chapter 11 is not one of the means we intend to take.'' Later Wednesday, spokesman Ned Walker said, ``The board examined several different options, one of which was Chapter 11. But it was rejected in a unanimous vote by the board. ``Chapter 11 just doesn't make sense for us. We have a lot of alternatives,'' Walker said. They include possible asset sales, introduction of outside investors and cost controls, such as the postponement of a multimillion-dollar image campaign, he said. Continental stock dropped 1| to $4 per share Wednesday on the American Stock Exchange. Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's Corp. said it had downgraded its ratings on debt of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. and Continental Airlines, because of problems brought on by higher fuel costs and sluggish demand for air travel. The airline decided last week to remove 17 aircraft that were no longer fuel efficient from service on Dec. 1 and replace them with more efficient models. Walker said jet fuel costs have risen 125 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. A $1.2 billion order for 25 Boeing 757s will still go through, he added. ``We're in discussions with some parties that are seriously interested in investing'' in Continental, Walker said. Continental's core operations ``remain strong,'' he said. ``Speculation that efforts to contain costs might include a major downsizing of the airline is just that - speculation,'' the airline's statement said. The reports that Continental had considered bankruptcy surfaced a day after the carrier realigned its senior management team by cutting five top executives in an effort to trim costs. For the first half of the year, Continental, which until June was known as Texas Air Corp., lost $8.7 million, compared with a loss of $365 million in the period a year ago. In June the carrier's liabilities totaled $1.6 billion. Third-quarter results, which have not yet been reported, are expected to show that Continental suffered losses during the normally busy summer travel season and has been hurt by higher fuel prices since the invasion of Kuwait. Frank Lorenzo, who recently stepped down as chairman of Continental but remains on the board, reportedly opposes a Chapter 11 filing by the airline, as does Jan Carlzon, chairman of Scandinavian Airlines System, which owns 16.8 percent of Continental stock. A bankruptcy petition filing would reduce the value of SAS's holdings.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Opposes Japanese Company Purchase Of Park Concession
With AM-MCA-Matsushita
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manual Lujan will try to prevent a Japanese company from owning food and lodging concessions in America's national parks, officials said Wednesday. The issue of foreign ownership surfaced in connection with a Japanese company's possible purchase of MCA Inc., which owns a subsidiary that provides concessions at Yosemite National Park in California. James Ridenour, director of the National Park Service, recently urged MCA to sell the Yosemite concessions before the Japanese company, Matsushita Electric Industries, acquires MCA, Interior spokesman Steve Goldstein said. He said Ridenour made the request in a telephone call to MCA chairman Lew Wasserman with the full support of Lujan. ``The secretary believes that the concessions in our national parks should be run by American-owned companies. He wants to make sure MCA was clear on our position,'' said Goldstein. The MCA subsidiary, Yosemite & Curry Co., has estimated holdings in Yosemite of between $100 million and $200 million. The company provides restaurants, lodging and stores at the park under a contract with the National Park Service. Officials with Matsushita, MCA and Curry declined comment about the discussions involving MCA and Matsushita or Ridenour's telephone call. Goldstein said there is nothing in law to prevent a Japanese company from being a concessionaire at a national park, but that such ownership could be taken into account when the Curry Co., contract is up for normal renewal in 1993. ``We understand the amount of ill will that would come from (a Japanese) acquisition,'' he said. ``Manuel Lujan believes in buying American,'' he added. Matsushita has been holding discussions to buy MCA for a reported $8.6 billion. The sides reportedly are having difficulty agreeing on a price and the Japanese company has put off further discussions until mid-November. MCA owns Universal Studios record companies, a film library and a television station in addition to Curry. Ridenour urged Wasserman to sell its park concessions subsidiary to a private group before dealing with Matsushita. He said the Park Service also would be interested in buying the concession. The Wilderness Society already has expressed interest in competing with Curry for the Yosemite concession in 1993. Normally, the contract holder has the advantage in bidding on a contract renewal. But recently the Interior Department, at Lujan's insistence, has sought to make the bidding more competitive. Park officials at Yosemite, meanwhile, have received about a half dozen letters from park visitors complaining about the possible ownership of the concessions by a foreign company. ``American parks and everything in them need to belong to Americans ... not to foreign investors,'' wrote Lenore Cymes of Palo Alto, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Industry Upset with Common Market Ban
DOC.TEXT: A hog industry group Wednesday condemned Common Market plans to ban U.S. pork shipments to 12 European countries because American plants don't meet European sanitation standards. ``This is an artificial trade barrier, not a food safety issue,'' said Mike Wehler, president of the National Pork Producers Council. ``The U.S. pork industry has bent over backwards to accommodate European sanitation requirements, even though many of those standards are not based on scientific evidence,'' he said. The council said the 12-nation European Community on Monday informed Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter it plans to stop all U.S. pork shipments as of next Wednesday on the grounds that no U.S. plant meets its sanitation requirements. The council said exports of U.S. pork products to the European nations account for more than $10 million a year in sales.

DOC.HEAD: Buffett Buys 9.8 Percent Stake in Wells Fargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock price in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Wells Fargo & Co., hammered on Wall Street along with other big banks this year, said Wednesday it welcomed billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett's purchase of a 9.8 percent stake in the company. Wells Fargo denied it was under any takeover pressure, despite the plunge in the price of its shares from a high of $86 during the past year to a low of $41.25 recently. The bank said it had not agreed to any special terms with Buffett, of Omaha, Neb., and did not view him as a ``white knight'' who bought the shares to thwart a takeover. ``We are pleased to have him as a shareholder, given his reputation as an astute investor,'' said Wells Fargo spokesperson Mary Essary. ``He recognizes long-term value in companies.'' The purchase made Buffett, known for his prescience in picking stocks, the largest shareholder of Wells Fargo stock. The next largest is The Capital Group Inc. of Los Angeles, which owns a 9.3 percent stake, according to a proxy statement filed last March. In a federal filing Tuesday, Buffett disclosed that nine subsidiaries of his company, Berkshire Hathaway, bought 5,030,600 shares of Wells Fargo. He did not state the price paid for the shares, but Wells Fargo stock has been trading in recent days at about $48 a share. Some 5 million shares at that price would come to about $240 million. Wells Fargo stock closed at $50.50 per share, up $1.37{, Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Buffett had no further comment beyond the filing, but planned to make a full statement in next year's annual report to Wells Fargo shareholders, said a spokeswoman at Berkshire Hathaway. Major California banks, including Wells Fargo, have been hurt on Wall Street this year by the sluggish economy, fears of a deepening recession, and worries that the real estate market might collapse the way it did in the Northeast. But some of those worries appear to have been exaggerated, and Wells Fargo and several other banks have weathered the problems reasonably well. Wells Fargo recently reported that earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 7 percent from a year ago to $3.03 per share on net income of $162.6 million. The bank has $51.5 billion in assets. ``We feel that our stock has been adversely affected by the marketplace in general and not by the results that we ourselves have been showing,'' Essary said. ``We have been giving consistent performance and we feel very positive about our company and our ability to weather any future downtowns.'' She said Buffett probably was interested in Wells Fargo because ``being a strong company, the decrease in the stock has provided an attractive buying opportunity.'' In the past, Buffett has bought sizeable stakes in companies under special terms. He has served as a friend of management once he is in place, deterring hostile bidders from making any takeover efforts against the company. His moves also are watched on Wall Street where he is seen as a savvy, long-term investor. A few months ago, Buffett agreed to buy 12 percent to 14 percent of USAir Group Inc.'s stock through a new issue valued at $358 million, a move that could block a hostile takeover. Buffett, who made a fortune buying little-known stocks, also owns big stakes in Coca Cola Co., the Salomon Brothers Inc. investment house and Gillette Co. He owns the Buffalo News newspaper. He played the role of friendly squire to razor maker Gillette, the object of two hostile takeover bids in three years.

DOC.HEAD: Shugrue Predicts Break-Even by February
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airline's push to get more business travelers could help the money-losing carrier break even by February, bankruptcy trustee Martin Shugrue said. The effort involves nearly doubling the size of Eastern's first-class cabins and offering first-class corporate fares below the industry's coach average. Shugrue, who was appointed in April to try to salvage the carrier, said the effort has ``taken off like a rocket ship.'' His optimistic outlook came in a Miami Herald interview Tuesday at a time when creditors are balking at releasing more operating funds and speculation has revived that Eastern may be dismantled. The Miami-based carrier has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization since March 1989 after Machinists went on strike, and was still losing $2 million a day in its most recent quarterly report during the summer. Eastern said its new business traveler program has added 4,000 bookings a day. The airline said it needs business travelers because they fly frequently and don't rely on so-called super-saver fares. Shugrue's rosy outlook wasn't shared by industry watchers. ``It would be a tall order to not only overcome their losses on a daily basis, but to then go to a profit,'' said Robert J. Joedicke, an airline specialist with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Meanwhile, Shugrue said he will ask creditors for more money from Eastern's escrow fund in November. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland approved a $50 million draw in October. Shugrue said American Airlines, America West, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and USAir have expressed interest in buying certain Eastern assets. He said Northwest Airlines, Pan Am and TWA have had discussions with Eastern, and Delta has confirmed interest in buying 19 Eastern gates in Atlanta. Delta, Eastern's chief rival because of their shared interest in Atlanta, has cut selected coach fares in response to Eastern, but Shugrue said he doesn't think Delta can do much to undercut Eastern's corporate push. ``We expected Delta to match the fares, but they can't double the size of their first-class cabins like we have,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Latest Chapter in Southland's Past
With AM-Southland Bjt
DOC.TEXT: John Jefferson Green figured one day in 1927 that he could lure more customers into his Southland Ice Co. store if he stocked milk, eggs and bread, giving birth to the convenience store industry. The same year, Joe C. ``Jodie'' Thompson Jr. went to work for the ice company, selling ice from the docks. Sixty-three years later, the company Thompson once led out of bankruptcy is back in bankruptcy court. The leading convenience store chain became a victim of a $4.9 billion debt-financed takeover and increased competition from gasoline retailers. Southland Corp. filed Wednesday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors. In hopes of speeding the process, Southland also filed a reorganization plan that would give 70 percent of the company to Japanese investors in exchange for $430 million in new cash. Creditors would get 25 percent of the company, leaving 5 percent for the Thompson family. Green's innovation started Southland's expansion beyond peddling ice. The stores, renamed Tote'm and using totem poles as a symbol, began selling gasoline in 1928; beer, snacks and grocery items and Slurpees came later. Diversification eventually would include dairies, refineries, food processors and even an auto parts chain. But by 1931 the company was struggling in the Great Depression, and went through its first takeover as Middle West Utilities bought out the shareholders. Thompson, then 30, was named president, and later became the receiver when Middle West itself went bankrupt. The Thompson family has controlled the company ever since. With the repeal of prohibition, Southland began selling beer in 1933; growth was spurred again in 1935 with the introduction of the paper milk carton. Thompson even founded Oak Farms Dairy to make the products that made Southland the largest retailer of dairy items in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. In 1939, Southland had 60 stores, all in Texas. Expansion outside of the state didn't come until 1954, when the now-renamed 7-Eleven stores opened in Miami and Jacksonville, Fla. The chain once reached a peak of more than 7,000 stores worldwide. Today there are closer to 6,800, with another 5,900 run by affiliates and franchisees. Jodie Thompson died in 1961 at the age of 60, and his oldest son, John P. Thompson took over as president. Jere W. Thompson, the second son, was elected to the company's board of directors. It wasn't until 1965 that the Slurpee, an iced slush drink, came along. Southland purchased Citgo Petroleum Corp. in 1983, but sold half interest in the refinery years later to a subsidiary of state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela, SA for $290 million. Four years later, the events began that laid the basis for Southland's demise. As junk-bond fed buyout fever was building, the Belzberg family of Canada began talking about buying the Dallas company. But the Thompsons wanted to keep control, so they undertook their own takeover. Using the technique known as a leveraged buyout, the family bought all the common shares outstanding with borrowed money, pledging as collateral Southland's assets. Then the stock market crashed, interest rates shot up, and the cost of borrowing money surged. Southland couldn't pay its bills and sought the sanctuary of bankruptcy court.

DOC.HEAD: Southland History at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a brief history of The Southland Corp., owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, which filed for protection from creditors Tuesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court:
- 1927: The Southland Co. is formed in the Dallas suburb of Oak Cliff from four separate companies operating eight ice plants and 21 retail ice stations. - 1928: Southland builds and leases gasoline sales stands to oil companies at its 10 Tote'm stores. - 1931: Middle West Utilities buys out Southland shareholders. A year later, the company becomes bankrupt and a reorganization is ordered. - 1945: Company's name is changed to The Southland Corp. A year later, the name 7-Eleven is coined for growing convenience store chain. - 1965: Southland is ranked 49th among Fortune magazine's top 50 merchandising firms. - 1968: The 3,000th 7-Eleven store is opened in Deltona, Fla. - 1973: 7-Eleven enters Japanese market when Southland grants a license to Japanese retailer Ito-Yokado Ltd. - 1978: Revenues reach $3 billion. - 1983: Southland purchases Citgo Petroleum Corp. for $795 million and three years later, sells half the common stock to a subsidiary of the state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela SA for $290 million. - July 1987: Southland announces the Thompson family will take the company private in a leveraged buyout. - October 1987: The stock market crashes, meaning much higher interest rates for the company in a turbulent bond market. - December 1987: Shareholders approve the Thompson family's $4.9 billion leveraged buyout financed with high-yield ``junk bonds.'' - March 1989: Southland announces 1988 loss of $216.2 million. - March 1990: Southland announces 1989 loss of $1.31 billion. - January 1990: Southland sells other half of Citgo for $661.5 million to Petroleos subsidiary. - March 1990: Southland announces restructuring plan giving Ito-Yokado 75 percent of the company's common stock and leaving 15 percent to Thompson. - June 1990: Southland makes exchange offer to bondholders, later revising plan to include a $430 million infusion from Japanese partners and reduction of Thompson family stake to 5 percent. - Oct. 23, 1990: Bondholders reject exchange offer. - Oct. 24, 1990: Southland files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS acreage, DELETES reference to North America's largest ski mountain. Rewrites throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Breckenridge Plans Ski Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Breckenridge Ski Corp. plans to nearly double its ski acreage with a 10-year project costing about $75 million, the company announced Wednesday. The expansion calls for the ski area to add 1,400 skiable acres to its existing 1,600 acres of skiing. The expanded acreage would be able to accommodate 18,000 skiers per day, compared to the present 11,000 skiers. Vail currently bills itself as North America's largest ski mountain, with 3,834 acres. Besides adding acreage to the resort, the expansion plan calls for upgrading lifts and adding more lifts, including a funicular - an elevated rail system. The U.S. Forest Service has contracted Winston Associates, a Boulder-based environmental planning firm, to prepare an environmental impact statement on the proposed expansion, the first step toward getting a government special use permit. Breckenridge is located in the Colorado Rockies about 80 miles west of Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Ocean Park Would Generate 36,700 Jobs, $3 Billion a Year
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. says its proposed nautical theme park and resort hotel in Long Beach would create 36,700 jobs and generate $3 billion in economic activity a year. The claims, released Wednesday, were contained in an economic analysis Disney presented to officials in Long Beach, the big seaport south of Los Angeles. Disney hasn't yet decided whether to build the nautical park as its ``second gate'' in Southern California. It also is studying the possibility of opening a different kind of park on property it owns in Anaheim beside Disneyland, setting up a bidding war of sorts between the cities. The winning city would collect $62 million in taxes and fees. Much of the Long Beach park, called Port Disney, would be built on landfill brought in and dumped in Long Beach Harbor beside the Queen Mary ocean liner, now operated as a hotel-tourist attraction by Disney. It would include five hotels with 3,700 rooms and 250,000 square feet of retail space. Disney said its owned and operated facilities, plus improvements to roads, sewers and the rest of the nearby infrastructure, would cost about $2.8 billion in 1990 dollars by the time the final phase is complete in 2010. How much of that price tag will be picked up by the city will be a subject of negotiations; Disney expects the rosy economic report to help wring concessions from the city. Still to be completed are studies by Disney and Long Beach on how smog, traffic and water would be affected by the park. But Disney officials said the economic study was a milestone. ``It's a very important step for us. It will enable us to begin financial negotiations with the city of Long Beach,'' Alan G. Epstein, vice president of Disney Development Co., said in a telephone interview from the company headquarters in Burbank. Disney presented its concept for the Long Beach park in July. It is less far along in its studies for the possible second park in Anaheim. Epstein said a facility similar to Epcot Center in Florida is among the proposals for the location beside Disneyland. Officials in both cities say they are eager to win the new park. However, its impact on Long Beach is less clear than for Anaheim. Long Beach officials, citing allegations of Disney high-handedness with Florida cities, have said they will insist the city as well as Disney must benefit. Long Beach Mayor Ernie Kell said his first reaction was that Disney's report is ``very impressive.'' ``But this is just one step in about 100 steps before we are in a position to say this is going to work,'' Kell said. ``Just to bring the landfill over from Catalina (Island) is going to cost about $300 million,'' Kell said. ``That's just the starter, and then we have infrastructure to look at - sewer lines, water, the trucks on the Long Beach Freeway that will have to be rerouted.'' The economic study, prepared by the Los Angeles consulting firm Kotin, Regan & Mouchly Inc. for Disney, said Port Disney would: - Create more than 36,700 permanent jobs in Southern California, including 23,900 in Long Beach, plus many more jobs during construction. Port Disney itself would employ about 12,400 people, making it the second largest private employer in Long Beach. - Generate about $1.7 billion in new economic activity each year in Long Beach as part of the $3 billion total for the five-county greater Los Angeles region. - Produce more than $62 million in new taxes and fees to Los Angeles County and the city of Long Beach. ``With this substantial increase in annual revenues, Long Beach would be able to fund not only the public infrastructure required to accommodate the project, but solutions to some of its most pressing problems,'' Epstein said in a statement. Kell, who told The Associated Press in an earlier interview that Disney cheiftain ``Michael Eisner didn't get to be the top-paid executive in the country by giving cities good deals,'' reserved judgement. ``There's still a lot of hurdles to go,'' he said. But he said that as a former real estate developer, he knew Long Beach has a far stronger hand in dealing with Disney than landlocked Anaheim because of a big advantage: ``Location, location, location.'' ``You have to have pretty great eyesight to see the ocean from Anaheim,'' Kell said.
